title: In Notepad++ and VSCode, replace all varied brackets at the beginning of lines in a todo list with a simple hyphen
body:
- in Notepad++ copy in this text
	----------------------
	[x] get money
	[] go to the store
	[..] install software
	[] get books
	[x] check out new book on Amazon
	[..] go to bank
	[] replace all [] with [x] in main todo list
	[] organize shelf
	[] clean desk
	----------------------
- you want to make it look like this:
	----------------------
	-  get money
	-  go to the store
	-  install software
	-  get books
	-  check out new book on Amazon
	-  go to bank
	-  replace all [] with [x] in main todo list
	-  organize shelf
	-  clean desk
	----------------------
- search and replace `\[.*\] ` with `- `
- notice that it also deletes those in the middle of the line, which was not your intention
- and notice that it what it means to be "greedy"
	- if you wanted to take these out as well, then you would have to tell it to be non-greedy: `\[.*?\] `
- but you want to only replace those at the beginning of the line, so do this: `^\[.*\] `
- do the same thing in Visual Studio Code and notice that you can see the selections as you type the regular expression

title: Indent blocks of lines below specific lines in a text
body:
- you want to indent each of the lines after lines that start with "TEXT ??"
	------------------------------
	TEXT 01 - This is a text about nnnnnn
	This is an item.
	This is some information.
	TEXT 02 - This is a text about nnnnnn
	This is an item.
	This is some information.
	This is an item.
	This is some information.
	TEXT 03 - This is a text about nnnnnn
	This is an item.
	This is some information.
	TEXT is an item.
	This is some information.
	This is an item.
	This is some information.
	------------------------------
- try in Visual Studio Code, Notepad++ and Regex101
	-----------------
	search: ^(?!TEXT \d\d)
	replace: \t- 
	-----------------
- explanation: `?!` is called "negative look ahead", i.e. searches for text that does not occur after another marker, in this case, the beginning of the line (`^`)

title: How to set up Datapod for Node including development environment
body:
- these instructions assume you are installing on Windows
	- Datapod for Node will run on Linux and Mac, but you'll have to substitute tools appropriately, etc.
- recommended pre-install tools
	- these tools will make your environment easier to work in, install them if you haven't yet
		- install 7zip 
			- you'll have more options zipping and unzipping files if you install 7zip
			- goto [7-zip.de](https://7-zip.de)
			- download and install
		- install Notepad++
			- even though you'll be using Visual Studio Code for your main editor, Notepad++ is a useful, non-nonsense text editor to quickly edit any text file
			- goto: https://notepad-plus-plus.org/download
			- download and install
- make a directory where you are going to put your Node websites
	- create `c:\nodewebs`
	- create `c:\nodewebs\main` (where "main" is the name of your datapod site)
- install Git
	- whether or not you save your code in Git, it gives you the bash command line interface, so that you have a more Linux-like command line where you can use bash commands such as `ls` and `pwd`
	- go to `https://git-scm.com/download`
	- then just download and click-accept-click to install it
	- to test if it was successful, right-click in directory `c:\nodewebs\main` and you should see option **Git Bash Here**
- install Node and NPM
	- go to `http://nodejs.org`
	- download the LTS version
	- install it with click-accept-click
	- check versions of each
		- in Windows Explorer, go to `c:\nodewebs\main`
		- right-click and choose **Git Bash Here**
		- type `node -v`, you should get something like **v10.16.3**
		- type `npm -v`, you should get something like **6.9.0**
- install Datapod
	- go to `http://tanguay.info/datapod`
		- TODO: make link here
	- go to [tanguay.info/tech/datapodForNode](http://tanguay.info/tech/datapodForNode)
	- unzip the file `dpn00300.zip`
	- copy all the files to `c:\nodewebs\main`
	- in the Windows Explorer at `c:\nodewebs\main`, right-click and enter the Git bash shell
		- type `npm install` (this may take a few minutes)
	- test Datapod 
		- starting it with `node server.js`
			- you may have to allow access to Node.js, click **allow**
		- it should say **Now listening at http://localhost:49901**
		- in your browser, go to `http://localhost:49901`
		- log in as `dev`/`dev`
		- if it logs in, then Datapod is correctly installed
		- log out
- install Visual Studio Code
	- goto `https://code.visualstudio.com`
	- download and install
	- in Windows Explorer, goto `c:\nodewebs\main`
	- right-click, **Git Bash Here**
	- type `code .`
- setup Datapod developer mode
	- since Datapod in developer mode makes changes to its own files and thus requires nodemon
	- install it like this: `npm install -g nodemon`
	- in `system\config.js`, change **exports.developing** to `true`
	- run Datapod again with `nodemon server.js`
	- click on login, 
	- test Datapod developer features
		- create page
			- call it `Information`
			- see that it is added to the menu
		- delete page
			- type `Information`
			- see that it was removed from the menu
- install DB Browser for SQLite
	- go to [sqlitebrowser.org](https://sqlitebrowser.org/dl)
	- for 64-bit machines, choose **DB Browser for SQLite - Standard installer for 64-bit Windows**
	- execute it, accepting all defaults
	- if it doesn't show in the start menu, go to `C:\Program Files\DB Browser for SQLite`, right-click on `DB Browser for SQLite.exe` and choose **pin to taskbar, so you have this:**##pintotaskbardebrowse
	- start DB Browser for SQLite
		- open `C:\nodewebs\main\data` and choose `main.sqlite`
		- right-click on **pageItems** and choose **Browse Table**
		- under column header **title**, type `logout`
		- change `Logout` to `Logout2` and then click on **Write Changes**
		- refresh the Datapod website, and you will see in your menu that the label **Logout** changed to **Logout2**
		- change it back
- setup quick-start icons 
	- we will now make it possible to start your Node server with one click, when you want to develop on your Datapod site
	- make directory: c:\start
		- create file: `start_main.bat` where **main** is the name of your site
			---------------------------------------
			cd C:\nodewebs\main
			nodemon server.js      
			---------------------------------------
		- right-click bat file: create shortcut
			- rename shortcut to `start_main`
		- right-click shortcut: properties 
			- in the `target` field, type `explorer ` in front of path
				- .e.g so that it reads `explorer C:\start\start_main.bat`
			- change icon to whatever you want
			- `OK` (enter)
		- drag shortcut to task bar
	- stop and close any nodemon you have running
		- with **CTRL-C**
		- and type `exit`
	- click on icon
		- test your site to make sure it works, e.g. go to `http://localhost:49901`
	- format the command window running Node so it looks different from others
		- (you will use this window to output information from backend files)
		- click on C:\ icon (upper-left) and properties
		- Colors, opacity 80%
		- Font, size: 12
	- if you want to run other CMD windows while this window is open, right-click, right-click on "Command Prompt", open
- customize Visual Studio Code
	- turn on autosave	
		- files will be automatically saved after you make any changes, so you will not have to press **CTRL-S** anymore
		- **CTRL-C**, `auto save`, change auto save to **afterDelay**
	- snippets
		- these are chunks of code with variable positions that you can inject into code by typing a short code and pressing TAB
		- click File, Preferences, User Snippets
			- click on **javascript.json**
			- replace the text there with:
				--------------------------------
				{
					"Show debug output": {
						"prefix": "dd",
						"body": "qdev.debug('$1',$2);"
					},
					"console.log": {
						"prefix": "cc",
						"body": "console.log('$1: ' + $2);"
					}
				}
				--------------------------------
		- now open up a controller file with CTRL-P, `controller`
			- in the file type `cc` and TAB to see it expand
	- test to make sure **emmet** works
		- emmet enables you to type large chunks of HTML code with short codes
		- it should be installed by default
		- open up an `.ejs` view file of any of your pages, e.g. CTRL-P and `ejs` and choose a page
		- in an open space in the HTML, type `ul>li#5` and then press TAB
		- see more basics in the [Emmet Basics Howto](http://tanguay.info/tech/howtos?id=27)
	- install the CSS/LESS formatter extension
		- open `system_main.less` with CTRL-P, type `less`
		- TAB a line to unformat it
		- press SHIFT-ALT-F to try to format it
		- click **Install Formatter...**
		- click the [[Install]] button on the extension called **formate: CSS/LESS/SCSS formatter**
		- again, open `system_main.less` with CTRL-P, type `less`
		- TAB a line to unformat it
		- press SHIFT-ALT-F to format it this time
- setup automatic LESS-to-CSS conversion
	- Datapod uses .less style files which need to be converted into css
	- open `system_main.less` with CTRL-P, type `less`
	- at the end, add the following *less* code:
		---------------------
		div.test {
			p {
				color: red;
			}
		}
		---------------------
	- open `system_main.css` with CTRL-P, type `main css`
	- see that you code was not yet automatically added
	- in Windows Explorer, go to `C:\nodewebs\main`
	- right-click and **Git Bash Here**
	- type `npm install -g less`
	- type `npm install -g less-watch-compiler`
	- type `less-` and TAB and ENTER
	- see that your change is not in `system_main.less`
	- add another style e.g.:
		----------------------
		div.test {
			p {
				color: red;
			}
			h1 {
				color: blue;
			}
		}
		----------------------
	- and see that your `system_main.less` file was automatically updated
	- from now on, when you start to develop, you will simply need to type `less-` then TAB and ENTER

	- and not if it has spaces or any other character in it

	--------------------
	sdjfk sjkf skdfj sdkf##ksjf2ksdjf
	sfjsdfsdlf##kdjfdkfjd
	ksdjfsdkfjsdkf##kdf
	##sdkfsdkfasd
	askdfjsfkjsdlkfj##
	asdfksdjfsdfkjsdf##sdjfksdfj.sdfjkdfjdf
	ksdjfsdkfjsdkf#kdf
	dkfjfiejfiefjefij## sdkfjs dfksjd f
	--------------------
- use this:
	- `##([a-zA-Z1-9])+$`

title: Create regex to find uppercase code with underlines
body:
- you want to identify if a user has put a code on a line to identify a header
- the code has to have the following characteristics
	- it is alone on the line
	- it is all uppercase
	- underlines are allowed
- e.g. only the last two items should pass:
	------------------
	this is not ok
	Not_this
	also_not
	THIS_IS not ok
	THIS_IS_OK
	THISTOO		
	------------------
- use this regex: `^[A-Z_]*$`

	- `bundle exec jekyll serve`
	- site works at: http://127.0.0.1:4000

title: How to provide real-time functionality in an Excel file
body:
- description
	- This code shows you how to program real time events into Excel. I used this to build a little "observer" file which constantly monitored a directory and sent an e-mail when a certain file was present. In this way your Excel file can play the part of a Windows service, i.e. running on some extra, unused machine on a network. Another interesting use for this is be able to give your Excel user live information, i.e. by checking the database, the file system, the date/time, or perhaps webservices. Interestingly, the updates happen silently in the background so that the user is not interrupted at all, can use his Excel file as usual all the while cells in his Excel file are being observed/updated by this service. 
- open blank Excel sheet
- save as `MainObserver.xlsm`
- [[ALT-F11]]
- for all instructions below, make sure you work in the VBAProject *MainObserver.xlsm* and not *PERSONAL.XLSB*##dontPersonalXlsb
- double-click *ThisWorkbook*, copy in this code:
	-----------------------
	Private Sub Workbook_Open()
		qexc_Observer
	End Sub
	-----------------------
- create Module1 `qexc` and save this code in it:
	------------
	Sub qexc_Observer()

		'declarations
		Dim intHours As Integer
		Dim intMinutes As Integer
		Dim intSectonds As Integer

		'config
		intHours = 0
		intMinutes = 0
		intSeconds = 1

		'do action that should be performed regularly
		tool_ObserverAction

		'observe again regularly
		Application.OnTime Now + TimeSerial(intHours, intMinutes, intSeconds), "qexc_Observer"

	End Sub
	----------------
- create a second module called `tools` and save this code in it:
	-----------------
	Sub tool_ObserverAction()
		Sheets("Main").Range("A1").Value = Time
	End Sub
	-----------------
- [[ALT-F11]]
- rename worksheet to `Main`
- close and save
- open and you will see the time ticking in A1

	Option Compare Database

		Set m_collection = New ObjectArrayList

	Private Sub FillCollection()

		Dim objPerson As Person
		Dim intCount As Integer

		Dim rcsPersons As DAO.Recordset
		Set rcsPersons = CurrentDb.OpenRecordset(m_sql, dbOpenDynaset)

		Do While Not rcsPersons.EOF

			Dim strMiddleName As String

			If IsNull(rcsPersons.Fields("middleName")) Then
				strMiddleName = ""
			Else
				strMiddleName = rcsPersons.Fields("middleName")
			End If

			Set objPerson = New Person
			objPerson.FirstName = rcsPersons.Fields("firstName")
			objPerson.MiddleName = strMiddleName
			objPerson.LastName = rcsPersons.Fields("lastName")
			objPerson.Rank = rcsPersons.Fields("rank")

			Call m_collection.Add(objPerson)

			rcsPersons.MoveNext
		Loop

		rcsPersons.Close

	End Sub

	Public Sub Display()

		Dim objPerson As Person
		Dim intIndex As Integer

		For intIndex = 0 To m_collection.NumberOfItems - 1
			Set objPerson = m_collection.GetItem(intIndex)
			objPerson.Display
		Next

	End Sub

		'increment internal counter
		m_intNumberOfItems = m_intNumberOfItems + 1

		'redimension container
		ReDim Preserve m_arrContainer(m_intNumberOfItems)

		'now add the item
		Set m_arrContainer(m_intNumberOfItems - 1) = varItem

	End Sub

	'method: returns the number of items for for/next loops

		NumberOfItems = m_intNumberOfItems
	End Function

	'method: return a specific item
	Function GetItem(intIndexNumber As Integer) As Variant
		Set GetItem = m_arrContainer(intIndexNumber)
	End Function

	'method: returns whether or not item exists
	Function ItemExists(varDesiredItem As Variant) As Boolean

		'declarations
		Dim intIndex As Integer
		Dim varItem As Variant

		'loop through and check
		For intIndex = 0 To m_intNumberOfItems - 1

			'variables
			varItem = Me.GetItem(intIndex)

			'if this is it, then return true
			If varItem = varDesiredItem Then
				ItemExists = True
				Exit Function
			End If

		Next

		'if we are here, it was not found

body:
- note that you should put the qexc (quick tools - Excel) and qarr (quick tools - arrays) in their own modules for organizational purposes
	---------------------------------------------
	Function ProcessCells(status As String)
		Dim row As Integer
		Dim column As Integer
		Dim cell As Range
		Dim theValue As String
		Dim total As Integer

		Dim Identifiers(6) As String

		Identifiers(0) = "G"
		Identifiers(1) = "G/C"
		Identifiers(2) = "G, C"
		Identifiers(3) = "C   G"
		Identifiers(4) = "G  MARX"
		Identifiers(5) = "G?"

		For column = 3 To 39

			For row = 2 To 32
				Set cell = Cells(row, column)
				theValue = Trim(cell.Value)

				If qarr_IsInArray(theValue, Identifiers) Then
					If status = "highlight" Then
						qexc_HighlightCell cell
						total = total + 1
					End If
					If status = "unhighlight" Then
						qexc_UnhighlightCell cell
					End If
				End If
			Next

		Next

		ProcessCells = total
	End Function

	Public Sub qexc_HighlightCell(cell As Range)
		With cell.Interior
			.Pattern = xlSolid
			.PatternColor = 16777215
			.Color = 65535
			.TintAndShade = 0
			.PatternTintAndShade = 0
		End With
		cell.Font.Bold = True
	End Sub

	Public Sub qexc_UnhighlightCell(cell As Range)
		With cell.Interior
			.Pattern = xlSolid
			.PatternColor = 16777215
			.ThemeColor = xlThemeColorDark1
			.TintAndShade = 0
			.PatternTintAndShade = 0
		End With
		cell.Font.Bold = False
	End Sub


	Public Function qarr_IsInArray(stringToBeFound As String, arr As Variant) As Boolean
		If stringToBeFound = "" Then
			qarr_IsInArray = False
			Exit Function
		End If
		Dim i
		For i = LBound(arr) To UBound(arr)
			If arr(i) = stringToBeFound Then
				qarr_IsInArray = True
				Exit Function
			End If
		Next i
		qarr_IsInArray = False
	End Function

title: Convert Tkinter .py file to single executable .exe file

- these instructions show you how to convert a Python-Tkinter *.py* file to an .exe file that you can execute by clicking an icon on your taskbar:##tkinterexeapp
- create `tk_two_buttons_with_class.py`:
	--------------------------
	from tkinter import *
	from tkinter import ttk

	class HelloApp:

		def __init__(self, master):

			self.label = ttk.Label(master, text = "English: house")
			self.label.grid(row = 0, column = 0, columnspan = 2)

			ttk.Button(master, text = "German",
					   command = self.german_hello).grid(row = 1, column = 0)

			ttk.Button(master, text = "French",
					   command = self.french_hello).grid(row = 1, column = 1)

		def german_hello(self):
			self.label.config(text = 'das Haus')

		def french_hello(self):
			self.label.config(text = 'la maison')

	def main():            

		root = Tk()
		app = HelloApp(root)
		root.mainloop()

	if __name__ == "__main__": main()
	--------------------------
- `pip install pinstaller`
- `pyinstaller --onefile --noconsole tk_two-buttons_with_class.py`

title: How to set up SASS processing for an HTML/CSS site with node-sass
body:
- set up node-sass
	- make directory and create [these HTML and CSS files](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/sass_base)
	- initialize GIT: `git init`
	- initialize NPM: `npm init -y`
	- install node-sass: `npm i -D node-sass` *(i = install, -D = dev-dependencies)*
	- make `.gitignore` with content `node_modules` on first line
- make SASS directory and files
	- make a copy of the `css` directory and call it `scss`
	- rename `scss/main.css` to `scss/main.scss`
- configure node-sass to watch and and automatically convert SASS files into CSS files
	- test SASS-to-CSS parsing with: `./node_modules/.bin/node-sass -r scss/main.scss -o css`
	- add this script to the `package.json` file:
		- `"start": "./node_modules/.bin/node-sass -r scss/main.scss -o css && node-sass --watch scss -o css"`
- test the script
	- delete the `css/main.css` file
	- notice that the HTML file now has no styling
	- make a change in the `scss/main.scss` file and the `css/main.css` file will be automatically created
- create modules
	- in main.scss, `@import "_variables.scss";` (must be preceded with underscore!)
	- make changes in `_variables.scss`, see that only `css/main.css` is created and not `_variables.css`

title: How to install and execute ten languages: five interpreted (Python, PHP, Ruby, JavaScript, TypeScript) and five compiled (Java, C#, Go, Rust, Kotlin)
body:
- These examples will show you not only the practical differences between interpreted and compiled languages, but will get these languages installed on your computer and will get you up and running using and learning them.
- An interpreted language is a programming language whose implementations execute instructions directly, without previously compiling a program into machine-language instructions. A compiled language requires a compile step which converts the programming code into a binary executable file.
- Interpreted languages:
	- **Python** (1994)
		- install Python on [Windows](https://onespace.netlify.app/howtos?id=326) or [Ubuntu](https://onespace.netlify.app/howtos?id=325)
		- create `helloFromPython.py`
			------------------------------
			print("Hello from Python.")
			------------------------------
		- execute with: `python helloFromPython.py`
	- **PHP** (1995)
		- install PHP with XAMPP on [Windows or Linux](https://www.apachefriends.org/de/index.html)
			- one Windows, make sure `C:\xampp\php` is in your system environment path
		- create `helloFromPhp.php`
			------------------------------
			<?php
			echo 'Hello from PHP.';
			------------------------------
		- execute with: `php helloFromPhp.php`
	- **Ruby** (1995)
		- install Ruby on [Windows](https://rubyinstaller.org) or [Linux](https://www.ruby-lang.org/en/downloads)
			- make sure environment path includes e.g. `C:\Ruby26-x64\bin`
		- install on [Ubuntu](https://stackify.com/install-ruby-on-ubuntu-everything-you-need-to-get-going)
		- create `helloFromRuby.rb`
			-------------------------
			puts "Hello from Ruby."
			-------------------------
		- execute with: `ruby helloFromRuby.rb`
	- **JavaScript** (1995)
		- install Node on [Windows or Linux](https://nodejs.org/en/download)
		- create `helloFromJavaScript.js`
			-------------------------------------
			console.log("Hello from JavaScript.");
			-------------------------------------
		- execute with `node helloFromJavaScript.js`
	- **TypeScript** (2012)
		- install Deno [on Windows](https://onespace.netlify.app/howtos?id=330) or [on Ubuntu](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61851774/how-to-install-deno-on-ubuntu)
		- create `helloFromTypeScript.ts`
			--------------------------------
			/* eslint-disable no-console */
			function capitalize(word: string): string {
				return word.charAt(0).toUpperCase() + word.slice(1);
			}

			function hello(name: string): string {
				return capitalize(name);
			}

			console.log(hello('hello from TypeScript'));
			--------------------------------
		- execute with: `deno run helloFromTypeScript.ts`
- Compiled languages:
	- **Java** (1995)
		- install Java on [Windows or Linux](https://onespace.netlify.app/forays?id=61)
		- create `HelloFromJava.java`
			--------------------------------------------
			public class HelloFromJava {
				public static void main(String[] args) {
					System.out.println("Hello from Java.");
				}
			}
			--------------------------------------------
		- compile to executable with: `javac HelloFromJava.java`
		- execute with: `java -classpath . HelloFromJava`
	- **C#** (2000)
		- Windows installation:
			- make sure you have [.NET installed](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/install/windows?tabs=net50) 
			- add path to system environment path to `C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319`
		- Linux installation:
			- install .NET on [Ubuntu](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/install/linux-ubuntu)
		- create `helloFromCsharp.cs`
			-------------------------------------
			using System;
			namespace HelloExample {
				class HelloFromCsharp {
					static void Main(string[] args) {
						Console.WriteLine("Hello from C#.");
					}
				}
			}
			-------------------------------------
		 - compile to executable with: `csc helloFromCsharp.cs`
		 - execute with: `helloFromCsharp.exe`
	- **Golang** (2007)
		- install Golang on [Windows or Linux](https://golang.org/doc/install)
		- create `helloFromGolang.go`
			---------------------------------------
			package main

			import (
				"fmt"
			)

			func main() {
				fmt.Println("Hello from Golang.")
			}
			---------------------------------------
		- compile to executable with: `go build helloFromGolang.go`
		- execute with: `./helloFromGolang.exe`
	- **Rust** (2010)
		- install Rust for [Windows or Linux](https://www.rust-lang.org/tools/install)
		- on Windows, add the following path to your environment PATH: `C:\Users\ADMIN\.cargo\bin` (where ADMIN is your user name)
		- create `helloFromRust.rs`
			-----------------------------------
			fn main() {
				println!("Hello from Rust.");
			}
			-----------------------------------
		- compile to executable with: `rustc helloFromRust.rs`
		- execute with: `./helloFromRust.exe`

	- **Kotlin** (2011)
		- install Kotline on [Windows](http://localhost:29900/howtos?id=391) or [Ubuntu](https://linuxhint.com/kotlin_ubuntu/)
		- create `helloFromKotlin.kt`
			--------------------------------
			fun main() {
				println("Hello from Kotlin.");
			}
			--------------------------------
		- compile to executable with: `kotlinc HelloWorld.kt`
			- this will produce `HelloWorldKt.class`
		- execute with `kotlin HelloWorldKt`

title: Install MySQL on Ubuntu and create Node/Express API
body:
- these instructions will show you how to
	- install MySQL on Ubuntu
	- install Node and npm
	- install MySQL Workbench and DBeaver to manage your MySQL databases
	- set up a Node/Express API to serve data from the Mysql database
- make sure you don't already have MySQL installed
	- `mysql -V`##nomysqlwithv
- install MySQL
	- `sudo apt update`
		- 30 seconds
	- `sudo apt install mysql-server`
		- 3 minutes
	- `sudo mysql_secure_installation`
		- password security level = 0
		- root password "rootroot" (test)
		- answer Y to all questions
		- not that root still does not need to type in correct password (!)
			- "Note that even though you’ve set a password for the root MySQL user, this user is not currently configured to authenticate with a password when connecting to the MySQL shell."
- note a non-superuser cannot access mysql
	- `mysql` (access denied)
- log into mysql database as superuser
	- as superuser you can log in without a password
	- `sudo su -`
	- `mysql`
- create a webuser that only has access to read the database
	- `CREATE USER webuser@localhost IDENTIFIED BY 'passpass';`
		- `GRANT SELECT on *.* TO webuser@localhost;`
	- see what users are in system
		- `SELECT User FROM mysql.user;`
- install northwind database into mysql
	- https://github.com/dalers/mywind
	- unpack and copy files
		- northwind.sql
		- northwind-data.sql
	- `SHOW DATABASES;`
	- `CREATE DATABASE northwind;`
	- `SHOW DATABASES;`
	- `USE northwind;`
	- `SOURCE northwind.sql`
		- 1 minute
	- `SHOW TABLES;`
	- `SELECT * FROM customers;` (empty)
	- `SOURCE northwind-data.sql`
		- 5 minutes
	- `SELECT * FROM customers;`
	- `SELECT company,last_name,first_name FROM customers;`
	- exit
- access with webuser
	- `mysql -u webuser -p`
	- `SHOW DATABASES;`
	- `use northwind;`
	- `SHOW TABLES;`
	- `SELECT * FROM products;`
	- `DESCRIBE products;`
	- `SELECT id,product_name FROM products;`
	- `INSERT INTO products (product_name) VALUES ("Product 888");` (command denied to user)
- install MySQL management console application
	- install and use MySQL Workbench
		- `snap install mysql-workbench-community`
		- Show Applications
			- add to favorites
			- open##thworkworkbenc
		- set up connection for webuser
			- get error: **An AppArmor policy prevents this sender from sending this message to this recipient**
			- problem: snap application is sandboxed
			- fix: `sudo snap connect mysql-workbench-community:password-manager-service :password-manager-service`
		- log in as webuser##thewebwebuserok
		- MySQL Workbench has issue with UTF-8 encoding on Ubuntu:##worksbenchubuntuchars
	- install DBeaver
		- `sudo snap install dbeaver-ce`
		- add to favorites
		- open
		- yes to create sample database
			- allow it to download SQLite drivers
			- explore database##theveavsdf
		- connect to MySQL database
			- Database
			- New Database Connection
			- enter credentials for webuser
			- open database
				- allow to download MySQL drivers
		- explore tables##explorerbeave
		- build SQL commands##employeesubuntubeaver
- install Node (**DON'T INSTALL LIKE THIS, IT TAKES TOO LONG!**) Instead, skip to instructions to install `nvm` below.
	- `sudo apt-get install nodejs`
	- `sudo apt-get install npm`
		- 15 minutes (!)
- make script that reads and displays data from MySQL database
	------------------------------------------
	var mysql = require('mysql');

	var con = mysql.createConnection({
	  host: "localhost",
	  user: "yourusername",
	  password: "yourpassword",
	  database: "mydb"
	});

	con.connect(function(err) {
	  if (err) throw err;
	  con.query("SELECT * FROM customers", (err, result) => {
		 if (err) throw err;
		console.log(result);
	  });
	}
	------------------------------------------
- error: **Failed to Connect to MySQL DB via MySQL**
	- fix: `ALTER USER webuser@localhost IDENTIFIED WITH mysql_native_password BY 'passpass';`
- switch to import
	- Node is Version 10
	- install nvm
		- `sudo apt install curl`
		- `curl https://raw.githubusercontent.com/creationix/nvm/master/install.sh | bash`
		- `nvm install node`
- install express
	- `npm i express cors`
	- change index.js
		------------------------------
		import express from 'express';
		import cors from 'cors';
		import mysql from 'mysql';

		const app = express();
		const port = process.env.PORT || 3011;

		app.use(cors());

		app.get('/', (req,res) => {
			const connection = mysql.createConnection({
				host: 'localhost',
				user: 'webuser',
				password: 'passpass',
				database: 'northwind'
			});
			connection.connect((err) => {
				if (err) throw err;
				console.log('mysql connected');
				const sql = 'SELECT * FROM customers';
				connection.query(sql, (err, result) => {
					if (err) throw err;
					res.json({
						customers: result
					});
				});
			});
		});

		app.listen(port, () => console.log(`listening on http://localhost:${port}`));
		------------------------------		
- other commands
	- `DELETE FROM mysql.user WHERE User = 'readwrite';`
	- `sudo apt remove nodejs npm`
	- uninstall mysql
		- `sudo apt-get remove --purge mysql*`
		- `sudo apt-get autoremove`
		- `sudo apt-get autoclean`

body:

	- cluster vs. database
		- a MontoDB Atlas cluster is like your local MongoDB server, or like your local MySQL server

			- each database has collections (like SQL tables)
			- each collection has documents (like SQL records)

title: Import a Northwind JSON file into MongoDB via the shell
body:
- the task is to import a JSON file into a collection in a Mongo database
- create working directory
- create Mongo database
	- `mongosh`
	- `show dbs`
		- make sure you don't have a `northwind` database yet
	- `exit`
- import the .json file
	- in your browser, go to: `https://github.com/raynaldmo/northwind-mongodb/tree/master/collections/json`
	- navigate to products.json
	- click on the *Raw* Button
	- copy the URL
	- `wget -O products.json https://raw.githubusercontent.com/raynaldmo/northwind-mongodb/master/collections/json/products.json`
		- if you are on Ubuntu, `wget` should be installed
		- if you are on Windows and don't have `wget`:
			- goto `https://eternallybored.org/misc/wget`
			- download the ZIP file
			- unpack
			- copy to somewhere that is in your Environment Path variable, e.g. `C:\Program Files\MongoDB\Server\5.0\bin`
	- make sure you have the JSON file your working directory
		- `ls`
	- make sure you have the `mongoimport` command installed
		- `mongoimport --version`
		- if you are on Ubuntu, `mongoimport` should be installed with MongoDB
		- to use `mongoimport` on Windows, you have to download and install **MongoDB Database Tools**
			- go to the **MongoDB Database Tools** download page [here](https://www.mongodb.com/try/download/database-tools?tck=docs_databasetools)
			- download the MSI file and execute it
	- import the file
		- `mongoimport --db northwind --collection products --type json --file products.json --jsonArray`
		- if successful, it should display how many records it imported
- view the collection in the shell
	- `mongosh`
	- `show dbs`
		- you should see *northwind*
	- `use northwind`
	- `show collections`
	- `db.products.find()`
	- notice that each document was automatically given its own, unique id

title: Mongo Querying and CRUD with MongoDB Shell, MongoDB Compass and NoSQLBooster + simple Node/Express/MongoDB API
body:
- in these instructions, we will use three interfaces to MongoDB to execute CRUD commands to the database - **MongoDB Shell** - **MongoDB Compass** - the free and standard GUI interface to MongoDB - **NoSQLBooster** - a nice GUI interface to MongoDB - to install these on Ubuntu or Windows, please see this howto: - [Install MongoDB development environment on Ubuntu/Windows (MongoDB 6.0 Server, Compass, mongoimport, mongosh, NoSQLBooster)](https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/howtos?id=668) - get the JSON files we will be working with - create a directory called **dataImport** - go to the [Northwind JSON files](https://github.com/graphql-compose/graphql-compose-examples/tree/master/examples/northwind/data/json) site and download the following files into the dataImport directory (make sure you click on **raw** then right click and **Save Page As...**, otherwise you download the HTML site instead of the JSON file): - 1. **employees.json** - 2. **customers.json** - 3. **suppliers.json** - import the JSON files into your MongoDB database - 1. import the **employees.json** file with mongosh - `mongoimport --db northwind --collection employees --type json --file employees.json --jsonArray` - 2. import the **customers.json** file with mongosh - but this time leave off the **collection** parameter and you will see that it uses the file name for the name of the collection - `mongoimport --db northwind --type json --file customers.json --jsonArray` - 3. import the **suppliers.json** file with Compass - you have to first create an empty collection - name it **suppliers.json** - click into it - click [Import Data], [Json], [Import] - basic Mongo commands (MongoDB Shell) - **MongoDB shell** - open shell - open a terminal - `mongosh` - show all databases - `show dbs` - open a database - `use northwind` - show which database you are currently in - `db` - show all collections of current database - `show collections` - **BE CAREFUL! MONGO DOES WHAT YOU SAY IMMEDIATELY!** - **delete an entire collection (!)** - `db.suppliers.drop()` - **delete the entire database you are currently on (!!!)** - `db.dropDatabase()`##protippp - on Ubuntu the file is actually here in MongoDB 6.0: - `~/.mongodb/mongosh/mongosh_repl_history` - on Windows: - `C:\Users\ADMIN\AppData\Roaming\mongodb\mongosh\mongosh_repl_history` - clear the screen - `cls` - leave the shell - `exit` - **MongoDB Shell in Compass** - note that Compass now has a MongoDB Shell at the bottom of the application now##bottomshelll - **MongoDB Shell in NoSQLBooster** - NoSQLBooster has a menu command to open the MongoDB Shell:##nobosterok - as you practice the following CRUD commands, execute them interchangeably in: - MongoDB Shell (`mongosh`) - Mongo Compass - NoSQLBooster - in order to: - see that each of these tools operates on the same data in the MongoDB database - to learn about and experiment with various features of each tool - basic CRUD commands - **READ** (C**R**UD) - **find** = return all documents in collections - `db.employees.find()` - **find specific fields** (projection), **sorting** and **filtering** - include only certain fields - `db.employees.find({}, {firstName: 1, lastName: 1})` - without _id - `db.employees.find({}, {firstName: 1, lastName: 1, _id: 0})` - sort by last name - `db.employees.find({}, {firstName: 1, lastName: 1, _id: 0}).sort({lastName: 1})` - sort by birth date - `db.employees.find({}, {firstName: 1, lastName: 1, birthDate: 1, _id: 0}).sort({birthDate: 1})` - sort by birth date descending order - `db.employees.find({}, {firstName: 1, lastName: 1, birthDate: 1, _id: 0}).sort({birthDate: -1})` - only output first 5 - `db.employees.find({}, {firstName: 1, lastName: 1, birthDate: 1, _id: 0}).sort({birthDate: -1}).limit(5)` - multiple sort fields / sub-fields (address.city) - `db.employees.find({},{ lastName: 1, "address.city": 1}).sort({"address.city": 1, lastName: 1})` - filter fields: only those from London - `db.employees.find({"address.city": "London"},{ lastName: 1, "address.city": 1}).sort({"address.city": 1, lastName: 1})` - exclude fields: all field but - `db.employees.find({title: "Sales Representative"}, {address: 0, notes: 0, territoryIDs: 0})` - `db.employees.find({title: "Sales Representative"}, {address: 0, notes: 0, territoryIDs: 0, _id: 0})` - **two syntaxes you might see:** - find(, ) `db.employees.find({title: "Sales Representative"}, {lastName: 1, firstName: 1, title: 1})` - find().**projection**() `db.employees.find({title: "Sales Representative"}).projection({lastName: 1, firstName: 1, title: 1})` - **countDocuments** = total number of objects based on criteria db.employees.countDocuments({title: "Sales Representative"}) - **findOne** = return only one object `db.employees.findOne({_id: ObjectId("62c17670c7a008886a499e92")})` - **exporting JSON to file** - *"2 days old with Mongo and I have a SQL background so bear with me. As with mysql, it is very convenient to be in the MySQL command line and output the results of a query to a file on the machine. I am trying to understand how I can do the same with Mongo, while being in the shell"* - [Printing Mongo query output to a file while in the mongo shell](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/22565231/printing-mongo-query-output-to-a-file-while-in-the-mongo-shell) - *"AFAIK, there is no a interactive option for output to file"* - Answer: just use JavaScript - output one object from collection to file - `fs.writeFileSync('employee_list.json', JSON.stringify(db.employees.findOne({employeeID: 7})))` - output array of object form collection to file: employee names sorted by last name - `fs.writeFileSync('employee_full_list8.json',JSON.stringify(db.employees.find({},{firstName: 1, lastName:1, _id:0}).sort({lastName: 1}).toArray()))` - **$eq** = equal to, **$ne** = not equal to - equal to - `db.employees.find({title: "Sales Representative"}).projection({lastName: 1, firstName: 1, title: 1})` - `db.employees.find({title: {$eq: "Sales Representative"}}).projection({lastName: 1, firstName: 1, title: 1})` - **not equal to** - `db.employees.find({title: {$ne: "Sales Representative"}}).projection({lastName: 1, firstName: 1, title: 1})` - **$gt** = greater than, **$lt** = less than, **$gte** = greater than or equal, **$lte** = less than or equal - in order to have realistic data to search on greater-than / less-than, we need to add a random age to each customer - this is a good opportunity to introduce how to use JavaScript to manipulate your Mongo database - create this script, **addRandomAge.js** ---------------------------------- db.customers.find({}).forEach(function(doc) { db.customers.updateOne({_id: doc._id}, { $set: {age: Math.floor(Math.random() * 30) + 20} }) }) ---------------------------------- - in your computer's terminal (not in mongosh), execute the JavaScript file: - `mongosh northwind addRandomAge.js` - **greater than** - `db.customers.find({ age: {$gt: 35}}, {_id: 0, contactName: 1, age: 1}).sort({age: 1})` - **less than** - `db.customers.find({ age: {$lt: 35}}, {_id: 0, contactName: 1, age: 1}).sort({age: 1})` - **greater than and less than** - `db.customers.find({ age: {$gte: 36, $lte: 39}}, {_id: 0, contactName: 1, age: 1}).sort({age: 1})` - **$in** = is contained in, **$nin** = is not contained in - city is either Strasbourg or Marseille - `db.customers.find({"address.city": {$in: ["Marseille", "London"]}}, {companyName: 1, "address.city": 1, _id: 0})` - company name, city for all that are not in London - `db.customers.find({"address.city": {$ne: "London"}}, {companyName: 1, "address.city": 1, _id: 0})` - `db.customers.find({"address.city": {$nin: ["London"]}}, {companyName: 1, "address.city": 1, _id: 0})` - **$exists** -------------------------------------------------------- // prepare: randomly add fields only to some db.suppliers.find({}).forEach(function(doc) { if(Math.floor(Math.random() * 3) + 1 === 1) { db.suppliers.updateOne({_id: doc._id}, { $set: {coupon: "new"} }) } }) // list those with coupon field db.suppliers.find({ coupon: {$exists: true} }, { companyName: 1, coupon: 1, _id: 0 }) // list those without coupon field db.suppliers.find({ coupon: {$exists: false} }, { companyName: 1, coupon: 1, _id: 0 }) // notice that it still finds field if value is empty -------------------------------------------------------- - **$and** / **$or** ------------------------------------------- // all customers older than 31 and less than 35 - automatic and db.customers.find({age: { $gt: 30, $lt: 35}}, {contactName: 1, age: 1, _id: 0}) // same db.customers.find({age: { $gt: 30, $lt: 55}, "address.country": "Brazil"}) db.customers.find({$and: [{age: { $gt: 30, $lt: 55}}, {"address.country": "Brazil"}]}) // city is London or people under 25 db.customers.find({$or: [ {"address.city": "London"}, {age: {$lt: 25}} ]}, {contactName: 1, "address.city": 1, _id:0, age: 1}) ------------------------------------------- - `$expr` ----------------------------------------------- // setup db.customers.find({}).forEach(function(doc) { db.customers.updateOne({_id: doc._id}, { $set: {managersAge: Math.floor(Math.random() * 30) + 20} }) }) // all whose age is greater than their manager's age db.customers.find({$expr: { $gt: ["$age", "$managersAge"]}}, {contactName: 1, age: 1, managersAge: 1, _id:0}) ----------------------------------------------- - **U**pdate - `updateOne` - `$set` ------------------------------------------------- // change name from Steven to Stephan db.employees.updateOne({_id: ObjectId('62c17670c7a008886a499e98')}, {$set: {firstName: "Stephan"}}) ------------------------------------------------- - `$inc` ------------------------------------------------- // increment age by one db.customers.updateOne({_id: ObjectId('62c177fb446b309f5d602e2b')}, {$inc: {age: 1}}) ------------------------------------------------- - `$push` ------------------------------------- // add territory ID to employee db.employees.updateOne({_id: ObjectId('62c17670c7a008886a499e96')}, {$push: {territoryIDs: 1111}}) ------------------------------------- - `$pull` ------------------------------------- // remove one territory ID from employee db.employees.updateOne({_id: ObjectId('62c17670c7a008886a499e96')}, {$pull: {territoryIDs: 55439}}) // remove many territory IDs from employee based on criteria db.employees.updateOne({_id: ObjectId('62c17670c7a008886a499e96')}, {$pull: {territoryIDs: {$gt: 40000}}}) ------------------------------------- - `updateMany` - `$rename` ---------------------------------------- // rename a field db.customers.updateMany({}, {$rename: { contactName: "customerName"}}) ---------------------------------------- - `$unset` ---------------------------------- // misspell a new field db.customers.find({}).forEach(function(doc) { db.customers.updateOne({_id: doc._id}, { $set: {vacationDayys: 29} }) }) // delete the misspelled field db.customers.updateMany({}, {$unset: {vacationDayys: ''}}) ---------------------------------- - `replaceOne` --------------------------------------- // replace object with new fields db.todos.replaceOne({_id: ObjectId('62c1f66c8063a4efa228542a')}, { "title": "examine all collections", "favorite": true, "deleted": false } ) // replace object with same fields, some with different values db.todos.replaceOne({_id: ObjectId('62c1f66c8063a4efa228542a')}, { "title": "examine all collections", "favorite": false, "deleted": false } ) --------------------------------------- - **D**elete - `deleteOne` -------------------------------------- db.todos.deleteOne({_id: ObjectId('62c1f66c8063a4efa228542a')}) -------------------------------------- - `deleteMany` ------------------------------------ // delete all from London db.employees.deleteMany({"address.city": "London"}) // delete all not from London (deletes rest) db.employees.deleteMany({"address.city": {$ne: "London"}}) ------------------------------------ - **C**reate - `insertOne()` ---------------------------------- use northwind show collections db.todos.insertOne({title: "examine all collections"}) show collections db.todos.find() ---------------------------------- - `insertMany()` ---------------------------------- db.todos.insertMany([ {title: "examine all collections"}, {title: "try out all commands"} ]) show collections db.todos.find() ---------------------------------- - **use MongoDB querying in Node/Express API** - `npm init -y` - `npm i express` - `npm i mongodb` - `npm i -D nodemon` - **package.json** ----------------------------------- "type": "module", "scripts": { "dev": "nodemon server.js" }, ----------------------------------- - **server.js** ------------------------------------------- import express from 'express'; import { MongoClient } from 'mongodb'; const app = express(); const port = 3022; const conn = 'mongodb://localhost:27017'; const client = new MongoClient(conn); const getData = async (done) => { await client.connect(); const db = client.db('northwind'); done(db); }; app.get('/', (req, res) => { res.send('

MongoDB Test

'); }); app.get('/employees', (req, res) => { getData(async (db) => { const users = await db .collection('employees') .find({ birthDate: { $gte: '1963' } }) .project({ firstName: 1, lastName: 1, _id: 0, birthDate: 1 }) .toArray(); res.json(users); }); }); app.listen(port, () => { console.log(`Listening on http://localhost:${port}`); }); -------------------------------------------

title: How to change a repository's default branch from master to main
body:
- these instructions assume you have a Git repository locally and on GitHub and want to change the default repository from **master** to **main** both locally and on GitHub
- rename the local branch from master to main:
	- `git branch --move master main`
- upload the local main branch to your GitHub repository
	- `git push --set-upstream origin main`
- you now have two branches in your GitHub repository: **master** (default) and **main**
	- so at GitHub, change the default branch from **master** to **main**:##theonetwosdf
- now delete the master branch from your GitHub repository
	- `git push origin --delete master`

title: Invest time in learning Vim in order to code faster
body:
- **what is Vim?**
	- Vim is a text editor originally **created in 1976** (vi) and then improved in 1991 (Vim) 
	- it enables you to edit files while **keeping your hands on the keyboard** and **not using a mouse**
	- Vim was useful in the 70s since **the mouse hadn't been invented yet**
	- Vim is still useful today since when you don't use the mouse and keep your hands on the keyboard, **you can code faster**#gif#vimfast
- **reasons not to learn Vim**
	- Vim has a **steep learning curve**, the commands are arbitrary and cryptic, and can be difficult to remember
	- until you spend a week or so internalizing the main commands, it will **at first slow your coding speed down**
	- Vim really only makes sense when you switch your keyboard to the **English layout**
		- if you type with a **German keyboard**
			- you'll have to install a **virtual English keyboard** and switch between them, which is quite easy:
				- Windows: **ALT-Shift**
				- Ubuntu: **Super-spacebar**
			- you'll have to **memorize where the keys are on the English keyboard** since many in different positions as the German keyboard##tehtwokeeyboards
			- e.g. **searching in Vim** is an example where it makes sense to use the English keyboard layout 
				- searching in Vim a very common task not only to **find** text but to **navigate and move** around your document
				- to search in Vim, you use the **?** and **/** characters
				- on the English keyboard, these are on the same key and very easy to reach with the right little finger
				- however, on the German keyboard, they are on different keys and harder to reach			
		- also, a prerequisite to using Vim is that you can touch type quickly without looking at the keys
	- so learning Vim can be quite a **feat of memorization**, particularly at the beginning
	- the best time to learn Vim is not when you have a lot of work and pressing deadlines
		- but when you have some **extra time**
- **reasons to learn Vim**
	- once you internalize the commands, you will be able to **code faster**
		- it generally only **take a week of constant practicing** until Vim makes you faster at coding
		- it's like riding bike: the more you practice, the better you get
	- you can **use Vim anywhere** since Vim is:
		- available on **every operating system** 
		- available as a **plugin** in most editors e.g. VSCode, Atom, PyCharm, Eclipse, JetBrains
		- available on e.g. **servers without a GUI** that you SSH into 
	- Vim commands are present in many Linux commands, e.g. `less`
		- Vim commands for moving and searching are common in many Linux commands
	- you **don't have to switch 100%**
		- Vim is simply a text file editor so you can **use any other editor** to edit the same text files at any time
			- while still in the learning-curve: switch back and forth as needed
			- use Vim when you have time to learn
		- in VSCode you can **easily disable and enable Vim**
		- switching your keyboard from English to German is a simple one-key press, e.g. **ALT-shift** in Windows, **Super+Space** in Linux
	- you will find **hundreds of useful learning resources** for Vim
		- e.g. start here: https://vim.is
	- Stack Overflow and other forums are full of answers to Vim questions
		- e.g. `delete to end of line in vim` finds [this answer](https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/4415/delete-from-cursor-to-end-of-line-in-vi)			
- **installation**
	- VSCode
		- simply install the [Vim extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=vscodevim.vim)##vimbraksenxt
		- immediately after you install the Vim extension
			- you won't be able to type anything
			- you have to press **i** to enter **insert mode** to type
			- then to get back out of **insert mode**, you press **ESC**
	- Linux command line
		- `sudo apt update`
		- `sudo apt install vim`
		- then to edit a file: `vim index.html`
- **white belt**
	- *normal mode and insert mode*
		- you start in normal mode
		- `i` for insert mode so you can type
		- `ESC` back to normal mode
	- normal mode move:
		- character: `h`, `j`, `k`, `l`
			- also `5h` or `7k`
		- word: `w`, `e`, `b`
		- line start/end: `^`, `$`, `0`
		- file start/end/all: `gg`, `G`, (`cie` or `1GVG`)
	- inserting
		- before/after character `i`, `I`, `a`, `A`
		- after word: `ea`
		- before/after line: `o`, `O`
	- undo/redo
		- `u`, CTRL-`r`
- **orange belt**
	- move
		- matching brace: `%`
		- goto definition: `gd`
		- go back: CTRL-`o`
		- move to same word at other positions in the file: `*`
		- : (line number)
		- move to blocks: `{`, `}`
	- editing
		- character: `r`
			- also: `9r-` or `9r_`
			- multiple: `R`
		- replace and type: `s`
			- also: `3s`
		- join: `J`
		- replace whole line: `cc`
		- change word: `cw`, `ciw`
			- also, rest of word: `cw`
			- till end: `C`
			- till character: `c/"`
			- change camelCase part:
				- e.g. `3s`
				- combine with . (repeat command)
		- delete line: `dd`
			- also: `3dd`
		- delete word: `dw`, `diw`
			- till end: `D`
			- till character: `d/;`
		- cut: `x`
			- swap: `xp`
		- copy/paste word:
			- `yiw`
			- `viwp`		
	- repeat: `.`
	- comment/uncomment: `gcc`
- **green belt**
	- habit: move by searching: `/`, `?`, `n`, `N`
	- move line up/down: `ddkP`, `ddp`
	- visual mode selection
		- three ways to select: `v`, `V`, CTRL-`v`
			- top/bottom: `o`
			- word: `aw`
			- (): `ab`
				- inner: `ib`
			- {}: `aB`
				- inner: `iB`
		- action on selection
			- delete/yank: `d`, `y`
			- paste before/after: `P`, `p`
				- at end of line: `$p`
			- case: `u`, `U`, `~`
			- comment/uncomment: `gc`
			- indent: `>`, `<`
				- also: `3>`
- **blue belt**
	- habit: pause and consider fewest strokes possible
	- `"*y`
	- search and replace
		- `:%s/this/that/g`
		- visual select
			- `:s/this/that/g`
	- past commands: `:` and arrow-up and arrow-down
	- select/change/delete inner text
		- change inside two tags
			- `cit` also: `dit`, `vit`
		- change inside double quotes
			- `ci"` also: `di"`, `vi"`
		- change inside singl quotes
			- `ci'` also: `di'`, `vi'`
		- change inside brackets
			- `ci)` also: `di)`, `vi)`
			- `ci}` also: `di}`, `vi}`
			- `ci]` also: `di]`, `vi]`
- **brown belt**
	- habit: before moving, "ma" (marker), then come back with `'a`
		- hop back and forth between two areas of code with `ma` and `ms`
	- tabs: `gt`, `gT`
	- repeat character 99 times: `i=` `ESC` `d99P`
	- black-hole deleting: `"_dd`
	- `:reg`
	- connection to operating system clipboard
		- copy to: `"*y`
		- paste from: `"*p`	
	- close file: `:wq!`
- **black belt**
	- habit: be able to type numbers without looking
	- sort: visual mark: `:sort`
	- numbers: `:set nu` and `:set nonu`
	- macros
		- `qq` - record
		- `q` - stop
		- `@q` - execute
		- `5@q` - execute 5 times
		- `@@` - execute again
- extra
	- open up new file in tab: 
		- VSCode: `:e` space, TAB
		- Linux: `:tabe .`
	- close tab: `:q`
	- close all tabs: `:qall`
	- next tab: `gt`
	- previous tab: `gT`

body:
- this bash script will accesses the [thispersondoesnotexist.com](https://thispersondoesnotexist.com) website to download images of people who don't exist, useful if you need images of non-real people for demos, instructional material, etc.#gif#bashScriptCreatePeopleImages
- based on [this code](https://gist.github.com/johnjreiser/b4e46c06dfb28e3034c3f78c819b4c3f)
- read about [Generative adversarial network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_adversarial_network), a set of machine learning algorithms that generate new photographs that look at least superficially authentic to human observers
- **getpics.sh**
	------------------------------------------------------
	#!/bin/bash

	MAX=10
	if [[ ! -z "$1" ]]; then
			MAX=$1
	fi

	for i in $(seq -f "%03g" 1 $MAX); do
		FILE=person${i}.jpg
		curl 'https://thispersondoesnotexist.com/image' -H 'authority: thispersondoesnotexist.com' -H 'pragma: no-cache' -H 'cache-control: no-cache' -H 'upgrade-insecure-requests: 1' -H 'user-agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_12_0) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/75.0.3770.80 Safari/537.36' -H 'accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,image/apng,*/*;q=0.8,application/signed-exchange;v=b3' -H 'referer: https://thispersondoesnotexist.com/' -H 'accept-encoding: gzip, deflate, br' -H 'accept-language: en-US,en;q=0.9' --compressed -o $FILE
		sleep 1
	done

body:
- sometimes when working on Ubuntu in React projects, I have seen the following problem:##watchererrorubuntu

- a solution that worked for someone on Ubuntu in one instance was this:
	- edit system control configuration file

	- add the following line to the bottom of the file:

body:
- background
	- in the [previous howto](https://edwardtanguay.netlify.app/howtos?id=510), we loaded an array of employees from a `getEmployees()` function in the same JavaScript file
	- the problem with this is that it doesn't scale: if you have two or three functions such as `getCustomers()` and `getProducts()` then the file becomes long and cumbersome
	- JavaScript modules are a solution to encapsulate these functions so that you import them in one line from any file
	- the goal of this howto is to convert the `getEmployees()` function from the previous howto file to a module and import it from the main file
	- we will then import `customers` and `orders` from modules and combine them with ES6 array functions
- set up project
	- using modules requires you to have a package.json file and hence a new directory and project
	- under you **projects** directory, create a directory called `moduletest`
	- go into it with `cd moduletest`
	- create `main.js` (this file will import your data modules)
- create **customers** module and import into `main.js`
	- copy the [customers.json](https://github.com/graphql-compose/graphql-compose-examples/tree/master/examples/northwind/data/json) files into `data_customers.js`

		- your `customers.js` file should look like this:##customersFileLook

		-----------------------------
		import { customers } from './customers.js';

		console.log(customers.length);
		-----------------------------
	- run it with `node main.js` and you will get this error:##thetypemoderror
		- set up an npm project by typing `npm init -y` which will create a `package.json` file
		- in the `package.json` file add `"type": "module" entry##addentrymodtyp
		- run `node main.js` again and it will display the number of customers in the JavaScript object in the `customers.js` file##gothe91

body:
- intro - this project shows you how to - create a data-driven website with JavaScript/DOM using Sass - use ES6 modules to organize helper functions and classes - test the application locally - publish the site to Netlify - test the online site in your browser and smartphone - make updates to your app and immediately publish live - when you complete this project, you will have everything you need to build data-driven apps that run on browser/smartphone, which you can continually update##thepreviewmodulesjs - find the full code for this site here: [edwardtanguay/create-publish-javascript-dom-netlify](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/create-publish-javascript-dom-netlify) - what you won't have - users will not be able to log in and there will be no protected data - for this you would need a backend - all code (HTML, CSS, JavaScript) is sent to the browser so all code is public - you will not be able to access a database - but you have access to a file with a JavaScript object - this makes the step toward using a database such as MongoDB later a smaller one - both solutions consume JavaScript objects in the same way - this project does not use React or any other frontend library (like Vue.js) - converting this project to React would involve quite a number of steps - adding Vue.js to this site would change the structure of it - both React and Vue.js invert how one views state in an appliation - loading data from APIs is not covered in this project, although - you won't be using the npm package manager - anything you add later will be via a CDN, e.g. Bootstrap, Vue.js - these notes are meant to be notes for a live-coding so not all code is supplied - if you are not following along in a live-coding, then refer to the [finished project](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/create-publish-javascript-dom-netlify) for the appropriate code - steps - make a minimal functioning DOM site with HTML, CSS and JavaScript - make directory - create a meaningful name, it will be the name of your site online, e.g. `nameofapp.netlify.app` - unique but short as possible - or for testing purposes: long and unique - copy VSCode in that directory - `index.html` - `css/main.css` - `js/main.js` - script element first top of file - **ERROR:** `Uncaught TypeError: contentElem is null` - **FIX:** then script element at bottom - works - then move back up - doesn't work - **FIX:** then add `defer` - works - add git - you always want to develop with Git, even if you do not publish your repository to GitHub - it helps you organize your code changes - you can go back to any previous state of your app - `git init` - commit locally - add Sass - you always want to develop with Sass instead of CSS - the nesting feature alone enables you to achieve more with less styling code - you can't add it via npm, so we will use a VSCode extension: - install **Live Sass Compiler, by Ritwick Dey**##thelivesassokok - rename `.css` file to `.scss` - click on the words **Watch Sass** that appear in your task bar at the bottom of VSCode##appearwatchsass - you will see that CSS files get automatically created##sassautomaticly - now anytime you change your `.scss` file, it will be compiled automatically into CSS - convert your CSS to SASS now (nest styles) and then look at the converted CSS - e.g. convert to dark mode and fix padding, etc. - check in Git - see history: `git log --oneline` - go back to initial commit: `git checkout HASH` - return to current HEAD: `git switch -` - add ES6 modules - make **tools.js** as test - `export const message = 'test';` - in main: import - **ERROR:** `Uncaught SyntaxError: import declarations may only appear at top level of a module` - **FIX:** in `index.html`: add `type="module"` to script tag - add **tools.js** - sentencize() - this is a test - --> This is a test. - getTodaysDate() - --> "Monday, March 23, 2022" - tools.js ------------------------------------------ export const capitalizeFirstCharacter = (text) => { return text.charAt(0).toUpperCase() + text.slice(1); } export const getTodaysDate = () => { const currentDate = new Date(); const options = { weekday: 'long', year: 'numeric', month: 'short', day: 'numeric' }; return currentDate.toLocaleDateString('en-us', options); } ------------------------------------------ - main.js --------------------------------------- import { capitalizeFirstCharacter, getTodaysDate } from './tools.js'; const contentElem = document.querySelector('.content'); contentElem.innerHTML = `

${capitalizeFirstCharacter('this is a test')}

${getTodaysDate()}

`; --------------------------------------- - convert tools.js to using documentation ------------------------------------------ /** * Capitalize the first letter of a string. * * tools.capitalizeFirstLetter("this is the title of the article"); * * "This is the title of the article" */ ------------------------------------------ - import as wildcard in order to get intellisense ------------------------------ import * as tools from './tools.js'; ------------------------------ - all available functions are now shown as intellisense##allavailablearefunc - it now shows documentation when you use the function##gettheintellisense - add data - create file `/js/data/flashcards.js` (copy from code from the [finished project](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/create-publish-javascript-dom-netlify)) - note you are exporting a constant that is an array of objects that represent flashcards - this data comes from a real project where I collect flashcards in order to find useful information fast - https://onespace.netlify.app/flashcards - style it in Sass - push to GitHub with same name as directory - publish at Netlify - change name to same name as directory and GitHub repository - for your free account on Netlify you have 300 minutes of build time - remember every time you push to your repository, Netlify will start a new build##netlifynotices - Jest testing - install Jest - `npm init -y` - `npm i -D jest` - in **package.json** set up `npm test` command: - `"test": "node --experimental-vm-modules node_modules/jest/bin/jest.js"` - (experimental syntax because we use ES6 `import` instead of CommonJS `require`) - also add `"type": "module",` - also in order to use ES6 `import` - set up tests: - create **testing/test.js** ----------------------------- import * as tools from '../js/tools.js'; describe('capitalizeFirstCharacter() is correctly implemented', () => { test.each` input | expected ${'test'} | ${'Test'} ${'this is a test'} | ${'This is a test'} ${'Test'} | ${'Test'} ${''} | ${''} ${'123'} | ${'123'} `('convert $input to $expected', ({ input, expected }) => { expect(tools.capitalizeFirstCharacter(input)).toBe(expected); }); }); test('getTodaysDate() is correctly implemented', () => { const currentDate = new Date(); const options = { weekday: 'long', year: 'numeric', month: 'short', day: 'numeric' }; const correctDate = currentDate.toLocaleDateString('en-us', options); expect(tools.getTodaysDate()).toBe(correctDate); }); ----------------------------- - run Jest tests with: `npm test`

How to run a React site and backend API simultaneously with npm-run-all
body:
- these instructions show you how to run local frontend (e.g. React) and backend (e.g. Node/Express) that you want to run simultaneously
- these scripts:##scriptsthatstartnn
- start the frontend and backend:##runpbackendfrontend
- see [documentation](https://www.npmjs.com/package/npm-run-all/v/4.1.5)
	- *run-s is for sequential, run-p is for parallel*
	- documentation for [run-p](https://github.com/mysticatea/npm-run-all/blob/HEAD/docs/run-p.md)
- installation and setup
	- `npm i -D npm-run-all` (`-D` means put it in devDependencies)
	- add backend script, e.g. `"backend": "./node_modules/.bin/nodemon",`
	- change React state script from start to appstart e.g. `"appstart": "react-scripts start",`
	- add new start script: `"start": "run-p backend appstart",`
- one problem is that if you will have at this point is if you have e.g. another React site already running on 3001, then when you start this site, the start script will ask you if you want to run it on another port, but this run-p script does not wait for the answer and your frontend won't be able to start
	- to fix this error, put a static PORT number in the `.env` file, e.g. `PORT = 3100` so that your React site always starts on that port

body:
- VIDEO: [Vite 2.0 Crash Course | Super Fast Build Tool for JavaScript, React, Vue, Svelte, & Lit (2021)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LQQ3CR2JTX8)
- Vite is the next generation in frontend tooling
- says it uses **Rollup** to build, **esbuild** to prebundle
- Vite was created by **Evan You**, creator of Vue, but Vite is not a Vue-only tool
- problems with Webpack, Parcel and Rollup:
	- they have to build everything every time you save
- to solve this problem, Vite has taken a completely backwards approach, but it works
	- Vite **prebundles with esbuild**, Rollup is used to bundle for production
	- **esbuild is written in Go** which makes it **100x faster** than bundlers written in JavaScript##esbuildthespeed
- what about [Snowpack](https://www.snowpack.dev)
	- a no-bundle, native ESM server as well
		- ESM or *EcmaScript modules* = [JavaScript's native module system](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/import)
	- **Vite was inspired by Snowpack** Version 1.0 but has key differences
		- Vite has **multipage support out of the box**
			- e.g. in JS/DOM you just have to create a new folder and file and it just works, modules are taken care of for you
			- to build for production, you just have to add your entry points:##buildforproduction
		- Vite has **automatic code-splitting**
			- only loads CSS for the part of the application that you are using
			- this is going to make large applications faster
		- Vite has **Automatic Dynamic Import Polyfill**
			- gives you better backward compatibility to older browsers
	- NOTE: actually as of four days ago, **Snowpack is no longer being developed**##nomoresnowpack
- shows how to use Vite
	- creates **JS/DOM app**
		- `npm init @vitejs/app` but looks like it is the same as `npm create vite`##lookssammm
		- although I get that this syntax is deprecated##deprecvite
		- `npm i`
		- `npm run dev`
			- shows every file
		- `npm run build`
			- looks in dist folder
			- serves this build with `npm run serve`
			- port 3000 is dev server, 5000 is build server
	- shows speed of **Vite vs. create-react-app** in building an app
		- you can use the dot notation to install in the current directory##usedotto
		- there are **more commands to type with Vite, but it is 4x faster**
		- Vite **00:30**, create-react-app **02:17** ##crawaitpic
		- compares **build sizes**
			- Vite dist folder: **144 K**
			- create-react-app build folder: **544 K**
		- compares **full project size**
			- Vite: **44 MB, 1,795 files**
			- create-react-app: **262 MB, 36,213 files**
		- compares **hot-loading**
			- makes a small change in a .js file
			- Vite: 0.05 seconds
			- create-react-app: 1.02 seconds
			- note in Vite: hot-loading does not change the state

title: Strategy for modern website development with React
body:
- **fetching, manipulating, displaying, sending, and reacting to changes in data** is 90% of web application programming
	- keep [Jamstack](https://jamstack.org) in mind
		- super fast, globally distributed **frontends**
			- free: Netlify, Vercel, Cloudflare
		- headless, dedicated **backends** that serve data
			- free: Heroku
			- low cost: Hetzner, Digital Ocean
		- communication between between frontends and backends requires **asynchronous data fetching**
- for React sites, this means:
	- **1. create state variables** you need
		- what data is going to change that will require a **react**ion to that data?
		- everything else can be a normal variable
	- **2. load data** you need
		- *local data*
			- simply import it before your function loads
			- if this is data that will change:
				- load it as a temporary variable (`_employees`) 
				- save it as the default value of a state variable 
					- `const [employees, setEmployees] = useState(_employees)`
		- *remote data*
			- load it in **useEffect()** 
			- load it with **fetch()** (or axios)
			- loading remote data always occurs in a different *time zone*
				- there it always requires **async/await**
			- *whenever* the data arrives, save it in a *state variable*
				- REMEMBER: always save a *copy* of a state variable as its new value since *state varialbles are immutable*
					- string
						- `setMode(mode);`
					- number
						- `setCount(count);`
					- boolean
						- `setDataIsLoaded(dataIsLoaded);`
					- **array** - spread it
						- `setEmployees([...employees]);`
					- **object** - spread it
						- `setConfig({...config});`
				- TIP: many problems in React revolve around problems with saving data to state variables, advice: always use _temp variable
					----------------------------------------
					const _employees = employees.filter(m => m.vacationDaysLeft > 10);
					setEmployees(_employees);
					----------------------------------------
	- **3. build logic into JSX** to *react* to and change *state variables*
		- usually you react to **state variables** that will be changing as the user uses the, as data loaded into the site, etc.
			- however, you often also need to react (once on pageLoad) to e.g. **props** sent into the component, or **normal** variables imported e.g. config variables, etc.
		- build conditional statements
			- if/then: `{employees.length === 0 && (...)}`
			- if/then/else: `{config.userIsPayingCustomer ? (...) : (...)}`
			- for everything else, extract logic to a function: `{jobRequiresFavoriteTechnologies(job) && (...)`
		- build event handles for events
			- inline
				-------------------------------------------
				<button onClick={() => setSiteLayout('darkmode')}>Dark Mode</button>
				-------------------------------------------
			- call a handling function
				-----------------------------------------
				<button onClick={() => handleProcessContract(contract)}>Process Contract</button>
				-----------------------------------------
		- common uses for JSX logic:
			- let the user know that data is loading
			- disable functionality that is not available yet (e.g. because data is still loading)
			- change state based on user activity: selected dropdown choice, pressed button, clicked link, etc.
			- make changes in state variables with events and event handles
	- **4. refactor app into components**
		- React makes refactoring code into components easy
		- therefore a common development strategy is to "refactor as you go", refactor when:
			- a component is more than two screens long - extract a obvious code units out into a component
			- you notice repetive code - collect all instances of repetative code, condense it into a component, call it from all places where it was used
		- obvious components
			- pages
			- a display unit for an item in an array - send object as prop
				------------------------------------
				{employees.map((emp, index) => {<Employee employee={emp}})}
				------------------------------------
			- any reusable code 
		- send props to the component that make it unique
			------------------------------------
			<SmartButton userIsOnline={userIsOnline} kind="warning"/>
			------------------------------------
		- remember that each component is its own universe with its own:
			- imports
			- state variables
			- useEffect() functions
			- JSX
			- child components
		- components trees have no depth limit
			- a React site is: components in components in components ... in App.jsx

it is also possible to publish your frontend React site at GitHub pages but not as straight-forward as with the Jamstack-philosophy providers Netlify, Vercel and Cloudflare - in my experience, the easiest free solution for frontend and backend publishing for MERN stack websites today is: - backend: Heroku - up to 5 sites which automatically pull on pushes from a GitHub repository - (up to 100 sites if you provide your credit card information) - machines sleep which can take up to 8 seconds to spin up, but this can be accounted for on the front end in order to provide decent UX - React testing overview and unit testing with Jest in a React application
body:
- As we move from monolith design (you control the environment in which your code runs) to distributed design (you don't control this environment), testing is becoming more import - the code you write is increasingly dependent on: - other code that you have written - other code that your team has written - third-party code that was written by people you don't know - characteristics of the - operating system environment - network environment - cloud environment - any changes in any of these code bases or environments can break your code - **therefore you need tests which make sure your code works as expected today and into the future** - Overview of testing React applications - 1. unit testing - e.g. test if all functions and classes in app libraries work as expected - tools - [Jest](https://jestjs.io/docs/tutorial-react) - 2. integration testing - e.g. test if a child component can update context state in a parent - tools - [React Testing Library](https://testing-library.com/docs/react-testing-library/intro) - [Enzyme](https://enzymejs.github.io/enzyme) - 3. end-to-end testing - test the application from the point of view of the user, e.g. uses a mock browser, clicks buttons, fills in fields, tests for certain error messages and results - tools - [Cypress](https://www.cypress.io) - Career tip: - make yourself an expert in testing and be forever appreciated in development teams - using Jest unit testing in various environments - 1. **an older React site created with create-react-app** - technical issues in making sure Jest works - getting Jest to work with ES6 modules (import) instead of with CommonJS modules (require) - testing both JavaScript and TypeScript files - course web site - this site was created with create-react-app and so Jest is automatically installed: - note that for some reason (our upgrade to React 18?) I had to install jest-watch-typeahead##hadtoinstallwatchahead - in a site created with create-react-app, you simply have to create files which end with `.test.js` and which contain tests which test classes or functions in the similarly named file - note you can have one centralized test file e.g. `global.test.js` which tests all tests in application - but having a test file for each file which is imported tends to keep your tests more organized in a larger application - developers know if they create a new function or class, where they need to create the test for it (in the similarly-named test file) - to execute all `.test.js` files, type `npm test` - qtools is a directory with "quick tools", e.g. files that can be imported which contain useful functions - qstr = functions that manipulate strings - qarr = functions that manipulate arrays - qmat = functions that do mathematical calculations - examine current tests - note we currently have **one test suite** (one test file) and **two tests** (two Jest tests in that one file) in that test suite:##overviewtestsuites - improve tests - common task between sprints - add edge cases ----------------------------------------------- expect(qstr.capitalizeFirstLetter('this is a sentence: !#$%^&*()')).toBe('This is a sentence: !#$%^&*()'); expect(qstr.capitalizeFirstLetter('1234567890')).toBe('1234567890'); expect(qstr.capitalizeFirstLetter('überhaupt')).toBe('Überhaupt'); ----------------------------------------------- - scenario: develop changes function which fixes their local problem, but causes problems elsewhere - break the test by changing a function for a specific reason - Menu.jsx ---------------------------------- import * as qstr from '../../../../qtools/qstr'; let projectTitle = 'taking notes on %tech% books'; projectTitle = qstr.capitalizeFirstLetter(projectTitle);

Project 001

Title: {projectTitle}

line = qstr.replaceAll(line, '%', ''); ---------------------------------- - fix this problem by creating a few function called `removeSpecialMarkdown()` using TDD (test-driven development) - write the tests first: ------------------------------------------ test('qstr.removeSpecialMarkdown() works', () => { expect(qstr.removeSpecialMarkdown('markdown')).toBe('markdown'); expect(qstr.removeSpecialMarkdown('%markdown%')).toBe('markdown'); expect(qstr.removeSpecialMarkdown('## - %markdown%')).toBe('- markdown'); expect(qstr.removeSpecialMarkdown('%% - %markdown%')).toBe('- markdown'); expect(qstr.removeSpecialMarkdown('%% - %öffnen%')).toBe('- öffnen'); }); ------------------------------------------ - develop the function until all tests pass, that's when you know you are finished ------------------------------------------- export const removeSpecialMarkdown = (line: string) => { line = qstr.replaceAll(line, '%', ''); line = qstr.replaceAll(line, '#', ''); line = line.trim(); return line; } ------------------------------------------- - if you would like to practice writing Jest tests, feel free to do so in the course site, there's lots of work to do - e.g. replaceAll ---------------------------------------------------------------- test('qstr.replaceAll() works', () => { expect(qstr.replaceAll('test','x', '')).toBe('test'); expect(qstr.replaceAll('test')).toBe('test'); expect(qstr.replaceAll('test', 'est', 'xx')).toBe('txx'); expect(qstr.replaceAll('ooxooxoo', 'x', '')).toBe('oooooo'); }); ---------------------------------------------------------------- - for an overview of all matchers besides (`toBe`) see: [Edward's Notes on Jest](https://onespace.netlify.app/techItems?id=19) - 2. **a new create-react-app site** - create new site with create-react-app - make a library file e.g. `tools.js` which exports functions - make a file in the same directory called `tools.test.js` to test the files - `npm run test` - 3. **a new React site created with Vite** - see this guide: [Setup Jest with Vite](https://hung.dev/jest-vite) - *"I had a chance to use Vite in my daily work and I’m very happy with that, my Developer Experience (DX) and productivity have increased dramatically, it’s blazing fast. However, speed is not the only factor to make a high quality web application. We also need tests. Even though I’m happy with Vite, it took me a while to successfully integrate Jest with Vite."*
