title: Create read-only Node/Express API and Search Engine Frontend
Publish read-only Node/Express API at Heroku with frontend search engine site at Netlify
body:
- the goal of this howto is to do the following:
	- publish a Node/Express/API at Heroku and a Vite-React site at Netlify dealing with the issue of **getting the environment variables set correctly** locally (in the .env file) and online (as environment variables on the Heroku and Netlify providers) so that **the local frontend automatically uses the local backend** and **the online Netlify frontend automatically uses the online Heroku backend**
	- start with this project: [edwardtanguay.netlify.app/howtos?id=570](https://edwardtanguay.netlify.app/howtos?id=570)
	- this project consists of two code bases: 
		- a backend Node/Express API which serves data fetched from various sources
		- a frontend React site which fetches its data from the backend
	- set up this project so that it works locally
	- publish the backend at Heroku
		- test with Postman
		- test with local frontend
	- publish the frontend at Netlify
		- enable online frontend to fetch data from online backend 
- **set up a parent directory that contains both backend and frontend projects**
	- create a directory under your projects folder called e.g. `howto-ejt-dern002`
		- note that you will create two folders under this called 
			- `howto-ejt-backend-dern002`
			- `howto-ejt-frontend-dern002`
		- note that **ejt** should be your initials so that you have a uniquely named sites at Heroku and Netlify
		- note that app names at Heroku cannot exceed **30 characters**
			- "backend-" is 8 characters
			- therefore **the name of this local parent project should be no more than 23 characters**
			- e.g. `howto-ejt-dern002` is **17 characters**
		- Netlify url names have a much longer limite of 63 characters which is an Internet domain limit
		- planning the name of your backend/frontend project now will save you confusion later
- **set up the backend**
	- create directory called e.g. `howto-ejt-backend-dern002` in parent directory
	- download this repository's files into it: [edwardtanguay/howto-ejt-backend-dern001](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/howto-ejt-backend-dern001)
	- `code .`
	- `npm i`
	- `git init`
		- initial commit
	- `npm run dev`
	- backend should be running locally like this##backendhsouldlocal
- **set up the frontend**
	- create directory called e.g. `howto-ejt-frontend-dern002` in parent directory
	- download this repository's files into it: [edwardtanguay/howto-ejt-frontend-dern001](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/howto-ejt-frontend-dern001)
	- `code .`
	- `npm i`
	- `git init`
		- initial commit
	- `npm run dev`
	- site should run and look like this, connecting to backend port number (3007), search works after 3rd character:##theshowandfront
	- fix key warning in browser console
		- `<React.Fragment key={i}>`
- **publish backend to Heroku**
	- note at Heroku, you have a limit of 5 free apps
		- if you give them your credit card information, you won't be charged and will have a limit of 100 free apps
		- if you have reached your limit, delete an app now to make room for this app that we are publishing
	- push local repository to GitHub
		- e.g. my repo is here: [edwardtanguay/howto-ejt-backend-dern002](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/howto-ejt-backend-dern002)
	- log into [heroku.com](https://id.heroku.com/login)
	- [New]
	- [Create new app]
	- enter name, e.g. `howto-ejt-backend-dern002`
	- [Europe]
	- [Create app]##tehcreatappisail
	- [GitHub]
	- search for your app
	- [Connect]##okandapp2find
	- [Enable Automatic Deploys]
	- [Deploy Branch]##enabbanddeploy
	- [Overview]##tooverviewsdf
	- [Open app]
	- note the site works, but the url links are still displaying localhost:##partareok
	- solve url link problem by creating environment variables
		- create `.env` file in root
			----------------------------
			BASE_URL = http://localhost
			----------------------------
		- add the `.env` file to `.gitignore` file so it doesn't get checked into GitHub:#gif#theenvgirtnorn
		- server.js
			--------------------------------------------
			import dotenv from 'dotenv';

			dotenv.config();
			const mode = process.env.MODE;
			const baseUrl = process.env.BASE_URL;
			const port = process.env.PORT;
			const url = mode === 'development' ? `${baseUrl}:${port}` : baseUrl;
			--------------------------------------------
	- **(NOTE: if you need to debug an error occurring in your Heroku compilation)**
		- `heroku login`
		- `heroku logs -a howto-ejt-backend-dern002 --tail`	
		- this will enable you to view log output during the compilation including exact errors that occurred:##seethelogisdfjk
	- push to GitHub
		- go to Heroku/Overview again and you will see "Build in progress...Just now"
		- when finished, click [Open app] again
		- note that baseUrl at Heroku is `undefined`
			- reason: there is no `.env` file at Heroku since it was not uploaded to GitHub
			- instead, we need to create matching environment variables at Heroku##theundefinjj
	- create environment variable `baseUrl` at Heroku
		- at Heroku, click on Settings and then [Reveal Config Vars]
		- enter `BASE_URL` and `howto-ejt-backend-dern002`:##thesetandsreveal
	- our backend routes now show correctly:##andnowitworksokdataapi
- **publish frontend to Netlify**	
	- test consuming Heroku backend from local frontend site
		- stop the local backend server
		- start the local frontend server which will not work since it has no access to the local backend:##nowonlyloading
		- change the base url to point to the online backend at Heroku
			-----------------------------------
			// const baseUrl = 'http://localhost:3007';
			const baseUrl = 'https://howto-ejt-backend-dern002.herokuapp.com';			
			-----------------------------------
		- the local frontend can use the online backend:##andcouworks
	- implement environment variables on frontend as we did on backend
		- create `.env` file and add an entry in `.gitignore` so that we don't push it to our GitHub repository
			--------------------------------------------
			VITE_BACKEND_URL = http://localhost:3007		
			--------------------------------------------
		- NOTE: 
			- In Vite, environment variables need to start with "VITE_"
			- And note, this is not the backend but the frontend. *"Since any variables exposed to your Vite source code will end up in your client bundle, VITE_* variables should not contain any sensitive information."* 
			- see: [vitejs.dev/guide/env-and-mode.html#env-files](https://vitejs.dev/guide/env-and-mode.html#env-files)
		- use environment variables in App.jsx
			------------------------------------
			const backend_url = import.meta.env.VITE_BACKEND_URL;

			const url = `${backend_url}/all`;
			------------------------------------
	- public site at Netlify
		- push code changes to GitHub
			- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/howto-ejt-frontend-dern002
		- login to [https://app.netlify.com](Netlify)
		- publish site
			- [Add new site]
			- [Import and existing project]
			- [GitHub]
			- search for e.g. "dern"
			- choose site, e.g. "howto-ejt-frontend-dern002"
			- leave all defaults and click [Deploy site]:##netfldefaulask
			- [Site settings]
			- [Change site name]
			- enter e.g. `howto-ejt-frontend-dern002`
			- click on live URL
			- notice it is just loading, since it doesn't have the backend URL:##nowonlyloadinj
		- add environment variable at Netlify to tell it where to find the Heroku backend
			- [Deploy settings]
			- [Environment]
			- [Edit variables]
				- Key: `VITE_BACKEND_URL`
				- Value: `https://howto-ejt-backend-dern002.herokuapp.com`##andnowatnetlvar
			- problem: the site still can't access the environment variable:##badonlinvie
				- solution: we need to redeploy the site so that it reads in the environment variables again:##triggerdeployde
			- after we redeploy, the site works accessing the backend:##worksandright

title: Understand the history and background of SQL and NoSQL databases
body:
- Today we have generally two kinds of databases, **SQL** and **NoSQL**, both being very much used in modern projects
	- SQL is older (1970s - today)
	- NoSQL is newer (2005 - today)
	- SQL is a solid, robust solution for saving data and allowing it to be easily queried, but around 2005 it became clear that it wasn't the best solution to handle **big data** and **distributed databases**
		- SQL is rigidly structured and centralized, saving data in rigid tables with **columns** and **rows** inside a database
		- NoSQL is more flexible, e.g. MongoDB saves loosely-structured blocks of JSON (called **documents**) in **collections** inside a database
		- **NoSQL** can save more complex data in a **collection** than **SQL** can save in a **table**##nownijsinjtable
	- today both SQL and NoSQL are well-established, both having many use-case scenarios
		- NoSQL is often used 
			- for big data 
			- for distributed data solutions
			- in scenarios where data is less structured, i.e. where each item doesn't necessary have the same fields or kinds of data
		- SQL is used in many classic scenarios
			- the LA**M**P stack uses (Linux, Apache, **MySQL**, PHP)
			- the .NET stack most commonly uses **SQL Server**
			- many content management platforms use **MySQL**, e.g. **Wordpress**
			- many projects and tutorials have **Postgresql** as their default database
				- Ben Awad: [Fullstack React GraphQL TypeScript Tutorial](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I6ypD7qv3Z8)
			- embedded IoT (Internet-of-Things) projects often use **SQLite** as a low-memory, file-based database
				- [Setting up SQLite lightweight database on Raspberry Pi](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OFi4qsoy0CM)
			- while Cloud platforms like AWS and Azure offer a range of NoSQL data services
				- **AWS** offers **RDS and Aurora** as SQL database services 
				- **Azure** offers a service that it simply calles **SQL Database**, basically a Microsoft SQL Server in the cloud
	- there are typically about [3-4 times more SQL jobs](https://www.stepstone.de/5/job-search-simple.html?what=mysql&where=berlin&radius=30) than NoSQL jobs, and many jobs require knowledge and skills in both##thesqlnosqls
	- therefore modern developers should have experience with both SQL and NoSQL databases
- a quick look at the difference between MongoDB and SQL query languages
	- [MongoDB Query Documents with SQL comparison](https://www.mongodb.com/docs/manual/tutorial/query-documents)
	- an example of sending queries to a SQLite database in DB Browser application:#gif#thesqlitetestshow
- a historical timeline of NoSQL and SQL databases
	- **SQL** 
		- a query language used in RDBMS (Relational Database Management Systems) aka "relational databases"
		- 1970s created as query language used in various database implementations
			- various syntaxes
		- 1979 **Oracle**
		- 1986/1989 first standards
		- 1989 Microsoft **SQL Server**
		- **1992 major standard: [SQL-92]**
			- SQL-92 became the basic standard of SQL: https://learnsql.com/blog/history-of-sql-standards
			- today the basic commands of SQL are the same for the most popular SQL database
				- SQL Server: `SELECT * FROM Employees WHERE age > 55 ORDER BY LastName`
				- MySQL: `SELECT * FROM Employees WHERE age > 55 ORDER BY LastName`
			- but SQL in applications is usually written for a specific database and can rarely be copy and pasted to be used in other SQL databases with out modificiation
				- SQL Server: `SELECT TOP 10 * FROM Employees`
				- MySQL: `SELECT * FROM Employees LIMIT 10`
		- 1995 **MySQL**	
			- when Oracle aquired MySQL in 2009, a fork of MySQL called **MariaDB** was created 
			- today these two databases are basically the same:
				- MySQL is owned and supported by Oracle
				- MariaDB is developed by the community and managed by the MariaDB Foundation
			- if you have skills in MySQL then you have skills in MariaDB, and visa versa
		- 1996 **PostgreSQL**
			- how to [pronounce PostgreSQL](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PG_0BBmVDok)
				- **[POST-gress]** (most common)
				- [post-GRESS-kyew-ell]
				- [post-gress-SEE-kwell]
		- 2000 **SQLite**
			- file-based
			- no installation
			- simplistic but SQL-92 compatible
		- problems with SQL
			- 1. you have to **map** the **objects** in your code to the rigid **relatonal** tables in your SQL databases, hence ORMs (**Object Relational Mapping**)
				- **Sequelize** for MySQL/MariaDB, Postgres, SQLite but also SQL Server
				- **Hibernate** for Oracle (Java projects)
				- **Entity Framework** and **NHibernate** for SQL Server (.NET projects)
			- 2. can't easily represent rich documents (e.g. curriculum.json)
			- 3. doesn't scale well with distributed systems (e.g. big data)
	- **NoSQL** 
		- solved all three of the problems of SQL 
		- 2003 **memcached**
			- provides a very large hash table distributed across multiple machines
		- 2005 Google's **Big Table**
			- wide-column and key-value NoSQL database service 
			- wide-column: has tables, rows, and columns like RDBMS but columns can vary, e.g. with "column families"
		- 2005 **CouchDB**
			- saves JSON documents, similar to MongoDB
		- 2007 **MongoDB**
			- CouchDB is good for pre-defined queries where MongoDB is better for dynamic queries
		- 2007 **Neo4J**
			- graph database: to map the hierarchical and complex relationships of the data structures with fast data analytics
		- 2008 Apache **HBase**
			- modeled after Google's Big Table
		- 2008 Facebook's **Cassandra**
			- Amazon's answer to Google's Big Table
			- designed to handle large amounts of data distributed across many servers
			- provides high availability with no single point of failure
		- 2009 **Redis** - most popular key-value database
		- 2010 **Elasticsearch** - full-text search engine based on JSON documents
		- 2012 **DynamoDB** - Amazon's NoSQL cloud database service that supports key-value and document data structures

title: How to install DB Browser for SQLite on Windows and Ubuntu and retrieve/change data in an SQLite database
body:

	- install

		- download test SQLite database file here: [edwardtanguay.netlify.app/share](https://edwardtanguay.netlify.app/share)

		- in the DB Browser application, click on [Open Database], go to your `test-sqlite` directory and click on the file named `northwind_database.sqlite`
		- it should look like this:##shouldlooklikei
- **learn basic SQL CRUD commands**
	- **Read** data
		- click on the [Execute SQL] table and type: `SELECT * FROM Employees` then press F5 to execute:##thefirsssql
		- then try these self-explanatory commands and see what they do:
			---------------------------------------------
			SELECT * FROM Employees WHERE BirthDate > '1960-01-01'
			SELECT * FROM Employees WHERE BirthDate > '1960-01-01' ORDER BY BirthDate
			SELECT * FROM Employees WHERE BirthDate > '1960-01-01' ORDER BY BirthDate DESC
			SELECT FirstName, LastName, BirthDate FROM Employees WHERE BirthDate > '1960-01-01' ORDER BY BirthDate DESC
			---------------------------------------------
	- **Create** a table
		- execute CREATE TABLE command with an autoincrementing ID, title and body 
			----------------------------------------------
			CREATE TABLE "Notes" (
				"id"	INTEGER NOT NULL,
				"title"	TEXT,
				"body"	TEXT,
				PRIMARY KEY("id" AUTOINCREMENT)
			)			
			----------------------------------------------
	- **Insert** records
		- insert a note
			-------------------------------------------------------------
			INSERT INTO Notes (title,body) VALUES ("First Note", "This is the first note.")
			-------------------------------------------------------------
		- list out all notes
			---------------------------------------------
			SELECT * FROM Notes
			---------------------------------------------		
		- insert another note
			-------------------------------------------------------------
			INSERT INTO Notes (title,body) VALUES ("Second Note", "This is the second note.")
			-------------------------------------------------------------
		- list out all notes
			---------------------------------------------
			SELECT * FROM Notes
			---------------------------------------------
	- **Delete** a record
		- delete the first note
			----------------------------------------------
			DELETE FROM Notes WHERE id = 1
			----------------------------------------------
		- show that only the second note remains
			---------------------------------------
			SELECT * FROM Notes
			---------------------------------------
	- **Update** a record
		- update the second note
			-----------------------------------------
			UPDATE Notes SET title = 'Changed Second Note' WHERE id = 2
			-----------------------------------------
		- show that the second note's title has changed
			---------------------------------------
			SELECT * FROM Notes
			---------------------------------------
- **learn advanced JOIN commands**
	- tables in SQL tables are typically related by the primary and foreign keys
	- the Northwind database is a good example of tables related by primary and foreign keys:##theforprimkeys
	- query data with these relationships using JOIN:
		-----------------------------------------------------------------
		SELECT * FROM Employees
		SELECT * FROM EmployeeTerritories
		SELECT * FROM Employees AS e JOIN EmployeeTerritories AS et ON e.EmployeeID = et.EmployeeID
		SELECT e.EmployeeID, e.LastName, e.FirstName, et.TerritoryID FROM Employees AS e JOIN EmployeeTerritories AS et ON e.EmployeeID = et.EmployeeID
		-----------------------------------------------------------------
	- now join the Terroritories table
		-----------------------------------------------------
		SELECT e.EmployeeID, e.LastName, e.FirstName, et.TerritoryID,t.TerritoryDescription FROM Employees AS e 
		JOIN EmployeeTerritories AS et ON e.EmployeeID = et.EmployeeID
		JOIN Territories AS t ON et.TerritoryID = t.TerritoryID
		-----------------------------------------------------
	- now only get the information for one employee
		---------------------------------------------
		SELECT e.EmployeeID, e.LastName, e.FirstName, et.TerritoryID,t.TerritoryDescription FROM Employees AS e 
		JOIN EmployeeTerritories AS et ON e.EmployeeID = et.EmployeeID
		JOIN Territories AS t ON et.TerritoryID = t.TerritoryID
		WHERE e.EmployeeID = 1
		---------------------------------------------
	- the final query will show the join data from three tables:##thejoindone

MongoDB overview and orientation within the larger database landscape
body:
- landscape of modern databases, management tools and ORMs
	- some databases are not listed, e.g. Oracle (SQL), CloudDB (NoSQL), and other NoSQL databases
	- there are many other ORMs, but those listed are the most popular:##serverLandscapeOrm
- MongoDB tools we will be using
	- 1. **MongoDB 6.0** - database server
	- 2. **MongoDB Compass** - GUI administration tool
	- 3. **NoSQLBooster** - GUI administration tool with some extra features
	- 4. **mongosh** - interactive shell to manipulate MongoDB database
	- 5. **mongoimport** - command-line tool to import JSON files into MongoDB collections
	- 6. **MongoClient** - the native Node driver for connections to MongoDB
	- 7. **Mongoose** - JavaScript/TypeScript ODM for more sophisticated access to MongoDB in Node/Express APIs, etc.
	- 8. **Mongo Atlas** - free, managed MongoDB database in the cloud, access via connection string and password from your applications, local or online
- MongoClient vs Mongoose
	- **MongoClient** 
		- use
			- `npm i mongodb`
			- `import { MongoClient } from 'mongodb';`
		- is used for simple data access to a MongoDB from code, but any larger application will use Mongoose or some other ORM/ODM such as Prisma	
	- **Mongoose**
		- use
			- `npm i mongoose`
			- `import mongoose from 'mongoose';`
		- schema
			- defines the structure of collection documents
			- a different file for each schema
		- model
			- a model is a schema in a form that you can use
				- class -> object
				- schema -> model
		- validation
		- middleware
			- pre- and post-define events that happen when saving
		- all Mongo commands are available in Mongoose
- MongoDB Atlas vs. self-managed MongoDB
	- **MongoDB Atlas** 
		- is a unique offer to not only have a cloud-based, managed database via connection string but with a generous free tier ([512MB/month](https://www.mongodb.com/mongodb-on-aws/pricing))  
		- compare to e.g. 
			- [Fly.io](https://fly.io/docs/about/pricing/#free-allowances) offers Postgres which is not a managed database service, and MySQL and beta SQLite, but it is not as straight-forward as MongoDB Atlas
			- managed SQL and NoSQL databases at AWS and Azure can be quite expensive even for the beginning pricing packages
				- AWS and Azure have a 12-month free-period on some services but after that you pay the full price
	- **self-managed MongoDB**
		- you can install MongoDB locally on your machine for free
		- you can also install MongoDB on a e.g. Hetzner or Digital Ocean machine and use it for free

body:
- background
	- the goal of this howto is to 
		- get a free MongoDB Atlas account
		- understand the basic terminology and online interface
		- connect to online MongoDB database via mongosh, mongoimport, Compass and NoSQLBooster so that you can manager your online databases and collections locally
		- copy collections from your offline to online databases and visa versa
		- connect your offline apps to online databases
	- a MongoDB Atlas account enables you to
		- create and use MongoDB databases that exist online
		- you can access them from local apps
		- you can access them from online apps, e.g. at Heroku
	- MongoDB Atlas has general free tier
		- no need to give credit card information (as with e.g. at AWS or Azure)
		- unlimited features that don't expire (as with e.g. NoSQLBooster)
		- you have anough features to use it as a main database solution for online apps
			- e.g. essential part of a free-to-run online MERN app:
				- Frontend: Netlify
				- Backend: Heroku
				- Database: MongoDB Atlas
- go to: https://www.mongodb.com
	- register with Google or GitHub
	- when you are registered and signed in, you should see something like this:##atlastthefirst
- note on terminology##thesixtermskdj
	- 1. account > 2. project > 3. cluster > **4. databases** > **5. collections** > **6. databases**
	- 1. account
		- you have one account at MongoDB Atlas
	- 2. project
		- for now you need only **one project** e.g. "mernprojects"
	- 3. cluster
		- for now you need only **one cluster** e.g. "Cluster0"
		- cluster vs. database
			- a MontoDB Atlas cluster is like your local MongoDB server, or like your local MySQL server
				- each cluster has databases (like SQL databases)
				- each database has collections (like SQL tables)
				- each collection has documents (like SQL records)		
	- **4. databases**
		- your cluster (server) has databases
		- but to get to your databases, you have to click on [Browse Collections]##tothecollll
	- **5. collections** and **6. documents**
		- after you click on [Browser Collections] you come to the most useful dashboard of MongoDB Atlas
		- here you have your main Cluster (server) where you can create databases, which have ##mostussatlas
- create databases and collections
	- click [Create Database]
	- give name and collection name
	- typically you will want to name your database the name of your **app**, e.g. `app-bookstore-001`##savethbookkk
	- the MongoDB Atlas interface is useful enough to manage your collections and documents directory online##andinserstisj
- enable access from local shell, applications (like Compass or NoSQLBooster) and your online apps
	- **Network Access** and **Database Access**:##dataneenet
	- **Network Access**
		- Add IP Address
		- Allow access from anywhere
			- `0.0.0.0/0`
			- this is quite secure since login/password is also needed
		- Confirm
			- notice "Pending..." message
				- changes to your MongoDB Atlas cluster can take 2-5 minutes to take effect##networkaccessokok
	- **Database Access**
		- [Add New Database User]
		- Password
		- *appuser*
			- this is not a person's account but your app's account
			- your app (e.g. at Heroku) will connect to your database using this account
			- therefore create an meaningful name for this user is e.g. **app001user** or **app-bookstore-001-user**
		- create a password yourself
			- best for test apps is to have an easy-to-remember-but-secure password since you find yourself often typing it into e.g. mongosh, etc.
			- save it in a password app such as [KeePass](https://keepass.info)
				- copy it from there when you need it with the "copy for 10 seconds" feature
			- note you won't be able to find out your password again, you can only reset it
			- later to further secure online apps, replace with autogenerated password
		- choose: **Read and write to any database**
			- however, if you have an app that really only needs to read data, then **Only read any database**
		- click *Add User*
			- note message: "We are deploying your changes (current action: configuring MongoDB)"
				- can take 2-5 minutes to take effect
- to get connection strings in order to connect from e.g. **mongosh**, **Compass**, **NoSQLBooster**, or a **Heroku app**
	- click **Database > Connect**##thedatabaseconnn
- access with **mongosh**
	- [Connect with the MongoDB Shell]
	- copy connection string
	- in shell, paste it in changing the information appropriately:
		- `mongosh "mongodb+srv://cluster0.ogshn.mongodb.net/api001" --apiVersion 1 --username app001user`##loginowksdoright
	- `show dbs`
	- `use api001`
	- `show collections`
	- `db.articles.find()`
	- `db.extraarticles.insertOne({title: "The New Article"})`
	- goto MongoDB Atlas online and check to see that what you just added exists there:##itdoesijidjde
- upload data with **mongoimport**
	- create file to import called `articles.json`
		----------------------------------
		[
			{
				"title": "Third Article"
			},
			{
				"title": "Fourth Article"
			}
		]
		----------------------------------
	- database > cluster0 > primary##gotheconnecinin
		- copy the cluster name
	- create mongoimport command:
		- mongoimport --host **cluster0-shard-00-01.ogshn.mongodb.net:27017**  --db **api001** --collection **articles** --type json --file **articles.json** --jsonArray --authenticationDatabase admin --ssl --username **app001user**
		- `mongoimport --host cluster0-shard-00-01.ogshn.mongodb.net:27017  --db api001 --collection articles --type json --file articles.json --jsonArray --authenticationDatabase admin --ssl --username app001user`##theartikjgtotgo
	- see that they were added to the online database, click **REFRESH**:##wasimportedokok
- access with **MongoDB Compass**
	- click: Database > Connect
	- Connect Using MongoDB Compass
	- copy and modify connection string, e.g.
		`mongodb+srv://app001user:<password>@cluster0.ogshn.mongodb.net`
	- start Compass
	- paste in above text with `<password>` text as is
	- click: **Authentication** > **Username/Password**:
		- username: `app001user`
		- password: (type in your password here)
	- you should have access to your online databases and collections##gotthearticlees
- access with **NoSQLBooster**
	- click: Database > Connect
	- copy and modify connection string, e.g.
		- `mongodb+srv://app001user:<password>@cluster0.ogshn.mongodb.net`
		- note: leave in the actual text `<password>`
	- start NoSQLBooster
		- Connect > Create:##goandconnectj
		- click **[From URI]** button:##clickfromuriok
		- paste connection string and click **[OK]**:##pasteandconnectionstring
		- click on **Authentication**, type password, and click on **Save & Connect**##andtheauuuth
		- you may now use your online database and collections as if they were local##andshowthetwo
- **copy collections** from local to online databases, or visa versa
	- export the collection you want to transfer
		- use Compass
		- go to e.g. local collection
		- click on [Export Collection]##cliskexpo
		- [x] Export Full Collection
		- [SELECT FIELDS]
		- [SELECT OUTPUT]
		- [JSON]
		- [BROWSE]
		- [EXPORT]##transferbooksdkj
	- import the exported collection you want to transfer
		- use Compass
		- go to e.g. online database in which you want to transfer the collection
		- create new collection, give it e.g. the same name as the original collection
		- in the menu, click **Collection > Import Data**
		- Select File > JSON > [IMPORT]
- **use online database collections from local apps**
	- e.g. an API running locally
	- make an environment variable for the connection string:
		----------------------------
		mongoose.connect('mongodb://localhost/bookapi');
		----------------------------
	- put the MongoDB Atlas connection string (with clear-text password) into your .env file as e.g.
		------------------------------
		MONGO_CONNECTION = mongodb+srv://app001user:thisisthepassword@cluster0.ogshn.mongodb.net/bookapi
		------------------------------
	- make sure you have `.env` listed in your `.gitignore` file so that your MongoDB password does not get checked into your online repository
	- note: in application development, you normally have your localhost connection locally:
		------------------------------
		MONGO_CONNECTION = mongodb://localhost/bookapi
		------------------------------
		- so that your MongoDB connection is not saved in clear-text anywhere
		- then on your Heroku app, you create an environment variabled called `MONGO_CONNECTION` and paste in your mongo connection string there where it is protected

Set up API that demonstrates how Sessions/Cookies work with Node/Express
body:
- **Background to state management for web applications**
	- the reason why you want to maintain state is mainly for **authentication**
		- a web application server (e.g. a Node/Express API) needs to know who is logged in, in order to provide the proper resources, give the proper access, etc.
		- the problem is that the web (HTTP) is stateless
		- therefore after the use provides correct credentials, the server needs a way for each subsequent request to the server to remember who they are and that they were logged in and that their session has not yet expired
	- there are basically two solutions to maintaining state in web applications: JWT and Sessions/Cookies
		- **JWT**
			- the **newer** more modern solution
				- created **2015**
			- how it works
				- 1. server generates **token**, sends token to browser
				- 2. browser receives token, and saves it client side
				- 3. the accessToken is included upon every subsequent request to the server
			- JWT is **stateless**
				- is not limited to one server, i.e. supports single-sign-on much easier
					- for this reason, in most larger applications the preferred solution
				- you have the manage the token on the frontend
					- save it somewhere (local storage, cookies)
		- **Sessions/Cookies**
			- the **older** solution
				- created **1995**
			- how it works
				- 1. server generates **sessionId**, signs it with secret key, sends browser cookie with sessionId
				- 2. browser receives cookie and saves it in cookie storage
				- 3. browser includes the cookie on every request
			- sessions are **stateful**
				- since the session is managed by and dependent on the server, it is more difficult to support single-sign-on, e.g. to allow the user to log into other servers after logging in on one server
				- you don't have to manage the token on the frontend
					- hence easier to test with API tools such as Postman or REST Client
- **What we will build**
	- the simplest API that demonstrates how session/cookies work in order to maintain state in a Node/Express application
	- we will not build a frontend, only an API
		- with session/cookies, you can test the functionality with an API tool such as Postman or REST Client
	- we will publish and test this app at Heroku to show the session/cookies work from an online server as well
		- to do this, we will fix two common errors using the Heroku CLI and logging command
- **How we will build it**
	- in order to focus on understanding how sessions and cookies work, we will simply the app as following
		- login name via URL
		- no passwords
	- to demonstrate how session time limits work, we will limit the session to 10 seconds
		- this means after logging in, the user will be automatically logged out in 10 seconds
- **What we will use**
	- Node/Express
	- NPM packages
		- express-session
		- cookie-parser
		- dotenv (to save session secret in .env file)
- you can get the full code for this project here:
	- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et01-node-sessions-basic
- the finished project will work something like this: #gif#gitforsesscookietest
- **set up basic Node/Express site:**
	- create directory, e.g. `et01-node-sessions-basic`
	- `code `et01-node-sessions-basic`
	- `npm init -y`
	- package.json: 
		- `"type": "module",`
	- `npm i express`
	- server.js
		------------------------------------------
		import express from 'express';

		const app = express();
		const PORT = 3024;

		app.listen(PORT, () => {
			console.log(`listening at http://localhost:${PORT}`)
		});		
		------------------------------------------
	- `node server.js`
	- the server should be listening:##thelistenijksj
- **set up nodemon with npm start**
	- `npm i nodemon -D`
	- package.json
		-----------------------------------
	    "start": "nodemon server.js"
		-----------------------------------
	- start now with `npm start`
- **create base route**
	- server.js
		----------------------------------
		app.get('/', (req, res) => {
			res.send('session/cookie basic test');
		});		
		----------------------------------
	- click on link in terminal to go to http://localhost:3024
	- you should see the text:##seetextokexpress
- **set up REST Client file for easier testing**
	- make sure you have the VSCode Extension "REST Client" installed
	- test.rest

		### base route
		{{url}}

- **set up Git and publish to GitHub (manual Git command line version)**
	- `git init -b main`

		---------------------------
		node_modules
		---------------------------
	- `git add .`
	- `git commit -m "initial commit"`
	- create repository on GitHub:##thercreaterep
	- push the directory
		- `git remote add origin git@github.com:edwardtanguay/et01-node-sessions-basic.git`
		- `git push -u origin main`
	- add a file and push
		- README.md
			----------------------------------
			# Session/Cookies test
			----------------------------------
		- `git add .`
		- `git commit -m "added README"`
		- `git push origin`
- **set up users and login route**
	- add mock user database
		------------------------------
		const users = [
			{
				username: 'ja',
				firstName: 'Jörg',
				lastName: 'Ackermann',
				email: 'ja@mail.com'
			},
			{
				username: 'ac',
				firstName: 'Angelika',
				lastName: 'Carstense',
				email: 'ac@mail.com'
			}
		];	
		------------------------------
	- create login route
		-----------------------------------------
		app.get('/login/:username', (req, res) => {
			const user = users.find((user) => user.username === req.params.username);
			if (user) {
				res.send(`User identified: ${JSON.stringify(user)}`);
			} else {
				res.status(500).send('bad login');
			}
		});		
		-----------------------------------------
	- add tests
		----------------------------------------

		GET {{url}}/login/ja

		### LOGIN ANGELIKA
		GET {{url}}/login/ac

		### BAD LOGIN
		GET {{url}}/login/nnn

		----------------------------------------
- **add current-user route and show it won't work without sessions/cookies**
	- add current-user route
		------------------------------------
		app.get('/current-user', (req, res) => {
			res.send('no user logged in');
		});
		------------------------------------
	- add test
		-----------------------------------
		### GET LOGGED IN USER

		-----------------------------------
- **add sessions/cookies in order to maintain user logins**
	- `npm i express-session`
	- `npm i cookie-parser`
	- import these in server.js
		---------------------------------------
		import session from 'express-session';
		import cookieParser from 'cookie-parser';		
		---------------------------------------
	- setup for sessions
		--------------------------------
		app.use(
			session({
				resave: true,
				saveUninitialized: true,
				secret: 'tempsecret'
			})
		);
		--------------------------------
	- setup for cookies
		------------------------------------
		app.use(cookieParser());		
		------------------------------------
	- modify login route to save user session for 10 seconds
		-------------------------------------
		req.session.user = user;
		req.session.cookie.expires = new Date(Date.now() + 10000); // 10 seconds
		req.session.save();
		res.send(`User logged in: ${JSON.stringify(user)}`);
		-------------------------------------
	- modify current-user route to check for saved user
		-----------------------------------
		app.get('/current-user', (req, res) => {
			if (req.session.user) {
				res.send(req.session.user);
			} else {
				res.send('no user logged in');
			}
		});
		-----------------------------------
	- test again and see that the logged-in user stays logged in for 10 seconds
	- create logout route
		-----------------------------
		app.get('/logout', (req, res) => {
			req.session.destroy((err) => {
				res.send('User logged out');
			});
		});
		-----------------------------
	- create test for logout

		-------------------------------
	- test again
- **create real session secret and hide it in .env file**
	- `npm i dotenv`

		-------------------------------------------

	- you will get an error:##heraerrero
	- debug the error
		- `heroku login`
			- click login button in browser
		- `heroku logs -a et01-node-sessions-basic --tail`##thenodmoskjdf
		- the **npm start** command starts nodemon but it should start Node, since your app at Heroku should run on Node
	- fix error

			---------------------------------
			"scripts": {
				"dev": "nodemon server.js",

- **What we will build** - this will be a simple Node app (server.js) which when executed, sends a mail to an email address - we can send unlimited e-mails with this solution - this is a good solution if you are building e.g. a registration page where the use needs to receive an email to confirm their email address - when we send a test mail, it will look something like this:##sendthemailkk - the email arrives immediately in the target mailbox and looks like this:##maillooksksklooks - **How we will build it** - we will use the free service **nodemailer** to send mail - we will send the mail via a **Gmail account that we set up** and secure with 2-factor authentication - we will use **dotenv** to hide the password in an .env file - **What we will use** - Node - nodemailer - dotenv - Gmail account - **Where to find the code** - GitHub repository of full code is here: https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et01-nodemailer-test - **1. Set up a Debian machine at Hetzner
body:
- **What we will do**
	- we will set up a Debian machine at Hetzner e.g. in order to run frontends and backends at a domain name
	- the machine will cost **3.92€ per month**
	- you pay by the hour, so **you can set one up for practice**, delete it and pay only e.g. 12 cents for 2 hours
- **set up machine**
	- log into your Hetzner account: https://accounts.hetzner.com/login
	- click on the [New Project] button##thenewprojsadclick
	- you may have to verify your account, e.g.##youmaypass	
	- call your project e.g. **main**##goveaname
	- click on button##theserversdod
	- choose Nürnberg, Debian, Standard, and CX11
		- this is the least expensive machine, you can upgrade later at any time
	- leave all other settings as default, e.g. we can set up a firewall later
	- however, do **set up an SSH-Key** which is secure practice and in Hetzner's case, setting up a SSH-key will ensure that you do not receive a root password via e-mail
		- make directory for local login, e.g. in `c:/hetzner`
			- in that directory, type the command e.g. `ssh-keygen -f windowskey001 -t ecdsa` (`windowskey001` should identify your local machine)
			- for passphrase, type a simple, easy-to-remember pin such as `1988`
				- the SSH will allow you to automatically log in from your local computer
				- your account is still protected by password
				- the pin is just for the unlikely case someone gets access to your local computer, they still wouldn't know the pin
				- the root login to your Hetzner machine is by default not allowed to be accessed via remote login, only from the Hetzner website console
				- so this is a quite secure setup for your cloud machine
			- this will create two files on your machine##thewtwofiles
			- open `windowskey001.pub` and copy contents
			- back at the Hetzner website, click the area to creaet a SSH-key##clickthssssheehj
			- paste the contents of into the box, change the name to windowskey001, and click as standard (for when you create other machines), and click the button##thesshkeyinto
	- rename the machine to e.g. **debian-001**
	- click "Kostenpflichtig erstellen"
- **log in as root**
	- because we set up an SSH-key during creation of our machine, Hetzner didn't send us a root password via e-mail, which one should avoid
	- to get the root password now so we can log in as root to create our first user, we need to reset the password in order to see what it is
	- click on machine
	- [RESCUE]
	- click the [ROOT-PASSWORT ZURÜCKSETZEN] buton##doclickthereset
	- copy and save the root password in e.g. your keepass
	- note that from your local terminal, you can try to log in as root, but **as a security measure**, it won't let you:##permssspleasetry
	- you can only log in as host via the Hetzner console##theckonsole
	- with the generated password that you saved earlier, you can log in as root##andnowloggggg
- **create main user**
	- you normally don't want or need to login as root user on Linux
		- we need to do it now in order to create our first user which will have sudo rights
		- having sudo rights means the user can temporarily have root rights
	- so we will now create a main user which you will use to regularly access and manage your machine
	- as root, create a main user (e.g. your name) like this:
		- `useradd -m edward` 
			- (`-m` creates a home directory)
		- `passwd edward`
		- `usermod -aG sudo edward` 
			- (`-aG sudo` adds user to the group which can execute sudo commands)
	- exit as root with `exit`
	- test to see in the console if you can log in and out as your main user
		- remember, to log out, type `exit`
- **on local machine log in via SSH **
	- now from terminal on your local machine, log in via SSH as the user you just created
	- note you can already log in via password, e.g. `ssh edward@195.201.25.54`
		- (get the IP address of your machine from the Hetzner page that lists your machines)##notetologinok22
	- but we want to make it easier to log in via ssh
	- so set up SSH for that user: `ssh-copy-id -i windowskey001 edward@195.201.25.54`	
	- you can now log in with command: `ssh -i windowskey001 edward@195.201.25.54`:
	- make file called e.g. `d1` (short for debian-001) with one line: `ssh -i windowskey001 edward@195.201.25.54`
	- now to log in with SSH:
		- go to `hetzner` directory in terminal 
		- `./d1`
		- enter passphrase
	- note if your local machine is Linux, then
		- in your home directory, create `.bash_aliases` with this line:
			-----------------------------------------
			alias d1='ssh -i ubuntukey001 edward@195.201.25.54'
			-----------------------------------------
		- then: `source ~/.bash_aliases`
		- now to log into your Hetzner machine, simply type: `d1`

title: Set up an Arch Linux machine at Hetzner
body:
- **What we will do**
	- the end goal of this howto is to set up a machine on Hetzner that runs **Arch Linux**
	- the machine will cost **3.92€ per month** with minimum features
		- you can scale up at any time, e.g. add CPUs or GigiBytes to your SSD or RAM
	- you pay by the hour, so **you can set this machines up to practice**, then shut it back off and pay e.g. 12 cents for the 2 hours of having it on
	- note that Arch Linux isn't an official choice at Heztner 
		- but there is a way you can install it by choosing e.g. Ubuntu first, then going through a rescue process and reinstalling the machine as Arch Linux
		- the only disadvantage I have seen from this is that for some reason the "rescued machine" does not have a "guest agent" installed and therefore cannot reset the root password if you need to
		- just be sure to save the root password that is provided to you when you start the rescue process
			- and of course create a sudo user so you don't have to log in as root anymore
- **How we will do it**
	- so we will first set up an **Ubuntu machine**
	- then "rescue" it and in so doing reinstall it as an Arch Linux machine
- **set up Ubuntu machine**
	- log into your Hetzner account: https://accounts.hetzner.com/login
	- click [New Project]##donewpro
	- if your account is new, you may have to verify it, e.g.##youmaypass	
	- call your project e.g. **main**##goveaname
	- NOTE: if you already have machines, go to your projects page and click on a project where you want your machine: https://console.hetzner.cloud/projects
	- click on [Add Server] button##theserversdod
	- choose e.g. **Nürnberg, Ubuntu, Standard, and CX11**
	- leave all other settings (Volume, Networking, etc.) as default, we can set up a firewall later
	- also leave the SSH-key empty for now
		- we can set that up after the machine is running if we like
	- rename the machine to e.g. **archlinux-007**
	- click "Kostenpflichtig erstellen"
- **convert Ubuntu machine to Arch Linux**
	- click on the Ubuntu machine you just created
	- [RESCUE]
	- [RESCUE AKTIVIEREN & RESET]##therescuses
	- choose **linux64**, select your SSH key, and click [RESCUE AKTIVIEREN & RESET] button##thenossh64
	- **IMPORTANT:** copy and save root password that is provided to you, e.g. into your keepass
		- you will not be able to retrieve or change this root password again##thepasswordsaveiii
	- enter Hetzner's web console:##clickthecononon
		- log in as root and the root password that you just saved
	- type `installimage`##therootress
	- choose Arch Linux:##thechoosesarch222
	- choose default image##choosethedddefa
	- click **[OK]** again##okagainss
	- in the blue editor, change hostname to e.g. **archlinux-007**##thehostokok222
	- remove **UEFI##** on this line:##thrremoveuuu
	- press F2 and Enter to save, then F10 to exit
	- confirm with **Yes**##andtheconfiirm222
	- wait while the machine is built:##andthbussymahc
	- after approximately 5 minutes it will finish:##andnowfinsihs
	- type `reboot`
- **connect to Arch Linux machine**
	- after the machine reboots, it will show a login, type `root`
	- and for the password, paste in the password you saved above in e.g. KeePass
	- you will be logged in as root on your new Arch machine:##loggedinonarchok
- **create a main user**
	- you usually don't want to log in as root user on Linux
		- you only need to log in as root in order to create the first main user, as we are doing now
	- so we will now create a main user which you will use to manage your machine
	- as root, you first after to update the system package manager and set up rights for the sudo group (wheel)
		- `pacman -Syu` (updates system)
		- `pacman -S nano sudo` (installed the nano editor and sudo functionality)
		- `EDITOR=nano visudo`
			- scroll to bottom of file
			- remove this `#` symbol and the space after it##theremovethepoind
			- file should look like this##andthefileschand
			- save and exit like this: **CTRL-O**, **[ENTER]**, **CTRL-X**
	- create user
		- `useradd -m -G wheel edward` (`-m` creates a home directory, `-G wheel` adds user to sudo group)
		- `passwd edward`
	- exit as root with `exit`
- **log into your Arch Linux machine from your local machine**
	- it is more convenient to log into your account from a termin on your machine
		- your local keyboard layout will work, and you can copy and paste more easily
	- open a local terminal
	- `ssh edward@YOUR-MACHINES-IP-ADDRESS`##withipeinlog

title: How to set up a HTML/CSS website with a HTTPS domain on a Debian machine at Hetzner with nginx and certbot
body:
- **What we will set up** - at the end of this howto, you will have - a Debian machine in the cloud at Hetzner that - hosts a HTML/CSS website at e.g. https://yourdomainname.info - the code for this site you will develop and push from your local machine - and pull from the Debian server in order to deploy it live - **How progress will look** - 1. we will start out with no website deployed on our Hetzner Debian machine - 2. using **nginx** we will deploy a test HTML website to our IP-address URL - 3. we will purchase a domain name of choice at Hetzner for circa 12€/year conveniently included in our monthly Hetzner payments - 4. we will develop a site locally, push it to GitHub, pull it from Hetzner, and use certbot to deploy it with HTTPS, then set up a firewall to allow incoming HTTPS traffic##namenowksok - **Prerequisites** - we will start with a newly created Debian server at Hetzner - if you don't have a Debian machine running at Hetzner, complete this howto first: - [Set up a Debian machine at Hetzner](https://edwardtanguay.netlify.app/howtos?id=603) - **How we will set it up** - we will first install the [nginx](https://www.nginx.com) web server to get a simple HTML site running at http://the-ip-address-of-your-machine - note that there are other web servers to install such as Apache and Caddy - nginx is the most performant - Apache has more features - Caddy is the easiest to install - we will then buy a domain name at Hetzner (e.g. yourdomainname.info) which will be circa 12€ for a year - will will configure nginx to serve your HTML site at this domain (e.g. http://yourdomainname.de) instead of at your IP address - in order to secure your connection, we will use the free service [certbot](https://certbot.eff.org) (which uses "Let's Encrypt") to convert your http connection to **https** - we will then set up a simple development flow for you to develop locally and deploy on your Debian machine - you will create a simple HTML/CSS site on your local machine, then push it to a private respository at GitHub - we will create an SSH key on your Hetzner machine and save it in your GitHub account - this will allow you to pull the contents of your GitHub repository to the directory that is being served at your domain address - as soon as you pull the code, it will be live - finally we will implement a firewall to allow incoming HTTPS traffic - **Set up Debian server at Hetzner** - follow [this howto](https://edwardtanguay.netlify.app/howtos?id=603) to get a Debian server running at Hetzner - **Get a simple HTML page running without a domain** - we will now get a site running at http://your-ip-address-of-your-machine - go to the ip address of your machine in your browser to show that it is now serving an HTML page##thenoipii - this is why we need to **install a web server**, i.e. in order to serve websites at your IP number via http - `sudo apt install nginx` - reload your browser on your IP URL and you will have a website running:##nowhavexng - now let's get our own simple HTML file running at this IP URL - create this file in your home directory `~/projects/mainsite/index.html` ------------------------------------ This is a test website. ------------------------------------ - let's first understand where the current site is coming - `sudo vim /etc/nginx/sites-available/default` - here you will get some clues where the HTML file is that we are seeing: - nginx is listening on the default port 80 - the file it is serving is in `/var/www/html` - and it has to be a file called `index.html`, `index.htm`, or `index.nginx-debian.html` etc. ##threearrirr - so let's go find the file - `cd /var/www/html` and we find##wefoundiiij - let's look in it: `sudo vim /index.nginx-debian.html` - we see that this is the file that is being served:##welcome2222j - change some text, save, and reload the browser:##thereloadandshow - now let's point our nginx server to our website at `~/projects/mainsite` - go to the nginx folder: `cd /etc/nginx` - first we are going to delete `sites-available` and `sites-enabled` because this approach is [apparently deprecated](https://www.reddit.com/r/nginx/comments/re8ksm/why_is_sitesenabled_and_sitesavailable_deprecated/) - `sudo rm -rf sites-available` - `sudo rm -rf sites-enabled` - your site will still work since these files had already been interpreted when nginx started - restart nginx `sudo systemctl restart nginx` and you will see that your site no longer works - we will now create a new config file to point to our mainsite test website that we made earlier - create file: `/etc/nginx/conf.d/mainsite.conf` --------------------------------------- server { listen 80 default_server; listen [;]:80 default_server; root /home/edward/projects/mainsite; index index.html; server_name _; } --------------------------------------- - restart the nginx server and you should see your site - `sudo systemctl restart nginx`##seesitengng - **Buy a domain name to host this site** - you can buy and manage domains with other providers (for example [domainssaubillig.de](https://www.domainssaubillig.de) where you will find slightly cheaper prices) - but ordering domains at Hetzner will enable you to pay for your hosting and domains with one monthly payment - in your Hetzner Cloud Console, click on **konsoleH**##onkonsolh - click **Neue Bestellung** - scroll down to the bottom to **Domainregistrierung** and click on **Bestellen**##canwebestlll - type in the domain and choose the extension you want, then click **Weiter**##thenameandordjd - click on **Weiter**##thebpapay - click **Zahlungspflichtig bestellen**##zahlungplf - it says everything worked:##gettheeeemal - the email:##theehtzemail1 - if you go to your domain, you will see that it has been reserved:##theserfversdomain - point your domain name to your server - go to konsoleH, Einstellungen, DNS-Verwaltung and type in the IP address of your machine under A-Records for @ and www:##thgreenaksdown - it will take up to 24 hours to be updated with your - refresh the browser page regularly until you see that same site that you see at your IP-address URL - in my case it took about **two hours** until my domain pointed to my machine's IP address:##thetsetwiwwi - **Set up workflow to develop locally and publish on Hetzner machine** - on your local machine, we will create an HTML/CSS website that we will publish at our domain hosted on our Hetzner machine - open a terminal window in your projects directory - `mkdir tkserv` (where `tkserv` is the name of your domain) - open VSCode in that directory: `code tkserv` - create these files - index.html -------------------------------------- tkserv

tkserv

This is a domain to use for various tech projects hosted at Hetzner.

-------------------------------------- - main.css -------------------------------------------- body { background-color: #333; color: #ccc; font-family: sans-serif; padding: .5rem 2rem; } p { font-size: 1.2rem; } -------------------------------------------- - set up Git workflow and push to online private Git repository and publish at Hetzner - in the directory of your website, create a local Git repository and commit your files to it - `git init -b main` - `git add .` - `git commit -m "initial commit"` - on GitHub, create an empty repository called e.g. `tkserv` - commit local files to private respository at GitHub - `git remote add origin git@github.com:edwardtanguay/tkserv.git` - `git push -u origin main` - at GitHub, refresh the page, select **SSH** and then click on the **clone icon**##tehgitshshs - on your Hetzner machine, go to your **projects** directory and delete the **mainsite** directory - `cd ~/projects` - `rm -rf mainsite` - note that your website is no longer there##nolongjtei - now (try to) clone the directory into your projects file (you will see that it's not possible since we haven't set up SSH yet) - type `git clone`, paste what you copied from the GitHub site, and add `mainsite` to it - `git clone git@github.com:edwardtanguay/tkserv.git mainsite` - if you don't have Git:##thenogit - install it with `sudo apt install git` - try to clone again: `git clone git@github.com:edwardtanguay/tkserv.git mainsite` - you see you get an error because you don't have rights to the private GitHub directory:##gotnorights - set up SSH - `ssh-keygen -t ed25519` - press ENTER for all questions##justhitener - we now need to copy the public key that was just generated and save it at GitHub - `cd ~/.ssh` - `cat id_ed25519.pub` - copy the outputted text (here in green)##copyonlythattextss - go to GitHub, click on your Icon, then **Settings** and **SSH and GPG keys** - click on **New SSH key** - give your key a name (e.g. the name of the machine where it is used) and paste the public key into the box##theaddthekey - at GitHub again, select **SSH** and then click on the **clone icon**##tehgitshshs - type `git clone`, paste what you copied from the GitHub site, and add `mainsite` to it - `git clone git@github.com:edwardtanguay/tkserv.git mainsite` - this time it can access your GitHub repository and clones your files into **mainsite** - refresh your browser and you will see that your locally developed site has been deployed live at your domain:##thedeployon - now to develop and deploy your site - make local changes - push to GitHub - log in on your Hetzner machine - go to `~/projects/mainsite` - type `git pull` - and your changes will be live - **Secure your website so that users access it via HTTPS instead of HTTP** - we will use [certbot](https://certbot.eff.org) which uses [Let's Encrypt](https://letsencrypt.org) to secure your website with HTTPS for free - update apt - `sudo apt update` - install snap - `sudo apt install snapd` - `sudo snap install core` - install certbot - `sudo snap install --classic certbot` - prepare the certbot command - `sudo ln -s /snap/bin/certbot /usr/bin/certbot` - `sudo snap set certbot trust-plugin-with-root=ok` - install and configure https in nginx - `sudo certbot --nginx` - enter your email to be notifed about security updates or expiration dates, etc. - type in name of your domain, e.g. `tkserv.eu`##deploycertifif - note the text that certbot added to your nginx config file - `cat /etc/nginx/conf.d/mainsite.conf`:##lookatcerttext - refresh your browser and see that your http site transfers automatically to https:##httpstkserver - **Set up firewall and allow HTTPS traffic** - your Hetzner machine should have a firewall so it doesn't allow all incoming traffic on all ports - let's set up a firewall and see that it blocks access to our https site - then we will allow traffic on the https port 443 - click **Firewalls** and **Firewall erstellen**##firewallanderstl - leave the suggested **22** port and click the **Firewall erstellen** button - refresh your page and notice that https is blocked##nowwithfirewallon - now go back in your firewall - change the name of the firewall to match the name of your machine - normally you'll have a separate firewall corresponding to each machine - add TCP 443 which means that incoming HTTPS traffic will be allowed - click the button to save the changes:##thetcp443 - refresh your browser to see that while your firewall blocks unwanted traffic, it allows https traffic to display your site:##httpstkserver

title: How to get a Node/Express API and a React Site running as subdomains on a Debian machine at Hetzner with pm2 and nginx
body:
- **What we will set up:** - we will start with a Debian machine at Hetzner which has an HTML/CSS site being served at an https domain: https://tkserv.eu - we will add a Node/Express API and use pm2 to serve it at https://testapi.tkserv.eu - we will add a React Site created with Vite and use pm2 to serve it at https://testreact.tkserv.eu - **the frontend React site will read data from the backend Node/Express site, both hosted at Hetzner at HTTPS subdomains:**##hetznerbackendfrontendapps - **Prerequisites:** - these instructions will be most straight-forward if you have a **Debian machine running at Hetzner** - if you have an **Ubuntu** machine at Hetzner, instructions should work as well - if you have an **Arch** machine or **Fedora/CentoOS/Rocky** machine - some of the commands will differ, particularly package management commands - you need to have a **domain name**, **https** set up, and a simple HTML site being served via **nginx** - if not then first do this howto: [How to set up a HTML/CSS website with a HTTPS domain on a Debian machine at Hetzner with nginx and certbot](https://edwardtanguay.netlify.app/howtos?id=605) - **Create a Node/Express API on your local machine** - open terminal on your local machine in your projects directory - make a directory for your API - `mkdir hetzner-debian002-testapi` - enter the directory in VSCode - `code hetzner-debian002-testapi` - open a terminal in VSCode and create a Node project - `npm init -y` - set project up for ES6 modules - **package.json** --------------------------------- "type": "module", --------------------------------- - import packages you need - `npm i express` - `npm i -D nodemon` (`-D` = dev dependency) - create a basic Node API that serves a test string on the base route - **server.js** ------------------------------------ import express from 'express'; const api = express(); const PORT = 4447; api.get('/', function (req, res) { res.send('Test API works'); }); api.listen(PORT, () => { console.log(`listening on http://localhost:${PORT}`); }); ------------------------------------ - test with: - `node server.js`##thetsetworksijok - set up scripts for dev and deployment - **package.json** -------------------------------------------------- "scripts": { "dev": "nodemon server.js", "start": "node server.js" }, -------------------------------------------------- - test both: - for local developing so app refreshes when files change - `npm run dev` - for online deployment - `npm start` - **Deploy the Node/Express site to Hetzner via GitHub** - deploying a site to Hetzner basically means - pushing it from a local repository to a GitHub repository - pulling it from the GitHub repository to the repository on your Hetzner machine - setting up a subdomain for it to run on - setting up pm2 and nginx for it to be accessible at that subdomain - create local GitHub repository - `git init -b main` (`-b main` creates a branch called `main` instead of `master`) - there are now 428 files to check in since node_modules is being included as files to check into GitHub##now444 - in order to exclude these, make a .gitignore file - **.gitignore** ------------------------------- node_modules ------------------------------- - now there are only 4 files to check in, which is correct:##nowonly4 - use VSCode to create a private repository at GitHub and push your code to it:#gif#recordpushingtogit - log into your Hetzner machine and go to your `~/projects` directory - clone the repository you just pushed to - note that you need to have set up an SSH key in order to access private respositories on your GitHub account - if you haven't set up an SSH key for your repository yet, [see this howto] (search for `keygen`)(https://edwardtanguay.netlify.app/howtos?id=605)##gettherepo2 - deploy your API at its port 4447 - if you don't have **node and npm** yet, then install them - `sudo apt update` - `sudo apt install nodejs npm` - on 2022-09-12, this gave me Node version 12 which is sufficient for our test application##gaveme12 - install the node modules with - `npm i` - start the app and view in browser - `npm start` - it says it is running on port 4447 - if you have a firewall attached to your Hetzner machine, open it now and create a rule to allow incoming traffic on port 4447##setfirewall4 - then in your browser, type e.g. `http://YOUR-DOMAIN-NAME:4447` (not https, but **http**), and you will see that it works:##the477works - **PROBLEM:** - 1. the current solution only works with http but not https - 2. you generally don't want to host applications on the Internet under port numbers but rather **subdomains** - with a subdomain, you can later change port numbers if you need to and remap it to the subdomain which stays the same for the users - a website with a port number looks less professional and is more difficult for users to type - **SOLUTION:** create a subdomain called "testapi" at your domain provider - if your domain provider is domainssaubillig.de, it looks like this - domain name [bearbeiten] - Subdomains - [Neue Subdomain anlegen] - enter name, e.g. `testapi` - testapi [bearbeiten] - then enter the IP address of your host for the subdomain:##testapiinin - it will then be listed as a subdomain:##saudomainin - if your domain provider is **Hetzner**, then - click on **konsoleH**:##onthekon - click on your Domain name - Einstellungen - DNS-Verwaltung - there is no section for subdomains, so enter the subdomain as an A-Record:##entertestapi - note that when you now go to **http://testapi.tkserv.eu**, it shows the content to the page **http://tkserv.eu** since this is the IP we gave for it##thetestapitk - in the nginx file, redirect the subdomain **testapi** to **port 4447**: - `cd /etc/nginx/conf.d` - create file e.g. **testapi.tkserv.eu** ---------------------------------------------------------- server { server_name testapi.tkserv.eu; location / { proxy_pass http://tkserv.eu:4447; } } ---------------------------------------------------------- - restart the nginx server - `sudo systemctl restart nginx` - start the Node/Express app again: - `cd ~/projects/testapi` - `npm start` - your app will now be available at **http://subdomain**:##availatsubthe - but note it is not yet available at **https://subdomain**:##notathpppt - secure your subdomain with HTTPS - if you don't have **certbot** installed, see [this howto](https://edwardtanguay.netlify.app/howtos?id=605) - `sudo certbot --nginx` - certbot will look through all files in your **/etc/nginx/conf.d** folder and list out the subdomains that are being used, choose the one you want to secure with https:##certbottkai - notes what certbot added to your nginx file:##notewhatadded - restart the nginx server - `sudo systemctl restart nginx` - start the Node/Express app again: - `cd ~/projects/testapi` - `npm start` - your Node app will now be running at your subdomain with a secure connection##thesecuapip - **PROBLEM:** if you stop your **npm start** command, or if your Node app encounters an error, then your site will no longer be available:##ifyoustoptheser - **SOLUTION:** use **pm2** to robustly serve your API app 24/7: - pm2 is a process manager which will keep your Node and React apps alive and running at their subdomains - install pm2 - `sudo npm install pm2 -g` - tell pm2 to serve your Node/Express app - navigate to your in your app folder - `~/projects/testapi` - app your app to pm2 - `pm2 start --name "testapi" npm -- start` - now note that your API is running without having to have the **npm start** command running - pm2 is managing the process in the background##pm2takingcareofit - **Make a local change in the Node/Express app and redeploy to Hetzner** - let's now make a change to our local Node/Express app and redeploy to Hetzner - we'll add a `/books` route which serves some books to display - later when we create and host our React app at Hetzner, we'll consume this API and display the books - we'll also put the port in an environment variable to show how environment variables work - make local changes and push code to GitHub - **server.js** ------------------------------------------ const books = [ { "idCode": "buildingMicroservices", "title": "Building Microservices", "description": "Seems to be a high-level abstract book how to not only implement microservices but how to get your head around the paradigm shifts involved, e.g. from request-response to event-driven patterns.", }, { "idCode": "gatsbyEcommerce", "title": "Gatsby E-Commerce", "description": "An interesting aspect of Gatsby: using it for e-commerce site which focuses on practical tips around this focus.", }, { "idCode": "rustWeb", "title": "Rust Web Programming", "description": "Looking forward to creating sites in Rust on my Debian box at Hetzner. This looks like a practical way to learn Rust in order to actually build something useful." } ]; api.get('/books', function (req, res) { res.send(books); }); ------------------------------------------ - in your browser, **/books** should now output the JSON array with three book objects##bookshouls - now let's set up an environment variable for our port and change the port to 4778 to make sure it works - `npm i dotenv` - **.env** --------------------------------- PORT = 4448 --------------------------------- - **server.js** ---------------------------------- import dotenv from 'dotenv'; dotenv.config(); const api = express(); const PORT = process.env.PORT; ---------------------------------- - the site now runs on port 4448 which comes from the .env file:##the4448 - the plan is at Hetzner to set up an .env file that has a different port, namely 4447, since we have that port open in the firewall - don't forget to add the .env to your **.gitignore** file, so that the .env file is not checked into GitHub: ----------------------------------- node_modules .env ----------------------------------- - push the changes to GitHub - deploy to Hetzner - on your Hetzner machine, go to `~/projects/testapi` - pull code from GitHub - `git pull` - restart the app with pm2 - `pm2 restart testapi`##twobutnowork - **PROBLEM:** notice in your browser, that the site does not work yet:##noticenopage - **SOLUTION:** look at the pm2 logs for this app: `pm2 logs testapi`: - we forgot to import the new node module that was added (dotenv)##cannotfinddotenv - `npm i` - `pm2 restart testapi` - **PROBLEM:** notice in your browser, that the site still does not work yet:##noticenopage - **SOLUTION:** look at the pm2 logs for this app: `pm2 logs testapi`: - we forgot to add a **.env file** here on the server:##nowtheundefined - create **.env** file with port **4447** since this is the port that we had opened for incoming traffic in the firewall --------------------------------------- PORT = 4447 --------------------------------------- - `pm2 restart testapi` - and now the book route works as well:##booksnowsiteworksh - **Create a React site on your local machine** - on your local machine, go to your projects directory - create the site - `npm create vite` - `hetzner-debian002-testreact` - **react** - **react-ts** (in general it's a good idea to program with TypeScript when you can) - open in VSCode - `code hetzner-debian002-testreact` - title: How to get a Node/Express API and a React Site running as subdomains on an Arch Linux machine at Hetzner with pm2 and Caddy
body:
- **What we will set up:** - we will start with a Arch Linux machine at Hetzner - if you don't yet have one set up, you can follow [this howto](https://edwardtanguay.netlify.app/howtos?id=604) - we will buy a domain name for 12€/year from Hetzner called tkserv.eu - we will add an HTML/CSS site that is being served via the [Caddy web server](https://caddyserver.com) at the https domain: https://tkserv.eu - we will add a Node/Express API and use pm2 to serve it at https://testapi.tkserv.eu - we will add a React Site created with Vite and use Caddy to serve it at https://testreact.tkserv.eu - **the frontend React site will read data from the backend Node/Express site, both hosted at Hetzner at HTTPS subdomains:**##hetznerbackendfrontendapps - **Set up Caddy web server and HTML/CSS page at http://your-machines-ip-address** - install Caddy - `sudo pacman -Syu caddy` - create test website - **Note:** unlike nginx, by default you can't serve a website from a **/home** directory - therefore we will serve a site from **/var/www** - create **/var/www** and give your use owner rights so you don't have to always type `sudo` in order to change the files in it - `cd /var` - `mkdir www` - `sudo chown edward www` - create file **/var/www/mainsite/index.html** --------------------------------------------- This is a test website. --------------------------------------------- - set up the Caddyfile to point to your website - **/etc/caddy/Caddyfile** ----------------------------------------- { admin "unix//run/caddy/admin.socket" } http:// { root * /var/www file_server } import /etc/caddy/conf.d/* ----------------------------------------- - you need to enable and start caddy before using it - `sudo systemctl enable caddy` - `sudo systemctl start caddy` - test it in the browser by going to the IP-URL:##thisisttestwebsite - **Purchase a domain name from Hetzner and and set up website as e.g. http://tkserv.eu** - you can buy and manage domains with other providers (for example [domainssaubillig.de](https://www.domainssaubillig.de) where you will find slightly cheaper prices) - but ordering domains at Hetzner will enable you to pay for your hosting and domains with one monthly payment - in your Hetzner Cloud Console, click on **konsoleH**##onkonsolh - click **Neue Bestellung** - scroll down to the bottom to **Domainregistrierung** and click on **Bestellen**##canwebestlll - type in the domain and choose the extension you want, then click **Weiter**##thenameandordjd - click on **Weiter**##thebpapay - click **Zahlungspflichtig bestellen**##zahlungplf - it says everything worked:##gettheeeemal - the email:##theehtzemail1 - if you go to your domain, you will see that it has been reserved:##theserfversdomain - point your domain name to your server - go to konsoleH, Einstellungen, DNS-Verwaltung and type in the IP address of your machine under A-Records for @ and www:##thgreenaksdown - it will take up to 24 hours to be updated with your - refresh the browser page regularly until you see that same site that you see at your IP-address URL - in my case it took about **two hours** until my site appeared at my domain address:##andtkserver - **Add HTTPS to your domain name** - Caddy makes it particularly easy to add HTTPS to a domain name - with nginx you have to use certbot - with Caddy, you simply have to make sure you use your domain name in the Caddy config file - in **/etc/caddy/Caddyfile** change `http://` to `tkserv.du` ------------------------------------------ tkserv.eu { root * /var/www/mainsite file_server } ------------------------------------------ - **Create a Node/Express API on your local machine** - open terminal on your local machine in your projects directory - make a directory for your API - `mkdir hetzner-003-testapi` - enter the directory in VSCode - `code hetzner-003-testapi` - open a terminal in VSCode and create a Node project - `npm init -y` - set project up for ES6 modules - **package.json** --------------------------------- "type": "module", --------------------------------- - import packages you need - `npm i express` - `npm i -D nodemon` (`-D` = dev dependency) - create a basic Node API that serves a test string on the base route - **server.js** ------------------------------------ import express from 'express'; const api = express(); const PORT = 4447; api.get('/', function (req, res) { res.send('Test API works'); }); api.listen(PORT, () => { console.log(`listening on http://localhost:${PORT}`); }); ------------------------------------ - test with: - `node server.js`##thetsetworksijok - set up scripts for dev and deployment - **package.json** -------------------------------------------------- "scripts": { "dev": "nodemon server.js", "start": "node server.js" }, -------------------------------------------------- - test both: - for local developing so app refreshes when files change - `npm run dev` - for online deployment - `npm start` - **Deploy the Node/Express site to Hetzner via GitHub** - first-time deploy to to a Hetzner machine basically means - pushing it from a local repository to a GitHub repository - pulling it from the GitHub repository to the repository on your Hetzner machine - setting up a subdomain for it to run on - setting up pm2 and nginx for it to be accessible at that subdomain - create local GitHub repository - `git init -b main` (note: `-b main` creates a branch called `main` instead of `master`) - there are now hundreds of files to check in since node_modules is being included as files to check into GitHub##now444 - in order to exclude these, make a .gitignore file - **.gitignore** ------------------------------- node_modules ------------------------------- - now there are only 4 files to check in, which is correct:##nowonly4 - use VSCode to create a private repository at GitHub and push your code to it - note: after typing `initial commit`, press CTRL-Enter:#gif#recordpushingtogit - log into your Hetzner machine and go to the `/var/www` directory - clone the repository you just pushed to - note that you need to have set up an SSH key in order to access private respositories on your GitHub account - `git clone testapi` - if you don't yet have Git - `sudo pacman -S git` - if you haven't set up an SSH key for your repository yet, [see this howto](https://edwardtanguay.netlify.app/howtos?id=605) (search for `keygen`)##gettherepo2 - then clone the repository again and it will work: - `git clone testapi`##nowthcloneworks - deploy your API at its port 4447 - check if you have **node and npm**##nodenpmnohave - if you don't have **node and npm** yet, then install them - `sudo pacman -Syu nodejs npm`##thenode18 - go into the directory of the Node application - `cd testapi` - install the node modules with - `npm i` - start the app and view in browser - `npm start` - it says it is running on port 4447 - if you have a firewall attached to your Hetzner machine, open it now and create a rule to allow incoming traffic on port 4447##setfirewall4 - then in your browser, type e.g. `http://YOUR-DOMAIN-NAME:4447` (not https, but **http**), and you will see that it works:##the477works - **PROBLEM:** - 1. the current solution only works with http but not https - 2. you generally don't want to host applications on the Internet under port numbers but rather **subdomains** - with a subdomain, you can later change port numbers if you need to and remap it to the subdomain which stays the same for the users - a website with a port number looks less professional and is more difficult for users to type - **SOLUTION:** create a subdomain called "testapi" at your domain provider - if your domain provider is domainssaubillig.de, it looks like this - domain name [bearbeiten] - Subdomains - [Neue Subdomain anlegen] - enter name, e.g. `testapi` - testapi [bearbeiten] - then enter the IP address of your host for the subdomain:##testapiinin - it will then be listed as a subdomain:##saudomainin - restart the Caddy server - `sudo systemctl restart caddy` - start the Node/Express app again: - `cd /var/www/testapi` - `npm start` - your app will now be available:##theattthttpattestapi - **PROBLEM:** if you stop your **npm start** command, or if your Node app encounters an error and crashes, then your site will no longer be available:##ifyoustoptheser -
