title: Install .NET Core on Debian and create console app
body:
- setup
	- `wget https://packages.microsoft.com/config/debian/11/packages-microsoft-prod.deb -O packages-microsoft-prod.deb`
	- `sudo dpkg -i packages-microsoft-prod.deb`
	- `rm packages-microsoft-prod.deb`
- install .NET Core SDK
	- `sudo apt-get update`
	- `sudo apt-get install -y dotnet-sdk-6.0`
- create console app and execute
	- make directory for project, e.g. `mkdir testdotnet`
	- `dotnet new console -lang C#`
	- `dotnet build`
	- `dotnet run`##andthdotnetrun
- basic C#:
	- **Program.cs**
		-----------------------------------------
		var countries = new List<string>() {"Germany", "France", "Sweden", "Netherlands"};

		Console.WriteLine("ALL COUNTRIES:");

		foreach(var country in countries) {
				Console.WriteLine("- " + country);
		}
		-----------------------------------------
	- `dotnet build`
	- `dotnet run`##therunohyeah
- use LINQ:

How to avoid and minimize costs when using Netlify's Starter Plan
body:
- **Netlify**
	- **Just because you have a Starter plan at Netlify doesn't mean you won't be charged.**
	- I have had a **Starter** plan with Netlify since April 2020, which Netlify advertises as free:##netlifypricing2
	- In September 2022, I received a notification from Netlify that **my sites had incurred a $55 fee**:##bandwithnetlifiy
	- This e-mail and the information I could find on the site was not clear about what the charges were exactly for, e.g. **1 Extra Bandwidth From 2022-08-29 to 2022-08-29**. I wrote to Netlify and received the following answer:##thenetexplan
	- The way I understand this is that a **Starter Plan** is **allowed to send 100 GB of data from its Netlify sites to browsers** which accumulates month after month (does not get reset each month). This is actually quite a lot of data, so unless you have large ISO files, videos or MP3s available for download on your site, you probably will never have to worry about exceeding this 100 GB limit. In my case, I have two sites (https://onespace.netlify.app) and (https://edwardtanguay.netlify.app) which list a large amount of text on each page load as well as screenshot images. In the 16 months since I have had my starter plan, these two sites indeed exceeded the 100 GB limit. 
	- The only way to track your data use over time seems to be to **Team Overview** and notice the number under **Bandwidth used** and then record this for yourself:##thenetlamount
	- Currently my sites seem to be sending about 500 MB per month, which means that I am **due to get another $55 charge in 199 months, or 16 years**.
		- **How my sites purportedly incurred 100 GB in only 16 months is still unexplained.**
		- I asked Netlify about this, they couldn't give me any information on data transfer per time period, and said that there is no way for customers to track this history either, other than to view the above page regularly.
	- for a full list of **what you can be charged for on your Starer Plan**, scroll down on [Netlify's pricing page](https://www.netlify.com/pricing). Note that here the **100GB /month** is very misleading, since as they explained in the e-mail, this does not reset every month, so if you use 50 GB in one month and 50 GB in the next, you will be charged the $55 fee. It should read **every 100 GB**:##netfullfeature

body:
- **nested components**
	- a React website is simply a component which contains other components, which contain other components, etc.
	- the React site-generation tools **create-react-app** and **Vite** both call the first component **App**
		- create-react-app calls the file **App.js**:##craappok

	- when you want to analyze a React website, you can get an overview of the site structure by clicking down into the collection of nested components in components until you get to the last one, then come back out, and click down through another line of components:#gif#reactcomponentsclickthrough
	- when you design a website with React, you imagine the site as a collection of nested components that you are going to build inside each other:##amazoncompoent
- **props**
	- value props:
		- nested components communicate via props##thenewbookcompon
	- function props:
		- in React, props can be sent from parent to child, but not child to parent
		- however, there is a workaround for this limitation: 
			- the parent can send a **function with a parameter** as a prop to the child
			- the child can call this function and send a parameter
			- the function is executed on the parent so that the parameter can change e.g. a state variable in the parent

Implement useReducer into a useContext solution
body:
- **what is useReducer**
	- useReducer is usually implemented into a useContext solution in order to simplify access to state from the front end
	- the reducer is located inside the useContext and is called from the frontend with one function: `dispatch()`
	- the dispatch function has two parameters: `action` and `payload` (option)
	- so the **reducer** reduces access to state down to one function 
	- then from the frontend views
		- you access state with a variable named **state** which has all app state as properties
		- to change state, you use the **dispatch()** function to indicate **what** you want done (action) with **which data** (payload)
- **what we will do**

What to enter for the key value when using map() in JSX
body:
- when using map() to iterate over an array of objects in JSX, if you forget the key attribute, you get a warning in your browser console:##andforgot
- a quick fix that one often does to get rid of this warning so that it is easier to debug in the browser console is to retrieve the **index as parameter from the map() function** and simply use that since **it is unique, i.e. 0, 1, 2, 3, ...**##indexisunique
	- the **problem with this quick index solution** is described well in this article ([Warning: Each Child in a List Should Have a Unique 'key' Prop](https://sentry.io/answers/unique-key-prop))
		--------------------------------
		React uses the key prop create a relationship between the component and the DOM element. The library uses this relationship to determine whether or not the component should be re-rendered.

		It is not recommended to use the index of the array as the key prop if you know the array will not be static. If the key is an index, reordering an item in the array changes it. Then React will get confused and re-render the incorrect element.		
		--------------------------------
	- this means that this solution **will work as long as you don't reorder the items**
	- if you do reorder the items, each item will have a new key and so React will not be able to guarantee that it refreshes the correct items when it is changed, since it is identified with this key
- the best way to resolve this is to make sure you have an e.g. **id field** in your objects which uniquely identifies each object, and use this field for the key##withidok
- however, e.g. in the above case of my [germanNouns](https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/share/germanNouns.json) data, I actually don't have a dedicated id field, but I do have a field **singular** which in this case is indeed unique, since there are no double entries for the same word, hence I can use it and (1) receive no browser console warning, and (2) React will be able to uniquely identify the object even when resorted##butdohavesingular
- one might have the idea to just **use the whole object as the identifier** like this, but it won't work, TypeScript gives us some indication of why, i.e. that key is of type **React.Key** which is a string, and React converts our object simply into a string `[object Object]` which for every item is the same##badobjetob
- what one could do, however, if one doesn't have an id property or any property that is always unique is to define the key as `JSON.stringify(obj)` which would be in some keys a relatively large string, and this would only work, of course, if there are no records which have the exact same data in the exact same fields##thestringifyok
- using solutions that have randomly generated strings such as using [Math.random()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Math/random) or [uuid](https://www.npmjs.com/package/uuid) would bring about the same internal confusion for React as with **index** if you reordered your objects, since the keys would all be randomly generated again

body:
- **Background** - Jest allows you to test functions, this is called unit testing - unit testing is just one level of testing in React applications, the three levels are: - unit testing (scripts that make sure functions act as expected) - component testing (scripts that make sure your components act as expected) - end-to-end testing (scripts that use your application as a user would and makes sure everything works as expected) - there are many advantages for implementing testing in general - it makes your application more secure - when tests are connected in your CI/CD workflow, your website will not build and go to production until tests pass - unit tests in particular are useful because - unit tests encourage Test Driven Development (TDD) which forces you to first determine what your exact programming task is - you create a test suite which defines everything a function should do - you run the test suite and see that every test fails - you develop the function so that the first test passes, then move onto the next test - when every tests passes, you are finished - Jest tests can be set to watch for code changes - as soon as you change something that breaks a test, you will know it - after you implement unit tests - you tend to move business logic from e.g. component code into functions so they can be individually tested - when you have testing in place - new developers can more quickly understand what your application does by reading the tests - function tests are a natural extension of TypeScript - TypeScript can ensure that e.g. a function returns a string - a unit test can ensure that e.g. a function returns a string that contains only lowercase letters and hyphens - Jest tests integrate well into CI/CD workflows with popular development tools and services such as - Visual Studio Code - GitHub - Vercel - **what we will do** - first we will look at a website that has Jest testing implemented in order to - see how it is implemented - how Jest testing works with VSCode - how Jest testing integrates with the `npm run build` - how Vercel integrates with the Jest testing and won't publish code that fails tests - how GitHub integrates with Jest testing and Vercel to indicate if your tests have passed or not - then we will build a Vite React site implementing Jest testing from the beginning step by step - this includes getting Jest to work with TypeScript - **final code** - the first project we work on based on the Datapod framework is here: - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et02-jest-site - the second project we build from the beginning step by step is here: - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et03-jest-test - **==> STEP 1. Clone a site that has Jest testing implemented <==** - clone this mini-framework repository to a directory under your projects folder: - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/datapod-react-2023 - e.g. `git clone git@github.com:edwardtanguay/datapod-react-2023.git et02-jest-site` - `code et02-jest-site` - in VSCode - go into terminal - `npm i` - `npm run dev` - set up Git repository - `rm -rf .git` - delete current repository - `git init -b main` - create new repository - do a "initial commit" - you'll see this site:##willseethis - **==> STEP 2. Analyze the code <==** - this site is a framework I'm working on - there is more here than Jest, see the README.md file - the src/qtools (quick tools) folder contains files that have general functions which can be used anywhere in the website - look at **src/qtools/qstr.ts** - it has three functions, each which performs a specific task - these functions are used on e.g. **PageWelcome.tsx** - generally for each code module containing helper functions, there is a corresponding test file - e.g. **src/qtools/qstr.test.ts** - to run these tests, look in the **package.json** file for the "test" script ------------------------------------- "scripts": { "test": "node --experimental-vm-modules node_modules/jest/bin/jest.js --watch" }, ------------------------------------- - in the terminal, type `npm test` - this starts the Jest test watch which observes your files for testing - press `a` to run all tests now - change the functions to make the tests fail - improve the testing by creating more tests - note that there are many other testing functions other than **toBe** - see many of them here: https://onespace.pages.dev/techItems?id=19 - make the tests fail and then do a `npm run build` - note that the application will not build when the tests do not pass - note the code `npm run build` executes in the **package.json** file: ---------------------------------- "scripts": { "build": "npm run testforbuild && tsc && vite build" "testforbuild": "node --experimental-vm-modules node_modules/jest/bin/jest.js", }, ---------------------------------- - fix the tests and do a `npm run build` - the application will build - publish to a GitHub repository - deploy at Vercel, it will deploy fine:##thefinedeploy - now change the code so the tests fail - let's say we don't have our Jest test watching turned on and we push this change to our repository - note the **red x** here:##notetheredskj - click the **red x** and you will see that Vercel failed to push your code to its production server since the tests failed - click on **Details** - you can see in Vercel's logs exactly what the problem is, where the tests failed##thevercelshowstests - fix the problem locally, and push the change to your GitHub repository - where the **red x** was you will now see a **green checkmark**, if you click it, you will see that Vercel published your site##allcheckbapapss - **==> STEP 3. Create a React site with Vite and add Jest testing step by step <==** - you are of course welcome to use my Datapod framework as a base for your sites - this will enable you to start with a site that has TypeScript running on the backend and frontend with Jest tests implemented - you would then simply have to create new tests for the functions you add - but let's implement Jest step-by-step into a new site to learn all of the steps, including getting it to work with: - TypeScript - ES6 modules - **STEP 3.1: create a minimal React site with Vite that uses TypeScript** - go to your project folder - `npm create vite` - project name, e.g. `et03-jest-test` - React - TypeScript - `code et03-jest-test` - in VSCode open terminal - `git init -b main` - do initial commit - `npm i` - `npm run dev` - **App.tsx** -------------------------------- import './App.css'; const message = 'this is a sentence'; function App() { return (

Message: {message}

import { surround } from './tools'; test('test that surround() is correctly implemented', () => { expect(surround('test', '[]')).toBe('[test]'); expect(surround('test', '()')).toBe('(test)'); expect(surround('test', '**')).toBe('*test*'); expect(surround('test', '***')).toBe('test'); // fail gracefully expect(surround('test', '')).toBe('test'); expect(surround('', '[]')).toBe('[]'); expect(surround('', '')).toBe(''); }); ------------------------------------------- - create **tools.ts** with a stub function for surround that returns some string ------------------------------ /** * Surrounds a string with two letters * * tools.surrounds('primary', '[]'); * * '[primary]' */ export const surround = (text: string, twoLetters: string) => { return 'nnn'; } ------------------------------ - now run the tests with: `npm test`##thefirstwhow - press **a** to run all tests - it fails the first test:##stopsatfirst - program it enough to pass the first test, i.e. that when you send **('test', '[]')**, it returns **[test]** ------------------------------------------------ export const surround = (text: string, twoLetters: string) => { const first = twoLetters[0]; const second = twoLetters[1]; return first + text + second; } ------------------------------------------------ - run the tests again, note it passes the first **three** tests but fails on the **fourth**##thefourthskdj - program in functionality that passes that test as well: ------------------------------ export const surround = (text: string, twoLetters: string) => { if (twoLetters.length != 2) { return text; } else { const first = twoLetters[0]; const second = twoLetters[1]; return first + text + second; } } ------------------------------ - to rerun the tests at any time, press **a** - **STEP 3.4: now use the function in the site - **App.tsx** ---------------------------------------

body: - **Background of Node** - before the invention of Node (**2009** by [Ryan Dahl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryan_Dahl)) one could only create JavaScript programs what ran in browsers - since Node, we could start using JavaScript to develop applications on the server as well - Node uses the **V8 engine** to interpret JavaScript which is the same engine that is used by the **Chrome browser** - this means that anything you can do with JavaScript in a standard browser such as Chrome or Firefox, you can do in Node - Firefox uses the Quantum engine which for all practical purposes interprets JavaScript code in the same way V8 does - note however in Node **JavaScript does not run in a browser environment** - this means that while you have access to the same JavaScript **native objects** e.g. `String`, `Math`, `RegExp`, `Object`, `Function`, you have access to a different set of **host objects** e.g. not `window` (the browser window) but `fs` (the file system) - **native objects** - objects in an ECMAScript implementation whose semantics are fully defined by this specification rather than by the host environment - EXAMPLES: `String`, `Math`, `RegExp`, `Object`, `Function` - **host objects** - objects provided by the browser environment which are distinct from native objects because not all environments will have the same host objects - EXAMPLES IN BROWSER: `window`, `XmlHttpRequest`, `History` - EXAMPLES IN NODE: , `fs`, `os`, `http`, `https`, `url` - **Finished site** - full code is here: https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et002-ssr-web-ts-es6 - final site will look like this:##thenounscrrrr - **==> STEP 1. Install Node <==** - to use Node you first you have to [install Node](https://nodejs.org/en/download) which is an **easy 3-minute process** on any operating system - be sure to download the **newest LTS version** (Long Term Support), which is currently **18.12.1** (on 2022-11-30) - for some tools and frameworks, you may need to be running a slightly different version of Node, e.g. for Angular##theangulok - if that is the case, install [nvm](https://heynode.com/tutorial/install-nodejs-locally-nvm) (Node Version Manager) which allows you to download numerous versions of node (`nvm install 16.18.0`) and then switch back and forth between different versions (`nvm use 16.18.0` and `nvm use 18.12.1`)##listavail - **==> STEP 2. Create the simplest Node script <==** - create a directory for our website project e.g. `et002-ssr-web-ts-es6` - go into the directory `cd et002-ssr-web-ts-es6` - create the file **test.js** ------------------------------------ console.log('this is a test'); ------------------------------------ - execute the file with Node --------------------------- node test.js --------------------------- - output:##thenodetest - delete the `test.js` file we created above since we won't be needing it - `rm test.js` - **==> STEP 3. Create an npm project <==** - while you can write lone scripts as in the above example, most Node applications are **npm projects**, since this allows you to - more easily organize files into a larger project - import and manage dependences, e.g. **axios**, **lodash**, **express** - import and manage custom modules - React, Next.js, Gatsby, Angular, Vue sites are also none other than Node applications which use various dependencies - **npm** (node package manager) is automatically installed when you install Node - it enables you to organize your project and dependencies - now turn the directory into an npm proect - `code .` enter VSCode in your directory - enter your VSCode terminal - `npm init -y` - `y` means "answer yes to all the questions - you can later change these values in the **package.json** file anyway - notice you have a **package.json** file which was created by your **init** command - after creating an npm project is always a good time to set up a local git repository - `git init -b main` - **==> STEP 4. Create the simplest web server that serves an HTML page <==** - **server.js** --------------------------------------------------- const http = require('http'); const port = 3005; http.createServer((req, res) => { res.writeHead(200, { 'Content-Type': 'text-plain' }); res.write('info site'); res.end(); }).listen(port); console.log(`listening on http://localhost:${port}`); --------------------------------------------------- - notice that we are using CommonJS modules (`require`) instead of ES6 modules (`import`) - CommonJS is the older technology which you should avoid if possible - when working in projects, you more or less have to choose between one or the other - it is difficult to use both of them in one project - both CommonJS and ES6 modules - enable you to keep your code more organized and maintainable - ES6 modules - are newer so some newer libraries only support ES6 modules - browsers already fully support ES6 modules now - you have to choose between one or the other so its better to go with the newer version - perhaps in 2018 one wouldn't have argued this, but in 2022 it is valid - in my experience, Jest was the last major piece of software that supporter CommonJS - but I got it running with ES6 modules with --experimental flags - and I now use Vitest which is based on Jest but fully supports ES6 modules and TypeScript - while Node still supports CommonJS by default, even VSCode encourages you with the suggestive three-dot-underling that you should convert your CommonJS statements to ES6 modules##notethatrequire - therefore we will now **switch from CommonJS to ES6 modules** - change the first line to ------------------------------------------- import { createServer } from 'http'; - **==> STEP 2. Prepare local site for deployment <==**
	- **package.json**
		--------------------------------------
		"scripts": {
			"dev": "vite",
			"build": "tsc && vite build",
			"start": "vite preview --host --port 3500",
			"deploy": "git pull --no-rebase && npm i && npm run build && pm2 restart jobs-tanguay-eu"
		},
		--------------------------------------
	- push to GitHub
- **==> STEP 3. Move files to Heztner server and test <==**
	- log in to Heztner machine
	- go to projects directory
	- pull directory from GitHub
		- e.g. `git clone git@github.com:edwardtanguay/jobs-tanguay-eu.git`
	- test to see if your site works on the server
		- `npm i`
		- `npm run build`
		- `npm start`##thestartedok
	- your site should work at your **domain:port** via **http**##onlyontheisjid
- **==> STEP 4. Connect subdomain to site in Nginx <==**
	- go to directory where Nginx saves all its website config files
	- `cd /etc/nginx/conf.d`
	- create conf file for your site: 
		- `sudo vim jobs.tanguay.eu.conf` 
		- **be sure to use the same port as you specified in your package.json**
			------------------------------------------------
			server {
				server_name jobs.tanguay.eu;
				location / {
					proxy_pass http://tanguay.eu:3500;
				}
			}
			------------------------------------------------
	- restart Nginx: `sudo systemctl restart nginx`
	- go back to your site directory and restart the site: `npm start`
	- confirm that your site can be accessed via your subdomain:##viathesubdomainon
- **==> STEP 5. Register a https certificate for your subdomain with certbot<==**
	- stop your site (CTRL-C)
	- go back to the Nginx configuration directory
		- `cd /etc/nginx/conf.d`
	- run **certbot**
		- `sudo certbot --nginx`
	- choose the number listed next to the site for which you want to activate HTTPS:##chooosethessiite
	- it will report that it has successfully activated the HTTPS certificate:##havethecerttti
	- go back to your site directory and restart the site: `npm start`
	- confirm that your site can be accessed via your subdomain with HTTPS:##thehttpsjob
- **==> STEP 6. Set up pm2 to run and manage your site in the background <==**
	- so that we don't need to keep manually starting our React app, let's register the app with pm2 and allow pm2 to start and run it as a service so that it runs in the background 24/7
	- stop your site (CTRL-C)
	- register your site with pm2
		- `pm2 start --name jobs-tanguay-eu npm -- start`
		- if it asks you to run `pm2 save` to synchronize, then do that as well##thepm2setup
	- your site will now be running in the background##thehttpsjob
- **==> STEP 7. Make local changes in your code and redeploy <==**
	- to redploy changes means basically to push to GitHub and run an npm script on the server
	- make a change in your local code##thejob2
	- push to GitHub
	- on your Hetzner server in your project directory run: `npm run deploy`
	- you will see your change online:##job2online
- **==> STEP 8. Add meta tags to create social media link previews of your site <==**
	- if you want to share your site via social media, enter the following meta tags in the HEAD area of the index.html file
	- these instruction apply to the whole site assuming you have only one page
		- if you have React router, then look into [React Helmet](https://www.npmjs.com/package/react-helmet)
	- put the image (in this case **screenshot.png**) in `public/images`
	- in **index.html** add these lines inside the HEAD area
		---------------------------------------
		<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" />
		<meta property="og:title" content="Get a Job">
		<meta property="og:type" content="site" />
		<meta property="og:description" content="Daily developer Jobs in Germany listed with information on skills needed and links to learn these skills">
		<meta property="og:image" content="https://jobs.tanguay.eu/images/screenshot.png">
		<meta property="og:url" content="https://jobs.tanguay.eu">
		<meta name="twitter:card" content="summary_large_image">		
		---------------------------------------
	- your social media link will look like this (Slack):##thesocianditwokr
	- **note: ** social media platforms cache your information, so if you change the text or the image, then be sure to send a suffix to your URL as in the screenshot here, e.g. `?9923` (some random number) so that you get the up-to-date data from your server instead of from the social-media platform's cache

title: Publish frontend/backend TypeScript/ES6-Module sites online on Hetzner/Arch/Caddy/pm2 box
body:
- **what we will do**
	- publish the frontend and backend repositories of an existing full-stack site to an HTTPS subdomain on a Hetzner Arch Linux machine with Caddy web server and pm2
	- I did this already with a Debian/nginx machine, the howto is here:
		- https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/howtos?id=662 (step 6)	
- **==> STEP 1. Set up frontend and backend locally <==**
	- the repositories are here:
		- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/getajob007-backend
		- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/getajob007-frontend
	- for both
		- clone
		- `npm i`
		- `npm run dev`
- **==> STEP 2. Publish backend to Hetzner Arch Linux box under subdomain <==**
	- **2.1. Setup subdomain**
		- log into your Hetzner machine:
			- https://accounts.hetzner.com/login
		- choose **konsoleH**:##ifkonsoleh
			- Einstellungen
			- DNS-Verwaltung##verwalkjd
			- [DNS Panel öffnen]
		- create record with your chosen subdomain name##tehcreaetrepore
		- [Add record]
	- **2.2. Prepare local backend site for deployment**
		- since the backend already exists in a repository, there is nothing to do in this step
		- however, if you have changed anything in the backend locally since you cloned it above
			- push the changes to the repository now
	- **2.3. Move files to Heztner server and test**
		- log into your Hetzner machine via ssh
		- go to projects directory
			- on my Arch machine, this is `/var/www` since there was an issue with exposing home directories to the web
		- pull directory from GitHub
			- e.g. `git clone git@github.com:edwardtanguay/getajob007-backend.git`
		- go into directory
			- `cd getajob007-backend`
		- create **.env** file on the server
			------------------------------------
			PIN = 1234
			PORT = 3501
			------------------------------------
		- note your npm scripts in **package.json**:
			--------------------------------
			"scripts": {
				"dev": "npm run build && nodemon",
				"start": "node dist/server.js",
				"deploy": "git pull --no-rebase && npm i && npm run build && pm2 restart getajob007-backend",       
				"build": "tsc"
			},			
			--------------------------------
		- test to see if your site works on the server
			- `npm i` - this will create **node_modules**
			- `npm run build` - this will create **dist**
			- `npm start` - this will run `dist/server.js`
			- then go to url with port
		- your site should work at your **domain:port** via **http**##getajobonline
	- **2.4. Register HTTPS subdomain in Caddy web server**
		- stop your site (CTRL-C)
		- open the file that Caddy uses to save all its website config files
			- `sudo vim /etc/caddy/Caddyfile`
			- create an entry for this backend 
				--------------------------------------------
				getajob007-backend.tkserv.eu {
					reverse_proxy localhost:3501
				}
				--------------------------------------------
		- restart Caddy
			- `sudo systemctl restart caddy`
		- start your site again with `npm start`
		- note that with Caddy, both subdomain and the https certificate are automatically registered with this one entry##notethatksjdf
	- **2.5. Set up pm2 to run and manage your site in the background**
		- so that we don't need to keep manually starting our React app, let's register the app with pm2 and allow pm2 to start and run it as a service so that it runs in the background 24/7
		- stop your site (CTRL-C)
		- register your site with pm2
			- `pm2 start --name getajob007-backend npm -- start`
			- if it asks you to run `pm2 save` to synchronize, then do that as well
		- test that your site is running in the background		
	- **2.6. Make a change to the backend in your dev environment and deploy it to production**
		- make a change in the `getApiInstructionsHtml` function in the **model.ts** file:##the222
		- commit and push change to GitHub
		- on the server, go to the directory of the site
			- `npm run deploy`
		- reload the site and you will see the change:##theks222orks
		- change it back the same way
- **==> STEP 3. Publish frontend to Hetzner Arch Linux box under subdomain <==**
	- **3.1. Setup subdomain**
		- log into your Hetzner machine:
			- https://accounts.hetzner.com/login
		- choose **konsoleH**:##ifkonsoleh
			- Einstellungen
			- DNS-Verwaltung##verwalkjd
			- [DNS Panel öffnen]
		- create record with your chosen subdomain name, e.g. `getajob007` (without the `-frontend`)
		- [Add record]
	- **3.2. Prepare local backend site for deployment**
		- since the backend already exists in a repository, there is nothing to do in this step
		- however, if you have changed anything in the backend locally since you cloned it above
			- push the changes to the repository now		
	- **3.3. Move files to Heztner server and test**
		- log into your Hetzner machine via ssh
		- go to projects directory
			- on my Arch machine, this is `/var/www` since there was an issue with exposing home directories to the web
		- pull directory from GitHub
			- e.g. `git clone git@github.com:edwardtanguay/getajob007-front.git`
		- go into directory
			- `cd getajob007-frontend`
		- create **.env** file, e.g.
			-------------------------------------
			VITE_BACKEND_URL = https://getajob007-backend.tkserv.eu
			-------------------------------------
		- test to see if your site works on the server
			- `npm i`
			- `npm run build`
			- `npm start`
		- your site should work at your **domain:port** via **http**:##shouldworkwotksjdifhttps
	- **3.4. Register HTTPS subdomain in Caddy web server**
		- stop your site (CTRL-C)
		- open the file that Caddy uses to save all its website config files
			- `sudo vim /etc/caddy/Caddyfile`
			- create an entry for this frontend 
				--------------------------------------------
				getajob007.tkserv.eu {
					root * /var/www/getajob007-frontend/dist
					try_files {path} /index.html
					file_server
				}
				--------------------------------------------
		- restart Caddy
			- `sudo systemctl restart caddy`
		- note that we are not serving this site via a PORT 
			- we are merely mapping the subdomain to the /dist directory
			- therefore the site will now run without an `npm start` or setting pm2 up to serve it
		- note also that with Caddy, both subdomain and the https certificate are automatically registered with this one entry
		- your site will now run at your secure subdomain address:##thesecurisjdfs
	- **3.5. Make a change to the frontend in your dev environment and deploy it to production**
		- in your local dev environment, make a change to **App.tsx**##changetoapptsx222
		- commit and push change to GitHub
		- on the server, go to the directory of the site
			- `git pull && git run build`
		- reload the site and you will see the change:##thenew222k22k
		- change it back the same way

How to name REST API routes
body:
- there is a good discussion here: 
	- [Hyphen, underscore, or camelCase as word delimiter in URIs?](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/10302179/hyphen-underscore-or-camelcase-as-word-delimiter-in-uris)
- and here is a clear set of rules for REST API naming conventions
	- [API Guidlines: Naming Conventions](https://adidas.gitbook.io/api-guidelines/rest-api-guidelines/evolution/naming-conventions)
- in general, REST API URIs:
	- should use **American English** (e.g. `color` instead of `colour`)
	- should use **hyphens** instead of camelCase to delimit combined words (`system-orders` and `get-current-user`)
	- should be **lowercase only**
	- should avoid acronyms (spell out route names even if they are long)
	- should not end with a trailing slash

title: Install MongoDB development environment on Ubuntu/Windows (MongoDB 6.0 Server, Compass, mongoimport, mongosh, NoSQLBooster)
body:
- what we will install
	- 1. **MongoDB 6.0 Server** - local database
	- 2. **MongoDB Compass** - standard GUI administation tool
	- MongoDB Database Tools
		- 3. **mongoimport** - command-line tool to import data into the MongoDB server
		- 4. **mongosh** - the improved shell for MongoDB server (use `mongosh` instead of `mongo` for CLI commands)
	- 5. **NoSQLBooster** - alternative GUI administration tool
		- free tool that has extra features which expire after a month
		- but even the free basic features have advantages over Compass, particularly for learning MongoDB query syntax
- **Ubuntu 22.04**
	- uninstall old MongoDB software first
		- **uninstall MongoDB 5.0**
			- check to see if you have MongoDB installed and if so, what version
				- `mongod --version`
				- if the command is not found then you don't have MongoDB installed##thenotinstall
				- if it shows a version that is not 6.0, then we need to uninstall it##themongddddddv
			- uninstall previous version of MongoDB
				- `sudo service mongod stop` (oder: `sudo systemctl stop mongodb`)
				- `sudo apt-get purge mongodb-org*`##deleteitall
				- `sudo rm -r /var/log/mongodb`
				- `sudo rm -r /var/lib/mongodb`
				- MongoDB will be uninstalled####thenotinstall
		- **uninstall Compass**
			- click on **Show Applications** and type in **compass**##theifcompa
			- if you have it installed
				- type `sudo dpkg --remove mongodb-compass`
				- it will be uninstalled
		- **uninstall NoSQLBooster**
			- NoSQLBooster is an AppImage so you don't have to uninstall it
			- search for it in "Show Applications"
			- if you find copies of it in e.g. "Downloads" then simply delete the files##thenosqllll
		- **uninstall mongoimport** and other mongo command tools
			- find out where the command `mongoimport` is located
				- `whereis mongoimport`##theimposdfusd
			- go to `cd /usr/bin`
			- `ls -al mon*`##theallthemon
			- delete all mongo commands with `sudo rm mongo*`
	- install **MongoDB 6.0 server**
		- **note that the below instructions are explicitly for Ubuntu 22.04**
			- if you have another version, please see detailed instructions at: 
				- https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/tutorial/install-mongodb-on-ubuntu
			- these instructions might also be helpful
				- https://techviewleo.com/install-mongodb-on-ubuntu-linux
		- prepare installation
			- `wget -qO - https://www.mongodb.org/static/pgp/server-6.0.asc | sudo apt-key add -`
				- shows warning but says: "OK"##wgetnotwokrdep
			- `sudo apt-get install gnupg`
			- `sudo apt-get update`	
			- `echo "deb [ arch=amd64,arm64 ] https://repo.mongodb.org/apt/ubuntu focal/mongodb-org/6.0 multiverse" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/mongodb-org-6.0.list`
			- `wget http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/pool/main/o/openssl/libssl1.1_1.1.1f-1ubuntu2.16_amd64.deb`
			- `sudo dpkg -i ./libssl1.1_1.1.1f-1ubuntu2.16_amd64.deb`
			- `sudo apt update`
		- install MongoDB
			- `sudo apt install mongodb-org`##isntalling6
			- start and enable
				- `sudo systemctl enable --now mongod`
			- `systemctl status mongod`##statusmongodoj
			- `mongod --version`##ver65666install
	- install **mongosh**
		- (for detailed instructions, see https://www.mongodb.com/docs/mongodb-shell/install)
		- `wget -qO - https://www.mongodb.org/static/pgp/server-6.0.asc | sudo apt-key add -`
		- `sudo apt-get update`
		- `sudo apt-get install -y mongodb-mongosh`
		- `mongosh` will open the shell
		- test **mongosh** shell
			- commands
				-------------------------------------------------
				show dbs
				use local
				show collections
				db.startup_log.find()
				-------------------------------------------------
			- should show something like this:##theshowmongoshok		
	- install **mongoimport** (and all other commands in **MongoDB Database Tools**)
		- MongoDB Database Tools are a set of command line tools including `mongoimport`
		- click here to download them:
			- https://www.mongodb.com/try/download/database-tools
		- choose **22.04**##choose333
		- in the file explorer, right-click and choose "extract here"
		- then navigate into the extracted folder
		- then into **bin**
		- and move the files from there to wherever `mongosh` is, probably **/usr/bin**`##copymongoimport
	- install **Mongo Compass**
		- https://www.mongodb.com/try/download/compass
		- note it shows the download for Mac (dmg)
		- switch to Ubuntu (deb)##thedebsoubunt2222
		- click on [Download] to save as file
		- `cd ~/Downloads`
		- `sudo apt install ./mongodb-compass_1.32.2_amd64.deb`
		- look in **Show Applications** and search for "compass"##thesearchforcompp
		- start Compass, click [Connect] and look around:##thelookaroundcomp222
	- install **NoSQLBooster** 
		- go to the download site: https://nosqlbooster.com/downloads
			- download the .AppImage file
			- copy the file from Downloads into a folder when you want to keep it to execute it, e.g. [~/Applications](https://docs.appimage.org/user-guide/faq.html#question-where-do-i-store-my-appimages)
			- make the AppImage file executable:
				- `chmod a+x nosqlbooster4mongo*.AppImage`
			- start it for the first time:
				- `./nosqlbooster4mongo-7.0.4.AppImage`
				- it will ask you to add it to your application menu, click **Yes**##applciationmenu
			- then search for it in your Applications, right click and add it to your favorites on your left navigation bar##thenaddtomenu
- **Windows**
	- uninstall old **MongoDB 5.0** software first
		- in the **Uninstall Software** area, uninstall all software from MongoDB##anythingmongoasdasd
		- also delete **NoSQLBooster**##alsonoboo
		- delete the **C:\Mongo\Program Files\Mongo** directory##deletetehmongodsf
		- delete any environment variables which refer to Mongo##thebothenvi
	- install new **MongoDB 6.0** and all tools
		- install **MongoDB 6.0 Server** and **MongoDB Compass**
			- go to download site: https://www.mongodb.com/try/download/community
			- download MongoDB Community Server
			- takes about one minute
				- 2021-01-15: mongodb-windows-x86_64-4.4.3-signed.msi
				- 2021-10-31: mongodb-windows-x86_64-5.0.3-signed.msi
				- 2022-06-25: mongodb-windows-x86_64-5.0.9-signed.msi
				- 2023-01-08: mongodb-windows-x86_64-6.0.3-signed.msi
			- double-click MSI file
				- next, accept, next, complete, next, next, install (2-3 minutes), finish
				- MongoDB Compass opens
	- install **mongosh**
		- download here: www.mongodb.com/try/download/shell
			- 2021-10-31: Version 1.1.1
			- 2022-06-25: Version 1.5.0
			- 2023-01-08: Version 1.6.1
		- unpack the zip file
		- copy the two files in the **bin** directory into **C:\Program Files\MongoDB\Server\6.0\bin**##twofilsdjisd
		- add the **Environment System Path**, add `C:\Program Files\MongoDB\Server\6.0\bin`##theaenviejspath
		- then in any directory, go into a terminal and type `mongosh`##tehmongshswork
	- install **mongoimport** (and all other commands in **MongoDB Database Tools**)
		- go to the download page: https://www.mongodb.com/try/download/database-tools
		- download the zip file
			- 2023-01-08: **mongodb-database-tools-windows-x86_64-100.6.1.zip**
		- unpack it
		- copy all files in the extracted directory's **bin** folder to **C:\Program Files\MongoDB\Server\6.0\bin**##allofwijijdijtoex
		- then in any directory, go into a terminal and type `mongoinstall` and it should find the command##shouldfindjsdf
	- install **NoSQLBooster** 
		- go to the download site: https://nosqlbooster.com/downloads
		- download the .exe
			- 2023-01-08: **nosqlbooster4mongo-7.1.17.exe**
		- double-click on the .exe file

Get account at MongoDB Atlas and connect via mongosh, mongoimport, Compass, NoSQLBooster, apps
body:
- **background**
	- the goal of this howto is to 
		- get a free MongoDB Atlas account
		- understand the basic terminology and online interface
		- connect to online MongoDB database via mongosh, mongoimport, Compass and NoSQLBooster so that you can manager your online databases and collections locally
		- copy collections from your offline to online databases and visa versa
		- connect your offline apps to online databases
	- a MongoDB Atlas account enables you to
		- create and use MongoDB databases that exist online
		- you can access them from local apps
		- you can access them from online apps, e.g. from cloud machines at Hetzner, Digital Ocean, or services such as Cyclic and Render
	- MongoDB Atlas has general free tier
		- no need to give credit card information (as you have to with e.g. at AWS or Azure)
		- you have enough features to use it as a online database solution for online apps
			- 512 MB data storage
				- enough for demo sites to practice online MERN-stack skills 
				- enough to host data for numerous apps for e.g. portfolio sites
			- 24/7 available 
			- no spin-up time
- **sign up for an account**
	- go to: https://www.mongodb.com
	- register e.g. with **Google** or **GitHub**
	- when you are registered and signed in, you should see something like this:##atlastthefirst
- **understand the basic terminology*##thesixtermskdj
	- 1. account > 2. project > 3. cluster > **4. databases** > **5. collections** > **6. databases**
	- 1. account
		- you have one account at MongoDB Atlas
	- 2. project
		- for now you need only **one project** e.g. "mernprojects"
	- 3. cluster
		- for now you need only **one cluster** e.g. "Cluster0"
		- cluster vs. database
			- a MontoDB Atlas cluster is like your local MongoDB server, or like your local MySQL server
				- each cluster has databases (like SQL databases)
				- each database has collections (like SQL tables)
				- each collection has documents (like SQL records)		
	- **4. databases**
		- your cluster (server) has databases
		- but to get to your databases, you have to click on [Browse Collections]##tothecollll
	- **5. collections** and **6. documents**
		- after you click on [Browser Collections] you come to the most useful dashboard of MongoDB Atlas
		- here you have your main Cluster (server) where you can create databases, which have ##mostussatlas
- **create databases and collections**
	- click [Create Database]
	- give name and collection name
	- typically you will want to name your database the name of your **app**, e.g. `app-bookstore-001`##savethbookkk
	- the MongoDB Atlas interface is useful enough to manage your collections and documents directory online
	- click [INSERT DOCUMENT]##andinserstisj
	- type in a document as JSON
- **use MongoDB Atlas from database management applications**
	- MongoDB Atlas can be used from your database management apps such as
		- **mongosh**
		- **Compass**
		- **NoSQLBooster**
		- **Node/Express APIs**
	- to do this you will need to set up **Network Access** and **Database Access**:##dataneenet
	- **configure network access**
		- click **Network Access** on the left side
		- Add IP Address
		- Allow access from anywhere
			- `0.0.0.0/0` (click [ALLOW ACCESS FROM ANYWHERE)
			- this is secure since a login/password is also needed to connect to your cluster
			- and it is convenient if you are connecting to your MongoDB Atlas databases from your local machine and your IP-address that you get from you Internet Service Provider regularly changes
		- click [Confirm]
			- notice the **Pending** message
			- changes to your MongoDB Atlas cluster can take 1-3 minutes to take effect##noticethestatus
		- eventually the address will be registered and the status will change to **Active**
			- ##networkaccessokok
	- **configure Database Access**
		- click **Database Access** on the left side
		- click [ADD NEW DATABASE USER]
		- type in user name
			- this is not a person's account 
				- rather, your app (e.g. Compass or your Node/Express API) will connect to your database using this account
			- therefore create a meaningful name for this user is e.g.
				- for your a chap-app API: **et-chatapp-main**
				- for Compass, mongosh, NoSQLServer: **mainadmin**
			- security tip: avoid using user names such as **admin** or **root** since these are common names often used in brute force attacks
			- if this is your first time setting up a user, create a user that your Compass, mongosh and NoSQLServer can use to read/write to any database, e.g. **mainadmin**
		- create password
			- best for test apps is to have an easy-to-remember-but-secure password since you find yourself often typing it into e.g. mongosh, etc.
				- e.g. `sh-0101`

How to sign up for a Hetzner Account and set up website on a HTTPS domain
body:
- **what we will do**
	- this howto will show you how to 
		- sign up for an account at Hetzner 
		- create a cloud machine running the Debian operating system
		- install Nginx and pm2 in order to host websites
		- publish three kinds of webistes sites on subdomains of you domain
			- 1. a simple HTML/CSS/JavaScript website (e.g. [https://tkserv.eu](https://tkserv.eu)
			- 2. React frontend (e.g. [https://getajob007.tkserv.eu/dashboard](https://getajob007.tkserv.eu/dashboard)
			- 3. Node/Express backend (e.g. [https://getajob007-backend.tkserv.eu](https://getajob007-backend.tkserv.eu)
- **how much it will cost**
	- the **cost per month** will be **less than 6 euros per month** for 
		- cloud machine + IP address = **4.75 euros**
		- domain name (e.g. tkserv.eu) - 10 euros per year, ca. **1 euro** per month
		- here are cost examples from my monthly statements:##thecosthetz
		- you can pay via **PayPal, Visa, SEPA, Überweisung**
		- you pay for machines by the hour, so you can create a machine and keep it on for one day, and on your monthly bill you will have a charge for e.g. less than a euro for the machine and the IP address it used
- **technology used**
	- **Debian** Linux
		- Debian is similar to Ubuntu yet Debian is typically used as a Server while Ubuntu for a desktop machine
		- you can also install Ubuntu, Fedora, CentOS, Rocky Linux, and there is a back door trick to install ([Arch Linux](https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/howtos?id=604))
	- **Nginx**
		- web server to server your pages
		- Nginx is worth learning as a developer skill
		- you can also install [Caddy](https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/howtos?id=607) which saves a step setting up HTTPS on each site
			- but Nginx is better if you setting up machines at Hetzner in order to improve your general Linux and web admin skills
	- **pm2**
		- this is a process manager which keeps your Node/Express sites running 24/7
- **create a Hetzner account**
	- go to: https://www.hetzner.com
	- click on **Login** and **Cloud**##thecloudandjo
	- click on **REGISTER NOW**##ontheregist
	- sign up for account
- **set up machine**
	- log into your Hetzner account: https://accounts.hetzner.com/login
	- click on the [New Project] button##thenewprojsadclick
	- you may have to verify your account, e.g.##youmaypass	
	- call your project e.g. **main**##goveaname
	- click on button##theserversdod
	- choose Nürnberg, Debian, Standard, and CX11
		- this is the least expensive machine, you can upgrade later at any time
	- leave all other settings as default, e.g. we can set up a firewall later
	- however, do **set up an SSH-Key** which is secure practice and in Hetzner's case, setting up a SSH-key will ensure that you do not receive a root password via e-mail
		- make directory for local login, e.g. in `c:/hetzner`
			- in that directory, type the command e.g. `ssh-keygen -f windowskey001 -t ecdsa` (`windowskey001` should identify your local machine)
			- for passphrase, just hit ENTER
				- the SSH will allow you to automatically log in from your local computer
				- your account is still protected by password
				- the root login to your Hetzner machine is by default not allowed to be accessed via remote login, only from the Hetzner website console
				- so this is a quite secure setup for your cloud machine
			- this will create two files on your machine##thewtwofiles
			- open `windowskey001.pub` and copy contents
			- back at the Hetzner website, click the area to create a SSH-key##clickthssssheehj
			- paste the contents of into the box, change the name to windowskey001, and click as standard (for when you create other machines), and click the button##thesshkeyinto
	- rename the machine to e.g. **debian-001**
	- click "Kostenpflichtig erstellen"
- **log in as root**
	- because we set up an SSH-key during creation of our machine, Hetzner didn't send us a root password via e-mail, which one should avoid
	- to get the root password now so we can log in as root to create our first user, we need to reset the password in order to see what it is
	- click on machine
	- [RESCUE]
	- click the [ROOT-PASSWORT ZURÜCKSETZEN] button##doclickthereset
	- copy and save the root password in e.g. your keepass
	- note that from your local terminal, you can try to log in as root, but **as a security measure**, it won't let you:##permssspleasetry
	- you can only log in as host via the Hetzner console##theckonsole
	- with the generated password that you saved earlier, you can log in as root##andnowloggggg
- **create main user**
	- you normally don't want or need to login as root user on Linux
		- we need to do it now in order to create our first user which will have sudo rights
		- having sudo rights means the user can temporarily have root rights
	- so we will now create a main user which you will use to regularly access and manage your machine
	- as root, create a main user (e.g. your name) like this:
		- `useradd -m edward` 
			- (`-m` creates a home directory)
		- `passwd edward`
		- `usermod -aG sudo edward` 
			- (`-aG sudo` adds user to the group which can execute sudo commands)
	- exit as root with `exit`
	- test to see in the console if you can log in and out as your main user
		- remember, to log out, type `exit`
- **on local machine log in via SSH **
	- now from terminal on your local machine, log in via SSH as the user you just created
	- note you can already log in via password, e.g. `ssh edward@195.201.25.54`
		- (get the IP address of your machine from the Hetzner page that lists your machines)##notetologinok22
	- but we want to make it easier to log in via ssh
	- so set up SSH for that user: `ssh-copy-id -i windowskey001 edward@195.201.25.54`	
	- you can now log in with command: `ssh -i windowskey001 edward@195.201.25.54`:
	- make file called e.g. `d1` (short for debian-001) with one line: `ssh -i windowskey001 edward@195.201.25.54`
	- now to log in with SSH:
		- go to `hetzner` directory in terminal 
		- `./d1`
		- enter passphrase
	- note if your local machine is Linux, then
		- in your home directory, create `.bash_aliases` with this line:
			-----------------------------------------
			alias d1='ssh -i ubuntukey001 edward@195.201.25.54'
			-----------------------------------------
		- then: `source ~/.bash_aliases`
		- now to log into your Hetzner machine, simply type: `d1`
- **set up Nginx webserver**
	- https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/howtos?id=605
- **Buy a domain name to host this site**
	https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/howtos?id=605
- **Set up HTML site at domain name**
	https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/howtos?id=605

How to test Node/Express API routes with Vitest and Supertest
body:
- **what we are going to do**
	- we will first set up a simple Node/Express API which uses TypeScript and ES6 modules
	- we will then use Vitest and Supertest to set up testing environment that tests if the routes function the way they should
- code is here
	- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/vitest004
- **set up and minimize Node/Express/TypeScript/ESM starter site**
	- download and set up
		- https://starters.tanguay.eu/list/backendSimpleReadonlyJsonApi
	- remove logging feature 
		- (otherwise you have to keep checking in the changed log file)
	- test with **test.rest**
- **prepare API for testing**
	- for us to test the backend, we have to split up server.ts into server.ts and app.ts
		- the reason we need to do this is that 
			- server.ts will run app.ts so that it functions as before
			- yet we will be able to write tests for app.ts
	- create **app.ts**
		- move all code from **server.ts** to **app.ts** except the `app.listen` block
		- add to bottom
			---------------------------------
			export default app;
			---------------------------------
	- test again with **test.rest**
- **set up API test of one route**
	- install necessary packages
		- `npm i vitest`
		- `npm i supertest`
	- create **server.test.ts**
		------------------------------------------
		import { test, expect } from 'vitest';
		import request from 'supertest';
		import app from './src/app.js';

		test('GET /', async () => {
			const response = await request(app).get('/');
			expect(response.statusCode).toBe(200);
			expect(response.text.length).toBeGreaterThan(250);
		});
		------------------------------------------

	- **How to provide real-time functionality in an Excel file**
		- This code shows you how to program real time events into Excel. I used this to build a little "observer" file which constantly monitored a directory and sent an e-mail when a certain file was present. In this way your Excel file can play the part of a Windows service, i.e. running on some extra, unused machine on a network. Another interesting use for this is be able to give your Excel user live information, i.e. by checking the database, the file system, the date/time, or perhaps webservices. Interestingly, the updates happen silently in the background so that the user is not interrupted at all, can use his Excel file as usual all the while cells in his Excel file are being observed/updated by this service.
			-------------------------------------------------

			CREATE A MODULE CALLED qexc AND SAVE THIS CODE IN IT:

			Sub qexc_Observer()

				'declarations
				Dim intHours As Integer
				Dim intMinutes As Integer

				'config
				intHours = 0
				intMinutes = 0
				intSeconds = 10

				'do action that should be performed regularly
				tool_ObserverAction

				'observe again regularly
				Application.OnTime Now + TimeSerial(intHours, intMinutes, intSeconds), "qexc_Observer"

			End Sub

	- **A self-made ArrayList for Excel VBA**
		- So I was tired of fooling around with the ideosynchracies of Redim Preserve etc. when using Excel VBA and decided to make an ArrayList like you have in VB.NET, C#, Java, etc.  Now arrays are FINALLY easy to use in VBA.
			-------------------------------------------------------
			Sub Test()

				'declarations
				Dim arlEmailAddresses As ArrayList
				Dim intIndex As Integer
				Dim strEmailToCheck As String

				'variables
				Set arlEmailAddresses = New ArrayList

				'add to it
				arlEmailAddresses.Add ("jim@company.com")
				arlEmailAddresses.Add ("roger@company.com")
				arlEmailAddresses.Add ("nancy@company.com")

				'check whether an item exist
				strEmailToCheck = "roger@company.com"
				If arlEmailAddresses.ItemExists(strEmailToCheck) Then
					Debug.Print strEmailToCheck & " exists"
				Else
					Debug.Print strEmailToCheck & " does NOT exist"
				End If

				'output them
				For intIndex = 0 To arlEmailAddresses.NumberOfItems - 1
					Debug.Print arlEmailAddresses.GetItem(intIndex)
				Next

			End Sub


			CREATE A CLASS CALLED "ArrayList" AND ADD THIS CODE TO IT:
			============================================================
			Option Explicit

			'internal variables
			Dim m_arrContainer() As String
			Dim m_intNumberOfItems As Integer


			'method: add an item
			Public Sub Add(objItem As Variant)

				'increment internal counter
				m_intNumberOfItems = m_intNumberOfItems + 1

				'redimension container
				ReDim Preserve m_arrContainer(m_intNumberOfItems)

				'now add the item
				m_arrContainer(m_intNumberOfItems - 1) = objItem

			End Sub

			'method: returns the number of items for for/next loops
			Function NumberOfItems() As Integer
				NumberOfItems = m_intNumberOfItems
			End Function

			'method: return a specific item
			Function GetItem(intIndexNumber As Integer) As Variant
				GetItem = m_arrContainer(intIndexNumber)
			End Function

			'method: returns whether or not item exists, assumes you are saving strings
			Function ItemExists(objDesiredItem As Variant) As Boolean

				'declarations
				Dim intIndex As Integer
				Dim objItem As Variant

				'loop through and check
				For intIndex = 0 To m_intNumberOfItems - 1

					'variables
					objItem = Me.GetItem(intIndex)

					'if this is it, then return true
					If objItem = objDesiredItem Then
						ItemExists = True
						Exit Function
					End If

				Next

				'if we are here, it was not found
				ItemExists = False

			End Function


			'method: sorts the contents of the array

	- **An ArrayList for objects**
		- This ObjectArrayList allows you to easily pack custom objects in a collection so you can iterate through them. This differs from the "ArrayList" that I have in these examples, pretty much the only difference is that the object array list has a "Set" in the Add method. Normally, however, you would probably want to create custom ArrayLists for each objects you have so that you can create custom methods to report on or change specific information about the custom objects in your collection. Interesting that the custom object that you put in the arraylist has to be a CLASS and not a TYPE, otherwise you get an error.

			-------------------------------------------------------
	- **How to send mails with Excel using CDO or Outlook**
		- This code shows you two ways to send mails with Excel VBA. The first uses CDO (e.g. for sending little status notes) and the second uses Outlook (e.g. which uses the user's Outlook application so that he has a record of the mail in his "sent items" just as if he sent it, good for when you have e-mails integrated into the business process and user's need to use Outlook to find out when mails were sent, etc. Notice this solution uses my ArrayList class so that you can conveniently add addresses to your variables without having to deal with redim, etc.
			----------------------------------------------------
			PUT THIS IN YOUR WORKSHEET CODE
			============================================================
			Sub TestSendMail()

				'declarations
				Dim arlToAddresses As ArrayList
				Dim arlCcAddresses As ArrayList
				Dim strSubject As String
				Dim strMessage As String

				'variables
				Set arlToAddresses = New ArrayList
				Set arlCcAddresses = New ArrayList

				'config
				strSubject = "test"
				arlToAddresses.Add ("info@company.com")

				'build message
				strMessage = ""
				strMessage = "Test message."

				'send it
				Call qsys_SendMailWithCdo(strSubject, strMessage, arlToAddresses, arlCcAddresses)

			End Sub


			CREATE A MODULE CALLED qsys AND SAVE THIS CODE IN IT:
			============================================================

			Function qsys_SendMailWithCdo(strSubject As String, strTextOfMail As String, arlToAddresses As ArrayList, arlCcAddresses As ArrayList) As Boolean

				'declarations
				Dim iMsg As Object
				Dim iConf As Object
				Dim strbody As String
				Dim strSmtpServerIpAddress

				'config
				strSmtpServerIpAddress = "10.10.10.10"

				'variables
				Set iMsg = CreateObject("CDO.Message")
				Set iConf = CreateObject("CDO.Configuration")

				'setup
				iConf.Load -1
				Set Flds = iConf.Fields
				With Flds
					.Item("http://schemas.microsoft.com/cdo/configuration/sendusing") = 2
					.Item("http://schemas.microsoft.com/cdo/configuration/smtpserver") = strSmtpServerIpAddress
					.Item("http://schemas.microsoft.com/cdo/configuration/smtpserverport") = 25
					.Update
				End With

				'send the message
				With iMsg

					'variables
					Set .Configuration = iConf

					'add the TO email addresses
					For intIndex = 0 To arlToAddresses.NumberOfItems - 1
						.To = arlToAddresses.GetSeparatedList(";")
					Next

					'add the CC email addresses
					If Not qstr_ArrayIsEmpty(arrCcAddresses) Then
						For intIndex = 0 To arlCcAddresses.NumberOfItems - 1
							.CC = arlCcAddresses.GetSeparatedList(";")
						Next
					End If

					'rest of fields
					.BCC = ""
					.from = "APPLICATION <application@company.com>"
					.Subject = strSubject
					.TextBody = strTextOfMail

					'send it
					.Send

				End With

			End Function


			Function qsys_SendMailWithOutlook(strSubject As String, ByVal TextOfMail As String, arlToAddresses As ArrayList, arlCcAddresses As ArrayList) As Boolean

				Dim OApp As New Outlook.Application
				Dim ONamespace As Outlook.Namespace
				Dim OMail As Outlook.MailItem
				Dim intIndex As Integer
				Dim blnMailWasSuccessfullySent As Boolean
				Dim intNumberOfEmailAddresses
				Dim strEmail As String
				Dim arrProgrammerEmails() As String
				Dim blnOnlyTesting As Boolean

				'FOR TESTING
				blnOnlyTesting = False

				'Constants
				Const olByValue = 1
				Const olMailItem = 0

				'variables
				Set OApp = CreateObject("Outlook.Application")
				Set OMail = OApp.CreateItem(olMailItem)
				OMail.Display

				'define who gets the mail
				If blnOnlyTesting Then

					'add email for test
					OMail.To = "programmers@company.com"

					'mark this as testing
					strSubject = "TESTING: " & strSubject

					'add TO addresses where mail would have gone to
					TextOfMail = TextOfMail & vbCrLf & vbCrLf & "TO ADDDRESSES FOR REAL MAIL:"
					For intIndex = 0 To arlToAddresses.NumberOfItems - 1
						TextOfMail = TextOfMail & vbCrLf & arlToAddresses.GetItem(intIndex)
					Next

					'add CC addresses where mail would have gone to
					TextOfMail = TextOfMail & vbCrLf & vbCrLf & "CC ADDDRESSES FOR REAL MAIL:"
					For intIndex = 0 To arlCcAddresses.NumberOfItems - 1
						TextOfMail = TextOfMail & vbCrLf & arlCcAddresses.GetItem(intIndex)
					Next

				Else

					'add the TO email addresses
					For intIndex = 0 To arlToAddresses.NumberOfItems - 1
						OMail.To = arlToAddresses.GetSeparatedList(";")
					Next

					'add the CC email addresses
					If Not qstr_ArrayIsEmpty(arrCcAddresses) Then
						For intIndex = 0 To arlCcAddresses.NumberOfItems - 1
							OMail.CC = arlCcAddresses.GetSeparatedList(";")
						Next
					End If

				End If

				'define the rest of the mail
				OMail.Subject = strSubject
				OMail.Importance = olImportanceHigh
				OMail.Body = TextOfMail
				OMail.BodyFormat = olFormatRichText

				'send the mail (you can use this but it causes the user to have to click a number of security OKs)
				'OMail.Send

				'this bypasses the security mechanism so that a mail goes out immediately
				Set WshShell = CreateObject("WScript.Shell")
				WshShell.AppActivate OMail
				WshShell.SendKeys ("%s") ' sends a CTRL-S as if the user himself typed it in the application

				'close it up
				Set OApp = Nothing
				SendMail = True

				Exit Function

			End Function



			SAVE THIS IN A CLASS CALLED: ArrayList
			============================================================
			Option Explicit

			'internal variables
			Dim m_arrContainer() As String
			Dim m_intNumberOfItems As Integer


			'method: add an item
			Public Sub Add(objItem As Variant)

				For intIndex = 0 To m_intNumberOfItems - 1

			'gets a list with e.g. commas separating each item
			Function GetSeparatedList(strSeparator As String) As String

				Dim intIndex As Integer
				Dim strListOfNames As String
				Dim intAnzahl As Integer
				Dim strName As String
				Dim strSep As String

				strListOfNames = ""
				intAnzahl = UBound(m_arrContainer)

				For intIndex = 0 To intAnzahl - 1
					If intIndex <> 0 Then
							strSep = strSeparator
						Else
							strSep = ""
					End If
				strName = m_arrContainer(intIndex)
				strListOfNames = strListOfNames & strSep & strName
				Next intIndex

				GetSeparatedList = strListOfNames

			End Function

	- **How to compare previous and current value of a cell**
		- Often you want to react to the event that a cell was changed from one value to another, especially in a dropdown, e.g. when a status is set from "Open" to "Closed" but you want to react differently when it is set from "Postponed" to "Closed". This is how you get both values so you can compare them.
			-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
			Option Explicit

			Private Sub Worksheet_Change(ByVal Target As Range)
				Debug.Print "The previous value of " & Target.Address & " was " & Sheets("PreviousValues").Range(Target.Address)
			End Sub

			Private Sub Worksheet_SelectionChange(ByVal Target As Range)

				'make sure it exists and make sure it is hidden
				qexc_ForceSheetToExist ("PreviousValues")
				Sheets("PreviousValues").Visible = False

				'assign the previous value of the cell that changed
				Sheets("PreviousValues").Range(Target.Address) = Target.Value

			End Sub

			'forces a sheet to exist (if not there, it is created)
			Sub qexc_ForceSheetToExist(strSheetName As String)

				'make sure sheet exists
				If Not qexc_SheetExists(strSheetName) Then

					'declarations
					Dim wsNewSheet As Worksheet

					'variables
					Set wsNewSheet = Sheets.Add

					'name it
					wsNewSheet.Name = strSheetName

				End If

			End Sub


			'returns whether or not sheet exists
			Function qexc_SheetExists(strSheetName As String) As Boolean
				On Error GoTo SheetDoesNotExist
				If Len(Sheets(strSheetName).Name) > 0 Then
					qexc_SheetExists = True
					Exit Function
				End If
			SheetDoesNotExist:
				qexc_SheetExists = False
			End Function

	- **How to insert code with an IF statement**

			'fill the internal collection based on DQL statementj, e.g. "all" or "rank < 10"

		- Often you run through an array and build a comma-separated string, then at the end you have to chop off the ", " off the end. Or perhaps you have to chop off an exclamation mark or question mark off the end, but only if it is there. Use this function.

			Function ChopRight(strContent As String, strPieceToChop As String)

				'declarations
				Dim r As String
				Dim intLengthOfPieceToChop As Integer
				Dim strEndPart As String
				Dim intLengthOfNewString As Integer

				'variables
				r = ""
				intLengthOfPieceToChop = Len(strPieceToChop)
				strEndPart = Right$(strContent, intLengthOfPieceToChop)
				intLengthOfNewString = Len(strContent) - intLengthOfPieceToChop

				'chop it if they are equal
				If strEndPart = strPieceToChop Then
					r = Mid$(strContent, 1, intLengthOfNewString)
				End If

				ChopRight = r

			End Function

				'declarations

				arrRangeNames = qstr_BreakIntoParts(strRangeNamesToProtect, ";")

				Sheets(strSheetName).Unprotect (strPassword)

				Sheets(strSheetName).Cells.Locked = False

				For intIndex = 0 To UBound(arrRangeNames)

					strRangeName = arrRangeNames(intIndex)

					Sheets(strSheetName).Range(strRangeName).Locked = True

				Sheets(strSheetName).Protect Password:=strPassword, Contents:=True, Scenarios:=True, UserInterfaceOnly:=True

			Public Function qsys_GetIniSectionValues(strPathAndFileName As String, strSection As String) As Variant

				'declarations
				Dim strBuffer As String
				Dim lngReturnValue As Long
				Dim arrRawItems() As String
				Dim strRawItem As String
				Dim arrItems() As String
				Dim intIndex As Integer
				Dim intBufferSize As Integer

				'variables
				intBufferSize = 32767
				strBuffer = Space$(intBufferSize)
				lngRetVal = GetPrivateProfileSection(strSection, strBuffer, intBufferSize, strPathAndFileName)

				'make sure it exists
				If lngRetVal = 0 Then

					'the section doesn't exist so go back
					ReDim arrRawItems(-1 To -1)
					qsys_GetIniSectionValues = arrRawItems
					Exit Function

				Else

					'get list of raw items from section
					arrRawItems = VBA.Split(Left$(strBuffer, lngRetVal), Chr$(0))

					'build array to send back
					If Len(arrRawItems(UBound(arrRawItems))) = 0 Then
						intUBound = UBound(arrRawItems) - 1
					Else
						intUBound = UBound(arrRawItems)
					End If

					'redim
					ReDim arrItems(0 To intUBound, 0 To 1)

					'run through and get all values
					For intIndex = 0 To intUBound

						'build array to send back
						arrParts = qstr_BreakIntoParts(arrRawItems(intIndex), "=")
						arrItems(intIndex, 0) = arrParts(0)
						arrItems(intIndex, 1) = arrParts(1)

					Next intIndex

				End If

				'return array
				qsys_GetIniSectionValues = arrItems

			End Function

			Option Explicit

			Public Declare Function lopen _
				Lib "kernel32" Alias _
				"_lopen" _

			Public Declare Function lclose _

			Public Function IsFileAlreadyOpen( _
							sFilename As String) _
							As Boolean
			  Dim hFile   As Long
			  Dim lastErr As Long

			  hFile = -1
			  lastErr = 0

			  hFile = lopen(sFilename, &H10)
			  If hFile = -1 Then
				lastErr = Err.LastDllError
			  Else: lclose (hFile)
			  End If
			  If (hFile = -1) And (lastErr = 32) Then
				IsFileAlreadyOpen = True
			  Else: IsFileAlreadyOpen = False
			  End If

					Debug.Print strTheDate1 & " is NOT a valid date"
				End If

				'test second date
				If qdat_DateIsValid(strTheDate2) Then
					Debug.Print strTheDate2 & " is a valid date"
				Else
					Debug.Print strTheDate2 & " is NOT a valid date"
				End If

			End Sub

			Sub test2()

				'declarations
				Dim strTheDate As String

				'variables
				strTheDate = InputBox("Enter a date: ", "Enter Date", "12/31/2007")

				'test first date
				If qdat_DateIsValid(strTheDate) Then
					Debug.Print strTheDate & " is a valid date"
				Else
					Debug.Print strTheDate & " is NOT a valid date"
				End If

			End Sub


			Function qdat_DateIsValid(strDate As String) As Boolean

				'declarations
				Dim datDate As Date

				'test it
				On Error GoTo HANDLEERROR
				datDate = CDate(strDate)
				qdat_DateIsValid = True
				Exit Function

			HANDLEERROR:
				qdat_DateIsValid = False
				Exit Function

			End Function
			-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
	- **Function which returns if text is contained in another text**
		- I need this in every language I program in, here is is for Excel VBA.
			-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
			'tool: returns whether or not a string contains another string
			Function qstr_Contains(strLine As String, strPart As String) As Boolean

				'declarations
				Dim rb As Boolean
				Dim intPosition As Integer

				'variables
				rb = False
				intPosition = InStr(strLine, strPart)

				'determine it
				If intPosition <> 0 Then
					rb = True
				Else
					rb = False
				End If

				'return it
				qstr_Contains = rb

			End Function
			-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
	- **How to list all range names in a worksheet**
		- To see all the range names you can click in the menu Insert | Name | Define, but many times you need a list of them to process in your code, etc. Range has a nice method called "ListNames" which does this.
			-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
			Sub ListOutAllRangeNames()
				Sheets.Add
				Range("A1").ListNames
				Columns("A:B").Columns.AutoFit
			End Sub
			-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
	- **How to rename a file in Excel VBA**
		- Here is the simplest way to rename a file. I wrap most functionality in functions like this in case I want to add more steps to it later, e.g. logging which names you renamed, or doing intelligent checking and error reporting if the file name you want to name it to already exists.
			-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
			'tool: renames a file
			Sub qfil_RenameFile(strOriginalPathAndFileName As String, strNewPathAndFileName As String)

				Name strOriginalPathAndFileName As strNewPathAndFileName

			End Sub
			-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
	- **How to copy a row to another row**
		- This could be used as a way to replace the contents of any line with a default value, e.g. if you want to "erase" a line.
			-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
			Sub Test()

				Call qexc_CopyRange(ActiveSheet.Rows(15), ActiveSheet.Rows(4))

			End Sub

			Sub qexc_CopyRange(objOriginalRange As Range, objTargetRange As Range)

				'error handling
				On Error GoTo CATCHERROR

				'copy it from one to another
				objOriginalRange.Copy
				objTargetRange.PasteSpecial xlPasteAll
				Application.CutCopyMode = xlCopy
				Exit Sub

				'there was an error
			CATCHERROR:
				MsgBox ("Could not copy " & objOriginalRange.Address)
				Exit Sub

			End Sub
			-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
	- **How to delete all worksheets**
		- I needed some quick code to clean out an Excel file with over 40 worksheets but I needed to keep the code. Used this, it got an error on the last one but I deleted it manually.
			-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
			Sub qexc_DeleteAllWorksheets()

				'declarations
				Dim objWorksheet As Worksheet

				'loop through and delete
				For Each objWorksheet In ThisWorkbook.Worksheets
					Application.DisplayAlerts = False
					objWorksheet.Delete
					Application.DisplayAlerts = True
				Next

			End Sub
			-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
