- **background** - this howto is useful for **React developers** to get up to speed with **Angular** - we will build **a basic but useful site** with Angular which have basic features such as: - **multiple pages** with navbar and URL routes - **user interaction** with checkboxes and buttons - fetch data from an **external API** - a **search box** that filters the API-fetched data that is displayed as one types - **component-based organization** to keep the code organized - learn where to **save and access images** within the site - you will also publish this site at **Vercel** - in building this site, you will also learn Angular concepts that are not familiar to React - **command-line creation** of components - each component consists of four files - **template file** (HTML with directives/pipes etc.) - **class file** (TypeScript) - **style file** (SCSS) - **test file** (default Karma) - **directives** to facilitate user interaction - creating custom directives - **pipes** to alter data in the template - creating custom pipes - **decorators** to attach meta-data to classes - working in an **object-oriented programming** paradigm with classes/methods instead of functional programming functions/hooks - Angular uses **TypeScript** by default - **finished project** - full code is here: - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et111-angular-site - when finished, the site will look like this:#gif#demositeangular - overview of Angular concepts that are either new to React developers, or how you use them are new - intro - learning Angular is in large part learning new concepts - coming from a React background, many of these concepts are new - the following are a list of concepts that one learns as one learns Angular - in this tutorial we will not do an example of every concept - we will create an example of many of them - but we also want to get an understanding of every concept in terms of this howto example - concepts we will cover in this howto - **components** - in Angular you create components as you do in React - however, in Angular, to create a component you use the CLI, e.g. - `ng generate component employees` - this will create a directory called **employees** and four files:##directandfiles - the four files are - **template** file (`.html`) - **style sheet** file (`.scss`) - **test** file (`.spec.ts`) - **class** file (`.ts`) - **templates** - a template can be a piece of HTML or is usually meant to be the whole HTML file that is created when you create an Angular component, see above - this file has an .html extension - but the HTML in the file has many other capabilities using e.g. directives: ------------------------------------------
This info-box warns a user. Success is displayed when no action is required. Unknown status code: {{status}}
------------------------------------------ - **OOP** - where React (since 2019) is based on **functional programming** with **functions** and **hooks** as the main structural components - Angular is based on **object-oriented programming** with **classes** and **methods** as the main structural components - one of the four files in every component is a class file, e.g. **info-box.component.ts** ---------------------------------------------- import { Component } from '@angular/core'; import { IEmployee } from 'src/shared/interfaces'; import axios from 'axios'; @Component({ selector: 'app-employees', templateUrl: './employees.component.html', styleUrls: ['./employees.component.scss'] }) export class EmployeesComponent { employees: IEmployee[] = []; searchText: string = ''; constructor() { (async () => { const rawEmployees = (await axios.get('https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/share/employees.json')).data; rawEmployees.forEach((rawEmployee: any) => { this.employees.push({ firstName: rawEmployee.firstName, lastName: rawEmployee.lastName, notes: rawEmployee.notes }) }) })(); } employeeHasSearchText(emp: IEmployee): boolean { const bulkText = emp.firstName + '|' + emp.lastName + '|' + emp.notes; return bulkText.toLowerCase().includes(this.searchText.toLowerCase()); } } ---------------------------------------------- - note: - **employees** and **searchText** are class variables - they are referenced with the `this.` prefix, i.e. a variable in *this* class - props that are sent to components (none in this example) are also class variables - **employeeHasSearchText** is a class methods (functions that belong to a class) - note there is a constructor which runs when the class is created - **directives** - commands that add additional behavior to elements in Angular templates - two types - structural - e.g. **ngIf** - attribute - e.g. **ngStyle**##directatrbi - these typically perform similar functionality as conditional rendering and e.g. .map() in JSX - **decorators** - used to attach metadata to a class, method, accessor, property, or parameter - we apply the decorator using the form @expression, where expression is the name of the decorator - decorators are **Typescript features** and still not part of the Javascript - e.g. this is a decorator called **@Component** that is included in every class file ------------------------------------------ @Component({ selector: 'app-info-box', templateUrl: './info-box.component.html', styleUrls: ['./info-box.component.scss'] }) ------------------------------------------ - **bindings** - allow data to flow between a component's class and its template - there are four kinds of bindings - **interpolation** - e.g. `{{title}}` - **property binding** - `[disabled]="isDisabled"` - **event binding** - `` - **two-way binding** - `` - **pipes** - take in data as input and transforms it into an output - e.g. `
{{title | uppercase}}
` - **forms** - reactive and template-driven - **services** - objects that get **instantiated just once** during the lifetime of an application - they are similar to components but don't have HTML - they enable components to load and change a data source, somewhat similar to useContext - at the end of this Howto, we refactor our Employee component so that it gives the responsibility of loading employees to an employee service which is accessible to numerous components - concepts we won't cover in this howto but which one should know about and eventually learn as an Angular developer - **animations** - Angular's animation system is built on CSS functionality, which means you can animate any property that the browser considers animatable - this includes positions, sizes, transforms, colors, borders, and more - **dependency injection** - [Dependency Injection](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GUcWjYHmYhY) (deutsch) - **built-in testing** - notes that when components are created, they automatically create a test file - **the observable type with RxJS** - RxJS is a library for reactive programming using observables that makes it easier to compose asynchronous or callback-based code - **==> 1. } else { prefix = `${selectedEmployees.length} selected employees: `; } return `${prefix}${selectedEmployees.map(m => m.lastName).join(', ')}`; } employeeHasSearchText(emp: IEmployee, searchText: string): boolean { const bulkText = emp.firstName + '|' + emp.lastName + '|' + emp.notes; title: How to create an interactive CLI tool
body:
- I review three tools for creating CLI tools
	- **1. [Commander.js](https://www.npmjs.com/package/commander)**
		- I found this tool the least useful because few users want to enter more than e.g. one or two arguments and options in a CLI command and so reading arguments from the command line can be done in most cases with the native node variable **argv** (e.g. argv [0], argv[1]) and then process them themselves.
	- **2. [chalk](https://www.npmjs.com/package/chalk)**
		- Chalk is useful for increasing the readability of text on the command line with colors and it's really easy to use.
		- I found that **hex** and **bgHex** colors don't work in some terminals such as VSCode terminals:##thenewcolorforchaclk
	- **3. [Inquirer](https://www.npmjs.com/package/inquirer)**
		- Inquirer is indeed a useful tool. It seems to be the tool that Vite uses to set up sites and gives you that same control of asking the user for numerous data points in one process at the command line. 
		- I also created an example where I **combined argv and Inquirer** to allow the user to enter the project name as a command line argument, and then using **chalk** I rendered that info as a preselected answer to make its color match Inquirer and look as if it comes from Inquirer.
- code is here:
	- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/ettestcmd
- the main file you want to look at is **inquirer.js** to see an example of using all the functionality of Inquirer
- also look at **inquirerWithPreselect.js** to see how to enable the user to type the answer to the first question on the command line as an argument
- I run inquirer as an npm script:
	------------------------------------
	"scripts": {
		"install": "node inquirer.js",
		"install2": "node inquirerWithPreselect.js"
	},	
	------------------------------------
- this is an example of inquirer.js#gif#inquirerdemo

title: How to set up a React site as the main domain site on a Debian machine at Hetzner with Nginx/pm2
body:
- I'm replacing a static HTML site at my home domain with a React site
- therefore I will first record the settings of the static site and then remove it
- **static site**
	- **/etc/nginx/conf.d/tanguay.eu.conf**
		--------------------------------------
		server {
				server_name tanguay.eu;
				root /home/edward/projects/mainsite;
				index index.html;
				location / {
						try_files $uri $uri/ =404;
				}


			listen 443 ssl; # managed by Certbot
			ssl_certificate /etc/letsencrypt/live/tanguay.eu/fullchain.pem; # managed by Certbot
			ssl_certificate_key /etc/letsencrypt/live/tanguay.eu/privkey.pem; # managed by Certbot
			include /etc/letsencrypt/options-ssl-nginx.conf; # managed by Certbot
			ssl_dhparam /etc/letsencrypt/ssl-dhparams.pem; # managed by Certbot

		}
		server {
			listen 80 default_server;
			server_name tanguay.eu;
			return 301 https://tanguay.eu/$request_uri;
		}		
		--------------------------------------
- create simple, local react site
	- creating the site from this starter
		- https://starters.tanguay.eu/list/blankViteDarkMenuUsecontext
		- set up here: **C:\ggg\tanguayeu\mainsitereact**
		- made small change: tanguay.eu
		- site works locally:##theinfositeok
	- pushing site to GitHub
		- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/mainsitereact
	- set up npm scripts for deployment
		-------------------------------------
		"scripts": {
			"dev": "vite",
			"build": "tsc --build --clean && vite build",
			"start": "vite serve --host --port 3555",
			"setup": "npm i && npm run build && pm2 start --name tanguayeu-mainsitereact npm -- start --update-env --time && pm2 save",
			"deploy": "git pull --no-rebase && npm i && npm run build && pm2 restart tanguayeu-mainsitereact --update-env --time && pm2 save",
			"cp": "node cli/cp.mjs"
		},		
		-------------------------------------
- clone the directory at Hetzner
	- logged into Hetzner
	- changed directory to **~/projects**
	- `git clone git@github.com:edwardtanguay/mainsitereact.git`
- test site without domain name
	- `cd mainsitereact`
	- `npm i`
		- if this process hangs on your slow 2GB machine, reboot the machine and try again
		- after reboot, it took about 50 seconds to install the node packages but then finally completed##tookabout23
	- `npm start`##thenpmstartok
	- opened port 3555 in my fire wall
	- it works at address **http://tanguay.eu:3555**
- now connect it to your domain, in my case **tanguay.eu**
	- stop Node serving your site with CTRL-C
	- `cd /etc/nginx/conf.d`
	- test your site in the browser first: https://tanguay.eu
	- rename the current conf file for your main domain, e.g.
		- `sudo mv tanguay.eu.conf tanguay.eu.conf-SAVE`
	- your site should still work in your browser
	- now restart Nginx
		- `sudo systemctl restart nginx`
	- your site will temporarily no longer work in the browser since there is no conf file to match your domain:##eusitenowork
- set up a conf file for your new React site
	- create **/etc/nginx/conf.d/mainsitereact.conf**
		-------------------------------------
		server {
				server_name tanguay.eu;
				location / {
						proxy_pass http://tanguay.eu:3555;
			   }
		}			
		-------------------------------------
	- create the https certificate for this site with certbot
		- `sudo certbot --nginx`
		- type the number that corresponds to your site, e.g. here **1** for **tanguay.eu**
		- renew it if it asks##therenewanddo
	- restart Nginx
		- `sudo systemctl restart nginx`
	- your site will still not work, but the reason now is that your React site is not being served at the designated port##notwokrijdifj
- set up your React site with pm2
	- go back to your site's directory
		- `cd ~/projects/mainsitereact`
	- look at the npm scripts
		- `cat package.json`
	- you need to run the **setup** and then the **deploy** script
		- note **setup** will install your node_modules again, so you might have to reboot again if you are on an inexpensive CX11 server
		- `npm run setup`
			- mine completed in 2 seconds
- check your browser, your test site should work:##siteeuworks
- make changes and deploy to server 
	- make changes to your test site locally so that it is the site you want to host
	- push to GitHub
	- go back to your terminal at Hetzner, make sure you are in your site's directory
	- `npm run deploy`##thedpleoyisin
- check your site
	- it should now have the latest changes#gif#thedemotanguayeuworks

title: Set up Vue 3 site with TypeScript, components, interaction, script setup syntax, API data fetch, and publish to Vercel
body:
- goals of this howto is to **help React developers**
	- 1. **get a broad understanding of the Vue ecosystem** 
		- which tools are used
		- which versions are used
		- what various concepts mean
		- understand the various ways Vue can be used
		- gain enough knowledge to identify which Vue tutorials, articles and documentation are out-of-date and which are relevant for learning Vue moving forward
	- 2. **get up-to-speed using the Vue framework** in order to e.g.
		- acquire the skills to create a customized Vue site, publish it at Vercel
		- which you link from your portfolio site 
		- as proof you have rudimentary Vue.js skills
		- and to give you the confidence to take on Vue.js development projects
- to do this, **we will create the following site:**
	- code is here:
		- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/vue-proj-003
	- router with three pages
	- user interaction
	- state variables (ref)
	- basic styling (scoped and non-scoped plain CSS)
	- TypeScript interfaces
	- API fetching#gif#demositeforvue003
- but first let's 
	- (1) get acquainted with the **background and fundamental concepts of Vue**
	- (2) discuss the **optimal tool and version choices** for getting into **Vue development in March 2023**
	- background
		- currently the three major JavaScript frameworks are
			- **React** - maintained by **Facebook**
			- **Angular** - maintained by **Google**
			- **Vue.js** - maintained by **Evan You** and the open-source community
				- Evan worked for Google from 2012-2014
					- he worked on AngularJS
					- after leaving, he created Vue.js, *"a framework that contained what I liked about Angular but really lightweight"*
				- in 2020, Evan also created **Vite**
		- Vue has gone through numerous changes in the last three years 
			- version change (Vue 2 to **Vue 3**)
			- build-tool change (Vue CLI to **Vite**)
			- changes in state-management tooling (Vuex to **Pinia**)
		- therefore use the following guide to make sure you
			- get started with the most up-to-date version and tooling
			- can identify up-to-date tutorials, articles and documentation
	- **==> 1.** Which **VERSION** should you use, **Vue 2** or **Vue 3**? ==> ANSWER ==>**Vue 3**
		- *Vue 2 support will end on December 31st, 2023*
			- https://v3-migration.vuejs.org
		- Vue 3 came out in November 2020
			- added support for TypeScript
			- smaller and faster
			- uses the new Composition API
			- uses the new script setup format
	- **==> 2.** Which **SFC LAYOUT** should you use, the **Options API** or the **Composition API**? ==> ANSWER ==> **Composition API + script setup**
		- SFC = Single File Component
		- **Vue 2** uses the **Options API**
			- the Options API is simpler 
				- but therefore less structured 
				- and so tends to become too complicated in larger applications		
			- the Options API will be phased out as Vue 2 is no longer supported at the end of 2023
			- if you need to use Vue 2 for backward-compatibility reasons
				- you can upgrade to Vue 2.7 which has the option to use the Composition API
		- **Vue 3** uses the **Composition API**
			- a new way to write Vue components
			- easier to reuse code
			- easier to organize code logically
			- better separation of concerns
			- easier to test because of a more functional style of programming
			- better structured for larger, more complex applications
		- this shows the differences in syntaxes between the two approaches##optionscomp
		- note there is also a **script setup** syntax that one can use for the Composition API
			- more succinct
			- less boilerplate
			- declare props and events with TypeScript
			- better IDE type-inference
			- see [script-setup documentation](https://vuejs.org/api/sfc-script-setup.html)
			- or as explained here, *the idea of script setup is that you want to get rid of the unnecessary wrapper and the other old component options so you can write components simpler and focused*:
				- [The 101 guide to Script Setup in Vue 3](https://vuedose.tips/the-101-guide-to-script-setup-in-vue-3)##thsetupcode	
			- VIDEO: [Vue 3 Script Setup](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9uSNKIXH_AI)
	- **==> 3.** Which **INSTALL METHOD** should you use to install Vue, **Vue CLI** or **Vite with create-vue**? ==> ANSWER ==> **Vite with create-vue**
		- **Vue CLI** is officially no longer recommended
			- even the Vue CLI website https://cli.vuejs.org now says:
				- *"please use **create-vue** to scaffold Vite-based projects"*
			- this is how you know a tutorial is installing Vue with the Vue CLI
				- the Vue CLI is installed globally
					- `npm install -g @vue/cli`
				- the Vue CLI is then used to create a site
					- `vue create site001`	
			- **NOTE:** don't confuse the command **vue create** (old) with **create-vue** (new) 
			- **Vue CLI** is to Vite as **create-react-app** is to React
				- both **Vue CLI** and **create-react-app** are slow, outdated and superseded by **Vite**
				- **Vue CLI** and **create-react-app** use **Webpack** which is written in **JavaScript** which makes them **slow**
				- **Vite** uses **esbuild** which is written in **Go** which makes it **fast**
			- but note that it is however possible to use the old **Vue CLI** to install **Vue 3**
				- so you may find Vue 3 tutorials that use Vue CLI##thevue3canuse
			- a Vue-CLI-created Vue site is started with `npm run serve`##thevuserve
			- a Vue-CLI-created Vue site will look like this:##nowvueoutdate
			- here is the code of a new Vue 3 site created with Vue CLI
				- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/vue-with-vue-cli-002
			- here is the same code after I created a new component (InfoSpace.vue)
				- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/vue-with-vue-cli-001 
			- note if you choose **Manually select features** you can make very fine-grained choices##ifmanulask
			- **Vue CLI** also has a **GUI option**
				- you type `vue ui` and get this, but it makes little sense to have a GUI to create websites:##thevueui
		- *** but the **modern, preferred, standard way** to create **Vue 3** websites is now to use **Vite** with **create-vue**
			- just as when you are building a React site, start Vite with `npm create vite` 
				- (note that `npm init vite` is the same command, `create` is simply an alias for `init`)
				- choose: **Vue** and then **Customize with create-vue**##withwithcreatevuew		
				- then you can choose the options you want initally in your application##choosealloptions
				- open editor, set up a Git repository, and run the three commands listed
					- `code <name-of-your-app>`
					- `git init -b main` - creates a local Git repository with a main branch
					- `npm i` - installs node_modules
					- `npm run format` - starts prettier watching the /src directory for changes
					- `npm run dev` - the standard command used in Vite React as well to start the app in development mode
				- when you click on the URL provided, your **Vite with create-vue site** will look like this:##vitevuestartpage					
				- the initial code of the site looks like this
					- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/vue-with-vite-create-vue-all-options
			- you may also see some tutorials and videos use the **create-vue** installation **without Vite**, here are some variations of that command:
				- `npm create vue` - latest **stable** version
				- `npm init vue`
				- `npm create vue@latest` - latest version, may not be stable
				- `npm init vue@latest`
				- `npm create vue@next` - latest pre-release version, upcoming changes, likely not stable, don't use in production
				- `npm init vue@next`
				- `npm init vue@3`
				- `npm create vue@3`
					- you can provide the version (2 or 3)
				- note that in npm syntax, `create` is merely an alias of `init`
			- it's important to note that **Vite with create-vue** and `npm create vue@latest` give you the **exact same install**##notethesamesproce
			- and note that the initial site looks exactly the same
				- it even gives the same message that you created a project with **Vite**:##sameaswithvite
			- so to create a modern Vue 3 website, you can either use:
				- `npm create vite`
				- `npm create vue`
				- both of these commands **use Vite**
			- **I recommend always using Vite** because:
				- Vite is becoming the standard tool to install JavaScript frameworks
					- **Vue**, **React**, **Svelte**
					- also **Nuxt** (the server-side version of Vue, much like Next.js is for React)
				- Vite is the most innovate and comprehensive install tool today
					- by using it frequently you stay up to day with new frameworks and technologies it can install, e.g.
						- server-side rendered JS/DOM, Vue, React, Svelte, Solid + Deno##ssrdeno
				- you can also use Vite to **install very simple JavaScript or TypeScript configurations of Vue 3**, e.g. 
					- `npm create vite` then choose **Vue** then **JavaScript**
						- the start site looks and works similar to when you set up a React site
						- it has a `ref` variable in the HelloWorld component for the interactive counter button
						- otherwise it is similar but not the same as when you set up with **Vue, Customize with create-vue** and answer only **No**
						- both have a 3.2 version of Vue installed
						- you would use this if you know you don't want any other app features, or know how to install them manually
						- here is the initial code for this project
							- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/vue-with-vite-javascript
						- the initial site looks like this, basically the same functionality as when you create a React site with Vite##vuewithvitejavascript 
					- `npm create vite` then choose **Vue** then **TypeScript**
						- this is the same site as above, but with TypeScript
						- here is the inital code, basically the same as above but with TypeScript files (`.ts`) instead of (`.js`)
							- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/vue-with-vite-typescript
						- the initial site looks the same, note that there are minor changes in the code and file names for TypeScript##thevuewithtyp
					- these two options are for extremely simple sites, e.g. without routing, etc. 
					- **my advice:** unless you want to install the simplest site and will never need Routing, state management, Testing, or Prettier, etc., always choose **Vue, Customize with create-vue** and select what you intially want to have installed
	- **=>4.** Should you start learning **Vue (client-side)** or **Nuxt (server-side)** first? ==> ANSWER ==> **Vue (client-side)**
		- **Vue** is a client-side framework like **React**
		- **Nuxt** is a server-side framework like **Next.js**
		- as a React developer, you have enough new concepts and tools to learn when beginning with Vue
			- **Nuxt** is the same as Vue but adds even more tools and concepts
			- therefore my recommended learn path is to **first get familiar with Vue, its concepts and tools**
		- nevertheless, let's at least be familiar with the two main ways to get Nuxt installed
		- **Nuxt install option #1:** use **Vite** which gives the option to install Nuxt
			- `npm create vite` then choose **Vue** then **Nuxt**##thenuxtinstall
			- the code is extremely minimal
				- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/nuxt-with-vite
				- the readme states that it is a "Nuxt 3 Minimal Starter"
				- basically you only have one file which shows a starter screen with code from the .next directory**app.vue**##allisnuxut
			- the starter site looks like this##thenuxtsiteie
		- **Nuxt install option #2:** use **npx create-nuxt-app**
			- this is the official installation method recommended on the Nuxt website:
				- https://nuxtjs.org/docs/get-started/installation
			- `npx create-nuxt-app <project-name>`
				- note that you get many options as you install, similar to using **create-vue** for a Vue site##nuxtoptions
				- there are even more options than with **create-vue**##nuxtmany
				- the entire process looks like this when finished##nuxtinstallprocess
			- starting the Nuxt site with `npm run dev` I got this error##startingnuxterror
				- tried various solutions suggested but none worked
				- it seems to have something to do with Tailwind
			- reinstalled, this time didn't choose Tailwind (vuetify.js instead) and didn't select GitHub Actions##threnuxtinstl
				- the build seemed to work fine:##notailworked
				- but the site gets an error:##nuxtsitewithseconderror
				- this [post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/64620120/nuxt-installation-error-rule-can-only-have-one-resource-source-provided-resou) suggested `"webpack": "^4.46.0"` which got past the above error but gave me this error##thenewnuxterror
			- trying an install on Nuxt 3 on Ubuntu to see if it is any different:##createnuxtlinux
				- even on Ubuntu it gets the same error (with Tailwind):##evenubuntjs
			- ok, back on Windows, resintalling with minimal feature selection##nuxtminimalaal
				- builds fine##buildsfinekjsd
				- but then crashes with same error##sameerror
				- but this got me further
					---------------------------------
					npm un webpack
					npm i -D webpack@^4.0.0
					---------------------------------
				- it begins to build##beginbuildkjdf
				- but then got a **PostCSS 8** error
				- executed the fix suggested in [this Stack Overflow post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/64057023/error-postcss-plugin-autoprefixer-requires-postcss-8-update-postcss-or-downgra)
					- `npm un autoprefixer` - somehow the packages are not listed in **package.json* but you can find the versions in **package-lock.json**
					- `npm i autoprefixer` - now it shows in **package.json**
					- **package.json** change the version down to **9.0.0**##downto9
					- do a full reinstall of node_modules
						----------------------------------------
						rm -rf node_modules
						npm i
						-----------------------------------------
				- now `npm run dev` successfully builds in the terminal##clientserversj
				- and site looks like this:##theworkonnuxtwin
				- and here is the code of the **Nuxt application** created with **create-nuxt-app**
					- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/nuxt-with-create-nuxt-app-minimal
					- note that it is also a very minimal site
					- you have a [/page/index.vue](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/nuxt-with-create-nuxt-app-minimal/blob/master/pages/index.vue) file
					- which calls a [/components/Tutorial.vue](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/nuxt-with-create-nuxt-app-minimal/blob/master/components/Tutorial.vue)
	- **==>5.** Should you use the **CDN link** or **install a Vue application** ==> ANSWER ==> **BOTH, depending on your use case**
		- the purpose of this howto is to show how to **set up a stand-alone web application** with **Vue**
			- similar to applications created with **React** or **Angular**
			- to do this, as explained above, you use **Vite** and then choose **Customize with create-vue**
		- however, unlike React and Angular, **Vue** can also be **accessed via a simple CDN link**
			- this is why they call Vue a **progressive framework**
				- it can have **a light footprint** by simply being imported via a CDN link to **add functionality to an existing page** of another website
				- or it can be used to create a **complex, stand-alone, enterprise application** as with React or Angular
			- for instance, this is the CDN link that you use:
				- https://unpkg.com/vue@3/dist/vue.global.js
				- when you click on it you see that it downloads the entire Vue 3 code for you to use on any page
			- hence Vue can be used as a way to easily add interactive functionality to static sites, e.g. 
				- plain HTML pages
				- any server-side rendered pages such as those from server-side frameworks such as PHP, Ruby-on-Rails, ASP.NET, EJS, etc.
		- for instructions on how to set up a HTML page with Vue as a CDN link, see [Using Vue from CDN](https://vuejs.org/guide/quick-start.html#using-vue-from-cdn)
		- for a detailed Howto on how to add Vue functionality to an existing HTML site, including loading data from an API and user interactivity, see this howto:
			- [Build interactive Vue.js into HTML site with API data call](https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/howtos?id=645)
	- **==> 6.** Which **ROUTER** should you use, **Vue Router** or an alternative Vue router? ==> ANSWER ==> **Vue Router**
		- [Vue Router](https://router.vuejs.org) is the official and recommended router for Vue
		- there are other routers you could try out such as [Vue-Routisan](https://www.npmjs.com/package/vue-routisan)
			- but most Vue projects use the standard **Vue Router**
			- and it can be installed with build tools such as **Vite**
	- **==> 7.** Which **STATE MANAGEMENT** should you use, **Vuex** or **Pinia**? ==> ANSWER == **Pinia**
		- **Vuex** and **Pinia** are equivalent to **useContext** in React
			- they provide a more organized way to centrally manage state in a single-page application
		- **Vuex** was created by **Evan You** in 2016
			- since then it has been the standard state management solution in Vue
		- **Pinia** was created in 2020 by Eduardo San Martin Morote
			- since then it has gained popularity as a **lightweight alternative to Vuex**
			- it's **more straightforward** than Vuex
			- Pinia is now recommended by the Vue core team
			- has excellent **TypeScript support**
			- VIDEO: [Vue State Management Pinia Crash Course](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ok6vO98RV_Q) (15 min)
		- note that there is a **third way**:
			- create a mini state-management system with **ref** and **reactive**
				- these commands allow you to share data between multiple components by creating composables
	- **==> 8.** Which **TESTING FRAMEWORK** show you use, **@testing-library/vue** or **Cypress**? ==> ANSWER ==> **BOTH**
		- use **@testing-library/vue** for **unit testing**
		- use **Cypress** for **end-to-end testing**
		- you can add both of these into your pull-requests and CI/CD system
	- **==> 9.** Which **STARTER TEMPLATE** should you use, **Vue 3 Enterprise Boilerplate** or **Vitesse**? ==> ANSWER ==> **Vitesse**
		- **Vue 3 Enterprise Boilerplate**
			- https://github.com/MrSunshyne/vue3-enterprise-boilerplate
			- might be useful for very large projects
		- **Vitesse**
			- uses Vite
			- file-based routing
			- Pinia
			- auto import of components
			- is lighter than Vue 3 Enterprise Boilerplate
			- VIDEO: [Vitesse](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rMD3A5BgDxE)
	- **==> 10.** Which **COMPONENT LIBRARY** should you use, **Vuetify** or **Quasar**? ==> ANSWER ==> **Quasar**
		- both of these provide pre-built components such as Bootstrap does
		- **Vuetify**
			- took a long time to upgrade from Vue 2 to Vue 3 and **lost many of their users to Quasar**
			- based on **Material UI**
		- **Quasar**
			- it is more or less its own framework with its own CLI
				- therefore offers more than Vuetify
			- supports desktop, tablet and mobile
			- has themes, internationalization
			- VIDEO: [Quasar Vue.js Tutorial - Getting Started](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C-v262YhYvw)
		- alternative: **Tailwind**
			- instead of pre-built components, learn Tailwind and create your own
	- **==> 11.** Which **VSCODE VUE EXTENSION** should you use, **Vetur** or **Volar**? ==> ANSWER ==> **Volar**
		- **Vetur**
			- was popular with Vue 2
			- doesn't work well with Vue 3 script setup
		- **Volar**
			- good support for TypeScript
			- works will with Vue 3 script setup
			- nice auto-completion
	- **==> 12.** Which **LANGUAGE** should you use with Vue projects, **JavaScript** or **TypeScript**? ==> **either work, but TypeScript is recommended** <==
		- while **Angular** more or less requires you to use TypeScript since you will run into limitations and problems if you don't
			- **React** and **Vue** are more flexible in allowing both JavaScript and TypeScript
		- **Vue officially recommends TypeScript** 
			- but it doesn't set up any unnecessary limitations if you choose JavaScript
		- as in React, while **TypeScript adds some coding complexity**, it also:
			- encourages cleaner, **more understandable code** 
				- by forcing you to define your types explicitly
			- provides**auto-completion** of e.g. objects properties
			- **catches type errors** as you develop
				- will alert you if you send a string to a function that expects a number
			- acts as a kind of **testing mechanism** to decrease the chance that your application will fail
				- types are not only checked as you develop, but anywhere you build the application, e.g. Vercel won't publish your site if TypeSript finds errors in it

Understand the basics of Docker, setup numerous containers and run on various machines
body:
- **what we will do**
	- this howto is for MERN-stack developers who have never worked with Docker before
	- we'll install Docker Desktop on our local machines
		- e.g. I have Docker Desktop installed on my Windows and Ubuntu machines
	- we'll create three Docker applications
		- minimalistic 10-line Node/Express API
		- Node/Express API that shows data from local JSON files
		- that Node/Express API plus a frontend React website that work together
	- each of these application will get running on three operating systems
		- local Windows machine
		- local Ubuntu machine
		- cloud machine at Hetzner
- **why learn Docker?**
	- technical reasons
		- it makes applications easier to deploy
			- especially if they have complex environments and complicated setup procedures 
		- replacement for virtual machines in many instances
			- wrap applications instead of machines
		- can be easily scaled
			- since they are abstracted
	- employment reasons
		- many companies are adopting Docker and Kubernetes into their DevOp solutions
		- it is often mentioned in job ads
			- https://jobs.tanguay.eu
- **what's difficult about Docker?**
	- Docker has a steep learning curve
		- not something you learn in a day, week or become an expert in a month
	- Docker is a technology that by its nature spans every kind of operating machine which you constantly have to deal with and understand the peculiarities of
		- Windows
		- Mac
		- many versions of Linux, particularly those used in Cloud computing, e.g. 
			- Ubuntu / Debian
			- Red Hat / Fedora / CentOS
	- Docker is primarily a DevOps technology, not a development technology
		- historically developers did not have much to do with deployment or application hosting
		- but today with the popularity of GitLab, GitHub, CI/CD pipelines, microservices, cloud computing
			- the boundaries of development and devops have been blurring over the past decade##devopstechs3
	- Docker has a high amount of new 
		- concepts 
		- vocabulary
		- tools 
		- technologies
- **Docker concepts, vocabulary, tools and technology**
	- Docker vocabulary
		- **repository**
			- a place where Docker images are stored and managed, e.g. at Docker Hub
			- a Docker repository stores Docker images, not Docker files that are used to create images
			- you clone a Docker repository, you are typically retrieving the source code and any associated files needed to build the Docker image. In some cases, the repository may also contain a Dockerfile that can be used to build the image
			- a Docker repository typically stores only the Docker images themselves and not the Dockerfiles used to build them
		- **image**
			- images are a lightweight, standalone, executable package that contains everything needed to run an application, including the code, libraries, dependencies, and configuration files
			- images are built from a Dockerfile, which is a script that contains instructions for creating an image
			- a Dockerfile is used to create a Docker image, which can then be used to create a Docker container
		- **container**
			- Docker containers are running instances of Docker images
			- a place to put each logical part of an application 
			- a Docker container is a running instance of a Docker image
			- to run an image as a container: `docker run ...`			
		- **Dockerfile**
			- the file is called `Dockerfile`
			- a Dockerfile is used to define and create a Docker image, not a container
			- used by Docker Composer
			- it specifies the base image to use, as well as any additional dependencies and configuration required to run the application
		- **docker-compose.yml** file
			- the config file for Docker Compose
			- defines how numerous images will work together to create containers which will function as an application
		- **volumes**
			- where data is kept in the containers
		- **shared local drives**
			- used by volumes
		- **networking**
			- Docker containers must be networked to interact
			- this is defined in the docker-compose.yml files
	- Docker tools
		- **Docker Engine**
			- the core technology that enables containerization
		- **Docker CLI**
			- command line interface that allows you to create and manage containers
		- **Docker Desktop**
			- GUI application that allows developers to create, run, and manage Docker containers on their local machine
			- you don't need Docker Desktop (you could exclusively use the Docker CLI) but it simplifies management of containers
			- originally only ran on Mac and Windows
			- as of **May 2022** available on Linux
				- https://www.docker.com/blog/the-magic-of-docker-desktop-is-now-available-on-linux/
		- **Docker Hub**
			- a central hub for Docker images
			- users can upload their own Docker images to Docker Hub
			- like GitHub provides both public and private repositories
			- free but has paid subscription for increased storage and bandwidth
		- **Docker Compose**
			- allows you to manage multiple containers as an application
			- tool used to define and run multi-container Docker applications
			- allows developers to define a multi-container application as a single unit, specifying the services, networks, and volumes required to run the application
			- developers define their application as a YAML file
				- specifies the containers, images, and configuration options needed for each service in the application
			- good for complex applications that require multiple containers to be deployed together
				- e.g. a web application that requires a web server, a database server, and a caching service
			- others features
				- environment variables 
				- command line overrides
				- enables scaling of application	
		- **Docker vs. Docker Compose**
			- this is actually a difference between the command **docker run** and the comand **docker-compose**
			- docker run is entirely command line based
				- docker-compose reads configuration data from a YAML file
			- docker run can only start one container at a time
				- docker-compose will configure and run multiple containers as an application
	- Docker technologies
		- **Docker Swarm**
			- manages Docker containers at scale
			- a clustering and scheduling tool for Docker containers, allowing users to manage a group of Docker hosts as a single virtual system
			- provides integration with Docker Compose
		- **Docker Swarm vs Docker Compose**
			- both tools are for managing Docker containers
			- Compose: defining and running multi-container Docker applications on a **single host**
			- Swarm: managing and orchestrating Docker containers across **multiple hosts in a cluster**
		- **Docker Swarm vs Kubernetes**
			- basically the same, Kubernetes just has more features	and is the industry standard
			- Docker Swarm is a Docker technology, installed with Docker
			- Kubernetes is a separate software
		- **wasm or WebAssembly modules**
			- a low-level virtual machine that can be used as a compilation target for a variety of programming languages, allowing developers to write code in their preferred language and compile it to wasm for execution in the browser
			- supported by all major web browsers, including Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge
			- ARTICLE: [Why Containers and WebAssembly Work Well Together](https://www.docker.com/blog/why-containers-and-webassembly-work-well-together)
				- heavyweight - virtual machines
				- middleweight - containers
				- lightweight - WebAssembly
	- Docker commands
		- list images
			- `docker images`
		- list containers
			- `docker ps`
		- create an image from a Dockerfile
			- `docker build -t (ACCOUNTNAME)/(IMAGENAME) .`
		- create and run a container from an image
			- `docker run -p 5000:5000 (ACCOUNTNAME)/(IMAGENAME)`
		- delete an image
			- `docker rmi -f 123abc` (123abc = first characters in the image di)
		- stop a container
			- `docker stop 123abc` (123abc = first characters in the container di) 
		- kill a container (if it won't stop)
			- `docker kill 123abc` (123abc = first characters in the container di) 
		- delete an container
			- `docker rm -f 123abc` (123abc = first characters in the container di)
		- push an image to the Docker Hub
			- `docker push (ACCOUNTNAME)/(IMAGENAME)`
		- pull an image from Docker Hub
			- `docker pull (ACCOUNTNAME)/(IMAGENAME)`
- **install Docker Desktop**
	- Mac/Windows/Linux
		- go to docker.com
			- Get Started
			- Docker Desktop
			- follow instructions
	- note that **Docker Desktop** originally was only available on **Windows and Mac**
		- it was created for Linux in **May 2022** and apparently **requires an AMD64 processor and either Ubuntu 21.10 or 22.04**
		- you can of course use Docker without Docker Desktop but it simplifies many tasks and eases one's introduction into Docker
	- **installing on Ubuntu**
		- also go to docker.com
		- note that Docker Desktop on Linux will not recognize images and containers that were made before you install it##notondeksks
		- click Ubuntu
		- click [DEB package] button to download
			- note you apparently need Ubuntu 22.04 and not Ubuntu 20.04##note2204ok
		- follow the instructions to install, e.g. on Ubuntu
			- `sudo apt-get update`
			- `sudo apt-get install (the-path-and-file-name-of-the-deb-file-you-downloaded).deb`
			- ignore "unsandboxed" error
		- easiest: 
			- click on **Show Applications** icon
			- add to favorites on the side
			- start Docker Desktop by clicking on the whale icon
- **get an account at hub.docker.com and log in with Docker Desktop**
	- https://hub.docker.com/signup
	- sign into this account from Docker Desktop##thesignjisjdindock
- **1. Create the simplest Node/Express API container and run other machines**
	- code for this step is here:
		- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/dockerhowto-01nodeexpress
	- create the Node/Express app
		- `npm init -y`
			- "type": "module"
		- `npm i express`
		- `"start": "node index.js"`
		- **index.js**
			--------------------------
			import express from 'express';

			const app = express();
			const port = 5000;

			app.get('/', (req, res) => {
				res.send('this is a test api');
			});

			app.listen(port, () => {
				console.log(`listening at http://localhost:${port}`);
			});
			--------------------------
		- test
	- dockerize it
		- create **.dockerignore**
			---------------------------------
			node_modules
			npm-debug.log
			---------------------------------
		- create **Dockerfile**
			----------------------------------------------------
			FROM node 

			WORKDIR /usr/src/app

			COPY package*.json ./

			RUN npm install

			COPY . . 

			EXPOSE 5000

			CMD ["npm", "start"]
			----------------------------------------------------
		- install Docker extension to make e.g. Dockerfile have hyperlinks##instalvsdcodedocker
		- create image from Dockerfile
			- make sure your Docker Desktop is started and you are signed in
			- `docker build -t edwardtanguay/01nodeexpress .`
				- it downloads the Node image and creates the new image you specified in the docker file
			- `docker images`##anddockimagies
			- and you will then see it in your Docker Desktop##nowseeimagevododck
		- create and run container from image
			- `docker run -p 5001:5000 edwardtanguay/01nodeexpress`
				- host machine: port 5001
				- container: port 5000
			- list containers
				- `docker ps`
		- test in browser:##andthetestwwdock
	- push image to Docker Hub
		- with Docker Desktop##dothepushtodock
	- pull and use image from another machine
		- with Docker Desktop##onaothrmahc
		- had this problem when I click **Pull** on Linux Docker Desktop##520undexpe
		- after a restart, the Pull worked, the image took about 60 seconds to load:##withimagesnow
		- created a container from the image##runningonwnew
		- test in browser##thetest1piaapidadock
	- run container at Hetzner
		- set up machine with Docker
			- server hinzufügen
			- Nürnberg, Apps, Docker CE, CX11, SSH key, erstellen
			- Rescue, Root-Password zurücksetzen
			- Hetzner console, root, einfügen ohne Formatierung
			- add user
				- `useradd -m edward`
				- `passwd edward`
				- `usermod -aG sudo edward`
				- `exit`
			- login from host machine
				- `ssh edward@ipaddress`
		- pull image and run it as container
			- `sudo docker pull edwardtanguay/01nodeexpress2`
			- `sudo docker run -p 5009:5000 edwardtanguay/01nodeexpress2`
			- view at http://ipaddress-of-machine:5009##thwokeronhetz
- **2. Create a Node/Express API that shows data from JSON files, and run other machines**
	- Dockerfile only
	- code is here:
		- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/03nodeexpressdata-backend
		- `docker build -t edwardtanguay/03nodeexpressdata-backend .`
		- `docker run -p 5001:5000 edwardtanguay/03nodeexpressdata-backend`
		- `docker push edwardtanguay/03nodeexpressdata-backend`
	- Linux
		- pulled from Docker Desktop
		- `docker run -p 5000:5000 edwardtanguay/03nodeexpressdata-backend`
		- worked
- **3. Add a React frontend to the above Node/Express API and use docker-compose to create a Docker application that runs on other machines**
	- backend
		- call it "step3reactnodeexpressdata"
		- x set it up again with Dockerfile
			- `docker build -t edwardtanguay/step3reactnodeexpressdata-backend .`
			- `docker run -p 5000:5000 edwardtanguay/03nodeexpressdata-backend`
	- frontend
		- code is here:
			- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/step3reactnodeexpressdata-frontend
		- x set up react and get working alone with Dockerfile
			- **package.json**
				-------------------------
				 "start": "vite serve --host --port 4000",
				-------------------------
			- `docker build -t edwardtanguay/step3reactnodeexpressdata-frontend .`
			- `docker run -p 4000:4000 edwardtanguay/step3reactnodeexpressdata-frontend`
		- x test with container frontend and host backend
	- put both together in docker-compose
		- create in parent directory: **docker-compose.yml**
			---------------------------------------
			#{remove}
			version: "3"
			services:
				client:
					container_name: frontend
					restart: always
					build: ./step3reactnodeexpressdata-frontend
					ports: 
						- "4000:4000"
					links:
					- api
				api:
					container_name: api
					restart: always
					build: ./step3reactnodeexpressdata-backend
					ports: 
					- "5000:5000"
			---------------------------------------
		- `docker-compose build`
		- `docker-compose up`
		- starts both and works: ##thecomsposkjworksdoc

title: Overview of DevOps
body:
- what we will do
	- the purpose of this howto is to **give MERN-stack students** an overview of **DevOps** and everything it entails
	- this is not a practical howto but **a theoretical explanation** which will help the MERN-student to 
		- better understand how their frontend and backend skills fit into **the complete landscape of IT projects** they will be a part of building
		- be able to better **discuss deployment and architecture** in job interviews for developer positions
		- more readily *8take on responsibility of DevOps tasks** and arcitectural planning in IT projects
- why learn about DevOps
	- an increasing number of [jobs](https://jobs.tanguay.eu) require frontend and backend developers to have DevOps skills
	- DevOps skills are becoming more important in our industry as as companies 
		- build more comprehensive **distributed applications**
		- process **larger amounts of data** 
		- continue to move their infrastructures from self-managed hardware to **cloud solutions**
		- demand more agile and **immediate deployment of changes and versioning**
	- MERN-stack curriculums typically lack coverage of the following skills which are nevertheless sought by most companies:
		- TypeScript 
		- testing (Jest, Vitest, Supertest, Cypress, Mocha/Chai)
		- server-side rendering (Next.js)
		- the other two frameworks (Vue.js, Angular)
		- DevOps (Docker, CI/CD, AWS)
- DEVOPS OVERVIEW
	- DevOps is the integration between the "Sofware **Dev**evlopment" and "IT **Op**eration**s**" departments
		- Continuous Integration
			- the **build** and **test** phases
			- testing can be everyting from
				- testing for syntax errors
				- end-to-end testing of software
			- the process of combining updates into an existing code base
		- Continuous Delivery = relase, deploy
			- Continuous Deployment = the term used when this process is **completely automated**
				- practed by 
					- brand new start-ups where agility is more important than liability
					- well-establish companies that have built up 100% testing to catch all issues automatically
			- gets your updates into the hands of the users
			- may be 
				- an upload of a file to be downloaded 
				- setting up a website
			- usually has release events
				- times when it will have low-impact on users
	- it solved the problem of the disconnect between creating software and deploying it
	- one can say that as DevOps became increasingly automated, it developed the CI/CD approach
	- became common around 2010 in larger projects to automate work between these two groups 
	- trend/concept: **as-a-service**
		- SaaS - Software-as-a-Service
			- Slack
			- Google Docs
			- Dropbox
		- PaaS - Platform-as-a-Service
			- Heroku, Cyclic, Render.com
			- AWS Beanstalk
		- IaaS - Infrastructure-as-a-Service 	
			- AWS
			- Azure
	- **the DevOps life-cycle**
		- development stages: plan, code, build, test
		- operational stages: release, deploy, operate, monitor##devopslifescyle
	- if you are a web developer, you basically have three areas in which you need skills
		- Frontend
		- Backend
		- DevOps
		- here is a good overview, from 2020, but still servers as a relevant orientation guide and checklist for the scope of technologies that one should know as a web developer today
			- https://coggle.it/diagram/XfeRbWj7xy3dsEX8/t/web-development-in-2020
	- [DevOps Graphical Overview](https://coggle.it/diagram/ZBqphgAjwnrfsZ0h/t/devops)##devopscoggg11122233
- **== Infrastructure Platforms =====**
	- **AWS**
		- **AWS Lambda**
			- 2014 introduced
			- a computing service that runs code in response to events and automatically manages the computing resources required by that code
			- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AWS_Lambda		
	- **Azure**
		- ARM (Azure Resource Manager) - Microsoft's deployment and management service for Azure, used to create, update, and delete Azure resources		
	- **Google Cloud**
	- simpler infrastructure
		- **DigitalOcean**
		- **Hetzner**
	- alternatives
		- **OpenStack**
			- created 2010
			- often seen as an **alternative to AWS and Azure**
			- **freely available** under the Apache 2.0 license
				- you may be more on your own
			- written in Python
			- main site: https://www.openstack.org
			- a collection of modules called projects
			- can used many computers to perform big data tasks
			- a set of software components that provide common services for cloud infrastructure
			- a free, open standard cloud computing platform
			- mostly deployed as infrastructure-as-a-service 
			- no LinkedIn videos	
- **== Container Virtualization =====**
	- **Docker**
		- the de facto standard for building containers and running them in various environments
	- small scale
		- deploy and run containers on DigitalOcean or Hetzner
	- medium scale 
		- **Docker Swarm**
			- Article: [Docker Swarm on DigitalOcean](https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-create-a-cluster-of-docker-containers-with-docker-swarm-and-digitalocean-on-ubuntu-16-04)	
		- **AWS Fargate**
			- Linked-In-Learning course:
				- 2019-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/aws-devops-continuous-docker-deployment-to-aws-fargate-from-gitlab
			- a serverless, pay-as-you-go compute engine that lets you focus on building applications without managing servers
	- large scale
		- **Kubernetes**
			- a complex framework for orchestrating containers
			- main site: https://kubernetes.io
			- 2019,de: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/kubernetes-grundlagen-fur-entwickler
		- tools that work with Kubernetes
			- **Helm**
				- a package manager for running apps on Kubernetes
				- main site: https://helm.sh	
				- Linked-In-Learning course:
					- 2020-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/kubernetes-package-management-with-helm
			- **Rancher**
				- is not an alternative solution to Kubernetes
				- it manages multiple Kubernetes clusters
				- main site: https://www.rancher.com
				- adds a complete UI and workload management layer to Kubernetes
				- a framework for managing and orchestrating containers or Kubernetes clusters
			- **Istio**
				- an open source service mesh that layers transparently onto existing distributed applications
				- Istio’s control plane runs on Kubernetes
				- main site: https://istio.io/latest/about/service-mesh
				- service mesh
					- a dedicated infrastructure layer for facilitating service-to-service communications between services or microservices, using a proxy
					- provides a set of tools and services for managing and controlling the interactions between microservices, including traffic routing, load balancing, service discovery, security, and observability
					- in a service mesh architecture, each microservice is equipped with a sidecar proxy that intercepts and manages all network traffic to and from the microservice
					- popular service mesh solutions include Istio, Linkerd, and Envoy				
				- Linked-In-Learning course:
					- 2018-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/kubernetes-monitoring-with-prometheus
	- container registries
		- container registry
			- a software application that is used to store, manage, and distribute container images
			- provides a central location for storing and sharing container images among developers, testers, and other stakeholders in the software development and deployment process
		- articles
			- [How to Choose a Container Registry: The Top 9 Picks](https://bluelight.co/blog/how-to-choose-a-container-registry)
		- **Docker Hub**
			- the most popular container registry as it is the default Docker Repository
		- **Amazon ECR**
			- main site: https://aws.amazon.com/de/ecr
		- **GitHub Package Registry**
			- 2020 release support for container images
			- not the container registry packed with the most features
			- but the price is lower in comparison
			- main site: https://github.com/features/packages
		- **Sonatype Nexus**
			- used by software development teams to store, manage and distribute software artifacts, such as libraries, dependencies, and components, across the development lifecycle
			- provides a central location for teams to share and distribute components 
			- helps with the management of software development workflows and builds
			- manages components, binaries and build artifacts across software supply chains
			- supports various repository formats such as Maven, Docker, npm, RubyGems, PyPI
			- main site: https://www.sonatype.com/products/nexus-repository
			- no Linked-In-Learning courses	
	- virutal machines
		- VirtualBox
			- a free operating-system virtualization package from Oracle 
			- Linked-In-Learning:
				- 2020-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/learning-virtualbox-2
		- KVM
			- s smaller and faster than VirtualBox, but VirtualBox is more scalable
			- KVM is better integrated with Linux, and while it will work with other guests, it works best with Linux
		- **Vagrant**
			- used to preserve purpose-build, isolated development environments
			- a Vagrant VM is frozen in time
			- main site: https://www.vagrantup.com
			- think of Vagrant as a scripting engine for VirtualBox
			- Stack Overflow: [Why should I use Vagrant instead of just VirtualBox?](https://superuser.com/questions/584100/why-should-i-use-vagrant-instead-of-just-virtualbox)
			- "Don't use vagrant if you dont need it. Use vagrant when you find creating VMs is becoming tedious."
			- Linked-In-Learning:
				- 2018-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/learning-vagrant				
		- LXC and LXD
			- 2008 created
			- an operating-system-level virtualization software
			- LXC containers are very much like a virtual machine, but significantly lighter weight since it is sharing the host kernel with the LXC host.
			- *"a common confusion for potential users of LXD is that LXD is an alternative to Docker or Kubernetes. However, LXD and Docker are not competing container technologies, and they tend to serve completely different purposes"*
			- LXC provides a simple and lightweight containerization solution, while LXD provides a more complete management and orchestration platform for containers			
- **== Server and Configuration Management =====**
	- concepts
		- infrastructure-as-code
		- provisioning
			- automatically setting up and configuring the infrastructure required to build, test, and deploy software applications
			- when a new version of the software is ready to be tested or deployed, the CI/CD system triggers a provisioning process that creates the necessary environment for that version. This environment could include virtual machines, containers, databases, load balancers, or other components needed for the software to run
			- is typically automated using tools like Terraform or Ansible	
	- comparisons
		- VIDEO: [Chef vs Puppet vs Ansible vs Saltstack](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_TVNCTK808I)
	- **Terraform**
		- 2014 created by HashiCorp
		- it is a **command-line program**
		- it is also a **language**##tehterrasform
		- free and open-source
		- lets you provision, manage and maintain cloud resources
			- servers
			- storage
			- networking
		- an **infrastructure-as-code** software tool 
		- HCL: HashiCorp Configuration Language
		- rather than using imperative commands to provision resources
			- Terraform uses **declarative configuration** to describe the desired final state
		- often used with AWS
		- LinkedIn-Learning
			- 2022-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/learning-terraform-15575129	
	- **Ansible**
		- 2012 created
		- 2015 acquired by Red Hat
		- configures both Unix-like and Microsoft Windows
		- a suite of software tools that enables **infrastructure as code**
		- Linked-In-Learning course:
			- 2021-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/ansible-essential-training-14199798
	- **Salt** (also known as **SaltStack**)
		- an open-source configuration management and automation software tool used to manage and provision servers, cloud resources, and software applications
		- main site: https://docs.saltproject.io/en/getstarted
		- no Linked-In-Learning courses
	- **Puppet**
		- configuration management tool
		- a configuration management tool that automates the deployment and management of software and systems
		- LinkedIn
			- 2015-de: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/konfigurationsmanagement-mit-puppet	
	- **Chef**
		- 2008 created
		- configuration management tool
		- automates the process of deploying and managing software applications and infrastructure
		- uses a declarative approach to define the desired state of servers, workstations, and other computing devices
		- concepts: kitchen, recipes and cookbooks
			- how to install, configure, and manage specific software packages, applications, or services
		- key benefit
			- ability to automate the entire software deployment process, from initial installation and configuration to ongoing maintenance and updates
		- LinkedIn
			- 2017-en https://www.linkedin.com/learning/learning-chef
	- **AWS CloudFormation**
		- one of the pioneer tools that allowed infrastructure to be expressed as code
		- Linked-In-Learning course:
			- 2019-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/learning-aws-cloudformation
		- expressed in JSON or YAML format##cloudformksjdf
		- cloud formation services##thecloudformation				
- **== Operational Visibility =====**
	- **Monitoring**
		- **Grafana**
			- 2014 created
			- main site: https://grafana.com
			- try the interactive [Grafana sandbox](https://play.grafana.org)
			- **free and open-source** software licensed under the Apache License 2.0
				- Grafana Labs also supports commercial features
			- you can get a **free forever plan** to test it out
			- written in TypeScript (frontend) and Go (backend)
			- expandable through plugin system
			- an analytics and interactive visualization tool that helps devops visualize and analyze system data in real-time
			- mainly targets **time-series databases** such as InfluxDB, Prometheus and Graphite
			- Linked-In-Learning course:
				- https://www.linkedin.com/learning/graphite-and-grafana-visualizing-application-performance
			- evolved to support MySQL, PostgreSQL and Microsoft SQL Server.#gif#grafanahshow
		- **DataDog**
			- main site: https://www.datadoghq.com
			- Linked-In-Learning course:
				- https://www.linkedin.com/learning/monitoring-and-observability-with-datadog
			- an observability service for cloud-scale applications, providing monitoring, tracing, debugging of servers, databases, tools, and services##thedatadogsdf
		- **New Relic**
			- monitors Web and mobile applications in real-time
			- **not free**, has various paid plans
			- main site: https://newrelic.com##thenewreleic
		- **Sentry**
			- an open-source error tracking and monitoring software that helps developers identify and fix errors in their applications
			- has a **hard-to-understand business model**
				- you can use the open source version of Sentry, which is free, by pulling it down from GitHub and hosting it yourself
				- there is a limited [free tier](https://sentry.io/pricing) for the hosted service plus many paid plans
			- detailed error reports, including stack traces
			- main site: https://sentry.io
			- integration with GitHub, Slack, and Jira##thesentrysok
		- **Prometheus**
			- event monitoring and alerting software written in Go
			- main site: https://prometheus.io	
			- Linked-In-Learning course:
				- 2018-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/kubernetes-monitoring-with-prometheus
		- **Nagios**
			- open-source tool used for monitoring IT infrastructure such as servers, applications, network devices, and services
			- originally developed in 1999
			- Linked-In-Learning course:
				- 2018-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/learning-nagios
		- **AWS CloudWatch**
			- resources monitored by CloudWatch##watchedbycloudwatch
	- **Logging**
		- **ELK Stack** - or "Elastic Stack"
			- **Elasticsearch**
				- both this and Apache Solr are based on Lucene
			- **Logstash**
				- a tool to collect, analyze and store logs
			- **Kibana**
				- open source data visualization dashboard for Elasticsearch
			- Beats
				- lightweight, purpose-built agents that acquire data and then feed it to Elasticsearch
			- can also be expensive
				- leave the authentication capabilities to the enterprise edition
			- search is fast
			- Linked-In-Learning course:
				- 2020-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/learning-the-elastic-stack-2
		- **Sematext**
			- main site: https://sematext.com
			- see live demo: https://apps.sematext.com/ui/integrations/apps##tehsematextok
		- **GrayLog**
			- an open-source log management platform that collects, indexes, and analyzes large volumes of machine-generated log data from various sources
			- allows users to search and visualize log data from multiple sources in real-time
			- offers features such as alerting, dashboards, reporting
			- compared to [Kibana and Splunk](https://thehftguy.com/2020/08/04/the-differences-between-splunk-kibana-and-graylog)
				- they are 90% the same
				- they all work well and at scale
				- they can all be expensive
			- consists of several components, including 
				- a web interface
				- a server for collecting and processing log data
				- uses **Elasticsearch** for indexing and storing the data
				-  a RESTful API for interacting with the platform programmatically
			- main site: https://www.graylog.org
			- no Linked-in-Learing courses
		- **Splunk**
			- a tool for analyzing and searching incoming machine-generated data like application or database logs
			- very expensive, *puts Oracle to shame*
			- ideal for monitoring the health of IT infrastructure, especially networks with complex and aging systems, and software in production
			- main competitor: ELK
			- performance in search is abysmal
				- whereas ElasticSearch (Graylog and Kibana) can complete the same search just fine in a couple seconds
			- has good support for join and transformations
				- ELK does not
			- main site: https://www.splunk.com
			- has dashboards for visual insights 
			- Linked-In-Learning course:
				- 2018-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/learning-splunk
	- **Big data**
		- **Apache projects**
			- **Hadoop**
				- 2006 created
				- pr. [hah-DOOP]
				- a collection of open-source software utilities that facilitate using a **network of many computers** to solve problems involving **massive amounts of data and computation**
					- uses a network of computers to solve problems such as data crunching and computation
				- an open source framework that is used to efficiently store and process large datasets ranging in size from gigabytes to petabytes of data
				- Apache project
				- consists of a storage part, known as Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS), and a processing part which is a MapReduce programming model
				- Internet used to only have documents
					- Big Data: around 2005 this changed to be all kinds of data: videos, audio, images, emails, etc.
				- two parts
					- 1. HDFS stores data in numerous sources
						- fault-tolerant
					- 2. MapReduce
						- processes separately and then collects data together
				- works together with others tools for Big Data management
					- **Apache Hive**
						- s SQL-like query language taht generates MapReduce code
					- **Apache Pig**
						- ETL library for Hadoop
							- an abstract language
						- **ETL = Extract, Transform, Load**
							- a data integration process that combines data from multiple data sources into a single, consistent data store that is loaded into a data warehouse or other target system
					- **Apache Spark**
						- 2014 created
						- in-memory distributed data analysis
							- enables **faster queries**
						- an open-source distributed general-purpose cluster-computing framework
						- Cloudera Impala were vendor-added features to Hadoop
							- Spark is the open-source community's response to this
				- Linked-In-Learning course:
					- 2020-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/learning-hadoop-2		
			- **Kafka**
				- also an Apache project
				- an open-source distributed event streaming platform used by thousands of companies for high-performance data pipelines, streaming analytics, data integration, and mission-critical applications
				- Linked-In-Learning course:
					- 2019-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/learn-apache-kafka-for-beginners
		- time-series databases 
			- InfluxDB
				- an open-source time series database that is designed to handle high write and query loads of time-stamped data
				- main site: https://www.influxdata.com
				- uses a SQL-like query language called InfluxQL 
				- Linked-In-Learning course:
					- https://www.linkedin.com/learning/introduction-to-influxdb
			- Graphite		
				- does two things
					- stores numeric time-series data
					- renders graphs on this data on demand
				- main site: https://graphite.readthedocs.io/en/latest/overview.html
				- Linked-In-Learning course:
					- 2018-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/graphite-and-grafana-visualizing-application-performance
						- (Graphite with Grafana)
- **== Continuous Integration / Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) =====**
	- Linked-In-Learning course:
		- 2020-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/continuous-integration-tools
	- hosted solutions
		- **GitHub Actions**
			- Linked-In-Learning course:
				- 2021-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/learning-github-actions-2
		- **CircleCI**
			- uses Docker containers to build CI/CD steps
			- main site: https://circleci.com
			- watch demonstration: https://circleci.com/product/demo
			- free tier: 
				- 1000 build units each month
				- unlimited number of repos
				- online one container
			- Orbs
				- sharable packages of CircleCI configuration
			- YAML configuration files##ymlconfigfiles
			- various stages have dependencies on other stages##thecirclisi
		- **Codeship**
			- main site: https://www.cloudbees.com/products/codeship
			- two versions
				- Codeship Basic
					- free
					- 100 builds/month
					- 1 concurrent build
					- unlimited users and teams
				- Codeship Pro
					- priced
				- uses Python 
			- codeship.yml
				- stored in repository along with the respositories code##thecodeship
			- shows build steps##thesecondcodeship
		- **GitLab**
			- can be used like GitHub: https://gitlab.com
			- Linked-In-Learning course:
				- 2022-en: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/continuous-integration-and-continuous-delivery-with-gitlab
	- internal solutions
		- **GitLab**
			- originally focused on source control like GitHub
			- vs GitHub
				- GitHub primary competitor 
				- GitLab strives to be an end-to-end CI/CD solution in a way that GitHub does not
					- e.g. adopting GitLab over GitHub might allow you to replace Jenkins
				- but GitLab is plug-and-play flexible, doesn't force you to use their solutions
		- **Jenkins**
			- automation framework
			- used in the build, test, release and deploy stages##jenkscycle
			- once test has passed, the artifact can be moved to the next stage
			- Linked-In-Learning courses:
				- 2022-en**: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/jenkins-essential-training-17420152
				- 2017,de: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/jenkins-grundkurs	
		- **Gradle**

- **== Microservices =====**
	- a architecture style that structures an application as a collection of services that are:
		- small
		- independent
		- loosely coupled
		- widely distributed
	- building on efficiencies of DevOps and CI/CD, microservices increase speed at which software can be updated and deployed
		- smaller teams responsible for one services (e.g. orders) can make a quick change and deloy it without redeploying the whole application	
	- concepts 
		- functional decomposition
		- each service manages its data source
			- data access to it is only via the service's API
			- encourages event-driven architecture
	- advantages
		- enables smaller and more focused teams 
		- fits better into a CI/CD structure
		- more scalable
		- more flexible
			- you can deploy smaller changes more easily
				- e.g. the shopping-cart team can continually make small improvements that customers see without launching a new application version
		- more resilient
			- if one service fails, the others can gracefully react
	- disadvantages
		- complexity
		- partial failure
		- split up databases, but still need transitions
		- testing is more complicated
		- deploying can be more complex
		- but there are solutions to most of these problems now
			- monoliths tend to not have solutions to their drawbacks

JSON does not allow single quotes to define strings, **only double quotes** - 2. **key names must be enclosed in quotes**, and of course with double quotes - 3. JSON parameters cannot end with a **trailing comma** - 4. JSON **cannot contain functions** - a JavaScript object with functions will be converted to a JSON object without functions##tehcomparjs - **who invented JSON and when and why?** - Douglas Crockford in 2001 - he also wrote JavaScript: The Good Parts, 2008, a pivotal book that lead to more JavaScript acceptance - **what did we use to transfer data before JSON?** - XML - and before that, various text and binary formats - **what is the basic structure of a JSON file?** - either an **object** or an **array** - learn to use JSON - **tools used to transform JSON** - online tools - [Convert Javascript Object to JSON](https://www.convertsimple.com/convert-javascript-to-json/) - *lenient, just has to be a JavaScript object* ----------------------------------------------- { firstName: 'Robert', "lastName": "Hansandi", "fullName": function() { return this.firstName + ' ' + this.lastName;
