body:
- creating this site will be useful for two reasons: - the site itself is informative to anyone looking for a web developer job as it lists **current webdev job ads** and **which skills are in most demand** - technically, it will show you how to use **TypeScript** in a real-world frontend/backend application - the final code can be found here: - nnn - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et005-jobskills-frontend - the final site works like this - nnn - **== WHAT IS TYPESCRIPT? ==** - since this howto serves as an **introduction to pragmatic TypeScript**, let's briefly discuss what TypeScript is - background - TypeScript is a **strongly-typed superset of JavaScript** - **superset** means that everything in JavaScript is also in TypeScript, but not visa versa - **strongly-typed** means that you are forced to define the type of every variable you use, e.g. - base language types such as string, number, boolean or HTMLAnchorElement ------------------------------------------- const createEmployee = (lastName: string, age: number, signedContract: boolean) => { ... } ------------------------------------------- - types in npm packages you use, such as in Express ---------------------------------------------- app.get('/', (req: express.Request, res: express.Response) => { res.send(model.getApiInstructions()); }); ---------------------------------------------- - custom types that you create such as IEmployee, ICustomer ------------------------------------------------ interface IEmployee { firstName: string; lastName: string; notes: string; } const employees: IEmployee[] = []; ------------------------------------------------ - **Anders Hejlsberg** works for Microsoft, created **C# in 2002**, and created **TypeScript in 2012** - this is one reason there are many similarities between C# and JavaScript - TypeScript gives JavaScript many of the advantages of strongly-typed languages such as C# and Java##andershejlsberg - advantages of TypeScript - **type safety** - catches errors at runtime - will not build the application or allow you to publish your code live until you fix all type errors - **intellisense on variables** - since all properties of objects are known, VSCode will give you a nice dropdown of all properites of objects, even on your custom objects such as IEmployee - **makes code more understandable** - if you want to know what properties an object might have in the application, you look at its interface (type) - with JavaScript, you never know what properties might be added to an object somewhere else in the code - **easier to refactor code** - you can add or remove a property of an object and TypeScript will inform of every change you need to make everywhere in your application so that this change will cause no errors - **TypeScript serves as a linter** - it makes sure your code is more organized and will easily find typos, e.g. will inform you if object properties are not spelled correctly - **TypeScript servers as a testing tool** - TypeScript guarantees the internal consistency of variable types, e.g. that all uses in your application of a functions, actually sends the correct types of variables to the function as parameters, e.g. that a number is not sent when a string is expected - **less bugs** - once you get TypeScript running smoothly in your applications, you'll notice you have less bugs, particulary less sloppy bugs caused by misspellings, typos, misunderstandings, use of wrong variables, ambiguous variable names, lack of planning and organization, etc. - disadvantages of TypeScript - **steep learning curve** - but the invested time is in most cases worth spending particularly if you work with large, complicated applications - **time-consuming frustration** - particularly with always having to define and find types for variables, even for variables in system and third-party packages - but in the end you always find them, and the more experience you accumulate, the faster you get in resolving missing type issues - **compilation overhead** - TypeScript needs to be compiled, which when developing a Node/Express site with TypeScript typically means waiting a few seconds after every code change for the TypeScript to compile to JavaScript and be ready to run - on the frontend, frameworks like Vite reduce this compile time to a negligably short time - **issues with third-party npm packages that don't have good TypeScript support** - some npm packages have better TypeScript support than others and when using npm packages, one often spends time looking for the right definitions - but for the most part, most popular npm packages are TypeScript compatible and installing the @types/packagename types is quick and works well, e.g. ------------------------------------------ npm i -D @types/lodash ------------------------------------------ - for some packages such as Jest, there are other packages with better TypeScript support, e.g. instead of **Jest**, use **Vitest** which was created to be a kind of Jest clone that is designed from the beginning to be compatible with ES6 modules and TypeScript - **can be difficult to get set up** - TypeScript can be difficult to set up in your programming environment since - TypeScript does not run natively in the browser or in Node - therefore TypeScript needs to be converted into JavaScript before your code can be executed - this involves some kind of (1) observation of code changes, and (2) a build process when those changes are made - on the frontend - build tools such as Vite completely solve this problem and make programming in TypeScript a seemless, immediate experience - on the backend - there is a setup process which involves using nodemon to observe the changes in code, then transpile TypeScript into JavaScript and run it each time there is a change in the code ----------------------------------------------- "scripts": { "dev": "nodemon", "build": "tsc" }, "nodemonConfig": { "watch": [ "src" ], "ext": "ts", "exec": "npm run build && node dist/server.js" }, ----------------------------------------------- - once you get TypeScript running on the backend once, you can use it for other projects - my [starter sites](https://starters.tanguay.eu) are all based on TypeScript and ES6 modules both frontend and backend, feel free to use them as templates which have TypeScript up and running - **avoid misunderstandings in TypeScript** - 1. **TypeScript does not check types at runtime** - TypeScript only exists - **during development**, e.g. VSCode will inform you if you use a function and send a parameter with the wrong type - **during build time**, e.g. your build will fail (and thus will not be published live at e.g. Vercel or Netlify) if there are any type inconsistencies - **TypeScript does not exist at runtime at all** - type script **compiles to plain JavaScript** which is run in the browser or in Node - this means that at run time, **TypeScript interfaces do not exist**, and **type checking is not performed at all** - in particular, this means that if your app fetches data from an external source such as an API, **there is no guarantee that the data you fetch from external sources will conform to the interfaces or types** - therefore if you fetch external data in your application, you have to check it at runtime - one of the best tools to verify the structure of data from external sources is **Zod** which works well with TypeScript, e.g. you can define Zod types based on TypeScript types - if you have never heard of Zod, let [Kyle](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9UVPk0Ulm6U) or [Theo]([Zod](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9UVPk0Ulm6U)) give you a quick overview - 2. **interfaces** and **types** are the same thing in TypeScript (more or less) - there are slight differences but both are commonly used and these terms can usually be used interchangeably - I tend to use interfaces since - this is a convention in C# which I programmed in for decades - when you use interfaces, it's common to prefix your interface names with an "I" so you have IEmployees and ICustomers - this makes it clearer when you look at the code what is an interface and what is not - types are typically named e.g. Employee or Customer, which can be easily confused with e.g. the name of a component, etc. - **tips for developing with TypeScript** - when using TypeScript, ChatGPT is your friend - particularly when TypeScript is complaining that a system variable such as an event object needs to have a type, simply ask ChatGPT - my experience is that ChatGPT will either give you the exact type you need, or it will get close and thereby give you useful terms and type names to google in order to find it yourself##chatgggafortype - learning by doing the best way to learn TypeScript - TypeScript can't be learned in a day or week, but over months by using it, having problems with it, solving those problems, and constantly learning new features - the best way to start is to choose a non-critical project and develop it with TypeScript, frontend and backend - you'll run into many problems, eventually solve them, and that's how you'll get good with TypeScript - title: How to copy the contents of a file to the clipboard on Windows, Linux and Mac
body:
- one sometimes has to copy the contents of a file onto the clipboard in order to paste it elsewhere
- this is common when e.g. you set up an SSH key, when you have to copy the public key to an external website
- here are commands to do this on each operating system
- Windows: 
	- `clip < id_ed25519.pub`
- Ubuntu:
	- `xclip -selection clipboard < ~/.ssh/id_ed255519.pub`
- Macbook
	- `pbcopy < ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub`

title: Set up a Vite React-Router site with Tailwind/Sass that uses Google fonts
How to set up Sass to use in website development
body:
- since **browsers do not understand Sass**, you have to have some way to convert your Sass code (in a `.scss` file) to CSS (in a .css file) - this is **similar to TypeScript** and JavaScript - browsers cannot understand TypeScript (`.ts` files), so it has to be converted to JavaScript (`.js` files) - the following are four ways to set up your web development environment to be able to use Sass - **1. VSCode Extension** - if you are creating a simple HTML/CSS website, e.g. `index.html` and `main.css` - the easiest way to set up Sass is by installing the [Live Sass Compiler](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=glenn2223.live-sass) extension for VSCode - be sure to install the version by **Glenn Marks** - not the version by *Ritwick Dey*, which is deprecated - **index.html** ------------------------------- Info Site

Info Site

Welcome to this page.

------------------------------- - **main.css** --------------------------------- * { margin: 0; padding: 0; box-sizing: border-box; } body { font-family: arial; padding: 2rem; } h1 { color: brown; margin-bottom: 1rem; } --------------------------------- - in VSCode, install the [Live Sass Compiler](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=glenn2223.live-sass) extension - change the name of your `main.css` file to `main.scss.` - **do not change** the reference to the `main.css` file in the link:##donotchangethecss - the extension will automatically generated a **main.css** file from **main.scss** - in your bottom task bar of VSCode, look for the words "Watch Sass" and click it - note you may have to expand the width your VSCode application as wide as possible to see it - click on **Watch Sass**##nowlookkdjfsd - note as soon as you click on Watch Sass, a `main.css` file is created - now everytime you change your **.scss** file, your **.css** file will be automatically regenerated - to turn it off, click "Watching..." in the bottom task bar - **2. node-sass** - I've experienced that the above VSCode extension sometimes doesn't work for one reason or the other - if that is the case, you can similarly set up automatic **scss-to-css** conversion with **node-sass** - to test this, start with the same HTML and CSS files above - set up your site as an npm project - `npm init -y` which will create a **package.json** file - install **node-sass** - `npm i -D node-sass` - `i` = install - `-D` = as a dev dependency##nodesassinsal - change your **main.css** file to **main.scss** - convert the file with this command -------------------------------------------------- ./node_modules/node-sass/bin/node-sass ./css/main.scss ./css/main.css -------------------------------------------------- - everytime you make a change to your SCSS file, simply run this command again, i.e. press **up-arrow** and **Enter** in your terminal - create a simpler npm script - **todo** - set node-sass up to watch and convert your file automatically after every change - **todo** - for options 3 and 4, we use - the static site generator **Vite** - takes care of both of these conversions automatically - you won't even have a `.css` file in your directory since this is converted on the fly and sent to your browser - note that we don't use the live-server extension anymore since Vite has its own server - we will also install TypeScript so we can use both Sass and TypeScript directly and automatically - **3. Vite Vanilla** - install manually - `npm create vite` - give our project a name e.g. `et020-info-site` - this will be the name of the directory it creates - choose **Vanilla** - choose **TypeScript** - open your project in VSCode - `code et020-info-site` - in VSCode terminal - `npm i` - installs node_modules - `npm run dev` - start the site - open in browser - click URL link that appears in terminal - install Sass - in terminal: `npm i -D sass` - change both file name and reference to file name in import statement to `.scss` - for a pre-styled version with dark theme, download or clone this project - https://starters.tanguay.eu/list/darkViteVanilla - **4. Vite React** - install manually - `npm create vite` - give our project a name e.g. `et021-info-site` - this will be the name of the directory it creates - choose **React** - choose **TypeScript** - open your project in VSCode - `code et021-info-site` - in VSCode terminal - `npm i` - installs node_modules - `npm run dev` - start the site - open in browser - click URL link that appears in terminal - install Sass - in terminal: `npm i -D sass` - change both file name and reference to file name in import statement to `.scss` - for a pre-styled version with dark theme, download or clone this project - https://starters.tanguay.eu/list/darkViteSimple

title: How to Refactor a React Site with React Router, JSON-data loading, a searchbox and Tailwind
body:
- **what we will do**
	- this howto allows you to compare two React projects for **learning purposes**:
		- 1. a React site created by a beginning React student
		- 2. the completely refactored site
	- while this howto is mainly for learning purposes, the finished site is also a good template for good React application structure:
		- completely **responsive**
		- uses **TypeScript**
		- uses **Tailwind-only for styling**
		- uses **React Router**
		- has **numerous components** including page components and regular components
		- loads various **Google fonts**
		- loads and displays **data from a JSON file**
		- has a **search box** that searches books as you type
		- has a **nicely-styled** light/dark toggle
	- so while this howto is mainly to demonstrate good app design and refactoring
		- you can also use it as a template for a site with the above features
- **where to find the site**
	- the original, unrefactored site
		- GitHub repository
			- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et01-bookstore-react-tailwind-unrefactored
		- Vercel site
			- https://et01-bookstore-react-tailwind-is8j.vercel.app
	- the refactored site
		- GitHub repository
			- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et01-bookstore-react-tailwind
		- Vercel site
			- https://et01-bookstore-react-tailwind.vercel.app
- **what the site looks like when finished**#gif#booksitedemo
- **Refactoring**
	- in this howto the main topic is how we refactor the site step-by-step
	- if you are looking for a howto or template for a React site, particularly one with Tailwind set up, simply use the [finished version](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et01-bookstore-react-tailwind) of this project
	- note that I don't do any refactoring of the **Tailwind** implementation 
		- the fact that this site has Tailwind built in is one reason I decided to refactor it
		- I wanted to have a solid example of a small React website with many features such as React Router, TypeScript, JSON-data and Tailwind
- **REFACTOR: Reduce two contexts to one AppContext**
	- this site had a ActiveContext for books and a SearchContext for searching
	- this was a misunderstand by the student
	- in a small to mid-sized React app, you simply need one context named **AppContext**
		- the idea is **all of your components** in your **App** get their data from this context, hence it is called **AppContext**##thectwocontexts
	- here's the cleaner **AppContext** with variables from both former contexts:##cleanedupappcontext
	- compare to the [finished AppContext](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et01-bookstore-react-tailwind/blob/main/src/AppContext.tsx)
- **REFACTOR: Unnecessary handling function**
	- this is an example of misunderstanding the state variables and functions can be used directly by event handliners like onClick
	- you don't need to create a "useless middleman" handling function##unnecessaryhandle
- **REFACTOR: Also import books into and serve from AppContext**
	- instead of loading books directly from a component
		- we load books into the AppContext so that book information is avaiable via the AppContext throughout our application##booksalsoinappcon
- **REFACTOR: Put data in a data file, code in a code file**
	- the book data in an array that was embedded in code in a data.ts file
	- we refactored this into a books.json file to have **separation of concerns**
		- data is nothing more than data in its own file
		- code is in a code file and fetches the data from the data file
	- this enables us to use our JSON file much like a database 
		- which will make a future modification to instead get the data from a database or API instead much easier##notfromdatajs
	- here's how the JSON file then looks##hereshowjson
- **REFACTOR: Loaded books from AppContext**
	- after the book data was in its own JSON file
		- we wrote the code to load the books into the AppContext
		- so that it would be available to any component in the app
		- [line 2 in AppContext](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et01-bookstore-react-tailwind/blob/main/src/AppContext.tsx) not shown here is: `import _books from './data/books.json';`##hereshowjson
- **REFACTOR: Replace URLSearchParams search with a state variable**
	- there was a [creative but misguided implementation for search](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et01-bookstore-react-tailwind-unrefactored/blob/dev/src/components/SearchBox.tsx) in this app which used URLSearchParams
		- it was changing the URL by adding the search text and then would read the URL to get the search text in another component (!)
	- we replaced all that with a standard state-variable **filter** which is handled in **AppContext** and so is used to change and use the current search keywords
	- the SearchBox.tsx is much more straight-forward now:##sonowthefilter
- **REFACTOR: Simplified pages and directory structure**
	- I then renamed the page componenets with a **Page** prefix
		- this allows you to have a page component called e.g. **PageBooks** while components can be called **Books** and **Book** etc.
	- the **PageBooks.tsx** file then reads in the params, e.g. `localhost:5714/books/8` and loads the appropriate component, very straight-forward##smpplifedfiles
	- this allows the **Book.tsx** component to remain simple and simply display a book, and nothing more##thebooksimple
	- note the example of passing a prop
- **REFACTOR: Fix the Vercel 404 error with React Router**
	- in order for permalinks on React-Router pages to work at Vercel, you have to add this file to the root directory
	- **vercel.json**
		-------------------------------------------------
		{
			"rewrites": [{ "source": "/(.*)", "destination": "/" }]
		}
		-------------------------------------------------
- **Note on Tailwind styles**
	- if you find yourself repeating Tailwind styles in elements
		- you can use the @apply keyword to create CSS-stylesheet-like styles##thestylesoksi

title: Overview of CSS tools and solutions based on a Theo video
body:
- **what this howto covers**
	- this is an overview of CSS tools
	- it is based on 
		- a video by Theo from November 2022: [CSS in 2023 - Tailwind vs MUI vs Bootstrap vs Chakra vs...](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CQuTF-bkOgc)
	- Theo calls this video a "love letter to Tailwind", through it is an explanation why Tailwind, particularly when used in a component architecture such as React, allows you to reach Zen mode when styling your applications, it reduces friction, styles are there where they need to be, in your JSX
	- Theo maps out a good classification of CSS tools:##theosoverviewcss
- **CATEGORY: CSS++**
	- **Sass**
		- nice, ubiquitous solution
		- variables, nesting, mixins, partials, operators, conditional statements
			see: https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/howtos?id=630
		- https://sass-lang.com/guide
	- **Tailwind**
		- because Tailwind provides solid design concepts, it takes a good bit of effort to make something ugly with it
		- when you learn Chakra and MUI, you learn Chakra and MUI, when you learn Tailwind, you're getting better at CSS
		- Tailwind is just CSS but easier to write
		- Tailwind allows you to own your style system		
		- nice cheat sheet for Tailwind, keep it open on your second monitor when you are learning Tailwind
			- https://nerdcave.com/tailwind-cheat-sheet
		- I don't think in 24px anymore for padding, I think in Tailwind's padding##tehpaddinkjs
		- the easiest tool that allows you to write CSS in a consistent way
		- it's the first time I've felt not only good but great writing styles after a decade of various solutions
		- it makes you fast at styling
		- it doesn't enforce a ceiling on the quality of what I can ship, e.g. as component libraries like MUI and Chakra do
		- Tailwind is changing a lot of things about how we architect our applications
		- but what do I do if I am using Tailwind and need a datepicker?
			- I google react date picker, find one, and use it
			- I would npm install a datepicker because its the one piece of UI that I don't feel like building
		- https://tailwindcss.com
- **CATEGORY: Behavior Libraries**
	- behavior libraries use JavaScript
	- **HeadlessUI**
		- unstyled UI components
		- integrates with Tailwind
		- makes e.g. a dropdown work with good assessibility
		- https://headlessui.com
	- Radix
		https://www.radix-ui.com
	- React Aria
		- https://react-spectrum.adobe.com/react-aria
- **CATEGORY: Component Libraries**
	- professional developers should own their component libraries, not install them
		- you need to be able to fix problems in styles and not rely on the library
	- **Mantine**
		- a fully featured React components library
		- https://mantine.dev
	- **MUI** 
		- has "weird prop-passing behaviors"
		- there no reason to use MUI unless you are a backend-leaning developer trying to avoid as much frontend issues as possible
		- MUI and things like it are a scary thing to adopt because you're choosing the new maximum of how good our application design can be
		- difference between Material Design UI and MUI
			- Material Design UI provides a set of design principles, guidelines, and components that developers can use to implement the Material Design style in their applications
			- MUI (Material-UI) is a React component library that follows the Material Design guidelines
		- https://mui.com
	- **ChakraUI**
		- for React
		- it kind of annoyed me
		- it has like 20 components, where Mantine has over 100
		- there was a lot to learn
		- not very tree-shakeable
		- the lock-in is absurd, not just code-based lock-in but brain lock-in
		- https://chakra-ui.com
	- **Vanilla Extract**
		- do a way better job at being a flexible component library
		- https://vanilla-extract.style		
- **CATEGORY: Style Systems**
	- **TailwindUI**
		- TailwindUI just gives you the code base
			- so it is easier to customize than the other style systems
		- but TailwindUI **costs money**
			- it's a good investment for a professional project
			- otherwise use DaisyUI
		- https://tailwindui.com
	- **DaisyUI**
		- built on top of Tailwind instead of on top of traditional CSS
		- pre-written Tailwind classes
		- if you are a backend developer, don't want to bother yourself with frontend styling, and so need to use a style system, use DaisyUI
		- https://daisyui.com
	- **Master.co**
		- odd, interesting, tries to build its own virtual CSS
		- https://master.co
	- **Bootstrap**
		- Can you customize Bootstrap? Yes. Are you going to have fun? No.
		- don't use Bootstrap, it's 2022, you know better
		- https://getbootstrap.com
		- https://react-bootstrap.github.io		
- **styled components**
	- styled components were very important
	- a powerful primitive for building a component library
		- but also the the problem, it is only good at this, similar to storybook
	- but in the end, styled components are a bastardization of CSS and JavaScript, a messy combination of the two, and the TypeScript definitions around it can be obnoxious
	- the best thing we learned from styled-components is that **inline styles are actually good**
		- for a long time we hated inline styled, but they are actually good
		- it's ok to simply write styling inline where styling goes
		- when you use Tailwind, you just create styles in the area that is used to create style, no referencing any other file, full on zen mode##inlineoktouse
	- https://styled-components.com
- **concepts**
	- the scope frameworks allow to create beautiful design##cssscopeofbeauty
	- an explanation that inline styles such as Tailwind make sense in a component-based system like React
		- you have a component which has a place for its logic and a place for styles, *which get written directly there in that place, i.e. the JSX*
		- compare this to a component library such as MUI where you have bring in bulky components from external files##theinlineoks
- **other various CSS tools**	
	- **Foundation**
		- apparently excels at responsive design
		- https://get.foundation
	- **Bulma**
		- every element in Bulma is mobile-first and optimizes for vertical reading, so by default on mobile
		- has five breakpoints
			- mobile: up to 768px
			- tablet: from 769px
			- desktop: from 1024px
			- widescreen: from 1216px
			- fullhd: from 1408px
		- https://bulma.io
	- **Materialize**
		- different than MUI but also based on Material Design principles
		- https://materializecss.com
	- **Stylus**
		- says it is "built for Node.js"
		- https://stylus-lang.com
	- **CSS Modules**
		- ensures that styles defined within that module do not collide with styles from other modules
		- automatic class name generation
		- https://github.com/css-modules/css-modules
	- **UIKit**
		- lightweight and modular
		- https://getuikit.com
	- **Emotion**
		- a library designed for writing css styles with JavaScript
		- https://emotion.sh/docs
	- **Styletron**
		- falls into the CSS in JS category
		- works great with React 
		- https://styletron.org
	- **JSS**
		- allows you to use JavaScript to describe styles in a declarative, conflict-free and reusable way
		- https://cssinjs.org
	- **Rebass**
		- React primitive UI components
		- https://rebassjs.org	
	- **PostCSS**
		- a Node.js tool that transforms your styles using JavaScript plugins
		- supports future CSS features
		- has plug-in architecture
		- supports CSS modules
		- https://postcss.org

Popular unstyled React component libraries and how to use them, based on Kyle video
body:
- video is here:
	- [Unstyled Component Libraries Are A Game Changer](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yn6vFCRkC3c) - Web Dev Simplified
- pre-styled libraries
	- useful pre-styled libraries and components:
		- [Bootstrap](https://react-bootstrap.netlify.app)
		- [ChakraUI](https://chakra-ui.com)
			- has the ability for more customization
		- [MUI](https://mui.com)
		- [Mantine](https://mantine.dev)
		- [React-Select](https://react-select.com)
			- handles custom select boxes which is difficult to do if done manually
	- problems with pre-styled libraries
		- they bring with them pre-defined styles that may not fit your design
		- these styles are generally difficult to change
- unstyled libraries
	- you get the best of both worlds
		- you can style them as you want
		- you get all the Aria assessibility features
	- two types of unstyled libraries
		- hook-based version
		- component-based version
	- **[React Aria](https://react-spectrum.adobe.com/react-aria)**
		- managed by Adobe
		- a library of React Hooks
			- Button
				- e.g. ButtonProps are retrieved from a hook##thehooksamekj
			- DatePicker
				- in more complex components, you retrieve more from the hook##thedatepickijsdfkj
				- the DatePicker looks like this:##thedatepickerworksjdfijsthis
				- the DatePicker HTML has **aria attributes**##theariasdjf
			- DateRangePicker
				- looks like this##alsohadrangjd
		- React Aria also has [components](https://react-spectrum.adobe.com/react-aria/#components) instead of hooks
	- **[Downshift](https://www.downshift-js.com)**
		- works similarly with hooks:##workswithhooksj
	- **[BaseUI-Overview](https://mui.com/base-ui/getting-started/overview)**
		- *"they essentially took what MUI is built on top of, and they broke it out into its own library"*
		- so these are components instead of hooks, so you "don't have to write all the HTML from scratch"
	- **[Radix](https://www.radix-ui.com)**
		- Kyle likes this one
			- Radix components are not as low-level as the hooks
				- they are just components with no styles
			- "this is the sweet spot that I like to live in"
				- they are easier to use since the HTML is written for you
				- you just don't get that much control over the HTML as with e.g. React Aria and Downshift		
		- Checkbox component
			- you get the code for the component##codechckbox
		- this is what the default looks like##thedfulksjlookslike
		- you look at the HTML##thehtmllookslijlihthin
		- and style it as you want##afteritsstyled
	- **[HeadlessUI](https://headlessui.com)**
		- made by **Tailwind**
			- if you use Tailwind, this is a very easy library to use
	- **[ReachUI](https://reach.tech)**
		- another popular unstyled library##thereachuisdkj
- Kyle recommends: **create your own component library** based on an unstyled library
	- when you use unstyled libraries, **always make custom components**##thesecondsomlkcheck
	- then you just call your checkbox##theyoujustcall
	- in this way, you create your own component library that is based on an unstyled component library
	- working in a medium-to-large project, it makes sense to set up a custom component system like this
		- multiple develops can easily use it and make changes to it

		- this is important since the directory name will be the same as the
			- repository name
			- URL name at Netlify

	- download repository
		- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et032-sports-store
	- copy files into above site directory, e.g. `nn012-sports-site`
	- go into directory and open VSCode
		- `code .`
	- view in browser

- **create GitHub repository for site**
	- create local repository first
		- open VSCode terminal
		- `git init -b dev`
	- create GitHub repository##theuploadandtisite
- **>>> PUBLISH SITE AT GITHUB**
	- go to GitHub respository
	- click on **Settings**##onthesettingj
	- on the left, click on **Pages**##onthepages
	- choose **dev** and **save**##choosedevandsave
	- click reload until you see the URL for your site##gotositegitbhub
	- click on it and go to your site##clickonandshowsite
	- make a small change, push to GitHub, and within about one minute, you will see the change live
- **>>> PUBLISH SITE AT NETLIFY**
	- go to: https://www.netlify.com
	- if you don't have an account, sign up##ifnoaccounet
	- sign up with **GitHub**##thegithusignup
	- Netlify needs to have a connection to your GitHub account so that it can watch repositories and automatically publish changes that you make to them
	- so sign into GitHub from Netlify in order to connect these two services##thesigninanddoit
	- when you are logged in
		- **Add new site** and **Import an existing project**##theaddsiteandother
		- search for the name of your site:##searcofrjnaam
		- make sure repository is correct, if you only have one, it will be##ameksure
		- because this is a simple HTML/CSS site (and your main file is named `index.html`), you can leave all fields blank and click the **Deploy** button##allokonemp
	- while site is being deployed
		- change site name
			- by default Netlify gives your site a random name
			- change this name to the name of your repository
			- click **Site configuration**##badnamekjd
			- click **Change site name**##changesitenamekj
			- copy the name of your repository and paste it as the name of your site##thenamenakjsd
	- when you see the site's preview, click on the new URL name of your site:##seetheprevisj
	- you should see your site at your new URL:##nowthenetlify
	- make a small change, push to GitHub, and within about one minute, you will see the change live
- **>>> PUBLISH SITE AT VERCEL**
	- go to: https://vercel.com
	- click on **Sign Up**##thevercelsignup
	- choose **Hobby** and type in your **full name**##choosehobby
	- Vercel needs to have a connection to your GitHub account so that it can watch repositories and automatically publish changes that you make to them##vercelgitgti
	- so sign up with GitHub to connect these two services##vercgiinon
	- when you are signed in via GitHub
		- click on **Add New...** and **Project**##addnewprojectsdf
		- the last repository that you pushed to will be the first one listed, click **Import**:##thelastfirst

	- within a few seconds, your site will be deployed and show as a preview:##congvercel

title: Overview of the various ways to use HTML/CSS/JavaScript to create websites, apps and tools
body:
- **purpose of this howto**
	- explain the wide landscape of websites, apps and tools one can create with HTML, CSS and JavaScript
	- encourage project ideas possible with HTML/CSS and JavaScript skills
- HTML/CSS/JS web sites
	- deployment
		- simple HTML/CSS/JS sites can be published for free at 
			- GitHub pages
			- Netlify
			- **Vercel** (my recommendation, best user experience)
	- **HTML**
		- the simplest website is simply text in a index.html file that is published to a server
		- this could be very useful: 
			- type shopping list in file
			- push to GitHub
			- it's automatically published to Vercel
			- you have an icon on your smart phone that goes to this page
		- **index.html**
			------------------------------------------
			milk, juice, bread
			------------------------------------------
		- one reason why HTML and the web won over other technologies (e.g. [gopher](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gopher_(protocol))) was that it was so lenient, flexible and tolerant of bad syntax 
	- **HTML/CSS in one file**
		- nnn
	- **HTML/CSS in multiple files**
		- nnn
	- **HTML/CSS/JS in one file**
		- nnn
	- **HTML/CSS/JS in separate files**
		- nnn
	- **HTML/CSS/JS in separate files with JavaScript modules**
		- nnn
	- **HTML/CSS/JS with JavaScript modules with CDN libraries**
		- Alpine.js
		- HTMLX
		- PicoCSS
		- CDN Vuejs
	- **HTML/CSS/JS with data fetching via fetch**
		- nnn
- self-made JavaScript framework
	- deployment
		- since your files need to be **built** by e.g. npm scripts, best is to host at a full provider
			- Netlify
			- **Vercel** (my recommendation, best user experience)
	- **HTML/CSS/JS with JavaScript modules and a web bundler or task runner**
		- Webpack
		- Parcel
		- npm scripts
		- Grunt/Gulp
		- advantages
			- Sass automatically transpiled to CSS
			- TypeScript automatically transpiled to JavaScript
			- image optimization
			- markdown file conversion
			- etc.
		- difficulties
			- complicated to set up
			- basically you are building your own JavaScript framework
- JavaScript frameworks
	- deployment
		- professional hosting services automatically recognize most major frameworks, hence deployment is simple
		- Netlify
		- **Vercel** (my recommendation, best user experience)
	- **Vite Vanilla frontend**
		- easy to set up
		- read-only database
			- local json files 
		- read/write 
			- via API with fetch
	- **Vite Vanilla app: frontend with local backend in one directory**
		- backend: json-server (read-write data)
		- backend: Node/Express (read-write data)
		- deploy: not necessary, i.e. used as local application (e.g. Course Website)
	- **Vite Vanilla frontend with local admin backend in one directory**
		- backend: json-server
		- backend: Node/Express
		- deploy: Netlify, Vercel but with no online backend functionality
	- **Vite React**
		- same variants as Vite Vanilla but with React State and JSX
	- **Vite Vuejs**
		- same variants as above
	- **Angular**
		- same variants as above
	- **Vite Svelte**
		- same variants as above
- Node projects
	- (execute Node scripts with console.log)
		- a way to learn and teach JavaScript
	- (Quokka)
		- basically used as a JavaScript teaching/learning tool, since it gives immediate output
		- perhaps useful for experimenting with algorithms, etc.
	- CLIs
		- scripting in JavaScript, possible only since Node was created in 2009
		- very useful, particularly when combined with npm scripts
			- e.g. https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et005-starter-example-showcase/tree/dev
	- NPM package as interactive script
		- https://www.npmjs.com/package/sweetstack
- desktop applications
	- [Electron](https://www.electronjs.org)
- Mobile devices
	- [React Native](https://reactnative.dev)
- classic server-side websites
	- [EJS](https://ejs.co) (Embeded JavaScript templating)
		- this is the JavaScript equivalent of old-school PHP, ASP.NET, Ruby-on-Rails, Django/Python sites, etc.
	- use cases
		- info site with no login
		- good SEO and Social Media previews needed
		- e.g. conference site
- arguably the future trend of React, MERN-stack and JavaScript frameworks:
	- **SSR** (Server Side Rendering)

		- [Remix](https://remix.run)
	- **SSG** (Static Site Generation) 
		- [Jamstack](https://jamstack.org)
			- **a general architectural approach** that decouples the web experience layer from data and business logic, improving flexibility, scalability, performance, and maintainability
		- [Gatsby](https://www.gatsbyjs.com)

title: How to use SVG graphics in websites with animation, interaction and dynamic data
body: - **purpose of this howto** - to get you up and running with SVGs - know what they are - how to create them - how to use them - how to change them - how to animate them - how to incorporate them into interactive websites - **what are SVGs** - SVG stands for **Scalable Vector Graphics** and they were created around **2003** - `.jpg`, `.png` or `.gif` images are **raster** graphics which means they are made up of **pixels** - `.svg` images are **vector** graphics which means they are made up of **math equations** - because **vector** graphics are made up of math equations, they are **scalable** - that is why they are called **Scalable Vector Graphics** (SVG) - this means that as they are infinitely scaled larger or smaller, they do not loose their sharpness##vectorraster1 - note that at optimal display sizes, vector and raster images can look similarly sharp, but it is important to remember that only vector graphics can be scaled without losing their sharpness and accuracy##vectorraster2 - SVGs can be used in `` tags just like other raster graphics (`.jpg`, `.png`, `.gif`), e.g. - **index.html** ---------------------------------------- SVG Test ---------------------------------------- - **images/ball.svg** ----------------------------------------------- ----------------------------------------------- - site looks like this:##svgblueball - but since SVGs are XML (similar to HTML), their contents can also be directly copied into the HTML - this enables you to easily make SVGs **interactive** with tools like **Alpine.js** - **index.html** ---------------------------------------------------- SVG Test ---------------------------------------------------- - site looks like this:#gif#svginteractivalll - **SVG basics** - learn how to alter SVGs, not necessarily create them - most work with SVGs involves - creating SVGs with graphic tools - altering SVGs to match your exact needs - animating SVGs - adding interactivity to SVGs - making SVGs dynamic by - wrapping them in components which are called with key parameters - setting them up so that they can be generated from dynamic data such as from a JSON file, API or database - so first simply familiarize youself with the 8 main SVG elements and what attribute values you can chanage to alter their shape - **1. circle** - https://www.w3schools.com/graphics/svg_intro.asp - **2. rect** - https://www.w3schools.com/graphics/svg_rect.asp - **3. ellipse** - https://www.w3schools.com/graphics/svg_ellipse.asp - **4. line** - https://www.w3schools.com/graphics/svg_line.asp - **5. polygon** - https://www.w3schools.com/graphics/svg_polygon.asp - **6. polyline** - https://www.w3schools.com/graphics/svg_polyline.asp - **7. text** - https://www.w3schools.com/graphics/svg_text.asp - **8. path** - https://www.w3schools.com/graphics/svg_path.asp - **free tools to create SVGs** - [Inkscape](https://inkscape.org) - full-featured, all-purpose vector graphics application - [Figma](https://www.figma.com) - design and prototyping tool that also creates SVGs - [SVGator](https://app.svgator.com) - decidated and streamlined web site that allows you to quickly create SVGs for your website - **make an interactive SVG "learning roadmap"** - 1. use [SVGator](https://app.svgator.com) to create the SVG code for the roadmap - 2. create a Vite Vanilla site - use this site that uses Tailwind/DaisyUI - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et024-vite-vanilla-daisyui-site - 3. display SVG as XML text on Welcome page - 4. animate it ---------------------------------------- .roadmap { width: 10rem; transition: width .3s; } .roadmap:hover { width: 40rem; } ---------------------------------------- - 5. convert it to a Roadmap component - show the advantage of making it a component, by calling it from both the Welcome and About page - 6. use Alpine.js to enable the user to click each of the tech boxes which toggles the color of that box between red to green - title: Develop a full-stack, full-feature MERN application deployed at Backend-Render.com and Frontend-Vercel
body:
- stages of this project - get a full backend/frontend MERN stack application running locally - deploy both backend and frontend at Render.com - create a [starter site](https://starters.tanguay.eu) based on it - publish the site at flashcards.tanguay.eu as an open-source application that is used publically - continually improve it with new features - source code is here: - Backend: https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et042-mernstackapp-backend - Frontend: https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et042-mernstackapp-frontend - application is live here: - Render Backend (OLD -- slow spin-up times): https://et042-mernstackapp-backend.onrender.com - Cyclic Backend (NEW -- always available): https://et042-mernstackapp-backend.cyclic.app - Frontend: https://et042-mernstackapp-frontend.vercel.app - features - the features of this site will be **held to a minimum** for learning purposes - but all the **features are all essential** for building a full-stack MERN app - separate frontend and backend - frontend - React - TypeScript - useContext - backend - Node/Express - TypeScript - MongoDB - Compass - use of a database for data permanence, in our case **MongoDB Atlas** - the online database will be used for both the local and online versions - this eliminates the need to transfer data from a local database to the online database - is also easier to debug locally - authentication/authorization - programatic sending of e-mails (member signup) - image uploading (profile picture change) - online deployment at Render.com - this application will be a **flashcard app** - this topic makes this app: - (1) a **good app for learning the MERN stack** - (2) a **useful app** as-is which can be customized and extended for one's own purposes - **authentication** - we will use **username and password** for identification - passwords will be saved as hashes in the database using bcrypt - the signup process use **e-mail verification** - for this we will use NodeMailer or SendGrid, whichever we can get to work at Render.com - we will use **JWT** to assert authentication claims - to keep authentication straight-forward and basic, we will issue JWT tokens that **expire in 60 minutes** - if a user is on the site longer than this, they need to log back in - for most use cases, users will never experience being logged out - having an expiration time increases security of the site - our tokens will be stored in **localStorage** - this is **straight-forward** for learning purposes and **safe enough** for low-profile sites - our JWTs have expiration times so even if they continue to exist in localStorage permanently, this is not a security breach - XSS attacks are resource-intensive to execute and so not a practical concern on low-profile sites, particularly with short-expiration durations - **authorization** - I will be using an **access-group concept** for authorization - this is a concept I created myself for my Datapod project and have refined throughout the years - a unique characteristic of this approach is the **anonymousUser** - this is a concept based on the [Null object pattern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Null_object_pattern) - any user that comes to the page is immediately identified by the application as anonymousUser - this means that **every user is always identified as a particular user** and has the rights of the groups to which they are assigned - the anonymousUser in most use cases only belongs to the group **loggedOutUsers** - this authorization pattern works well to **granually assign users rights based on groups** - accessGroups - **loggedOutUsers** - are not logged in - e.g. users new to the site or members who have not logged in yet - can test themselves on the flashcards, but cannot mark their process - in menu there is a login page but no logout page - **loggedInUsers** - in menu there is a logout page but no login page - **members** - have identified themselves with username/password - have their own profile page where they can change their information - see extra member-specific information on the welcome page - can record their progress when testing themselves on flashcards, e.g. mark if they have learned it or not - can view a Members page which shows all members sorted by how many flashcards they have learned - **contributors** - can add, edit, delete and delete flashcards - **administrators** - can add, edit, delete and delete flashcards - can add, edit, delete and delete users - **responsive** - application can be used on all computer screens as well as all common smart phones and tablets - **sign-up with email verification** - **image upload for profile picture** - **frontend and backend in TypeScript** - **menu** - Welcome, Flashcards, Members, Login, Logout - **(1) create local Node/Express backend in JavaScript** - set up local project structure, the name for my project is `et042-mernstackapp`, choose your own name - create two directories in a project directory: - /et042-mernstackapp - /et042-mernstackapp-backend - /et042-mernstackapp-frontend - make the simplest Node/Express server that servers "testing" at router "/" - create npm project - `npm init -y` - create local git repository - `git init -b dev` - **.gitignore** --------------------------------------- node_modules dist --------------------------------------- - make first local commit##theinitcommidijdd - install Express - `npm i express` - **src/index.js** --------------------------------- import express from 'express'; const app = express(); const port = 3601; app.get('/', (req, res) => { res.send('testing'); }); app.listen(port, () => { console.log(`listening on post http://localhost:${port}`); }); --------------------------------- - **package.json** ------------------------------------------- "type": "module", ------------------------------------------- - start the API with `npm run dev`##thefirsttesting - **(2) convert Node/Express backend to TypeScript** - because we don't have a framework like Vite in the backend, we have to set up JavaScript compiling ourselves - install TypeScript as a dev dependency - `npm i -D typescript` - install nodemon as a dev dependency - nodemon is a tool that will watch our TypeScript files and each time they are changes, we will - (1) compile our TypeScript files into JavaScript files which can be run by Node - (2) restart Node so we see our changes - `npm i -D nodemon` - change `index.js` to `index.ts` - you will notice that there are ellipses markers in the code##thelittledots - install the @types for Express so that these no longer appear - `npm i -D @types/express` - it took 16 seconds for the backend on Render.com to wake up and send data - **(7) Create a loading spinner for the frontend** - Note that the Render.com: - **free instance types will spin down with inactivity** - web services on the free instance type are **automatically spun down after 15 minutes of inactivity** - when a new request for a free service comes in, Render **spins it up again** so it can process the request - this will cause a **delay in the response of the first request** after a period of inactivity while the instance spins up - this is why in this section, we are going to create a loading spinner for the frontend - if your website has not been used in the last 15 minutes, then - when the Frontend tries to fetch data from it - it will take from 15-40 seconds (in my experience) to spin up and send data to the front end - therefore, if the full-stack app you are creating is intended to actually be used by people - you want to give them some indication that the data for the website is loading - and give them something to read/do while the data is loading - in this way, you can use the free-tier at Render.com and Vercel for more or less useful online applications at no cost - if another person accesses the site before 15 minutes after the last user accessed it - the spinner will appear for less than a second - this may cause an unpleasant flicker, which is not a positive user experience - therefore we will build in a default wait of 1 second in all cases - so that the user has the feeling that "data is loading" - Notes on ThePrimeagen's algorithm course at Frontend Masters
body:
- these are my notes on this course at Frontend Masters
	- https://frontendmasters.com/courses/algorithms
- reflections on taking this course
	- 1. if you are a Quereinsteiger developer who never had any formal computer science education
		- you may not be familiar with algorithms
		- in fact, as in my case, you can work as a developer for decades and not ever have to
			- write algorithms
			- know algorithms as such
			- answer questins about algorithms in interviews
		- at least this is my experience
			- of course when you program, you are using languages, libraries, frameworks that use algorithms
			- and just in solving some problem, you may write what is commonly known as an algorithm without knowing it as such
		- you may even have studied e.g. object-oriented patterns such as factory, observer, singleton without having to write algorithms as such
			- **pattern**
				- a recurring and recognizable form, structure or arrangement of elements of data
				- used to identify common behaviors and regulatiries within data or processes
			- **algorithm**
				- a step-by-step set of instructions or well-defined computational procedure that is designed to solve a specific problem
				- used for problem-solving in a precise and systematic way
	- 2. so formally studying algorithms will give you more concepts and a deeper knowledge of how to solve problems
		- therefore, if you didn't formally study computer science, I recommend taking a class or reading a book on algorithms at some point
		- this class is excellent, ThePrimeagen is the kind of developer who is deeply smart
			- you learn more than the topic at hand
			- listening to him talk is a rich source of side-tips and insightful quotes based on decades of solving problems
			- and he is humorful, entertaining and fun to listen to##
			- he uses the Vim editor like a boss, basically his thoughts just make code appear on the screen, its beautiful to watch
		- you don't need to understand everything in this course or a book on algorithms
			- I think algorithms is a topic you will learn increasingly deeply on each pass
			- the first pass will be mainly absorbing a large quantity of vocabulary and basic concepts, e.g.
				- Big O, bubble sort, linked list, ArrayList, ArrayBuffer, recursion, base case, pathing, QuickSort, divide and conquer, MergeSort, greedy search, pivot, trees, breadth-first vs. depth-first, heap, graphs, queue, stack, adjacency matrix, LRU (least recently used) cache, etc.
			- *"when learning algorithms, there will be a period where you may not be able to use these concepts, but you will begin to see them in code"* - ThePrimeagen
				- whereas if you never formally read a book on them or took a course on them, you may not ever see them as such 
		- the more you understand algorithms, the more you think about the **performance** of not only your code, but the code that your code uses (e.g. third-party software)
			- when you use functions, methods and other tools, you will be more concerned with how these work internally
			- you will be concerned not only whether an object method works for processing 1 item
				- you will wonder how it will perform, how long it will take, and what resources it will consume when processing 10, 100, 1000, or a million items
		- in general, algorithms are going to be more of a focus for backend developers than frontend developers
	- 3. I was surprised that the focus of this course was not only **algorithms** but also very much on **data structures** and their diferences
		- these two concepts seem to be inextricably intertwined
		- for instance, whether you are using an **array** or a **linked list** will determine how resource-intensive your algorithm is
	- 4. an import concept when talking about arrays is **Big O**
		- this is an ill-chosen name for **worst-case time and resource complexity of an algorithm**
			- which basically answers the question: 
				- what is going to happen to my machine's memory and speed as I add more input to an algorithm?
				- depending on the **Big O** of an algorithm
					- it may take an insignificant difference of time and resources to process 1, 100, or 1000 items
					- but to process 10,000 items, it will crash a normal machine by consuming its entire RAM or taking a week instead of 5 seconds
- **===BASICS===**
	- **>>> 1. Big O Time Complexity**
		- https://frontendmasters.com/courses/algorithms/big-o-time-complexity
		- Big O categorizes you algorithm on time or memory based on the input
			- it's only a generalized way to understand how your algorithm will react to various inputs
				- and how it will act differently as your application grows
			- **it measures growth with respect to input**
		- *"strings are effectively an array when you think about it"*
		- algorithm #1: 
			- O(N)
			- the algorithm's execution time or resource usage grows linearly with the size of the input
			- e.g. if N doubles, the time it takes the algorithm to run will roughly double as well##looksatalgo
		- algorithm #2:
			- not O(2N) for some reason
			- "always drop constants"##alg2
			- just because N is faster than N^2, doesn't mean practically it's always faster for smaller input
		- algorithm #3
			- running time is O(N)
			- because we always consider worst case##alg3
			- in interview, always assume worst case scenario
		- graph
			- "you can't solve the traveling salesman for 12 cities"
				- you have a list of cities
				- you need to find the shortest possible route that visits each city exactly once and returns to the starting city
				- time complexity is described as O(N!), where N is the number of cities
				- e.g.##thefexpl
			- Big-O Complexity graph##thebigogra
		- The Primeagen's favorite algorithms
			- [quick sort](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vtckgz38QHs) is nice
			- but [ring buffer](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KyreJSKEagg) is always awesome
	- **>>> 2. Arrays Data Structure**
		- https://frontendmasters.com/courses/algorithms/arrays-data-structure
		- somehow `const a = []` is not an array
		- an array is a data structure
			- a contiguous memory space that contains a certain amount of bytes
			- to a developer, this is abtracted away, but an array is at a low level simply a collection of 0s and 1s##thearraybuff
			- when he says "array" its this
			- a "list" is something different
			- "you don't delete something out of contiguous memory"
				- you set it to e.g. 0
				- you have to be able to tell yourself that it is not in the array anymore
				- "there's not something in this very something spot"
			- what is the Big O for getting a value out of an array
				- it's all O(1) because you don't have to iterate through the array to get to a specific position, you simply do the math to get there
				- we do a constant amount of things no matter what the input is
				- it does not grow with more input at all
	- **>>> 3. Arrays Q&A**
		- 4-5 various questions
		- "when you use Rust and you use an array, you realize you have to define a size at the beginning"
			- you can't grow it
			- you can reallocate it
- **===SEARCH===**
	- **>>> 4. Linear Search & Kata Setup**
		- developer tip:##thedevtippr
		- visualize problem first on paper, whiteboard or [excalidraw](https://excalidraw.com) first
			- then translate abstraction into concreteness
		- linear search is the simplest kind of search
			- this is what [indexof](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/indexOf) does under the hood:##indexofis
			- what is the **Big O** of this type of approach?
				- what's the worst-case situation?
					- what we are searching for is not in the array
					- we will search through the whole array and not find it
					- this is **O(N)** pronounced [oh of n]
						- if there are 10 more items in your array, then it have ten more cycles to find it
						- time grows linearly with input
		- clones a repository
		- example of linear search
			- *"I normally don't return in the middle of a for loop, but for a simple example I will make an exception"*
			- `npx jest Linear`##thejestok
	- **>>> 5. Binary Search Algorithm**

- **===SORT===**
	- **>>> 9. Bubble Sort**
		- *"algorithm courses often start with sorting, but search is a simpler concept to understand"*
		- *"sorting often gets into this weird world"*
		- *"bubble sort is not only easy to visualize what is happening, it's also 3 lines of code, it's an extremely simple algorithm"*
		- *"if you are on a plane and a stewardess yells 'the plane is crashing, we need someone to write a bubble sort', you could write a bubble sort while the plane is crashing"*
		- to know if an array is sorted:
			- you need to know that any item in the array is less or equal to the next item
			- the mathy way to say this is:##themathy
		- a bubble sort works like this
			- go through each item
			- if the item to the right is less than you, then swap positions
			- *"a single iteration will always produce the largest item in the last spot"*
			- you keep moving the end bar back toward the front
				- dividing the array in not-sorted to the left and sorted to the right
		- what is the **Big O** of this algorithm?
			- it is something like **O(N)** but less since each iteration, the number of iterations is reduced by 1:##thennnsk
			- it is **O(N^2)**
	- **>>> 10. Implementing Bubble Sort**

	- **>>> 15. Stack**
		- todo
	- **>>> 16. Implementing a Stack**
		- todo
- **===ARRAYS===**
	- **>>> 17. Arrays vs Linked List**
		- arrays are fast and simple to use
		- most of what you do with arrays is **O(1)**: resources consumed grows only linearly with growth of inputs
		- problem with arrays
			- if you want to store 1000 items, you have to reserve all that memory up front
		- a linked-list is different: 
			- when you create it, it has nothing to begin with
			- if you insert one item, it reserves memory only for that item
			- but with arrays, you can more easily use what you have reserved
			- however, the usability of an array is more cumbersome
				- basically it is always linear
	- **>>> 18. ArrayList**

	- **>>> 19. ArrayBuffer**

	- **>>> 20. Data Structures Q&A**

- **===RECURSION===**
	- **>>> 21. Recursion**
		- recursion is technically not an algorithm
			- recursion is a technique that can be used to design and implement algorithms
			- many algorithms are recursive in nature
			- one can speak of a "recursive algorithm"
		- recursion is something that keeps calling itself over and over again until a problem is solved
		- a **base case** is the point at which the problem is solved
			- *"base case is extremely important, always determine clearly what your base case is, if you don't know your base case, recursion is extremely hard"*##therecuss 
		- recursion often has a pattern in which you go deeper and deeper into itself until you can't go any deeper
			- then you start coming out again changing a value at each level going upward that you will ultimately return from the recursive function when you get back to the top
			- if you have ever watched the movie [Inception](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YoHD9XEInc0), you have experienced a similar idea
				- "Downward is the only way forward." - Dom Cobb
			- the base case is the bottom of the stack of functions that have been called
				- on the way down, you build a stack of functions until you get to the base case 
				- from there, you start executing this stack of functions until you get back to the top
				- at which point you have a value that you return
				- *"you can see that the execution of a recursive function goes down the stack, gets to the base case, and then starts coming back up the stack"*##backupthestack
			- in recursive function, you have three areas:
				- pre: do something before recursion
				- recursion
				- post: do something after recursion
		- *"it's hard to write a tree algorithm without some knowledge of recursion"*
		- *"when you first look at recursion, your lizard brain says: I could solve this with a simple for loop, but that just means you don't understand what recursion does, you just don't grok the need for it yet"*
		- *"the most important thing about writing recursive functions is that you have a solid base case, remember that, it's so important"*

		- to explain divide and conquer concept, MergeSort is often used, but we will use QuickSort
		- divide and conquer
			- split your input into parts, then go over these smaller subsets, splitting them each into smaller subsets, etc. in order to solve the problem faster
			- watch a [visualization of QuickSort](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kPRA0W1kECg&t=90s)

		- a super fun algorithm

			- pick some element out of the array
				- call it "p" since it is referred to as the "pivot"
				- put all items that are greater than p on one side of the array

			- this is called a weak sort

		- QuickSort does not always sort quickly

				- in this case, it is O(N^2), which is going to be exponentionally slower based on number of inputs

title: The basics of JavaScript/TypeScript classes
body:
- class terminology - the difference between a **class** and an **object** (or instance) of the class - a **class** is like a blueprint - an **instance** is the **object** that is created based on the blueprint##classandobject - the difference between **properties** and **methods** of a class - **properties** - represent the **state** of the class - are **variables** - can have various access levels: public, private or protected - **methods** - represent **actions or behaviors** of class - are functions called **methods** in OOP terminology - can have various access levels: public, private or protected - **getters** and **setters** are simply **methods** that changed **properties** - a **getter** *gets* the value of a private property from the outside - a **setter** *sets* the value of a private property from the outside - JavaScript doesn't support this concept well or fully - TypeScript gives you a bit more control and familiarity with OOP of other languages such as C# and Java - examples - bicycle##classmethodprop - dog##tehdogclass - cat##classcat - OOP terminology - **constructor** and **this** keyword - **constructor** - the method that is used to contruct the class with the new keyword - **this** keyword - used internally in the object to refer to the object itself example##claconstruct - **inheritance** - a mechanism that allows a subclass to inherit properties and methods from its superclass - **extends** keyword - **super()** method - **method overriding** and **polymorphism** - **method overriding** - allows a subclass to provide a specific implementation for a method that is already defined in its superclass - don't confuse with *method overloading* (not possible in JavaScript) - **polymorphism** - allows objects of subclasses to be treated as objects of a common superclass - example - you have a superclass called File - it has a method called **create()** - your file superclass has many subclasses which have subclasses - `ExcelFile extends File` - `OldFormatExcelFile extends ExcelFile` - `NewFormatExcelFile extends ExcelFile` - `WordFile extends File` - `OldFormatWordFile extends WordFile` - `NewFormatWordFile extends WordFile` - `JsonFile extends File` - `CssFile extends File` - you create an array of file objects, e.g. [excelFile, wordFile, excelFile, cssFile, cssFile, jsonFile) - **abstract** classes and **interfaces** - **abstract classes** don't exist in JavaScript - **interfaces** don't exist in JavaScript - you have something similar in TypeScript called interfaces - in JavaScript, a class functions similarly to an interface - **static methods** - methods that can be called on the class, not on the object - used for factories, e.g. to create a method of the class with another constructor signature - more realistic examples: what would be useful properties and methods? - File - properties - ... - methods - ... - CustomScript - properties - ... - methods - ... - Product (with subclasses Book and Magazine) - properties - ... - methods - ... - coding classes and objects with JavaScript - create code examples of the above examples and concepts - do some examples in JavaScript and most in TypeScript - note the differences - create a debug() method for debugging of objects - **(1) house** ----------------------------------- class House { constructor(roofColor, doorColor, windowColor) { this.roofColor = roofColor; this.doorColor = doorColor; this.windowColor = windowColor; } describe() { return `The roof is ${this.roofColor}, the door is ${this.doorColor} and the window is ${this.windowColor}.`; } } const house1 = new House('red', 'orange', 'blue'); const house2 = new House('blue', 'red', 'blue'); console.log(house1.describe()); console.log(house2.describe()); ----------------------------------- - notice how you don't need setters ------------------------------------ house1.roofColor = 'black'; ------------------------------------ - but JavaScript has a way to fake this -------------------------------------- #roofColor = ''; constructor(roofColor, doorColor, windowColor) { this.#roofColor = roofColor; this.doorColor = doorColor; this.windowColor = windowColor; } -------------------------------------- - this gives you intellisense of only public properties and methods - but this syntax is **uncommon** in other languages - you have no concept of protected properties so it is - **use TypeScript instead** - coding classes and objects with **TypeScript** - set up multi-page JS-DOM Vite site from [this starter](nnn) - **PageWelcome.ts** -------------------------------------------------- export const PageWelcome = () => { class House { private roofColor: string = ''; private doorColor: string = ''; private windowColor: string = ''; constructor(roofColor: string, doorColor: string, windowColor: string) { this.roofColor = roofColor; this.doorColor = doorColor; this.windowColor = windowColor; } public getDoorColor(color: string) { this.doorColor = color; } public describe() { return `The roof is ${this.roofColor}, the door is ${this.doorColor} and the window is ${this.windowColor}.`; } static instantiateSimpleHouse(roofColor: string, doorColor: string) { return new House(roofColor, doorColor, 'blue'); } } const house1 = new House('red', 'orange', 'blue'); const house2 = new House('blue', 'red', 'blue'); const house3 = House.instantiateSimpleHouse('red', 'orange'); return /*html*/`
