title: Create Vite JS-DOM site with TypeScript and Vitest unit testing
body:
- **what we are going to do** - we will use Vite to set up a JS-DOM website - this will be a simple **one-page site** - since the purpose of this howto is to show **how to add unit testing** to a website application - since we are setting up this site with **TypeScript**, we will use **Vitest** instead of Jest - **Jest** is a standard for unit testing particularly in React websites - **Vitest** is basically Jest but faster and uses TypeScript natively - but if you learn Vitest and then work on a project with Jest, the practice of writing tests is the same, and with the same syntax - **code is here** - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et964-vitest-site - **why do we need unit testing at all?** - so we know that are code works - we will set up our Vite JS-DOM project so that when we build it (with `npm run build`), it executes all tests - if any of the tests fail, our application will not build - this means that when we push changes to GitHub, and Vercel pulls our changes from GitHub, Vercel executes `npm run build` which executes the tests, and if one of them fails, then this code will not be deployed to production - note that using TypeScript has a similar protection - if you have a TypeScript error in your application, your application still may work locally, but it will not build - and if you push it to GitHub, and Vercel pulls the code and execute `npm run build`, it will not build and not be deployed to production - therefore, using a combination of TypeScript and unit testing gives your application much more security than what you would have if you used JavaScript with no unit testing - **what does unit testing test?** - unit testing tests the **smallest units** of an application, in most cases: **functions** - therefore in our project, we will keep all functions in a directory called **tools** - in this folder we will have files that each contain a certain kind of function that we use in our application, e.g. - **qstr.ts** - *quick string functions* e.g. - **capitalizeFirst()** - capitalizes the first character of a string - **chopLeft()** - removes a certain string from the left side of another string - **qarr.ts** - *quick math functions* e.g. - **sortObjects()** - sorts an array of objects based on a property - **shuffle()** - randomizes an array of objects - **cart.ts** - *business logic functions* e.g. - **addProductToCart()** - adds a product to a shopping cart - **when does one know one has written enough tests for a function to test it properly?** - this is in many cases a nuanced and debated issue - one can in most cases only approach 100% tested code - this is why in many companies, there are dedicated testers - there job is to think of realistic and likely ways that each unit could fail - but whether you are a developer writing your own tests, or a dedicated tester - you need to think of the most probably ways your function could fail - for instance, if you are writing tests for the **capitalizeFirst()** function - the purpose of this function is to capitalize the first character of a string - so you could write the following tests - expect **capitalizeFirst("test")** to be **"Test"** - expect **capitalizeFirst("")** to be **""** - expect **capitalizeFirst("TEST")** to be **Test** - here, for instance, you may need to consider or ask other developers or a program manager - should **TEST** be changed to **TEST** or **Test**? - in this way, writing tests forces you to make the meaning of your tests **explicit** - for instance, if your application supports languages such as Mandarin or Arabic, what is **capitalizeFirst()** expected to do with these languages? - **besides making your application more stable, what benefits does unit testing have?** - enables you to make changes quickly regardless how large your code base is - change what you want to fix a bug or get a new feature to work - your tests will inform you if your changes cause anything to break in any other part of the application - helps new developers more quickly get up to speed in the project - if you want to know what the application is requied to do and not do, read the tests - this is even more true for end-to-end testing, which tests the entire application programmatically from the user's point of view - **>>> 1. CREATE A MINIMAL JS-DOM SITE WITH VITE** - create base site - `npm create vite@latest` - name of project, e.g. **et964-vitest-site** (choose your own project name of course) - Vanilla - TypeScript - open site in VSCode and start - `code et964-vitest-site**` - `npm i` - `npm run dev` - minimalize site - delete **counter.ts** - **main.ts** ---------------------------------- import './style.css' document.querySelector('#app')!.innerHTML = `

Vitest Site

testing

`; ---------------------------------- - empty **style.css** - delete **typescript.svg** - **index.html** ------------------------------- Vitest Site ------------------------------- - minimalized site##minimvites - install Sass - `npm i sass` - rename **style.css** to **style.scss** - **main.ts** ---------------------------------------- import './style.scss'; ---------------------------------------- - install Tailwind - `npm install -D tailwindcss postcss autoprefixer` - `npx tailwindcss init -p` - **tailwind.config.js** -------------------------------------- content: [ "./index.html", "./src/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx}", ], -------------------------------------- - **style.scss** ---------------------------------------- @tailwind base; @tailwind components; @tailwind utilities; ---------------------------------------- - basic Tailwind-styled site:##basetaillla - add Tailwind styles - **index.html** -------------------------------------- -------------------------------------- - **main.ts** ----------------------------------------

Vitest Site

---------------------------------------- - minimized site looks like this:##minsetupokvitest - **>>> 2. CREATE AND USE A FUNCTION** - **/src/tools/qstr.ts** -------------------------------------------- /** * capitalizeFirstLetter() * * capitalizeFirstLetter('this is a test') * * "This is a test" */ export const capitalizeFirstLetter = (text: string) => { return text.charAt(0).toUpperCase() + text.slice(1); } -------------------------------------------- - **main.ts** -----------------------------------------

capitalizeFirstLetter()

  • ${qstr.capitalizeFirstLetter('this is a test')}
----------------------------------------- - note that because we `/**...*/` comment above the function, it appears when we use the function as a kind of in-place documentation##notethehelpsdj - **>>> 3. SET UP VITEST TESTING AND CREATE TEST FOR FIRST FUNCTION** - set up Vitest - `npm i -D vitest` - **package.json** ---------------------------------------- "test": "vitest --ui" ---------------------------------------- - `npm test`##thetestandrunjjj - answer "y" (it installs) - `npm test` - vitest runs but finds no tests, since we haven't written any yet##thenotestjsi - write a test for capializeFirstLetter() - **/src/tools/qstr.test.ts** --------------------------------------------------- import { capitalizeFirstLetter } from "./qstr"; describe('capitalizeFirstLetter', () => { }); --------------------------------------------------- - note that it is telling us we need to install the TypeSript types for **jest** which vitest will use##isntalltypesjest - `npm i -D @types/jest` - the error will disappear - **qstr.test.ts** ------------------------------------- describe('capitalizeFirstLetter', () => { it('uppercases and lowercases correct letters', () => { expect(capitalizeFirstLetter('test')).toBe('Test'); }) }); ------------------------------------- - now run the tests again - `npm test` - it will tell you it can't find **test**##tesllcantfind - in the root directory, create **vitest.config.ts** -------------------------------------------------- import { defineConfig } from 'vitest/config' export default defineConfig({ test: { include: ['./src/tools/**/*.test.ts'], globals: true }, }); -------------------------------------------------- - again run `npm test` - your terminal will show that the test passed:##thefirsttestjsjspast - note because we specified **--ui** in our test script, our browser opened with the following page:##thefollpagetestse - write more expectations for the test "uppercases and lowercases correct letters" - **qstr.test.ts** ------------------------------------- expect(capitalizeFirstLetter('Test')).toBe('Test'); ------------------------------------- - note is still shows that one tests passes - now add in **qstr.test.ts** ------------------------------------- expect(capitalizeFirstLetter('TEST')).toBe('Test'); ------------------------------------- - and you see that it fails - so we need to update our function to be able to pass this test##thefirstfailksj - **qstr.ts** - add `.toLowerCase()` to the end ----------------------------------------- return text.charAt(0).toUpperCase() + text.slice(1).toLowerCase(); ----------------------------------------- - all three expectations of the one test will immediately run again and this time succeed:##thetestsrunagain - also tests multiple words - **qstr.test.ts** ------------------------------------------ expect(capitalizeFirstLetter('two words')).toBe('Two words'); ------------------------------------------ - now write another test to handle edge cases - **qstr.test.ts** -------------------------------------- it('handles all edge cases', () => { expect(capitalizeFirstLetter('')).toBe(''); expect(capitalizeFirstLetter(' ')).toBe(' '); expect(capitalizeFirstLetter('!@#$%^&*()')).toBe('!@#$%^&*()'); }); -------------------------------------- - note two tests pass now##nowthatwotests - now write another test to handle German characters - **qstr.test.ts** ----------------------------------------- it('handles German characters', () => { expect(capitalizeFirstLetter('äpfel')).toBe('Äpfel'); expect(capitalizeFirstLetter('öfter')).toBe('Öfter'); expect(capitalizeFirstLetter('über')).toBe('Über'); expect(capitalizeFirstLetter('ÄÄÄÄ')).toBe('Ääää'); expect(capitalizeFirstLetter('ÖÖÖÖ')).toBe('Öööö'); expect(capitalizeFirstLetter('ÜÜÜÜ')).toBe('Üüüü'); }); ----------------------------------------- - **>>> 4. SET UP TEST COVERAGE** - Vitest has a feature to see how much of your code you are testing - **package.json** ----------------------------------- "testcov": "vitest --coverage" ----------------------------------- - `npm run testcov` - you will have to install it first - press "y"##sodotheinsllfirst - run again: `npm run testcov` - at the moment you have 100% coverage##sodotheinsllfirstsdfdf - but now let's create a new function in **qstr.ts** without testing it ----------------------------------------------------- export const sentencize = (text: string) => { return 'nnn'; } ----------------------------------------------------- - run again: `npm run testcov` - you will see that you now have less than 100% - and it tells you which lines are not yet tested:##needthe100 - **>>> 5. CREATE AND TEST A SECOND FUNCTION** - we will now add a second function to our tools - we will practice Test-Driven Development (TDD) - we will first write our test for this function - we will write as many expectations necessary to make sure - when all expectations are fulfilled, the function does what it is supposed to do - we will then run the tests and see that the test for this function fails of course - we will then write our function until all tests pass - when all tests pass, we know we are finished - we want to test a function that will be called **sentencize()** - it should **take a string of text and convert it to a sentence** - note that this is a quite vague statement, e.g. - what exactly is considered a sentence? - does it have to have period at the end? - what about a question mark or exclamation mark? - what if it ends with a colon or semi-colon, is it still a sentence? - does it need to start with a capital letter? - what if it is a Spanish question that starts with a "¿"? - is a text that is only one character long considered a sentence? - is a text of all numbers considered a sentence? - what does the function return do if e.g. one character is not considered a sentence? - return that character? - return a blank string? - return a text that shows some kind of error message? - throw an error from the function? - ignore it but write in a log file what text was sent leave it - all of these questions depend on the context of the application - in many cases in a work context, what you need to test is decided: - by **program management** who determines the business logic of the application - together with the **developer team** when creating and discussing tasks for a sprint - in addition, a developer/tester should test edge cases such as - what happens when an **empty string**, an **extremely long string**, etc. - note also that **TypeScript** covers the basic tests, e.g. - you don't have to test what happens when you send e.g. a **number** or **boolean** - since TypeScript won't compile if you don't send a **string** - let's say that program management and your developer team decide on the following functionality for the function **sentencize**: - 1. it receives a string as parameter - 2. if the first character is not capitalized, then capitalize it - 3. if the last character is not a period, question mark or exclamation mark, then add a period - 4. if the last character is a comma, semi-colon or colon, then remove it before added a period - 5. even if the string is one character or all numbers, treat it as a sentence, e.g. - e.g. "who was it?" / "i" --> "Who was it?" / "I." - e.g. "how many?" / "23" --> "How many?" / "23." - 6. if it begins with "¿", then capitalize the second character - e.g. "¿por qué?" --> "¿Por qué?" - 7. if there are multiple end-punctuation marks, reduce them to only one, namely, the first one - e.g. "who was it????" --> "Who was it?" - e.g. "what they hell??????!!!!!!" --> "What the hell?" - e.g. "what they hell!!!!!!??????" --> "What the hell!" - here are is the test you could write that would arguable fulfill the above specifications: - spec 1 is covered by TypeScript - specs 2-5 might be something like this: - **qstr.test.ts** ---------------------------------------------------- describe('sentencize', () => { it('handles no capital and no punctuation mark', () => { expect(sentencize('this is a text')).toBe('This is a text.'); expect(sentencize('hello')).toBe('Hello.'); }); it('handles no capital and punctuation mark', () => { expect(sentencize('hello!')).toBe('Hello!'); expect(sentencize('hello?')).toBe('Hello?'); }); it('handles no capital and bad punctuation mark', () => { expect(sentencize('hello,')).toBe('Hello.'); expect(sentencize('hello:')).toBe('Hello.'); expect(sentencize('hello;')).toBe('Hello.'); expect(sentencize('hello/')).toBe('Hello/.'); }); it('handles capital', () => { expect(sentencize('Hello')).toBe('Hello.'); expect(sentencize('Hello///')).toBe('Hello///.'); expect(sentencize('This is a test.')).toBe('This is a test.'); expect(sentencize('AAA')).toBe('AAA.'); }); it('handles task examples', () => { expect(sentencize('who was it?')).toBe('Who was it?'); expect(sentencize('i')).toBe('I.'); expect(sentencize('how many?')).toBe('How many?'); expect(sentencize('23')).toBe('23.'); }); }); ---------------------------------------------------- - **qstr.ts** ---------------------------------------------- /** * sentencize() * * sentencize('this is a test') * * "This is a test." */ export const sentencize = (text: string) => { let r = text; r = text.charAt(0).toUpperCase() + text.slice(1); if (',:;'.includes(text.slice(-1))) { r = r.slice(0,-1); } if (!'.!?'.includes(text.slice(-1))) { r += '.' } return r; } ---------------------------------------------- - **DOING...** - specs 6-7 might be something like this: - **qstr.test.ts** ---------------------------------------------------- ---------------------------------------------------- - **qstr.ts** ---------------------------------------------- ---------------------------------------------- - now use the function sentencize() - nnn - **>>> 6. title: An overview of the many ways to build websites from HTML/CSS to JS-DOM to SPA/SSR/SSG frameworks
body:
- **background**
	- web development has been evolving for more than 30 years, from 1989 to 2023
	- hence there are many various ways to build a website: from (1) a simple **HTML file** to (2)  a complex **JavaScript application** built with a JavaScript framework
	- these many methods each have their specific advantages and disadvantages on various spectrums
		- historical/practical spectrum
		- size of project
		- complexity of project
		- appropriateness for learning
		- what kind of website: interactive/static/SEO-friendly
- **===METHODS OF BUILDING WEBSITES FOR LEARNING PURPOSES===**
	- **---DISPLAY SITES---**
		- **=== 010 Text site** ( [howto](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/743) | [repo](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et837site) | [live](https://et837site.vercel.app) )
		- **=== 020 HTML site** ( [repo](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/web020-htmlsite) | [live](https://web020-htmlsite.vercel.app) )
		- **=== 030 HTML/CSS site in one file** ( [repo](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/web030-html-css-one-file) | [live](https://web030-html-css-one-file.vercel.app/) )
		- **=== 040 HTML/CSS site in two files** ( [repo](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/web040-html-css-two-files) | [live](https://web040-html-css-two-files.vercel.app) )
		- *mainly used for beginners to learn HTML/CSS*
		- *very accessible: all you need is a text editor and a browser*
		- *you can easily publish these sites to hosting services such as Vercel and Netlify*
		- PROBLEM: **no optimization** of files, development files are simply copied 1-to-1 to the hosting provider
		- PROBLEM: **difficult to use TypeScript, Sass, or npm packages etc.**	
		- PROBLEM: **not a professional solution**, and so only used for simple, static pages, or templates, etc.
		- PROBLEM: **no user interaction**
	- **---SIMPLE JS-DOM SITES---** 
		- **=== 050 HTML/CSS/JavaScript site in one file**  ( [repo](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/web050-htmlcssjsone) | [live](https://web050-htmlcssjsone.vercel.app) )
		- **=== 060 HTML/CSS/JavaScript site in three files**
		- *mainly used for beginners to learn JS-DOM website programming*
		- *enables interaction with JavaScript: buttons that show/hide sections, forms that process data, etc.*
		- *professional editors such as VSCode usually used*
		- *you can easily publish these sites to hosting services such as Vercel and Netlify*
		- *hot reloading available with VSCode Live-Server extension*
		- *events and data fetching possible*
		- PROBLEM: **no optimization** of files, development files are simply copied 1-to-1 to the hosting provider
		- PROBLEM: **difficult to use TypeScript, Sass, or npm packages etc.**	
		- PROBLEM: **not a professional solution**
		- PROBLEM: **no JavaScript modules and hence unorganized, unisolated (global variables) and unscalable code**	
	- **---MODULAR JS-DOM SITES---** 
		- **=== 070 HTML/CSS/JavaScript site in three files with CommonJS modules (using Browserify)** ( [howto](https://browserify.org/#install) | [repo](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/web070-commonjs-site) | [live](https://web070-commonjs-site.vercel.app) )
		- **=== 080 HTML/CSS/JavaScript site in three files with ES6 modules** ( [howto](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/742) |  [repo](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et882-module-javascript-website) | [live](https://et882-module-javascript-website.vercel.app) )
		- **=== 090 HTML/CSS/JavaScript site in three files with ES6 modules and multiple pages**
		- *mainly used for beginners to learn the concepts of JavaScript modules in websites*
		- *you can easily publish these sites to hosting services such as Vercel and Netlify*
		- *events and data fetching possible*	
		- PROBLEM: **no optimization** of files, development files are simply copied 1-to-1 to the hosting provider
		- PROBLEM: **difficult to use TypeScript, Sass, or npm packages etc.**	
		- PROBLEM: **not a professional solution**
		- PROBLEM: **no concepts of components, hence you have code duplication on every page, e.g. header, navbar, footer, etc.**	
	- **---JS-DOM FRAMEWORK APPLICATION---**
		- **=== 100 Vite Vanilla JS-DOM framework site with JavaScript**
		- **=== 110 Vite Vanilla JS-DOM framework site with TypeScript/Sass/Tailwind**
		- **=== 120 Vite Vanilla JS-DOM framework site with TypeScript/Sass/Tailwind/components**
		- **=== 130 Vite Vanilla JS-DOM framework site with TypeScript/Sass/Tailwind/components/router**
		- **=== 140 Vite Vanilla JS-DOM framework site with TypeScript/Sass/Tailwind/components/router/events**
		- **=== 150 Vite Vanilla JS-DOM framework site with TypeScript/Sass/Tailwind/components/router/events/npm-packages**
		- **=== 160 Vite Vanilla JS-DOM framework site with TypeScript/Sass/Tailwind/components/router/events/npm-packages/tools**
		- **=== 170 Vite Vanilla JS-DOM framework site with TypeScript/Sass/Tailwind/components/router/events/npm-packages/tools/unit-testing**
		- **=== 180 Vite Vanilla JS-DOM framework site with TypeScript/Sass/Tailwind/components/router/events/npm-packages/tools/unit-testing/fetch-API-data**
		- **=== 190 Vite Vanilla JS-DOM framework site with TypeScript/Sass/Tailwind/components/router/events/npm-packages/tools/unit-testing/fetch-API-data/json-server**
		- *Vite Vanilla framework enables you to build real-world, interactive applications in JS-DOM*
		- *native hot-reloading with `npm run dev`*
		- *build process (`npm run build`) optimizes files for speed*
		- *build process (`npm run build`) increases stability by not publishing if TypeScript or unit-testing find errors*
		- *you can easily publish these sites to hosting services such as Vercel and Netlify*
		- *TypeScript, Sass, Tailwind and all npm packages easy to install and use*
		- *easy to fetch information from external data sources such as backends and external APIs*
		- *easy to set up with json-server for local-application CRUD manipulative of a JSON file*
		- *React-style components easy to create, eliminates code-duplication and increases code organization*
		- *easy to set up simple router to eliminate code-dpublication for multipage sites*
		- *is an excellent framework to learn JS-DOM in a 90% React-like programming environment without the initial complexity of state management (useState, useEffect)*
		- *can be used to build semi-complex, stable and secure applications*
		- PROBLEM: **does not compare to React/Angular/Vue/Next.js/etc. as a professional solution** since it lacks state management and the rich component ecosystem of these advanced frameworks
		- PROBLEM: Vite Vanilla **does not build an SPA** (single-page-application) and so every page requires a round-trip to the server, which makes e.g. use on mobile devices slow 
		- PROBLEM: event processing is **procedural instead of declarative**, which leads to applications that become unscalable with increased complexity
			- when a user clicks a button, you have to specify the step-by-step **procedure** of how e.g. a dropdown has to change
			- in a JavaScript framework like React, Angular, Vue.js, you **declare** what you your application should look like and how it should behave based on the current **state** of the data your application
				- you **wire your app up to your data** and then simply **change your data**
- **===PROFESSIONAL SOLUTIONS FOR BUILDING WEBSITES USED BY COMPANIES===**
	- **CUSTOM JS-DOM FRAMEWORK**
		- **=== 210 JS-DOM framework built with Parcel that parses TypeScript/Sass** ([tutorial](https://adrianhall.github.io/javascript/react/2020/03/29/parcel-typescript-react))
		- **=== 200 JS-DOM framework built with Webpack that parses TypeScript/Sass** ([tutorial](https://marketsplash.com/tutorials/typescript/how-to-setup-webpack-for-typescript-and-sass))
		- **=== 220 JS-DOM framework built with Rollup that parses TypeScript/Sass** ([tutorial](https://www.thisdot.co/blog/how-to-serve-a-single-page-application-spa-using-rollup-js-and-web-dev))
		- *many companies build their own frameworks using a website bundler such as Webpack or Rollup in order to have complete control over processed resources and custom build workflows*
		- PROBLEM: the complexity of using a web bundler and creating a custom website build workflow is considerably more difficult than using established frameworks such as React, Angular and Vue.js
	- **FRAMEWORKS THAT PRODUCE SINGLE-PAGE APPLICATIONS (SPA)** 
		- **=== 300 React**
		- **=== 350 Angular**
		- **=== 400 Vue.js**
		- **=== 450 Svelte**
		- *each of these frameworks has a sophsicated state management solution which enables you to create websites **declaritively** instead of **procedurally**, which enables you means you can create applications that are both complex and scalable*
	- **FRAMEWORKS THAT PRODUCE SERVER-SIDE-RENDERED APPLICATIONS (SSR)** 
		- **=== 500 Next.js**
		- **=== 550 Remix**
		- **=== 600 SvelteKit**
	- **FRAMEWORKS THAT PRODUCE STATIC-SITE-GENERATED APPLICATIONS (SSG)** 
		- **=== 650 Astro**
		- **=== 700 Gatsby**
		- **=== 720 Hugo**
		- **=== 730 Jekyll**
		- **=== 760 Eleventy **

title: Learn the basics of regular expressions (regex) and how to use them in JavaScript
body:
- **what are regular expressions and what are they used for**
	- **regular expressions**, often referred to as **regex**, is a pattern-matching syntax used for searching, extracting, and manipulating text based on patterns
	- it allows you to define a pattern or a set of rules that describe a specific sequence of characters or a textual structure
	- it is often used in programming to **validate** certain patterns such as **email addresses**, **postal codes** or custom syntax such as **product ids**
	- regular expressions are also used for **searching**, **text extraction**, **text transformation** and **parsing** of commands, e.g. when creating a computer language or compiler	
- **what is the history of regex**
	- regular expressions were being used as early as the **1950s and 1960s** in computer science and linguistics
	- the **grep** command, introduced in Unix in the **1970s**, allowed users to search for patterns using regular expressions
	- during the **1980s**, regular expressions were included in many languages being developed such as **C++** and **Haskell**
	- particularly the language **Perl** embraced regular expressions as a core feature
	- by **2000** nearly all major computer languages had support for regular expression, e.g. **Python**, **Java** and **JavaScript**
	- by the **early 2000s** all **SQL variants** had regular expression support
	- since then regular expressions have found adoption as a **search option** in non-developer tools such as **Microsoft Excel/Word**, **Google Sheet/Documents** and editors such as **Notepad++**

body:
- **what we will do** - create a website that uses the old version of JavaScript modules **CommonJS** - note that you would learn this for **academic** or **legacy**, e.g. if you have to work on an old project that uses CommonJS modules - if you are creating a JavaScript modular site today (2023), use the newer [ES6 modules](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/742) - **final code is here** - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et389-commonjs-site - **the final site is here** - https://et389-commonjs-site.vercel.app - **create base HTML site** - create directory for site, e.g. **et389-commonjs-site** - *if you are following along, don't use this name, but choose your own name, so you can have a unique url at Vercel later* - go into the directory and type `code .` which opens VSCode in the directory - create **index.html** -------------------------------------------- CommonJS Site

CommonJS Site

Welcome to this site.

-------------------------------------------- - view it by right-clicking on the file name and selecting **Open with Live Server**##thedoandlookslive - site should look like this##thecommonjom - **create local Git repository** - `git init -b dev` - make initial commit - **add CSS** - **css/main.css** -------------------------------------------- body { padding: 0 1rem; font-family: sans-serif; } h1 { color: navy; } -------------------------------------------- - **index.hml** add in head area ---------------------------------------- ---------------------------------------- - site should look like this:##colorcommons - **add JavaScript without modules** - add button to **index.html** ------------------------------------------

CommonJS Site

Welcome to this site.

------------------------------------------ - add in **js/main.js** an event handler --------------------------------------- const btnInfoElem = document.querySelector('.btnInfo'); btnInfoElem.addEventListener('click', () => { alert('clicked'); }); --------------------------------------- - PROBLEM: the button doesn't do anything when clicked - REASON: we have not referenced the JavaScript code from the **index.html** file yet - SOLUTION: in **index.html**, reference the JavaScript file from inside the HEAD section ----------------------------------------- Modular Site Test ----------------------------------------- - PROBLEM: the button still doesn't do anything when clicked - REASON: when the JavaScript is executed, the HTML button element doesn't exist yet - SOLUTION: in **index.html**, move the **script** line down to right before the **** tag ----------------------------------------- ----------------------------------------- - when you click the button, the attached event code is executed:##stilwokrjsoj - but since HTML 5, you can keep the **script** code block that references JavaScript files in the HEAD section by using the **defer** attribute ----------------------------------------------------------------- Modular Site Test ----------------------------------------------------------------- - the button continues to work - now let's change the text above the button when it is clicked - in **index.html** add a class to the **

** tag ----------------------------------------------

Welcome to this site.

---------------------------------------------- - **main.js** ------------------------------------------------ const btnInfoElem = document.querySelector('.btnInfo'); const messageElem = document.querySelector('.message'); btnInfoElem.addEventListener('click', () => { messageElem.innerText = 'the button has been clicked' }); ------------------------------------------------ - now when you click on the button, the text above it changes:##thebuttonwrjsokuw - add JavaScript module - we will now add a JavaScript module file called **tools.js** which exports a function - we will then import that function into **main.js** - **js/tools.js** ---------------------------------------------------- exports.sentencize = (text) => { return text.charAt(0).toUpperCase() + text.slice(1) + '.'; }; ---------------------------------------------------- - **notice the difference of syntax from ES6 modules:** ------------------------------------------ export const sentencize = (text) => { return text.charAt(0).toUpperCase() + text.slice(1) + '.'; } ------------------------------------------ - **js/main.js** ----------------------------------- const tools = require('./tools.js'); const btnInfoElem = document.querySelector('.btnInfo'); const messageElem = document.querySelector('.message'); btnInfoElem.addEventListener('click', () => { const sentence = tools.sentencize('the button has been clicked'); messageElem.innerText = sentence; }); ------------------------------------------ - **notice the difference of syntax from ES6 modules:** ----------------------------------- import * as tools from './tools.js'; ----------------------------------- - PROBLEM: the button doesn't work and the browser shows an error:##therroeisthere - PROBLEM: the deeper problem here is that **browsers do not support CommonJS modules** - SOLUTION: you need to use **[Browserify](https://browserify.org/#install)** to convert your CommonJS modules to JavaScript that browsers can use - **Browserify** - is an open-source JavaScript tool - created in 2011 - it allows developers to use CommonJS modules in the browser - it bundles together CommonJS modules into a single JavaScript file typically called **bundle.js** - this JavaScript file can be loaded and executed in a web browser - install Browserify globally on your computer - `npm install -g browserify` - transpile your CommonJS JavaScript files into a file that your browser can read - `browserify js/main.js -o js/bundle.js` - you will now find a file called **js/bundle.js** in your project##thebundlesj - PROBLEM: the button on your site still doesn't work - SOLUTION: instead of **main.js**, you need to link **bundle.js** - **index.html** --------------------------------------------------- --------------------------------------------------- - your site now works:##sitenowkkkwork - set up build script - since you need to transpile your JavaScript code into **bundle.js** everytime you make a change - set up an npm script called **npm run bundle** which executes that command - create npm project - `npm init -y` - in **package.json** make the bundle script ------------------------------------------ "scripts": { "bundle": "browserify js/main.js -o js/bundle.js" }, ------------------------------------------ - test the script - make a small change in **main.js** ------------------------------------------------ messageElem.innerText = tools.sentencize('the button has been clicked222'); ------------------------------------------------ - note that the change is not yet in your site, since your site reads **bundle.js** now - run the script: - `npm run bundle`##againrunbundle - you now see the change:##nowthe222ok - revert the change in **main.js** ------------------------------------------------ messageElem.innerText = tools.sentencize('the button has been clicked'); ------------------------------------------------ - run the script again: - `npm run bundle` - publish to Vercel - push your code to GitHub - go to https://vercel.com - click **Add new...** and **Project** - click the **Import** button next to your repository - click **Deploy** - the site works online at Vercel:nnn - note that Vercel doesn't run **npm run bundle** as it runs **npm run build** for a Vite site - **npm run bundle** is a script we run manually to create **js/bundle.js** - this enables our site to work locally with **js/bundle.js** - then we upload this file with all our other files (**index.html** and **index.css**) - technically we don't need to upload **main.js** or **tools.js** since their code is contained in **bundle.js** - we could create a build process with e.g. WebPack, Gulp, Parcel, etc. which then copies all files to **/dist** much like Vite - if you have to work on a legacy CommonJS project, it will probably have some build workflow like this - but this Howto was merely to demonstrate how CommonJS modules work in general - CommonJS module sites in context - if you are creating a new JavaScript module site, then **do not use CommonJS**, since it is an outdated technology - use the newer [ES6 modules](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/742) instead - and unless you are creating an extremely simple site without TypeScript, Sass, Tailwind, unit testing, or any npm dependencies (axios, cors, marked, dayjs, lodash-es, etc.) - then you want to **use a JavaScript framework** such as - [Vite Vanilla JS-DOM](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/739) - [Vite Vanilla JS-DOM site with pages and router](https://starters.tanguay.eu/list/darkViteVanillaMenu) - Vite React - Angular - Vue.js - Next.js - Svelte - etc. - for an overview of the many ways to create JavaScript websites, see: - [An overview of the many ways to build websites from HTML/CSS to JS-DOM to SPA/SSR/SSG frameworks](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/740)

body:
- **what we will do** - since we want to create a website that reads a JSON file - and display specific employee information from the file on the website - specific **fields**: first name, last name, city - sorted in a specific **order**: sorted by last name - display **relationships** between the employees: who each employee reports to - creating a simple HTML/CSS/JavaScript site would not work - since websites cannot read data from the client's hard drive - this is a good thing, otherwise any website you visit could read any file on your computer (!) - therefore we need to create a site with a framework such as Vite JS-DOM - this framework has a backend which reads the file while we are developing - when the site is published e.g. at Vercel - the **npm run build** process converts the JSON file into a **JavaScript object** - which exists in the JavaScript code - which is sent to the browser along with the HTML and CSS - **code is here** - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et558-json-data-site - **finished site is online here** - https://et558-json-data-site.vercel.app##toreportsok - **>>> 1. CREATE A MINIMAL JS-DOM SITE WITH VITE** - create base site - `npm create vite@latest` - name of project, e.g. **et558-json-data-site** (choose your own project name of course) - Vanilla - TypeScript - open site in VSCode and start - `code et558-json-data-site**` - `npm i` - `npm run dev` - minimalize site - delete **counter.ts** - **main.ts** ---------------------------------- import './style.css' document.querySelector('#app')!.innerHTML = `

Employees

testing

`; ---------------------------------- - empty **style.css** - delete **typescript.svg** - **index.html** ------------------------------- Employees ------------------------------- - **style.css** ---------------------------------------- body { font-family: sans-serif; padding: 0 1rem; } ---------------------------------------- - minimalized site looks like this:##theminforjson - **>>> 2. CREATE JSON FILE** - we will now create a JSON file that contains employee data - go to: https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/share/employees.json - click on **raw data**##therawdatas - **CTRL-A**, **CTRL-C** - create a new file: **src/data/employees.json** - click inside the file and paste the copied data in with **CTRL-V** - you should have a file that looks like this:##thelookfiljson - **>>> 3. READ AND DISPLAY DATA FROM THE JSON FILE** - note that this file contains a **JSON array of objects** - we will now read this file into a **JavaScript array of objects** - **main.ts** ------------------------------------------ import './style.css'; import employees from './data/employees.json'; document.querySelector('#app')!.innerHTML = `

Employees

There are ${employees.length} employees.

`; ------------------------------------------ - your site now shows that the **employees** array has 9 objects:##hasnineoks - **>>> 4. DISPLAY DETAILED DATA FROM THE EMPLOYEES ARRAY** - let's now display - the full name of each employee - the city they are from - **main.ts** --------------------------------------------
    ${employees.map(employee => { return /*html*/ `
  • ${employee.firstName} ${employee.lastName} - ${employee.address.city}
    • ` }).join('')}
`; -------------------------------------------- - the employee list should look like this:##thefififemplist - **>>> 5. SORT THE LIST OF EMPLOYEES BY LAST NAME** - **main.ts** ---------------------------------------------- employees.sort((a, b) => a.lastName > b.lastName ? 1 : -1); ---------------------------------------------- - the employee list should look like this:##thefififemplist222 - **>>> 6. ALSO LIST TO WHOM EACH EMPLOYEE REPORTS** - **main.ts** ------------------------------------------------- document.querySelector('#app')!.innerHTML = `

Employees

There are ${employees.length} employees.

    ${employees.map(employee => { return /*html*/ `
  • ${employee.firstName} ${employee.lastName} - ${employee.address.city}
    • reports to: ${getManagerName(Number(employee.reportsTo))}
    • ` }).join('')}
`; function getManagerName(reportsTo: number) { if (isNaN(reportsTo)) { return 'nobody'; } else { const employee = employees.find(m => m.employeeID === reportsTo); if (employee) { return employee.firstName + ' ' + employee.lastName; } else { return `(error: employee #${reportsTo} does not exist)`; } } } ------------------------------------------------- - you should now see who each employee reports to:##toreportsok - **>>> 7. UNDERSTAND HOW THIS WEBSITE "READS A JSON FILE" FROM THE HARD DRIVE** - a Vite site has a **backend** (it runs in **Node**) which **generates the website** you see - and thus has access to the **JSON file** - everytime you make a **change** to the site as you developer - Vite **compiles** all your files into HTML/CSS/JavaScript which is then sent to your browser - this happens very fast since for this compilation, Vite uses the extremely fast **[esbuild](https://esbuild.github.io/)** bundler - when you build the website for **production**, you can see the files that it produces - type `npm run build` into the terminal - when building for production, Vite uses the **[Rollup](https://rollupjs.org)** which is slower but more sophisticated than esbuild - this process creates the files for production##lookintojs - look into the **index-(random-letters-numbers).js** file that was produced - you see that in it there is a variable "**a**" whose content is the entire employees array##readsafilefake - this JavaScript file will be **sent to the browser** along with the HTML and CSS files - so when your users visit your website, your JSON file **is not read from the hard drive** at all - rather, this **JavaScript array** that contains the content of your original JSON file is simply **sent down to the browser** with the rest of the HTML, CSS and JavaScript

title: Learn to use state variables and events to change the state of React site
body:
- **purpose of this howto** - learn **useState** and **event handling** in a React application - **most important concepts and skills** - **concepts** - **Q:** how is a state variable different than a regular variable - **A:** when a state variable is changed - the current components are rerendered - your entire application will be updated based on the new value of the state variable - **Q:** how do you change the value of a state variable - **A:** with a set variable, e.g. `setCount(count + 1)` - **Q:** why for an **string**, **number** or **boolean**, can you simply save the changed state variable - **A:** because these kinds of variables are saved on the stack - when you update a string, number or boolean, you are actually creating a new string, number or boolean with the updated value - which means when you change them, React recognizes that they changed - **Q:** why for an **array** or **object**, do you have to save a **copy** of the state variable - **A:** because arrays and objects are saved on the **heap** - they only point to values - if you don't change the pointer to the value, React will not recognize that the variable changed - React compares the references of the old and new objects. If the references are the same, React assumes that nothing has changed and does not trigger a re-render - state variables are **internally immutable** - this means you have to send a **complete copy** of them into your set function so that your application is properly updated - this is a concept of **functional programming** as opposed to **object-oriented programming** - **Q:** why you should deep clone objects with structuredClone() not spread operator - **A:** using the spread operator to copy an object creates only a shallow copy - using structuredClone() to copy an object creates a true deep clone - see: [Why you should deep clone objects with structuredClone() not spread operator](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/758) - **Q:** what important thing happens when state changes - **A:** all of your components re-render - **skills** - create and change state variables with useState - string - number - boolean - array - object - create a button that uses onClick to change a state variable - create an input field that uses onChange to change a state variable - **code is here:** - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et913-react-state-events - **online site is here:** - https://et913-react-state-events.vercel.app - **site works like this:**#gif#thestateeventstiedemo - **>>> 1. title: Learn how to make an interactive form with FormData in React by creating a content management app that publishes at Vercel
body:
- **the purpose of this howto** - this howto is **part one of a two-part howto** in which we will create two types of forms in React - (1) a **simple form** with FormData - (2) a **complex form** with state variables - **what we will build** - this site will run as a **local React application** in which you can add data to a database (a JSON file) via forms - when you publish the site to **Vercel**, the pages which contain the forms will not be displayed - only the pages that display data will be displayed - this is a **practical and safe** way to create a content management system for an online website - so in the process of completing these two howtos, you will - build a simple **content management system** for yourself or others - learn the difference between **two kinds of forms** you can build - (1) an HTML form with **FormData** - simple and practical - this technique is also being used today in [Next.js server-only forms](https://nextjs.org/docs/pages/building-your-application/data-fetching/forms-and-mutations) - (2) a custom, feature-rich, client-side solution with **state variables** for more complex, interactive forms - in this howto we will build the first kind of form - there are many other tools and concepts will use to build this application such as - **json-server** to store our data - **environment variables** to determine if the app is in development or production mode - we use **Postman** briefly to test the json-server API - basic **React Router** to have multiple pages - how to create an **npm run dev** script that starts two applications listening on two ports - (1) a Vite React site - (2) a json-server API - **GitHub repository:** - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et711-react-forms-site - **live site:** - https://et711-react-forms-site.vercel.app - **site will work like this:** - you add data to your JSON file locally with user-friendly forms - when you publish online, your site is read-only##theofandonline - **most important concepts, skills and tools** - **concepts** - **what are the two main different ways to create custom forms in React** - 1. use FormData which automatically collects data from fields based on their **name** attribute - the FormData API became a W3C Recommendation in 2015 - today it is supported by all major browsers - use this if you do not need instant validation or if the standard HTML form validation is sufficient - 2. with an object state variable which has a property for each field which is itself an object - this is a bit more work in setting up - but it allows you to create custom, complex live validation - e.g. you could query an API and appropriately respond based on what the user is typing in a field - this method allows you to control every aspect of the user experience while using a form - **why don't you need to set up state variables for each field when using FormData?** - because FormData automatically reads the values of the form fields based on their **name** attribute - **what do environment variables do?** - these variables are outside of your website and store configuration settings for a particularly environemnt, usually for development, testing and production - an example might be - in Vite sites and Node backends, you save environment variables in an **.env** file - at Vercel, you can enter environment variables for a specific site##tehvensavercel - **what do you have to do after you change an environment variable locally** - restart your application with `npm run dev` - **what do you have to do after you change an environment variable at a provide like Vercel** - redeploy the site - **why is it that we can use json-server locally in this app, but not at Vercel** - because of the fact that Vercel does not have a backend in the sense that your local machine has a backend - Vercel does not have a file-system - it does have a **backend cloud-function area** where you can fetch data from an online database or API and send it to the browser, e.g. using Next.js - understanding this is key to understanding the direction React is moving with the SSR and SSG trends##thenosqlite - **skills** - **how do you read an environment variable in Vite** - put it in an .env file as e.g. `VITE_ENVIRONMENT = development` - then read it out in your Vite app with `const environment = import.meta.env.VITE_ENVIRONMENT;` - **how to you set up a site so that with "npm run dev" you start the frontend Vite site and the "backend" json-server?** - install **npm-run-all** - set up npm scripts in **package.json** e.g. ---------------------------------------- "dev": "run-p api frontend", "api": "json-server --watch ./src/data/db.json --port 4801", "frontend": "vite --port 4800 --open", ---------------------------------------- - 	- Remix is based on web standards
	- "Remix is a remix of the fundamentals of the early web with the user experience of the modern web. That's why it's called Remix, we're remixing how simple it was to build apps years ago with how complex apps are today in terms of user interaction." //quote
	- Remix is a server-rendered web framework so there's no static site generation with Remix and that's extremely intentional. The best UX is impossible with SSG, that's it.
	- Remix is good at nested routing, it can have file-system routing like Nest.js and Gatsby
		- but Remix also has layout-nested routing
		- each file is a route (pronounces it [rowt])
		- each component says: I am responsible for this, and if I have any children, they go here
		- if you don't have layout UI routes, routes are responsible for the entire page
			- this is why you have a layout route in Next.js
	- with nested routing, you don't have the problem at all
		- the team that is reponsible for the left header is going to be in charge of route including loading the data for it
			- the child doesn't think anything about the parent, it's totally independent, if it needs to get data, it can
			- if the parent needs to know something about the children, e.g. to render a bread crumb area for them, they can find out about their children, but they don't have to know about their children
		- in Remix the team isolation is very nice
		- Remix solves the problem of spinners and bounce-around-jankiness
	- Remix is your bundler, your compiler, your data fetching library, and your router
		- we know all of your data requirements and your code requirements, just by looking at your URL
			- this helps us preload
			- we're using link tags with prefetch
	- "In Remix, we just use forms the way the web was designed from the beginning, so in the same file you have a server-side action which handles the form for you. When you submit the form, you get a full page refresh so the HTML you get back is all up to date, like in the old days. There are ways to fine tune this if you need that optimization, but the point is the HTML on your page after a form submit is always correct."##formfrombeg //quote
	- the problem with React error boundaries is they don't work on server render

	- "ISR, n. (Incremental Static Regeneration), a hybrid approach that combines the benefits of SSR (Server Side Rendering) and SSG (Static Site Generation). It allows for the partial regeneration of static pages at build time and runtime. During the build process, some pages are pre-rendered as static HTML, while others are marked as stale. When a user requests a stale page, the server regenerates it on-the-fly and caches the result for subsequent requests. ISR strikes a balance between performance and real-time data, making it suitable for dynamic but frequently visited pages."  //quote
	- "How does Remix handle state management? / What is state management? No, just kidding, but only sort of, since I'm going to show you that you don't actually think about state management when you're using Remix. No Redux, no Apollo, no MobX, no React Query, no application state management. title: Data-loading with React Router: createBrowserRouter, useEffect data-loading, React Query
body:
- **the purpose of this howto** - examine the topic of data-loading in React sites including - (1) the new **createBrowserRouter** which enables you to load data for each route - (2) conventional data-loading strategies using useEffect - (3) basic data-loading features of React Query - discover and discuss advantages and disadvantages of these approaches - **what we will build** - we will build a website with createBrowserRouter - each page will have a different data-loading strategy - **code is here** - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et201-createbrowserrouter-site - **live site is here** - https://et201-createbrowserrouter-site.vercel.app - **===== MOST IMPORTANT CONCEPTS, SKILLS AND TOOLS =====** - **concepts** - **what is the difference between BrowserRouter and createBrowserRouter** - **BrowserRouter** - older and much more widely used - has more documentation, examples, tutorials and videos - is still a very useful solution to routing in React applications - **createBrowserRouter** - newer and so less widely used - has forward-looking paradigms particularly regarding data loading and form handling - documentation, examples and tutorials are sparse - has its own variations - e.g. most tutorials I found teach createBrowserRouter with [createRoutesFromElements](https://reactrouter.com/en/main/utils/create-routes-from-elements) - is not simple to learn - I could get data-loading to work, but it is blocking - can't get it to load asynchronously - I can implement suspense but it's still blocking - **which approach should you choose for new projects** - **BrowserRouter** is the **conversative** choice - use it for mission-critical, public-facing sites - **createBrowserRouter** is the **progressive** choice - start learning it now and use it when you can - the approaches that it uses are part of the server-side direction in which React is moving - it's not low-hanging fruit but rather a collection of new paradigms you learn over time and after multiple tries - learn other frameworks and pay attention to new data-loading approaches they are introducing - particularly Remix, which more or less uses createBrowserRouter at its core - perhaps even switch to it in public-facing sites - since using its data-loading features is optional - outside data-loading and actions, many concepts are similar or the same as with BrowserRouter - **what is the relationship between React Router and Remix** - both are made by the same team of developers - but there isn't a 1-to-1 correspondance that I could see - **where is a good place to learn more about createRouterBrowser and data-loading routes** - this extensive tutorial from the React Router team in which you create a CRUD site - 	- "So why use Redux, doesn't React today come with a useReducer that kind of basically does the same thing? Yes, it is similar, but it also lacks a lot of the bells and whistles that Redux has. Reducer is like a single speed bike which is useful for getting around town, but it's not a mountain bike or a racing bike like Redux is. Redux has things like middleware, bindings for higher order components, features that will take care of memorization, etc. In a large enough applciation, you're either going to use Redux or you'll find yourself putting so many plugins into useReducer that you'll effectively recreate Redux without the same level of support." //quote

body:
- **what you will learn** - we're going to build a simple site with Angular 17 (released November 2023) that uses many of the basic concepts that are unique to Angular including CLI-created, 4-file components, ng-directives, pipes, plus learn to use Angular's class structure such as constructors and decorators like @Component, how to use props, and set up user interactivity such as button clicking, etc. and practical skills such as how to set up a routing menu and fetch and display API data on the page, build a search box that responds instantly, reference images with img tags and make sure they work both locally and when published at Vercel - **finished project** - full code is here: - from Dec 2023: https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et673-angular-site (Angular 17, live-coding) - from Dec 2023: https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et672-angular-site (Angular 17) - from Feb 2023: https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et111-angular-site (Angular 15) - live site here: - https://et673-angular-site.vercel.app - finished site works like this:#gif#theangularsdemo - **background** - this howto is useful for **React developers** to get up to speed with **Angular** - we will build **a simple but useful site** with Angular which has basic features such as: - **multiple pages** with navbar and URL routes - **user interaction** with checkboxes and buttons - fetched data using axios from an **external API** - a **search box** that filters the API-fetched data that is displayed as one types - **component-based organization** to keep the code organized - you'll learn where to **save and access images** within the site - you will also publish this site at **Vercel** - in building this site, you will also learn Angular concepts that are not familiar to React - **command-line creation** of components - each component consists of four files - **template file** (HTML with directives/pipes etc.) - **class file** (TypeScript) - **style file** (SCSS) - **test file** (default Karma) - **directives** to facilitate user interaction - creating custom directives - **pipes** to alter data in the template - creating custom pipes - **decorators** to attach meta-data to classes - working in an **object-oriented programming** paradigm with classes/methods instead of functional programming functions/hooks - Angular uses **TypeScript** by default - **overview of Angular concepts** - intro - learning Angular is in large part learning new concepts - coming from a React background, many of these concepts are new - the following are a list of concepts that one learns as one learns Angular - in this tutorial we will not do an example of every concept - we will create an example of many of them - but we also want to get an understanding of every concept in terms of this howto example - concepts we will cover in this howto - **components** - in Angular you create components as you do in React - however, in Angular, to create a component you use the CLI, e.g. - `ng generate component employees` - this will create a directory called **employees** and four files:##directandfiles - the four files are - **template** file (`.html`) - **style sheet** file (`.scss`) - **test** file (`.spec.ts`) - **class** file (`.ts`) - **templates** - a template is the HTML that builds the struture of the component - this file has an .html extension - but the HTML in the file has other capabilities such as directives (e.g. `ngIf`, `ngSwitch`, `ngFor`, etc.) ------------------------------------------
This info-box warns a user. Success is displayed when no action is required. Unknown status code: {{status}}
------------------------------------------ - **OOP** - where React (since 2019) is based on **functional programming** with **functions** and **hooks** as the main structural components - Angular is based on **object-oriented programming** with **classes** and **methods** as the main structural components - one of the four files in every component is a class file, e.g. **info-box.component.ts** ---------------------------------------------- import { Component } from '@angular/core'; import { IEmployee } from 'src/shared/interfaces'; import axios from 'axios'; @Component({ selector: 'app-employees', templateUrl: './employees.component.html', styleUrls: ['./employees.component.scss'] }) export class EmployeesComponent { employees: IEmployee[] = []; searchText: string = ''; constructor() { (async () => { const rawEmployees = (await axios.get('https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/share/employees.json')).data; rawEmployees.forEach((rawEmployee: any) => { this.employees.push({ firstName: rawEmployee.firstName, lastName: rawEmployee.lastName, notes: rawEmployee.notes }) }) })(); } employeeHasSearchText(emp: IEmployee): boolean { const bulkText = emp.firstName + '|' + emp.lastName + '|' + emp.notes; return bulkText.toLowerCase().includes(this.searchText.toLowerCase()); } } ---------------------------------------------- - note: - **employees** and **searchText** are class variables - they are referenced with the `this.` prefix, i.e. a variable in *this* class - props that are sent to components (none in this example) are also class variables - **employeeHasSearchText** is a class method (function that belongs to a class) - there is a constructor which runs when the class is created - **directives** - commands that add additional behavior to elements in Angular templates - two types - structural - e.g. **ngIf**##ngifjfidj - attribute - e.g. **ngStyle**##thengstyle - these typically perform similar functionality as conditional rendering and e.g. .map() in JSX - **decorators** - used to attach metadata to a class, method, accessor, property, or parameter - we apply the decorator using the form @expression, where expression is the name of the decorator - decorators are **Typescript features** and still not part of the Javascript - e.g. this is a decorator called **@Component** that is included in every class file - it associates a component with particular template and style files ------------------------------------------ @Component({ selector: 'app-info-box', templateUrl: './info-box.component.html', styleUrls: ['./info-box.component.scss'] }) ------------------------------------------ - e.g. @Input is a decorator for a property of a component, the equivalent of props in React##antheinputprops - **bindings** - allow data to flow between a component's class and its template - there are four kinds of bindings - **interpolation** - e.g. `{{title}}` - **property binding** - `[disabled]="isDisabled"` - **event binding** - `` - **two-way binding** - `` - **pipes** - take in data as input and transforms it into an output - e.g. `
{{title | uppercase}}
` - **forms** - reactive and template-driven - concepts we won't cover in this howto but which one should know about and eventually learn as an Angular developer - **services** - objects that get **instantiated just once** during the lifetime of an application - they are similar to components but don't have HTML - they enable components to load and change a data source, somewhat similar to useContext - you can see an example of a service [in this howto](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/690) which is Angular 16, but in Angular 17 they changed to a "standalone" approach and so services are implemented differently - **built-in testing** - note that when components are created, they automatically create a test file - **the observable type with RxJS** - RxJS is a library for reactive programming using observables that makes it easier to compose asynchronous or callback-based code - **dependency injection** - [Dependency Injection](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GUcWjYHmYhY) (deutsch) - **animations** - Angular's animation system is built on CSS functionality, which means you can animate any property that the browser considers animatable - this includes positions, sizes, transforms, colors, borders, and more - **>>> 1. Create basic Angular site** - in terminal, go to projects folder - install the Angular CLI - when you develop in Angular, you use the CLI (Command Line Interface) - check if it is installed and what version you have: - `ng version` - if it shows an error, then install the CLI like this: - `npm install -g @angular/cli@latest` - then try `ng version` again##theangnpm - create Angular site - to create an Angular site, type `ng new` followed by the name of the directory you want the site to have - `ng new et672-angular-site` - choose SCSS - choose no SSR or SSG for now - it installs in about 40 seconds##choosesasskjkj - open the project in VSCode e.g. - `code et672-angular-site` - note that - node_modules have been created - Git repository is installed - look at **package.json**##thengstart - to start the site - `npm start` - to start the site in your browser, ctrl-click the link##click4200222 - the site will look like this:##angsitelikethis - note just as with Vite, to change the local port the site runs on, you use with the same syntax - change from 4200 to 4300 - **package.json** -------------------------------- "start": "ng serve --port 4300", -------------------------------- - restart and the site now runs on port 4300 - install VSCode Extension for Angular##angularextensions - publish at Vercel - let's publish this base site at Vercel and make sure it continues to work online as we develop - push to a repository on GitHub##publisbrjj222 - publish it as private or public (either way it will publish at Vercel) - go to [Vercel](https://vercel.com) - Add New - Project - Import##thajwangverc - Deploy - Angular start site publishes without problems:##onlinejsoverc - **>>> 2. Notes on Video: "Prisma Vs. TypeORM Vs. Sequelize | Which is Better?"
body:
- VIDEO is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8WoeGcJ_nNM
- recorded Jun 2023
- summary
	- Prisma and TypeORM are similar
		- the larger the project, and particulary if TypeScript is important, choose Prisma
		- smaller projects, even with Typescript, you can choose TypeORM
	- only use Sequelize if you are working on a project that already uses Sequalize
	- his choice is: **Prisma**
		- using for 2 years
		- it's 100% TypeScript support is future-oriented
		- works well with PlanetScale
- **Prisma (2016)**
	- the ORM that seems like everyone is talking about nowadays
	- modern and lightweight
	- supports TypeScript out of the box
	- pros
		- good support for TypeScript
		- good [documentation](https://www.prisma.io/docs/orm/overview/introduction)
		- good developer experience
			- Prisma studio##theprismdfstudio
		- it's popular and gaining notoriety and hence has a lot support in the community
		- works will with PlanetScale
- **TypeORM (2016)**
	- supports a wide variety of databases
	- support for transactions
	- cons
		- learning curve can be harder, not a quick and simple solution
		- although it has support for TypeScript, not even close to Prism's full support
- **Sequelize (2010)**
	- the oldest of the three
	- probably the easiest to learn
	- a promise-based ORM that works in Node.js
	- he doesn't use it anymore
	- pros
		- has the bigger variety of database compatibility
		- easy to get answers to problems since it has been around for so long
	- cons
		- the syntax is very verbose
			- not as 
		- not good support for TypeScript
			- people are steering away from Sequalize because of this
- others
	- not as popular as the above three:
		- [MicroORM](https://mikro-orm.io)
		- [ObjectionJS](https://vincit.github.io/objection.js)
	- Mongoose
		- not an ORM for SQL databases as all the aboe are
		- it's an ODM (Object Document Mapper) for Mongoose

But it's never that simple, because relationships kill this simplicity. As soon as you have one resource that needs another resource, as we do in our app, it gets complicated. If someone asks for a product, and product has a relationship with product details, we have to ask ourselves, do we send them product details as well? And you say, well let them ask for it in the query string. But then you're just creating your own query language. So REST works up until about 2005 and then it doesn't work anymore. But we're still going to use it because mostly everything is based on REST anyway. So let's create some routes." //quote

First of all, nothing is technically stopping you from using get for every CRUD acction when you create a REST API, these verbs are just suggested conventions if you're following REST guidelines. But according to the guidelines, when you put an object, you should replace everything in an object except the id, and when you use patch, you should only update the properties you send up." //quote
	- "Hmm, do I prefer gRPC over REST? I would recommend using gRPC if you are creating an API for an application that you use internally by a client that you also work on, for example if you are making an API only for a frontend app you are creating. Yeah, then gRPC all the way, since you don't need your API broken up per resource like you typically do in REST, since you are often going to need to update more than one resource, which can be four or five different API calls. In gRPC, you just call one function that makes all the updates that you need when you call it from your frontend. But gRPC is not great for external APIs that other developers are going to use, because it's too specialized, you don't know what their use cases are for consuming your API. And, of course, if you're going to monatize your API, it's in your interest to require your users to make more API calls." //quote

	- what is a JWT
		- "JWT is basically this: you take a JavaScript object, and that JavaScript object, given a secret, which is a string, can deterministically be converted to a random string, and that string can be converted back to the same object given that secret, it's similar to hashing. The reason we use JWTs is so we don't have to store anything on the server. The alternative would be a session where you have to keep track of who is logged into your API at any time, which eats up resources with session management. With a JWT, it's the client, not the server, who has to store the token and has to send it along with every subsequent request to the server because the server is going to check it every single request to make sure it is the token the client originally was issued after they successfully identified themselves." //quote

	- **auth.ts**
		---------------------------------------
		import jwt from 'jsonwebtoken';

		export const createJWT = (user) => {
			const token = jwt.sign({ id: user.id, username: user.username }, process.env.JWT_SECRET as string);
			return token;
		}
		---------------------------------------
	- "What's the preferred me thod for storing the JWT on the client side? I've tried many different places, what I landed on eventually was just storing it in the cookie. I think storing it in a cookie is ideal because cookies are automatically sent up. It just saves you time on the front end. It gets kind of tedious having to access localStorage every time you want to grab your JSON web token and attach it to the header, or come up with some interceptor on the frontend that does it for you automatically, whereas cookies get automatically sent to the server so the server can just check them. But on the server, I actually prefer the token to be on the authorization header, which makes more sense. So from the client perspective, I like having the JWT in the cookie, but from the server perspective, I prefer to have it in the authorization header. So I guess it depends on what side of the project I'm working on. But today, we're on the server side, so it's going in the authorization header, which means it will probably be in localStorage." //quote

	- wide column databases
		- Google Bigtable

	- message broker

		- [Azure Cosmos DB](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cosmos-db/introduction)

	- ACID
		- atomicity
			- does this query happen all at once
			- i.e. transactions: if I subtract 10 euros from your account and add 10 to mine, we want both to happen or neither to happen
		- consistency
			- always have multiple databases running at the same time, so if one goes down, the others fill in 
		- isolation
			- you can run pieces of a query concurrently
		- durability
			- if your server crashes, you can restore it to the state it was previously
		- ACID is safe, but it's slow
		- transactions
			- many queries you can't break up
			- either all of these queries happen, or none

It was a really hot marketing term in, like, 2010 and just stuck. It's a meaningless term, but I'm using it because you'll be seeing it everywhere in the documentation and marketing material. What we'll really be talking about today is a document-based database. One of the biggest advantages of a document database is that it is schemaless so you can actually be defining a data schema on the fly. It makes it really easy to get up and running with one of these, and it is very conducive to the dynamic scripting kind of thinking that you would get from a JavaScript or Python type language. Document databases are a double-edged sword where while you never have to define your databases up front, if you misspell a field name, then your database will say oh you're creating a new field, here you go, so you have to be careful. With great power comes great responsibility." //quote

The reason why I encourage you to use this mental model is that TypeScript only does things for you during development and build time, not a run time. Using TypeScript is not the same as using C# or Java which have type validation at run time. So think of TypeScript as something that helps you while you're building your project, and then sort of melts away when your project gets compiled and pushed to the production server as regular JavaScript with no type checking." //quote - starting to become a ubiquitous part of a modern frontend stak - "Why are types such a big deal? Why is TypeScript so popular? Well, first of all, it lets you leave more of your intent on the page. If you mean something to be a number, then specify it as a number. If you mean something to be a string, then specify it as a string. Later when a developer, including you, tries to use a string where you meant it to be a number, TypeScript will let you know that this was not your original intent. And this will prevent errors later at runtime. So TypeScript removes things that typically would be problems at runtime into development time so that you get this feedback earlier." //quote - "In larger applications, JavaScript gets to a point where you start tripping over your own shoelaces. You begin to not be able to hold the conventions that you established in your own mind, and TypeScript helps you put that into source code." //quote - https://frontendmasters.com/courses/typescript-v4/workshop-setup - 	- one of the earliest programming languages, Lisp pioneered many ideas in computer science, including 
		- tree data structures
		- automatic storage management
		- dynamic typing
		- conditionals
		- higher-order functions
		- recursion
		- the self-hosting compiler

	- procedural language

		- the less features, the easier to use

	- characteristics
		- simplicity

					- 9,500 lines will give you an operating system
