LearnApp Project: Fullstack app with full local CRUD frontend/backend which publishes read-only site at Vercel
body:
- **multi-howto project**
	- this LearnApp project extends over multiple howtos
	- these howtos build on each other and so are meant to be done in sequence from the beginning to the end
	- but you can start at any step by cloning the finishing code from the step before it and working from that
	- [LearnApp Part 1: Create backend API with full CRUD functionality that uses lowdb as database](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/804)
	- [LearnApp Part 2: Create React CRUD frontend to communicate with Node/Express CRUD backend](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/806)
	- [LearnApp Part 3: Enable user to delete and edit flashcards via the frontend and publish site at Vercel](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/807)
	- [LearnApp Part 4: Deployment to Vercel using environment variables for local CRUD site and online read-only site](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/809)
	- [LearnApp Part 5: API middleware and routing, and error handling](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/810)
	- [LearnApp Part 6: API testing with Vitest and Supertest](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/813)
- **the live-coding project for this LearnApp project is here**
	- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et888-learnapp
	- after each live-coding, I make a copy of the repository as frozen code for that step
		- in each step, you can find code from
			- (1) the preparation code base
			- (2) the live-coding code base
			- these repositories can differentiate in minor ways, e.g. refactorings which we decided on in the live-coding session, etc.
	- but this project **et888-learnapp** will eventually have the code for the finished project	
- **overview of project**
	- the LearnApp project has two purposes:
		- (1) to **learn how to build a complete CRUD API** including routes, handlers, database, MVC pattern, middleware, error handling, logging, testing
		- (2) to build a **useful application that you can use and extend** to record what you learn
	- technical structure
		- the LearnApp project contains a backend and frontend in **one directory**
		- **backend**: 
			- Node/Express API with [lowdb](https://www.npmjs.com/package/lowdb) as a database
			- TypeScript / ES6 modules
			- the backend exists in /backend and contains
				- `/backend/api`
					- contains all routes necessary for full CRUD of items, e.g. flashcards, howtos, notes, techItems
				- `/backend/cli`
					- CLI can be extended to automatically generate code in backend and frontend
		- **frontend**:
			- Vite-React with createBrowserRouter
			- TypeScript / ES6 modules
			- axios
		- **development/production**
			- the site will look and function completely differently depending on if it is 
				- running locally on your computer - will enable full editing of items
				- published at Vercel - no admin pages will appear, all data will be read-only
			- the site will be published at Vercel	
				- but of course the API running on Node/Express will not work at excel since there is no backend at Vercel
			- therefore, we will have an environment variable called APP_ENVIRONMENT which is "development" locally and "production" at Vercel
			- when environment is "development", the user has full access to all frontend pages and backend API functionality to change all items in user-friendly forms via the frontend, e.g. flashcards
			- the data is saved in **JSON files**
			- when in development, the site reads and writes data via the backend API which access these JSON files
			- when in production, the site has been built (`npm run build`) and so the JSON files have been converted to JavaScript objects
	- **technology and tools NOT used in this project**
		- in order for us to focus on **API design, construction and integration with the frontend**
			- which is enough to learn in itself at one time
			- there are particular areas which we intentionally will not include in this project
		- **(1) no classic database such as SQLite, MySQL, Postgres or MondoDB**
			- we will use **lowdb** as our database, which allows to perform full CRUD on objects in a JSON file with a minimum of code
			- so we won't have to concern ourselves with
				- database installation
				- database-specific syntax such as SQL or MongoDB querying
				- ORMs or ODMs such as Prisma or Mongoose
				- connections strings and online database accessibility
			- note that if we wanted to learn SQL, **SQLite** would be a good replacement for **lowdb** since 
				- it requires no installation
				- the database is simply one local (binary) file, similar to lowdb's one local (text/JSON) file
		- **(2) no login, authentication or authorization**
			- since the idea of this application is to have one local user who 
				- creates and edits data locally on their computer 
				- publishes to a read-only site at Vercel
				- there is no need for authetnication (one merely has to log into the computer on which the application is used)
				- there is no need for authorization (there is only one user who has complete access to code and data locally)
		- **(3) no need for online security implementation**
			- since the published site at Vercel is read-only (Jamstack-style HTML/CSS/JS), has no login and no database
				- there is no need to implement a login, JWT tokens, hash passwords or anything that is normally required of a full-stack application

JavaScript was only a language you could run in the browser, it was considered a kiddie-language, people really didn't take it seriously, because it was like, oh, you can use JavaScript to make a little swirling thing on a Myspace page. So at some point, some guy named Ryan Dahl got really sick of not having JavaScript on his computer, so he made Node.js, which was basically a fork of V8, which is Google's engine to run JavaScript in the Chrome browser. But Node is different in that you can write code in parallel on one thread. It does that by using an event loop. An event loop is basically just a registry for work that needs to be done which enables you to write asynchronous code, and this means Node can handle concurrent requests on one thread, something that is quite unique in the world of languages. This doesn't mean that Node is necessarily faster, for example, Node is really not good at CPU intensive work since it only uses one thread. So Node isn't good at things like machine learning, which is why people tend to use Python for that. But for handling concurrent processes, Node is a very good language and it is Node unique in this way, so especially if you are coming from another language like Ruby, Node makes you rethink how you write your code."//quote

- **what we will learn** - we will build a EJS site - **code is here** - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et370-node-express-ejs-site - 2024-01-16 preparation - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et371-node-express-ejs-site - 2024-01-17 from live-coding - **site is online here** - https://et370-node-express-ejs-site.onrender.com - **site works like this**#gif#gbookskdjbpage - and when you link to individual books on the site in social media, they appear like this####thecslackpost - **background** - this howto serves two purposes - (1) show you how to make Node/Express website with EJS - (2) introduce you to server-side rendering to better understand how it relates to client-side rendering - server-side rendering is becoming more relevant today with frameworks such as **Next.js** and **Nuxt** - and the concepts that you learn in building your own server-side website will help you better understand server-side rendering in general##clienserversiderend - note that in this tutorial we publish our website using a free account at **Render** - **free accounts** at Render enable you to make as many "web services" as you want (e.g. Node/Express APIs, websites) - but after they are not accessed for **15 minutes**, they **spin down** and are **inactive** - the next time they are accessed via their URL, they have to **spin up** which can take up to **90 seconds** - waiting 90 seconds for a website to appear is not usable in almost any circumstance expect for learning purposes as in this howto - therefore, if you want to actually publish a Node/Express/EJS site that is usable on the Internet, use - a free account at [Cyclic](https://www.cyclic.sh), but here you can only publish **one site** - a paid (around 10€/month) account at a hosting provider such as [DigitalOcean](https://www.digitalocean.com) or [Hetzner](https://www.hetzner.com) - although the process to set up a site on a cloud machine requires more **know-how and time** than at user-friendly hosting services such as Render or Cyclic - but server websites from a cloud machine is also good devops experience, e.g. setting up an **nginx server** with **pm2**, setting up and **domain** name, **subdomain** name, configuring **https**, etc. - and using cloud machines you can of course host an **unlimited amount of sites** and have **complete control** the environment to install literally anything in the environment that your website is running - **>>> 1. Build simplest Node/Express web server with TypeScript** - we will start with a blank directory for our project - in your project folder, create the folder e.g. **et370-node-express-ejs-site** (use your own initials and number of course) - copy in VSCode `code et370-node-express-ejs-site` - create npm project - `npm init -y` - install Git - `git init -b dev` - make initial commit - **.gitignore** ------------------------------------ .vscode node_modules .env ------------------------------------ - install Express - `npm i express` - `npm i -D @types/express` - **src/index.ts** ------------------------------------------- import express from 'express'; const app = express(); const port = 4112; app.get('/', (req, res) => { res.send(` Info Site

Info Site

`); }); app.listen(port, () => { console.log(`Listening at http://localhost:${port}`); }); ------------------------------------------- - set up prettier - **.prettierrc** ---------------------------------- { "trailingComma": "es5", "tabWidth": 4, "semi": true, "useTabs": true, "singleQuote": false } ---------------------------------- - set up start script **npm run dev** with TypeScript - install tsx (to run TypeScript files) - `npm i -D tsx` - set up nodemon (to watch for when TypeScript files change so server can be restarted) - `npm i -D nodemon` - **package.json** ----------------------------------------- "dev": "nodemon", "nodemonConfig": { "watch": [ "src" ], "ext": "ts, json", "exec": "tsx src/index.ts" }, ----------------------------------------- - you will see your site in your browser:##willseesite - **>>> 2. Add CSS file to style the page** - **index.ejs** - add link to CSS file ---------------------------------------------- ---------------------------------------------- - you now have to consider, where should you put **main.css**? - your HTML is being served from the "/" route on your server, much like for an API - and so HTML files being served here have no access to any files on our server - but the HTML that we send to the client expects to have under it a directory **css** and in that directory a file named **main.css** - so we need to somehow **serve this CSS file as well** - the way we do this is to define a folder on our server called **public** which has in it **static files** which can be accessed from the HTML that we send to the client, e.g. - **public/css**: CSS files - **public/js**: *client-side* JavaScript files - **public/images**: images - **public/media**: media files such as audio or video files - **public/download**: any downloadable files such as PDF or Zip files - **public/css/main.css** ------------------------------------- body { background-color: #ccc; padding: 0 1rem; font-family: sans-serif; } ------------------------------------- - now define this public directory as the directory that will serve the static files for our site - **index.ts** -------------------------------------------------- app.use(express.static('public')); -------------------------------------------------- - your page will be formatted with the CSS file##hhformaskjdf - note that when you **view source**, you can navigate to the **main.css** file to which your browser has access - since it is being served as a static file along with any other file and directory we put in the **public** directory##notesonjsiesour - and note that this set up also works at Render, even after compiling our TypeScript files to JavaScript in the **npm run build** process:##onrenderfixjcss - **>>> 8. Create books and about pages** - we will now add a menu and three pages to our site: **Welcome**, **Books**, **About** - renaming refactoring - rename **src/index.ts** to **src/server.ts** which makes more sense - be sure to fix this in **package.json** - **package.json** ------------------------------------------------- "scripts": { "dev": "nodemon", "start": "node dist/server.js", "build": "tsc -p tsconfig.json" }, "nodemonConfig": { "watch": [ "src" ], "ext": "ts, json", "exec": "tsx src/server.ts" }, ------------------------------------------------- - rename **src/pages/index.ejs** to **src/pages/welcome.ejs** which makes more sense - **server.ts** ---------------------------------------- app.get('/', (req, res) => { res.render('pages/welcome', { books: model.getBooks() }); }); app.get('/books', (req, res) => { res.render('pages/books', {}); }); app.get('/about', (req, res) => { res.render('pages/about', {}); }); ---------------------------------------- - **src/views/pages/books.ejs** --------------------------------------------- Books

title: Create server-side Node/Express site with Handlebars and implement client-side loading
body:
- **what we will create** - in this howto, we will create a local Node/Express website with TypeScript - instead of using the templating engine EJS as we did in [this howto](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/814), we will use **Handlebars** - **EJS and Handlebars** are equally popular with **13 million downloads** per week - as a comparison of popularity: - **Axios** has **47 million downloads** per week - **Express** has **26 million downloads** per week - **React** has **21 million downloads** per week - **Winston** has **10 million downloads** per week - **Handlebars** has arguably a **simpler syntax than EJS** and so is a good choice for building websites with Node/Express##ejshandgraph - **why create a Node/Express site with a templating engine** - websites built with **Node/Express** don't really compete with - client-side frameworks such as React, Angular and Vue.js - server-side *+ client-side* frameworks such as Next.js, Nuxt and Remix - but rather compete with **classic server-side solutions**: - **Laravel** websites (**PHP** backend, **TypeScript** frontend) - **.NET** websites (**C#** backend, **TypeScript** frontend) - **Django** websites (**Python** backend, **TypeScript** frontend) - **Spring Boot** websites (**Java** backend, **TypeScript** frontend) - **Node/Express** websites (**TypeScript** backend, **TypeScript** frontend) - in this space, the obvious advantage that **Node/Express** websites have is - you have the **same language in the frontend as you do in the backend** - since **TypeScript has become a mature language** that compares with C# and Java, you no longer have a disadvantage with JavaScript - also, combining a classic server-side solution with a client-side solution such as Vue.js - you can **manually build** a custom website that deliever solutions not unlike **Next.js** and **Nuxt** - as a learning exercise, building custom website with Node/Express with TypeScript in the backend and frontend, is a good way to more deeply understand the concepts which the server-side JavaScript frameworks such as Next.js and Nuxt are solving today##clienserversiderend - having the **skills** to set up a quick Node/Express website enables you to quickly build - **developer tools** that run on either your local network, e.g. - monitoring dashboards - data-conversion tools - custom internal tools that enable you to control internal processes, workflows via a web interface - the main advantage of backend frameworks is the combination that they have - complete access to the **operating system** to be able to e.g. - create/delete/change files and directory - start/stop processes - ability to interact with the user/developer via a **web browser** - companies use templating engines and [list them as desired/required skills](https://de.indeed.com/jobs?q=handlebars&l=&from=searchOnHP&vjk=89f7cdbef8180b2b) - **features we will build into the website in this howto** - in order to demonstrate some of these advantages of a Node/Express web site - in the project in this howto, we will - create a hybrid site by using Vue.js to enhance client-side interaction - **site will work like this** - it will look the same as the EJS site - but will implement client-side loading in order to provide a better user experience with e.g. slow-loading data#gif#thewaitijgksbooks - **code is here** - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et411-node-express-handlebars-site - 2024-01-17 research (incomplete code) - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et412-node-express-handlebars-site - 2024-01-17 preparation - **>>> 1. Set up copy of Node/Express/TypeScript/EJS site** - copy and clone the Node/Express/TypeScript/EJS project repository - instead of starting from scratch, we will convert a functioning Node/Express/TypeScript/EJS website that we made with [this howto](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/814) - and simply swap out EJS with Handlebars - if you want to learn the process of building up such a site from scratch, then work through that howto first - go to the [repository](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et371-node-express-ejs-site) of the Node/Express/TypeScript/EJS site - click on **Use this template** and **Create a new repository**##thestmeplusejkd - give your repository a name such as **et412-node-express-handlebars-site**##thanemreposjsjs - in your terminal, clone the project e.g. `git clone git@github.com:edwardtanguay/et412-node-express-handlebars-site.git` - enter VSCode in that directory with e.g. `code et411-node-express-handlebars-site.git` - setup and start website - `npm i` - `npm run dev` - CTRL-click on the url shown##ctrlclickonit - the site should work like this in your browser#gif#likethisthesiteinbro - **>>> 2. Convert base site to Handlebars** - install handlebars - `npm i express-handlebars` - - **server.ts** -------------------------------------- import { engine } from 'express-handlebars'; app.engine('.hbs', engine({ extname: '.hbs', layoutsDir: path.join(baseDir, '/src/views/layouts'), partialsDir: path.join(baseDir, '/src/views/partials'), })); app.set('view engine', '.hbs'); -------------------------------------- - convert all **.ejs** extensions to **.hbs** - **>>> 3. Convert welcome page to Handlebars** - load the welcome page in the browser now, and you will see that Handlebars is looking for a **main layout** file##needsthemain - unlike EJS, Handlebars always requires a default **layout** named **main** so let's set that up - **src/views/layouts/main.hbs** ------------------------------------------- INFO SITE {{{body}}} ------------------------------------------- - since our **main layout** now has the HTML/BODY code for each site - reduce **welcome.hbs** down to what will be inside the body --------------------------------------------

Welcome to this site.

-------------------------------------------- - you will see a minimal site:##hbwlecomjs - passing a variable to a page is the same as in EJS: - **server.ts** ------------------------------------------------- const versionName = 'Handlebars 1.0'; app.get('/', (req, res) => { res.render('pages/welcome', {versionName}); }); app.get('/welcome', (req, res) => { res.render('pages/welcome', {versionName}); }); ------------------------------------------------- - for variables, where EJS had `<%= varName %>`, Handlebars has `{{{varName}}}` - **welcome.hbs** --------------------------------------------------

Welcome to the {{{versionName}}} version of this site.

-------------------------------------------------- - welcome page now shows the variable##showthatjsversion - add style sheet - **main.hbs** - make sure you put a **/** in front of the style sheet path, to make it absolute ------------------------------------------------ ------------------------------------------------ - stylesheet is now attached##stylessshsdfj - implement the Handlebars version of the menu partial - **menu.hbs** -----------------------------------------
Welcome Books About
----------------------------------------- - oddly, Handlebars doesn't support conditional string comparison natively - so we have to "create and register a helper" to do this, we will call it **ifEquals** - install **handlebars** itself (we installed **express-handlebars** above) - `npm i handlebars` - **server.ts** --------------------------------------------------------- import Handlebars from 'handlebars'; Handlebars.registerHelper('ifEquals', (arg1, arg2, options) => { return (arg1 == arg2) ? options.fn(this) : options.inverse(this); }); --------------------------------------------------------- - where EJS used `<%- partialName, {prop: value} %>` to include a partial, Handlebars uses `{{>partialName prop="value"}}` - **welcome.hbs** ---------------------------------------------- {{>menu pageIdCode="welcome"}} ---------------------------------------------- - you now have a menu##nowhavemeneue - add header partial - **header.hbs** is the same as with EJS - since the head is on every page, in Handlebars we can add it to the layout - **main.hbs** ------------------------------------- {{>header}} {{{body}}} ------------------------------------- - you now have a header##nowhaveheadfdkfj - **>>> 4. Convert books page to Handlebars** - if you click at the books page now, you see the old EJS syntax:##thebookspajskdjd - paste in the Handlebars version of the page - **books.hbs** --------------------------------------------------- {{>menu pageIdCode="books"}}

Convert book page to Handlebars** - if you click on one of the books, you see the book page with the old EJS syntax:##thebookspajskdjd222 - **book.hbs** --------------------------------------------------- {{>menu pageIdCode="books"}}

--------------------------------------------------- - about page converted##aboutpagkjd - **>>> 7. Convert the 404 page to Handlebars** - **404.hbs** --------------------------------------- {{>menu pageIdCode="404"}}

Sorry, you have requested a page that does not exist.

--------------------------------------- - 404 page converted to Handlebars##th404ksdj - **>>> 8. Convert the books page to load client-side instead of server-side** - background - a problem with server-side sites is - if the page takes a long time to load it's data - the user doesn't get to see any data until the page has all its data - a solution to this problem is to send down a minimal amount of HTML to the browser - so that user at least sees something immediately - along with the HTML content - JavaScript is sent as well - which then executes on the browser - while a page loader and/or information is shown to the user - to inform them that data is loading - then the JavaScript code fetches data from a route on your Node/Express application - that acts as an API which serves JSON instead of HTML - in this way, your web server becomes a hybrid **web server** and **API** - optimizing how data loads - in order to optimize the user experience - understanding how this works, gives you insight into the problems that popular server-side web frameworks are trying to solve - such as Next.js, Nuxt, Remix, etc. - let's implement an example of this client-side/server-side hybrid functionality - by sending Vue.js code down with the HTML for our books page - the Vue.js will execute - show a waiting spinner - then fetch and display the books a few seconds later - as a first step, let's send Vue.js code down along with the HTML which simply changes an element on the page - **main.hbs** ---------------------------------------------- ---------------------------------------------- - **books.hbs** -------------------------------------------------

TESTING: [\{{message}}]

There are {{{books.length}}} books.

{{#books}} {{/books}}
------------------------------------------------- - the text inserted by Vue.js will be showed##thevueswiljs - note that the H1 element is not being filled until the JavaScript is loaded and executed on the browser - note also that the **/** is necessary to tell Handlebars not to parse the Vue.js brackets as Handlebar brackets##showthevuehand - **>>> 9. Create an API route that Vue.js can load in the background** - **server.ts** - insert before the 404 catchall route -------------------------------------------------- app.get('/api/books', async (req, res) => { res.json(await model.getBooks()); }); -------------------------------------------------- - the books JSON is now served on http://localhost:4116/api/books##thenojksjwiiapi - **>>> 10. Change the books page so it doesn't render the books on the server anymore** - since we will be loading the books on the client now - we no longer need to load them on the server - instead of showing books, we will show an animated spinner - this will be sent to the client and shown until it is replaced by the books HTML that Vue.js loads on the browser - **main.css** ----------------------------------------- .spinner { margin: 2rem 1rem; padding: 2rem; border: 1rem solid rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1); border-top: 1rem solid orangered; border-radius: 50%; width: 40px; height: 40px; animation: spin 1s linear infinite; } @keyframes spin { 0% { transform: rotate(0deg); } 100% { transform: rotate(360deg); } } ----------------------------------------- - **books.hbs** ----------------------------------------
---------------------------------------- - now the spinner is shown instead of the books#gif#thespinjjjsshown - **>>> 11. Program Vue.js to load the books and replace the spinner with the book images** - **books.hbs** --------------------------------------------------- {{>menu pageIdCode="books"}}
--------------------------------------------------- - let's put in a 2 second wait in order to emulate slow data loading - **model.ts** -------------------------------------------- setTimeout(() => { resolve(books); }, 2000); -------------------------------------------- - be sure to remove the loading of the books from the **books** route - **server.ts** ---------------------------------------------------- app.get('/books', async (req, res) => { res.render('pages/books'); }); ---------------------------------------------------- - books now load like this:#gif#thewaitijgksbooks

title: Install and try out Bun 1.0
Install MySQL on Ubuntu, import Northwind database and create EJS site that serves data from the MySQL database
body:
- **what we will do** - this howto will show you how to install MySQL on Ubuntu and use in as a database to serve data in a website - **code is here** - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et641-ejs-site-with-mysql - preparation - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et642-ejs-site-with-mysql - live-coding 2024-01-23 - **website looks like this**##mmmmainstijsmysql - **>>> 1. Install MySQL** - these instructions will show you how to - install MySQL on Ubuntu - install MySQL Workbench to manage your MySQL databases - since one time that I installed Workbench on Linux the character encoding was broken, I also show how to install an alternative MySQL manager: DBeaver - if you want to install MySQL on **Windows** instead of Ubuntu, see this howto: - [Install MySQL and MySQL Workbench on Windows and import Northwind database](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/577) - make sure you don't already have MySQL installed - `dpkg --get-selections | grep mysql` - shows six lines with "install" - `mysql -V` - shows: "mysql Ver 8.0.35-0ubuntu0.22.04.1 for Linux on x86_64 ((Ubuntu))" - `mysql -u root -p` - asks for password, the one I saved didn't work - if you don't have it installed, it looks something like this:##nomysqlwithv - if you have MySQL installed, it will look something like this:##mmmhmsql - if you do have MySQL installed for some reason, and want to **uninstall** it to then start with a fresh system - (note that by uninstalling your MySQL server, any data in the MySQL databases will be lost) - `sudo systemctl stop mysql` - `sudo apt-get purge mysql-server mysql-client mysql-common mysql-server-core-* mysql-client-core-*`##mmm234un - `sudo rm -rf /etc/mysql /var/lib/mysql` - `sudo apt autoremove` - `sudo apt autoclean` - **install MySQL** - `sudo apt update` - can take ca. 30 seconds - `sudo apt install mysql-server` - can take ca. 3 minutes - to enter the MySQL server, we need superuser status - `sudo mysql` - note that you area automatically logged in as the **root** user and can freely view all current databases, etc.##mmmshowthedata - as good practice, let's secure the MySQL server as we would have the server in production, which is also a good idea for your local development setup - `ALTER USER 'root'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED WITH mysql_native_password BY 'rootroot';` - the password **rootroot** is simply to show here on this howto - of course change it accordingly to fit your purposes, e.g. - if local test database: use a simple password that is easy to remember - if production: use a highly secure password - `quit` - `sudo mysql_secure_installation`##theanonanon - first two questions about passwords: - for development: answer no - for production: answer yes - remove anonymous users: YES - disallow root remotely: YES - remove test database: YES - reload privilege tables: YES - note that mysql database is now secure, even root user needs mysql password - log in and out to test - `sudo mysql -u root -p`##mmmrootin - log out with `quit` - **>>> 2. Import the Northwind database into MySQL server** - we will now import a realistic database into our MySQL server - download SQL files which we will import as database content - in the Ubuntu terminal, make directory `~/northwindSetup` - https://github.com/dalers/mywind - download as zip file##downloadassszip - unpack and copy these two files to `~/northwindSetup` - northwind.sql - northwind-data.sql - set up the database - in terminal, navigate to setup directory - `cd ~/northwindSetup` - log into mysql - `sudo mysql -u root -p` - `SHOW DATABASES;` (only four originals) - `CREATE DATABASE northwind;` - `SHOW DATABASES;` (now lists northwind) - `USE northwind;` - `SHOW TABLES;` (none) - `SOURCE northwind.sql;` - `SHOW TABLES;`##mmshowtables - `SELECT * FROM customers;` (empty) - `SOURCE northwind-data.sql` - `SELECT * FROM customers;` - `SELECT company,last_name,first_name FROM customers;` - notice if special characters such as in **Pérez** and apostrophes are being displayed correctly##showingcorrectutttf8 - `exit` - **>>> 3. Create secure webuser that only has read rights to the northwind database** - since our API will be read only, let's make user that can only READ database but not WRITE data - this is a strategy to increase security - this way, if a hacker can get access to our database as this user, he still can only read data, not write it - list all current users on the MySQL server - `SELECT User FROM mysql.user;` - create the webuser - `CREATE USER webuser@localhost IDENTIFIED BY 'passpass';` - list users again to see that it was added - `SELECT User FROM mysql.user;` - in order that this user has only specific rights, let's first remove all rights - `revoke all privileges on *.* from webuser@localhost;` - now let's give the user READ-ONLY writes, which in SQL is "SELECT" - `GRANT SELECT on *.* TO webuser@localhost` - **>>> 4. Login as webuser to show that he only has read rights** - get out of MySQL back to the Linux prompt - `exit` - log into MySQL as webuser - `mysql -u webuser -p` - confirm that, as webuser, you can view data but not change it - `SHOW DATABASES;` - `use northwind;` - `SHOW TABLES;` - `DESCRIBE products;`##mmmdescribeprod - `select product_name, list_price from products;`##mmmlistprod - `INSERT INTO products (product_name) VALUES ("Product 888");`##mmmtrytotinser - **>>> 5. install MySQL management console applications** - we want to have some way of visually editing our MySQL database - so let's install some tools for that - **install MySQL Workbench** - if you want to check if you have this installed with snap already, remove it and install it fresh:##mmmsnaplist - install with snap - `snap install mysql-workbench-community` - Show Applications - add to favorites##mmmaddtofav - open##thworkworkbenc - click "Local instance 3306" and log in as **root** - click on the arrow to display schemas##mmmthearrorw - show all customers and make sure that your installation can display special characters as in "Pérez"##mmmshowpereznorth - test to see if you can edit the data in the database - make a small change and click **Apply**##mmmontwochange - log into mysql in the terminal again and see if the data has changed##mmmlechange - **install DBeaver** - since I've experienced UTF-8 issues with MySQL Workbench in the past - let me show you how to install another useful tool to manage your MySQL databases - `sudo snap install dbeaver-ce` - add to favorites - open - **yes** to create sample database - explore sample database - if it asks, allow it to download SQLite drivers##mmmdbeaverkj - connect to MySQL database - Database - New Database Connection - enter credentials for root##mmmloginbeav - explore tables, make a change, and apply it to the database##mmmmakeashcan - log into your mysql from the terminal and see that the change is also reflected there##mmmxiwchange - **>>> 6. Create a simple API that gets its data from the MySQL database and serves it on a route** - we will now create the simplest API to demonstrate how to get and use data from a MySQL database in Node - create a new folder in projects, e.g. - `mkdir et889-simple-express-mysql` - enter this directory in VSCode - `code et889-simple-express-mysql` - create an npm project - `npm init -y` - install everything we need - `npm i express mysql dotenv` - **server.js** ------------------------------------------------------------ import express from 'express'; import mysql from 'mysql'; import dotenv from 'dotenv'; const app = express(); const port = 3032; dotenv.config(); app.get('/', (req, res) => { res.send('test api'); }); app.get('/customers', (req, res) => { const connection = mysql.createConnection({ host: 'localhost', user: process.env.MYSQL_USER, password: process.env.MYSQL_PASSWORD, database: 'northwind' }); connection.connect((err) => { if (err) throw err; const sql = 'SELECT company,last_name,first_name FROM customers'; connection.query(sql, (err, records) => { if (err) throw err; res.send(records); }); }); }); app.listen(port, () => { console.log(`Listening on http://localhost:${port}`); }); ------------------------------------------------------------ - **.env** ---------------------------------------------------------- MYSQL_USER = webuser MYSQL_PASSWORD = thepass ---------------------------------------------------------- - start the API - `node server.js` - the main route should work: http://localhost:3032##thetestapijsmmm - now go to the customers route in which MySQL is accessed: http://localhost:3032/customers - **POTENTIAL PROBLEM**: depending on your version of Node, you may get this error:##mzsqlkserr - **SOLUTION**: - you need to make a change for the mysql user that is connecting to the database so that it can connect via your version of Node - log into mysql as **root** and make this change for the **webuser**: - `ALTER USER 'webuser'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED WITH mysql_native_password BY 'thepass';` - `FLUSH PRIVILEGES;` - customers will show like this:##mmmcustomersworks - **>>> 7. Create a EJS website that serves data from a MySQL database** - set up a base EJS website from a template - go to this **Node/Express EJS Website Template with TypeScript** - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/template-node-express-ejs-website-typescript/tree/dev - "Use this template" - "Create a new repository" - name it something like **et641-ejs-site-with-mysql** - clone your new repository locally - open it in VSCode - `npm i` - `npm run dev` - the site should look like this:##mmmtebooks - replace the **Books** page with an **Employees** page and display mock employee data first - **interfaces.ts** ---------------------------------------------------- export interface IEmployee { id: number; first_name: string; last_name: string; job_title: string; } ---------------------------------------------------- - **model.ts** --------------------------------------------------- import { IEmployee } from './interfaces'; export const getEmployees = () => { return new Promise(async (resolve, reject) => { resolve([ { id: 1, first_name: 'first1', last_name: 'last1', job_title: 'title1' }, { id: 2, first_name: 'first2', last_name: 'last2', job_title: 'title2' }, { id: 3, first_name: 'first3', last_name: 'last3', job_title: 'title3' } ]) }) } --------------------------------------------------- - **server.ts** --------------------------------------------------- app.get('/employees', async (req, res) => { res.render('pages/employees', { employees: await model.getEmployees() }); }); --------------------------------------------------- - **employees.ejs** ---------------------------------------------------- <%- include('../partials/htmlHead') %> Info Site <%- include('../partials/header') %> <%- include('../partials/menu', {pageIdCode: 'employees'})%>

There are <%= employees.length %> employees.

<% employees.forEach((employee) => { %>

<%=employee.first_name%> <%=employee.last_name%>

<%=employee.job_title%>

<% }) %>
---------------------------------------------------- - search your project for **book** and delete all the book residue code - your employee page with mock data should look like this:##mmmthedataemppage - replace mock employee data with real employee data from the MySQL database - install tools you will need - `npm i mysql` - `npm i -D @types/mysql` - `npm i dotenv` - **mysqltools.ts** ------------------------------------------------------------ import mysql from 'mysql'; import dotenv from 'dotenv'; dotenv.config(); export const getRecordsWithSql = (sql: string) => { return new Promise((resolve, reject) => { const connection = mysql.createConnection({ host: 'localhost', user: process.env.MYSQL_USER, password: process.env.MYSQL_PASSWORD, database: 'northwind' }); connection.connect((err) => { if (err) throw err; connection.query(sql, (err, records) => { if (err) { reject({ message: err }) } else { resolve(records); } }); }); }); } ------------------------------------------------------------ - **model.ts** --------------------------------------------------- export const getEmployees = () => { return new Promise(async (resolve, reject) => { try { const employees = await getRecordsWithSql('SELECT * FROM employees'); resolve(employees); } catch(e) { reject(e); } }) } --------------------------------------------------- - **.env** ---------------------------------- MYSQL_USER = webuser MYSQL_PASSWORD = thepass ---------------------------------- - employees page will look like this:##mmmnewemplsite - format and style the employees page - **main.css** ---------------------------------------- .employee { margin-bottom: 1rem; } .employee .name { font-size: 1.2rem; margin: 0; font-weight: bold; } .employee .job_title { font-style: italic; margin: 0; } ---------------------------------------- - pages looks like this:##mmmformaemp - add images of employees - delete all book images in `public/images/books` - create a directory `public/images/employees` - download images from [this page](https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/share)##mmmthepicsforeemp - **employees.ejs** ---------------------------------------------

Create customer page that lists number of orders for each customer** - we will now make a page that executes a more complex SQL command - in MySQL Workbench or DBeaver, create an SQL command to list customers by number of orders ------------------------------------------------ SELECT c.id, c.company as company_name, COUNT(o.id) AS number_of_orders FROM customers AS c LEFT JOIN orders as o ON c.id = o.customer_id GROUP BY c.id, c.company ORDER BY number_of_orders desc ------------------------------------------------ - **interfaces.ts** -------------------------------------------- export interface ICustomer { id: number, company_name: string, number_of_orders: number; } -------------------------------------------- - **menu.ejs** -------------------------------------------- Customers -------------------------------------------- - **server.ts** --------------------------------------------- app.get('/customers', async (req, res) => { res.render('pages/customers', { customers: await model.getCustomers() }); }); --------------------------------------------- - **model.ts** --------------------------------------------- export const getCustomers = () => { return new Promise(async (resolve, reject) => { try { const customers = await getRecordsWithSql(` SELECT c.id, c.company as company_name, COUNT(o.id) AS number_of_orders FROM customers AS c LEFT JOIN orders as o ON c.id = o.customer_id GROUP BY c.id, c.company ORDER BY number_of_orders desc `); console.log(customers); resolve(customers); } catch(e) { reject(e); } }) } --------------------------------------------- - **customers.ejs** --------------------------------------------- <%- include('../partials/htmlHead') %> Info Site <%- include('../partials/header') %> <%- include('../partials/menu', {pageIdCode: 'customers'})%>

title: Install DB Browser for SQLite on Ubuntu and Windows, learn the basics of SQL, and create an API that serves data from an SQLite file
body:
- **background**
	- we'll be working with the database **SQLite** in this howto
	- SQLite is an **SQL** database
	- there are basically two kinds of database: SQL and NoSQL
	- [Understand the history and background of SQL and NoSQL databases](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/howtos/573)
- **code is here**
	- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et401-api-with-sqlite - preparation for live-coding
	- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et402-api-with-sqlite - code from live-coding 2024-01-22
- **>>> 1. Install DB Browser**
	- SQLite is a good database to learn SQL since **an SQLite database is simply a binary file**
	- this means there is **no SQL server installation** as with MySQL, Postgres and MongoDB
	- you merely need a **database manager tool** to create databases (files) and manage the data in them
	- a good cross-platform tool that works similarly on Windows, Linux and Mac is **DB Browser for SQLite**
	- **install DB Browser for SQL on Windows**
		- uninstall
			- if you want to uninstall it, click on the Window, type **uninstall**, find your application, right-click and remove it
		- install
			- go to the [DB Browser download page](https://sqlitebrowser.org/dl)
			- click the download link##downlodbdb
			- double-click on the downloaded msi file##doudoubddb
			- next, accept, next, next, next, install, finish
			- find in C:\Programs, right-click and attach to task bar##rightclickandattachto
			- click on the icon in the taskbar to open it, should look like this:##shoulddbdb
			- download test SQLite database file here: [edwardtanguay.vercel.app/share](https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/share)
			- right-click and download this zip file:##gotothedodb222
			- unzip the SQLite file and put it in your project directory in a new directory named e.g. `c:\test-sqlite`
			- in the DB Browser application, click on [Open Database], go to e.g. `c:\test-sqlite` and click on the file named `northwind_database.sqlite`
			- you should see tables shown here:##seetablesok
	- **install DB Browser for SQL on Ubuntu**
		- if you want to uninstall it
			- check to see that it exists as an apt-get application
				- `sudo apt list --installed`##calllsquiteij
				- if so, remove it:
					- `sudo apt-get remove sqlitebrowser -y`
			- check to see if it exists as a snap application
				- `snap list`##thesdlkonsanp
				- if so, remove it:
					- `sudo snap remove sqlitebrowser`				
		- prepare installation
			- `sudo add-apt-repository -y ppa:linuxgndu/sqlitebrowser`
			- `sudo apt-get update`
		- install
			- install with **apt-get**
				- **use this:** `sudo apt-get install sqlitebrowser`
				- this one was buggy for me, didn't display tables correctly: `sudo snap install sqlitebrowser`
			- click on 9-dots icon in lower-left and add DB Browser for SQLite to favorites##addtofavdbubun
			- download test SQLite database file here: [edwardtanguay.vercel.app/share](https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/share)
			- right-click and download this zip file:##gotothedodb222
			- unzip the downloaded .zip file
			- copy the file `northwind_database.sqlite` to e.g. `~/home/edward/projects/test-sqlite`
			- in the DB Browser application, click on [Open Database], go to your `test-sqlite` directory and click on the file named `northwind_database.sqlite`
			- it should look like this:##shouldlooklikei
- **>>> 2. Learn basic SQL CRUD commands**
	- **Read** data
		- click on the [Execute SQL] table and type: `SELECT * FROM Employees` then press F5 to execute:##thefirsssql
		- then try these self-explanatory commands and see what they do:
			---------------------------------------------
			SELECT * FROM Employees WHERE BirthDate > '1960-01-01'
			SELECT * FROM Employees WHERE BirthDate > '1960-01-01' ORDER BY BirthDate
			SELECT * FROM Employees WHERE BirthDate > '1960-01-01' ORDER BY BirthDate DESC
			SELECT FirstName, LastName, BirthDate FROM Employees WHERE BirthDate > '1960-01-01' ORDER BY BirthDate DESC
			---------------------------------------------
	- **Create** a table
		- execute CREATE TABLE command with an autoincrementing ID, title and body 
			----------------------------------------------
			CREATE TABLE "Notes" (
				"id"	INTEGER NOT NULL,
				"title"	TEXT,
				"body"	TEXT,
				PRIMARY KEY("id" AUTOINCREMENT)
			)			
			----------------------------------------------
	- **Insert** records
		- insert a note
			-------------------------------------------------------------
			INSERT INTO Notes (title,body) VALUES ("First Note", "This is the first note.")
			-------------------------------------------------------------
		- list out all notes
			---------------------------------------------
			SELECT * FROM Notes
			---------------------------------------------		
		- insert another note
			-------------------------------------------------------------
			INSERT INTO Notes (title,body) VALUES ("Second Note", "This is the second note.")
			-------------------------------------------------------------
		- list out all notes
			---------------------------------------------
			SELECT * FROM Notes
			---------------------------------------------
	- **Delete** a record
		- delete the first note
			----------------------------------------------
			DELETE FROM Notes WHERE id = 1
			----------------------------------------------
		- show that only the second note remains
			---------------------------------------
			SELECT * FROM Notes
			---------------------------------------
	- **Update** a record
		- update the second note
			-----------------------------------------
			UPDATE Notes SET title = 'Changed Second Note' WHERE id = 2
			-----------------------------------------
		- show that the second note's title has changed
			---------------------------------------
			SELECT * FROM Notes
			---------------------------------------
- **>>> 3. Learn advanced JOIN commands**
	- tables in SQL tables are typically related by the primary and foreign keys
	- the Northwind database is a good example of tables related by primary and foreign keys:##theforprimkeys
	- query data with these relationships using JOIN:
		-----------------------------------------------------------------
		SELECT * FROM Employees
		SELECT * FROM EmployeeTerritories
		SELECT * FROM Employees AS e JOIN EmployeeTerritories AS et ON e.EmployeeID = et.EmployeeID
		SELECT e.EmployeeID, e.LastName, e.FirstName, et.TerritoryID FROM Employees AS e JOIN EmployeeTerritories AS et ON e.EmployeeID = et.EmployeeID
		-----------------------------------------------------------------
	- now join the Terroritories table
		-----------------------------------------------------
		SELECT e.EmployeeID, e.LastName, e.FirstName, et.TerritoryID,t.TerritoryDescription FROM Employees AS e 
		JOIN EmployeeTerritories AS et ON e.EmployeeID = et.EmployeeID
		JOIN Territories AS t ON et.TerritoryID = t.TerritoryID
		-----------------------------------------------------
	- now only get the information for one employee
		---------------------------------------------
		SELECT e.EmployeeID, e.LastName, e.FirstName, et.TerritoryID,t.TerritoryDescription FROM Employees AS e 
		JOIN EmployeeTerritories AS et ON e.EmployeeID = et.EmployeeID
		JOIN Territories AS t ON et.TerritoryID = t.TerritoryID
		WHERE e.EmployeeID = 1
		---------------------------------------------
	- the final query will show the joined data from three tables:##thejoindone
- **>>> 4. Learn as much SQL as you need**
	- how much SQL does a developer need to know today?
		- if you are going to work more in **frontend**
			- you should at least know the basics including all CRUD commands and JOINs 
			- e.g. in case you have to query a database or fix a SQL query in some project
		- if you are going to work **full stack or in backend**, the deeper you understand SQL, the better
			- while ORMs such as Prisma, Sequelize, Drizzle are widely used
			- databases need to be planned and created
			- queries need to be optimized
			- you need to understand what tables and fields to index based on what needs to be most often queried, etc.
	- here are some online resources to learn SQL
		- https://www.w3schools.com/sql
			- interestingly, W3Schools also uses a similar Northwind database as we used above
			- most of the tables and fields are the same 
		- https://sqlbolt.com
			- a series of interactive SQL lessons which give immediate feedback
		- https://www.sql-easy.com
			- a series of interactive SQL lessons which give immediate feedback
		- https://www.sqlcourse.com
			- a series of interactive SQL lessons which give immediate feedback
- **>>> 5. Create API with routes that serve data from an SQLite database (file)**
	- to focus on the database in this howto, let's set up a Node/Express API from a starter template
	- **set up API**
		- go to: https://github.com/edwardtanguay/template-api-node-express-typescript-es6-modules-lowdb
		- "Use this template"
		- "Create a new repository"
		- give your new repository a name, e.g. **et401-api-with-sqlite** (of course don't use et401 but your own initials and number, etc.)
		- "Create repository"
		- clone it locally
		- `npm i`
		- `npm run dev`
		- click auf dem Link: http://localhost:4206##seethestrxapi
		- click on the **Get all flashcards** link to make sure it works##withfjsflash
	- **set up an /employees route that returns mock data**
		- our goal is to serve employee data from the route **/employees**
			- the data will come from the SQLite database that we used above
		- **server.ts**
			--------------------------------------
			import * as employeeHandlers from '../handlers/employeeHandlers.js';

			app.use('/employees', employeeRouter);
			--------------------------------------
		- **employeerouter.ts**
			----------------------------------------
			import { Router } from 'express';
			import * as employeeHandlers from '../handlers/employeeHandlers.js';

			export const employeeRouter = Router();

			employeeRouter.get('/', (_req, res) => {
				const employees = employeeHandlers.getAllEmployees();
				res.json(employees);
			});			
			----------------------------------------
		- **employeeHandlers.ts**
			-------------------------------------------
			export const getAllEmployees = () => {
				return [
					{
						firstName: 'fff1'
					},
					{
						firstName: 'fff2'
					}
				]
			}			
			-------------------------------------------
		- you will now be able to access your mock employee data with the route **/employees**##withfjsemplejdjdj
	- **get data for handler from SQLite database**
		- copy **northwind_database.sqlite** to **/src/data**
		- open in DB Browser##openindebkjaskdjf
		- install the npm package **SQLite3**
			- this will enable us to access our SQLite database via Node
			- `npm i sqlite3`
		- **interfaces.ts**
			------------------------------------------
			export interface IEmployee {
				id: number,
				firstName: string;
				lastName: string;
				title: string;
			}			
			------------------------------------------
		- **employeeHandlers.ts**
			-------------------------------------------
			/* eslint-disable @typescript-eslint/no-explicit-any */
			import { IEmployee } from '../interfaces.js';
			import * as sqlitetools from './sqlitetools.js';

			const employees:any[] = await sqlitetools.getRecordsWithSql('SELECT * FROM Employees');

			export const getAllEmployees = (): IEmployee[] => {
				return employees.map(m => {
					const employee: IEmployee = {
						id: m.EmployeeID,
						firstName: m.FirstName,
						lastName: m.LastName, 
						title: m.Title
					}	
					return employee;
				})
			}			
			-------------------------------------------
		- **sqlitetools.ts**
			----------------------------------------------------
			/* eslint-disable @typescript-eslint/no-explicit-any */
			import sqlite3 from 'sqlite3';
			import path from 'path';

			const baseDir = process.cwd();
			const absoluteDbPathAndFileName = path.join(baseDir, '/src/data/northwind_database.sqlite');

			export const getRecordsWithSql = (sql: string) => {
				return new Promise<any[]>((resolve, reject) => {
					const db = new sqlite3.Database(absoluteDbPathAndFileName);
					db.all(sql, function (err, records: any[]) {
						if (records === undefined) {
							reject(err);
						} else if (records.length === 0) {
							resolve([]);
						} else {
							resolve(records);
						}
					});
					db.close();
				});
			};			
			----------------------------------------------------
- **>>> 6. Add TypeScript generics to getRecordsWithSql in order to make it dynamic**
	- in order to get rid of the **any** types that we put into getRecordsWithSql
		- we are going to have to identify a specific type that we will want to get out of the database
		- but we can imagine that we will not only want to get IEmployees out of the database with this function, but also e.g.
			- ICustomers
			- IProducts
			- IOrders
			- IShippers
			- ITerritories
			- etc.
		- and we don't want to write a new function for each of these types
		- therefore, we will use an advanced feature of TypeScript (and C#/Java) called **Generics**
		- we will make our function getRecordsWithSql **generic** by allowing it to process **any kind of type**
	- **interfaces.ts**
		--------------------------------------
		export interface INorthwindEmployee {
			EmployeeID: number,
			FirstName: string,
			LastName: string,
			Title: string;
		}		
		--------------------------------------
	- **sqlitetools.ts** - convert the **any** types to **T**
		----------------------------------------------------
		export const getRecordsWithSql = <T>(sql: string) => {
			return new Promise<T[]>((resolve, reject) => {
				const db = new sqlite3.Database(absoluteDbPathAndFileName);
				db.all(sql, function (err, records: T[]) {
					if (records === undefined) {
						reject(err);
					} else if (records.length === 0) {
						resolve([]);
					} else {
						resolve(records);
					}
				});
				db.close();
			});
		};		
		----------------------------------------------------
	- **employeeHandlers.ts** - here we send the type that we want getRecordsWithSql to process
		----------------------------------------------
		const employees = await sqlitetools.getRecordsWithSql<INorthwindEmployee>('SELECT * FROM Employees');
		----------------------------------------------
- **CHALLENGE: Create a route to get a single employee with ID, e.g. /employee/3**
- **CHALLENGE: Create CRUD routes for employees**

body:
- **background**
	- this howto is an theoretical and practical background to start thinking about security of passwords in your applications
	- it is also a demonstration of why and how to use **bcrypt**
	- code used in this howto is here
		- https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et661-bcrypt-encryption
- **why we use bcrypt** - a background to encryption, hashing and password security
	- we all know the golden rule: **never save passwords in the database in plain text**
		- but we often save e.g. database connection strings that contain passwords in plain text in the .env file
			- how secure is that?
			- it is relatively secure
				- but in production the .env should require sudo rights
				- one has to be certain that .env files do not get pushed to a repository or copied into a backup file
				- so an .env file in production is treated with special security
				- one must also consider screen sharing, etc. that a plain text password is not seen
				- when companies get certificates such as ISO 9001, they commit to abiding by security regulations such as how to store passwords
					- these certificate requirements is where you find the best security rules
				- keep in mind that security is always balanced with convenience
					- high security means low flexibility/convenience
					- low security means high flexibility/convenience
			- I would argue that a plain text password in an .env file is secure enough for most low-profile websites
				- if you have reason to make it more secure, you could secure the admin password with bcrypt
			- ChatGPT on this topic:##envfilepasworsk
	- all that said, **to save all passwords for all users in the database stored in plain text is another level of egregious**
		- if a hacker gains access to your database, they can instantly impersonate any user with any security level
		- you would have to inform all users to change their passwords
	- **>>> 1. possible solution: use encryption/decryption**
		- you could write your own encryption algorithm
			- something like a [cryptogram](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptogram)
		- you could make it quite complicated to decrypt
			- have numerous characters that represented one character
			- have numerous mapping tables and save the id number of the mapping table in the key
		- the problem is that if you can encrypt it, you can decrypt it
			- given time, computer processing power, and artificial intelligence, encryption/decryption is generally not secure anymore
		- **therefore, don't use encryption/decryption for passwords**
	- **>>> 2. possible solution: use a hashing algorithm such as md5**
		- encryption vs. hashing
			- an encrypted password can be decrypted
			- but a hashed password cannot be unhashed
				- you cannot go back
				- you can only compare the hashes to find out if someone knows the original password
		- problem:
			- there are ways to figure out what the hash algorithm is
				- computer power is increasing and AI is becoming more powerful which makes it easier
			- ChaGPT on the security of md5##tehmmmm5		
		- demonstration
			- create project for testing
				- `mkdir et661-bcrypt-encryption`
				- `code .`
				- `npm init -y`
				- `git init -b dev`
				- make git ignore node_modules
					- **.gitignore**
						--------------------------------
						node_modules
						--------------------------------
				- enable ES6 modules
					- **package.json**
						------------------------------------
						"type":"module",
						------------------------------------
			- install md5
				- `npm i md5`
			- **md5test.js**
				-------------------------------
				import md5 from 'md5';

				const password = 'secret';
				const encryptedPassword = md5(password);

				console.log(password, encryptedPassword);
				console.log(password, encryptedPassword);
				console.log(password, encryptedPassword);
				console.log(password, encryptedPassword);
				console.log(password, encryptedPassword);
				-------------------------------
			- note it produces the same hash each time:##thesammmtime
			- this means that you could 
				- 1. save the encryptedPassword in the database
				- 2. ask the user to type in their password
				- 3. encrypt the password the user typed in
				- 4. compare the encrypted password with the encrypted password in the database
				- 5. if they are the same, then you know the user typed in the correct database
			- this worked well in the 90s and until about 2005
				- ChatGPT on when MD5 became insecure:##chatmmmwhenmd5	
			- the problem is that you can decrypt many md5 encrypted passwords by googling **decrypt md5**, clicking on the first result, e.g. [MD5Online MD5 Decryption](https://www.md5online.org/md5-decrypt.html) typing in the encryptedPassword and you see:##thespaswencrdec
			- the simple reason these services exist is that they use something called **rainbow tables**, i.e. large databases of precomputed hash values for common passwords and combinations of characters##rainbommtabl
			- test for yourself which passwords can and can't be found in these rainbox tables
				- many seemingly complex but lightly predictable passwords can be found in rainbow tables	
			- this means that a hacker that gains access to your database of passwords encrypted with md5 can probably instantly decrypt some or many of the users passwords
				- of course, the more strict your enforced policy was that forces users create **complex** passwords
				- the fewer md5 encrypted passwords would be able to be decrypted
				- but if (1) have a weak password enforcement rule and (2) someone with high access rights has a weak password, then someone who gains access to the encrypted passwords can seriously compromise your site, e.g. by logging in as someone with high access rights
			- and with more time, better algorithms, and more powerful artificial intelligence, even more complicated passwords can be decrypted
			- some sites boast that they have billions of stored md5 rainbow tables (for a price) which they can use to quickly find nearly any password
			- md5 today is not used for storing passwords, but more for **authenticating e.g. downloads to make sure nobody changed the file in transit**
			- therefore, while you see still will see md5 in use todo, **don't use md5 to encrypt passwords in your database**
	- **>>> 3. possible solution: use a salt**
		- a salt is a text is used to slightly change the algorithm used to create a hash
		- the salt is saved separately outside the database, e.g. in an .env file
			- for instance, this is what a SESSION_SECRET is when using express-sessions
			- it just has to be some random string that hackers don't know
		- **salts generally make rainbow tables useless**
		- so instead of MD5, you could use [Salted MD5](https://www.npmjs.com/package/salted-md5)
		- however, the problem with this is that computers are becoming so powerful that **simple passwords can be cracked within days**
			- *"MD5 and SHA-1 are emphatically poor choices for storing passwords. The problem is not so much their low collision-resistance; **the problem is that MD5 and SHA-1 are designed to be extremely fast**. A modern GPU can attempt upwards of billions of passwords per second when brute-forcing through a list of hashes. This can shred through every possible eight-character alphanumeric password in at most a few days; that's with just one GPU."* - [Is salted MD5 or salted SHA considered secure?](https://security.stackexchange.com/questions/61489/is-salted-md5-or-salted-sha-considered-secure)
			- this means that if a hacker can break into your MongoDB Atlas and export the **users** collection from your database to a JSON file, then within a few days, they can find out all of the weakest passwords in your database within a few days
		- **therefore, don't use MD5 or SHA-1 hashing for saving passwords even if the hashing is salted**
	- **>>> 4. best solution: use slow-hashing algorithms such as bcrypt**
		- bcrypt is **more secure** than MD5 and SHA-1 at hashing passwords because
			- A. **it's slower** (ironically, the fact that the algorithm takes **longer** to encrypt makes it **safer**)
			- B. in addition, it requires a random salt for each password by default
		- **A. slowness is a feature**
			- *"Password hash functions should be relatively expensive to calculate in case of brute-force attacks."*
				- the longer it takes to compute the hash, the less practical it is to calculate hashes on a large scale and less effective brute force attacks are
			- instead of instantly creating a hash, you can configure it to take e.g. between 1 and 5 seconds
				- this means that users when logging in will have to wait a few seconds before their password is checked, but this is usually tolerable and often not even noticed
				- however, this means that instead of a hacker being able to check e.g. 100,000 password combinations per second, it can only check e.g. 10 per second
		- **B. require a random salt for each password by default**
			- bcrypt stores the salt in the hash in plain text
				- when you create a password, a random string (salt) is created and added to the front of the hash, the resulting salt+hash is stored in the database
				- for two passwords that are similar, the resulting salt+hash stored in the database is vastly different
				- this makes rainbow tables useless
		- **therefore, to secure passwords in your database, use bcrypt**
			- bcrypt pushes the hacker back to their previous attack method: 
				- they have a different salt for each password which makes the resulting salt-hash strings completely random
				- the hashing algorithm is programmed to be slow so they can't use computer speed to create and try millions of password combinations within any reasonable amount of time
- **How to use bcrypt**
	- 1. create and compare hash at register and login
		- install bcrypt
			- `npm i bcrypt`
		- **at signup**, take password, create hash with salt using `bcrypt.hash()`, store hash in database
		- **at login**, take password, compare password with hash in database using `bcrypt.compare()`
			- bcrypttest.js
			-------------------------------
			import bcrypt from 'bcrypt';

			const register = async (password) => {
				const salt = await bcrypt.genSalt(12);
				const hash = await bcrypt.hash(password, salt);
				console.log(hash); // store hash in database in user's record
			};

			const login = async (password) => {
				const hash = '$2b$10$Q7OpcC8DJ6qnDFtTDXwdyeI8zjzKBqOn68kV3U8UM1vOW0hnfspK6'; // get hash from user record in database
				const result = await bcrypt.compare(password, hash);
				console.log(result)
			};

			// register('test111');
			login('test000'); // false 
			login('test111'); // true
			-------------------------------
	- 2. understand how bcrypt can successfully compare the password without knowing the original salt
		- for the password "password", signing up three times produced the following three hashes:
			-----------------------------
			$2b$10$XEcAhERMwhaM1bk/10xAwuhY6oeYH27uM.W44ycMeFdYkBBqR7Cdy
			$2b$10$cK7Wui1Aex127Qcf/U59W.9OliIm5oLwvRGXU2XopBnGlZbjnpmXG
			$2b$10$oiqPsOlhIYS6ocOFgls7Huo.a4819mV5P/qbKRv2Id8rUJKGOO/nK
			-----------------------------
		- this is because the **salt** is random and hence different each time, which produces a different hash each time
			--------------------------------------
			const register = async (password) => {
				const salt = await bcrypt.genSalt();
				const hash = await bcrypt.hash(password, salt);
				console.log('SALT', salt); // random salt that produces a random has each time
				console.log('HASH', hash); // hash is store in database
			};
			--------------------------------------			
		- do you recognize a similarity between each **salt** and the **hash** it produces?##mmmrecognisfpat
		- right: when creating the hash, the salt is used as the first 29 characters (in our case here, but this may vary)
		- so **registration** works like this:
			- generates a random salt, e.g. `$2b$10$v3LXMvdqkaALgMEMqNaexe`
			- encrypts salt+password to create a **prehash**, e.g. `zhj9bxX1FKHEsxMR97MMETXEFEQFUDu`
			- adds the **salt** to the **prehash** go get the resulting **hash**: 
				- `$2b$10$v3LXMvdqkaALgMEMqNaexezhj9bxX1FKHEsxMR97MMETXEFEQFUDu`
			- the hash is then stored in the database
		- and **login** works like this:
			- takes the attempted password from the user
			- gets the salt from the stored hash (in our case, the first 29 characters)
			- takes this **salt** and the attempted **password**, and generates a **prehash** again
			- adds the **salt** to the **prehash** and to get a **hash**
			- if they match, then the user typed in the right password
	- 3. how to throttle bcrypt's speed of hash creation
		- while random salts make hacking the password more difficult
			- it is the speed throttling which disables brute force attacks
		- you can slow down the speed of hash creation 
			- to make it more difficult for a hacker to compare millions of passwords with brute-force
		- to slow down speed, add a **rounds** parameter when you call the **genSalt** function
		- generally **12** is a highly secure number of rounds which allows for even weak passwords
			- this makes the time to create the hash about 250ms, or a quarter of a second
			- this is tolerable for any user when registering and logging in
				- but slows a hacker down to comparing only 4 passwords second
				- 86400 seconds in a day * 4 = only 345600 passwords compared per day
			- **what you are doing here is not so much preventing hackers from ever cracking user's passwords, but buying your users time to change their passwords after an attack**
			- since even with bcrypt an extremely week password such as **password** will be once of the first most hackers choose to test, and so it will usually be hacked within the first few minutes
			- one can appreciate now how important it is to have both (1) **bcrypt** and (2) a **secure password policy** in place, e.g. at least 8 digits with upper and lowercase, numbers and special characters
				- since this buys your users time **not in minutes or hours** but **weeks and months** in the case of having the password hashes stolen from the database
		- here is a general chart listing rounds and seconds, combined with a secure password policy
			-----------------------------------------
			Rounds:4  | Time: 0.0016 s /* security too lax */
			Rounds:5  | Time: 0.0029 s
			Rounds:6  | Time: 0.0060 s
			Rounds:7  | Time: 0.0115 s
			Rounds:8  | Time: 0.0232 s
			Rounds:9  | Time: 0.0459 s
			Rounds:10 | Time: 0.0907 s /* good enough */
			Rounds:11 | Time: 0.1834 s 
			Rounds:12 | Time: 0.3563 s /* standard */ 
			Rounds:13 | Time: 0.7215 s 
			Rounds:14 | Time: 1.4437 s /* in critical systems for e.g. superuser password */
			Rounds:15 | Time: 2.9140 s
			Rounds:16 | Time: 5.8405 s			
			-----------------------------------------
